p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Andrew Wallace ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report

Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): I present the 35th report of the Petitions Committee for the 46th Parliament, together with 130 petitions and 232 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented.
As the first presentation for 2022, we can see the large volume of petitions and ministerial responses today reflects the break in sittings.

The committee has been pleased to see the public's continued engagement with petitioning continue over the summer. Working with the House of Representatives' social media team, we have used the break to continue our petitions education and public engagement efforts. This has included sharing information on:
what a petition is, and the rules around petitioning;
advice on who can create and sign a petition; and
suggestions for how to request action on an issue of public concern.
This has seen continued engagement with petitions, and, as the only method for the public to have a direct voice to parliament, petitions remain an important part of our democratic process.

The committee has been pleased to see the ongoing engagement with petitioning continue into the new year. With all Australian citizens and residents entitled to petition the House, we can see a diversity of issues and approaches to petitioning. For example, while some requests are advocated by individuals, others make up part of more coordinated and wide-reaching campaigns. Of note, there is no signature threshold for petitions, and all are treated equally.
I look forward to further updating the House on the work of the Petitions Committee.
Chair Mr Ken O'Dowd MP
Deputy Chair Hon Justine Elliot MP
Mrs Bridget Archer MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Ms Gladys Liu MP
Mr Julian Simmonds MP
Mr James Stevens MP
Ms Susan Templeman MP

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and Ministerial r
The committee met in private session on 24 November 2021, 1 December 2021, 12 January 2022 and 9 February 2022.
1. The committee resolved to present the following petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

PETITIONS
Presentation
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): I present the following petitions:
Jetstar

Jetstar has cancelled Bookings, and issued unauthorized vouchers, which are then invalidated by actions which suggest it is carried out by Jetstar itself. There is considerable evidence pointing to Jetstar acting illegally, and maliciously to void vouchers. It uses personal data of customers to book an alternative flight, which becomes a no-show. This is done without the authority of the person making the original booking. Incorrect or inaccurate information was used. Jetstar had the details to carry out the fraud itself. Jetstar monitors social media and collects data, enabling it to act illegally. It failed intentionally its duty of care to a customer.

We therefore ask the House to set up a Parliamentary Inquiry, into Corporate Jetstar Fraud looking specifically at Bookings, and inviting responses from affected Australians. The Terms of Reference should include a complete and thorough review of all steps within the process from when an original booking is made. The Inquiry should also recommend appropriate steps to be taken to avoid this occurring again in the future, and recommend appropriate penalties and compensation for affected Australians.

from 42 citizens (Petition No. EN3544)
Migration

Temporary Residents have lived in Australia and supported the economy during the COVID-19 pandemic. Their support of the economy has taken many forms: work, study, paying rent, paying taxes, supporting local businesses and Australian online retailers, etc. Disruptions to the migration program during the pandemic coupled limited or unattainable pathways to Permanent Residency means that the future for many Temporary Residents in Australia is uncertain. Over the next couple of years, many will be forced to leave Australia, a country they have grown to love. Australia must follow the lead of countries like New Zealand and Canada and recognize the contribution of Temporary Residents during the pandemic with a Permanent Residency pathway.
We therefore ask the House to establish a pathway to Permanent Residency for Temporary Residents who have lived in Australia and supported its economy during the COVID-19 pandemic.
from 62,282 citizens (Petition No. EN3547)
Vaccination

The most vulnerable members of our community are forced to interact with public servants, often several times each month, in order to receive the meagre allowances which are well below the poverty line. Allowing those public servants to come into close contact with vulnerable members of the public without adequate precautions is an unacceptable health risk.

We therefore ask the House to mandate vaccinations of all public servants, including the staff of members of parliament. A shorter timeframe should be mandated for any public servants who regularly interact with members of the public.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN3548)
International Development Assistance

Many times over the last several years there have been legitimate governments taken over by coups. Australia has responded poorly to these coups by continuing to send foreign aid to these countries (much of which likely ends up in the hands of the new "government") and imposing no trade sanctions.

We therefore ask the House to introduce new foreign relations rules which make it clear that Australia will not support any "government" which has been implemented against the wishes of the population of that country. This clear lack of support should include, but not be limited to:
Withholding of foreign aid funds from that country.
Imposition of trade sanctions against that country.
Withdrawal of any diplomats from that country.
Opposition to any attempted actions by that country within international bodies such as United Nations.
Petitions to reduce the standing of that country within international bodies such as United Nations.
Support of and participation in military action to restore the legitimate government of that country, or to introduce democratic elections if the legitimate government is no longer viable.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN3549)
Iran

In 1988 the government of Iran summarily executed over 30,000 political prisoners which is a crime against humanity, and this crime has continued up to the present with the killing of more than 1,500 demonstrators in the November 2019 peaceful protests in Iran.
The last 43 years have proven that the Iranian regime has never complied with international human rights standards and will never do so.

In July 2021, Hamid Noury was put on trial by the Swedish Federal Court in Stockholm for his complicity in the 1988 massacre as a crime against humanity and genocide. It is the first trial conducted in relation to the 1988 massacre of political prisoners. Millions of Iranian people are following the trial sessions which continue until April 2022.
The new President of Iran, Ebrahim Raisi, played a major role in the 1988 massacre and the deadly repression in November 2019.
We are seeking the truth, justice, reparation and guarantees of non-recurrence of the 1988 massacre of political prisoners.

We therefore ask the House to recommend to the Australian government that a clause be inserted into the draft Third Committee resolution on human rights in Iran at the November 2021 UN General Assembly, to call for the urgent establishment of an International Commission of Inquiry into the 1988 mass execution of over 30,000 Iranian political prisoners, and to identify the perpetrators of this crime.

from 27 citizens (Petition No. EN3554)
COVID-19: Vaccination

I am writing to you as a matter of urgency to express my view in relation to the current availability of vaccines for Covid 19. I am an extremely concerned citizen who has considered the current vaccines and researched them extensively. Covax-19 does not appear to have any severe side-effects other than those similar to the flu vaccination. It is a vaccine that is based on older technology that has been around for decades and is a protein-based vaccine not MRNA nor a viral vector vaccine. Covax-19 has shown exceptional results in phase 3 clinical trials and phase 1 and 2 prior to this, unlike the current options of Pfizer and AZ vaccines which have not completed Phase 3 clinical trials and has been approved for use in Iran.

We therefore ask the House to grant this petition in the hopes that you may be able to assist me in a push to fast track the approval and supply of the vaccine Covax-19. Covax-19 has shown exceptional results in the phase 3 clinical trials and phase 1 and 2 prior to this, unlike the current options of Pfizer and AZ vaccines which have not completed Phase 3 clinical trials. I feel Australians deserve to have a choice of which vaccine we put into our bodies.
from 102 citizens (Petition No. EN3555)
Australian Defence Force

The decision in November 2020 to extinguish 2SQN from the Army's Order of Battle (ORBAT) in an early response to the Brereton Report inflicted group punishment on all past and present members of that proud unit for alleged crimes that are yet to be tested in a court of law. Group punishment is invariably an abhorrent and arbitrary measure, tainting the entirety for the alleged crimes of the few. The repugnant nature of group punishment is compounded in this case by being applied prematurely and selectively against the rank and file while failing to censure the senior commanders who had a personal responsibility for oversight when alleged crimes were committed. Worse still, the punishment has been applied retrospectively. 2SQN's removal from the ORBAT casts doubt on the honour, sacrifice and reputation of 2SQN veterans dating back to the unit's establishment in 1964. Hundreds of former members who have served in the squadron since that time are now forever shamed and linked to untested crimes allegedly committed by the few in the past decade. We are firmly in favour of punishment where wrongdoing is proven, but the disproportionate sweep of this group punishment is an overreach. The shaming of innocents through the generations is no way to address the matters raised in the Brereton Report. 2SQN SASR must be restored to the ORBAT as a matter of natural justice for all.
We therefore ask the House to restore 2 Squadron, Special Air Service Regiment, to the Australian Army's Order of Battle.
from 25 citizens (Petition No. EN3556)
Donations to Political Parties
Our political system is being abused and taken advantage of by rich individuals and corporations and overseas undemocratic actors who donate copious amount of money to Australian political parties.
Our right to vote is being diluted and nullified by rich individuals, corporations and overseas undemocratic actors.
Political parties should represent the people of Australia and our our right to vote needs to be protected in law.

We therefore ask the House to ban all donations to political parties over the value of $99.00 and reduce abuse and nullifying unrepresented corporations and overseas undemocratic influence in the political process and protect the the right to vote of eligible Australian electors.
from 32 citizens (Petition No. EN3557)
Waste Management and Recycling
The plastic pollution crisis in Australia needs a solution.

300 million tonnes of plastic are produced every year around the world, from plastic straws, plastic bottles, plastic packagings to plastic toys; plastic wastes are slowly filling up the oceans and lands. According to statistics, since plastic's creation, more than 8.3 billion tonnes were created, and 60% of these plastics have ended up as wastes in landfills, ocean and other natural environments, with only 9% of plastics ever produced being recycled. As plastics take centuries to decompose, and may never disappear, a solution is needed to protect the environment for future generations.
We therefore ask the House to pass a new legislation, to ban the production and use of all non-recyclable and new plastics in Australia—tackling plastic pollution at its sources.
from 21 citizens (Petition No. EN3558)
Gambling
Australia has the highest gambling losses per adult in the world, we are gambling nation. The Australian media has done a lot to promote this social behavior and needs to be held to account.

Gambling advertising has become a growing problem in Australian media, it is inescapable for sports fans, free to air/foxtel viewers and now there is a growth market of gambling advertising in esports which has predominately pre teen and teenage audience.

In 2017-18 Australians spent 242 Billion on gambling with a loss of around 25 billion, the losses accumulated averages out to be $1260 per year per person and remember, that's if EVERYONE gambled. Since 2017-18 we have seen a change in the way people gamble, betting apps have brought the TAB to your pocket and with a constant reminder to BET BET BET those losses are sure to continue rising.

Why is this an issue? There are direct connections between gambling harm and family violence and mental ill-health. Gambling harm encompasses everything from the loss of homes and relationships to the loss of lives through deaths by suicide.

Gambling isn't going away, the Australian media needs to be responsible for not promoting or normalising actions that are demonstrably harmful to Australian citizens and those around them. We ddi it for ciggies, now it is time for gambling.
We therefore ask the House to ban Gambling advertising in all Australian media.
from 1,700 citizens (Petition No. EN3559)
COVID-19: Vaccination

Covax-19 is a protein based vaccine developed by an Australian company, Vaxine, here in Australia. This company has received no funding support from the Australian Government (other than a small token grant) despite petitioning for funding.
They have completed Phase 3 trials and are now approved for use in Iran and are looking to expand to other countries.

They are the first vaccine for Covid-19 developed in the Southern Hemisphere and the first protein based vaccine to receive Emergency Use Authorisation, and yet Australia has provided no support, no funding, and no opportunity for manufacturing in Australia.

For many people, taking an essentially untested mRNA vaccine is too risky, but they will happily take a traditional protein based vaccine. This is a perfect opportunity to further boost vaccine rates in Australia by providing an alternative, well known and trusted type of vaccine.

We therefore ask the House to : in general, support Australian vaccine companies such as Vaxine; to provide funding to Australian vaccine companies (like they do for CSL); and also provide opportunities for Aussie vaccine companies to manufacture vaccines within Australia (like CSL are manufacturing the UK AstraZeneca but won't agree to manufacture Covax-19). We also ask the House specifically to review the product created by Vaxine—Covax-19—with the aim of approving it for use in Australia as an alternative to the mRNA vaccines. This will provide more choice to Australians and likely boost vaccine-take up.

from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN3567)
Migration

Nobody can deny that Australia is in shortage of skilled labor in every field. From nurses and accountants, to hospitality staff and construction workers, Australian economy lacks the cogs for the economy to get moving. Inside the country are located thousands of skilled workers, who stayed in Australia during these extraordinary times, working hard with their fellow Australian colleagues to help built a strong line of defense against the heavy economic impact of Covid19. Some of these workers have their visas nearly expiring, others cannot renew them, and others need to apply for new visas with less working rights. These people are the ones that have proven during the hardest of times, that they have the necessary skills that Australia needs to help restart the economy and overcome the difficulties of the past 2 years. New Zealand, acknowledging the contribution of her own temporary workers, has offered an one-off permanent resident visa to all these people that helped her during the pandemic. from 2,401 citizens (Petition No. EN3668)

Data shows at least 10 children have been reported as killed in Australia over the last 5 years from being left in hot cars, 5 of those in QLD alone (statistics provided by KidSafe QLD), with thousands of near misses every year causing harm to vulnerable children. Currently there is no requirement in the Australian Design Rules for vehicles to include electronic warning systems for the detection of children left alone in vehicles, to alert relevant people to the imminent danger they are in. This leads to unnecessary loss of young life and significant grief for family, friends and the wider community.

Our Non-Profit Organisation, Remember Rylee Inc, calls for the government to change legislation to mandate these systems; in honour of my daughter Rylee Rose Black, and all children who have been needlessly killed as a result of hot car death. These children died a most painful death, and leave behind loved ones who will forever grieve their loss.
The technology is readily available and at minimal cost, we can prevent these tragedies; we say enough is enough, let us stop Hot Car Deaths.

from 2,619 citizens (Petition No. EN3670)
Climate Change

Climate change is the most important challenge humanity faces today. Manufacturers of vehicles with internal combustion engines (ICE) know exactly what damage their products cause to our climate, and to people's health. Nevertheless, many of them choose to delay the transition to clean solutions, for example electric vehicles (EVs). They attempt to maximise their profits now, at the expense of society later.

Mainstream car manufacturers today act just as tobacco companies acted a generation ago: Every time we turn on the radio we are bombarded with advertising for yet another ICE vehicle, making it sound so exciting and cool. That's how they trick consumers into buying vehicles that will poison the air for decades to come.
One successful policy that worked against smoking will work in this context too: a blanket ban on advertising for ICE vehicles in all media.
Such a ban will accelerate the uptake of clean vehicles at no cost to the taxpayer. It will:

* Incentivise manufacturers that choose sell clean vehicles only overseas to bring more models to Australia, to have products they can still advertise. That leads to more clean choices for Australian consumers.
* Incentivise manufacturers that have no clean vehicles to accelerate investments into their own transition, to avoid losing market share.
* Increase public awareness of the benefits of EVs through a focus in advertising.
We therefore ask the House to introduce legislation to parliament to implement a blanket advertising ban on ICE vehicles, modelled on the successful legislation banning tobacco advertising.
