The "Anti-Troll" legislation aims to force international Social Media companies to hand over user private information and require proof of identity for sign up. There is no longer a compelling argument that international adult material (R18+ and unrestricted) content providers can't be forced to require proof of age.
Protecting our children from demonstratable harm from access to online adult material is more important than protecting millionaires and politicians from false news about them and being called names.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN3731)
Skilled Migration Program

Why are the offshore expired 485 visa holders being forced to wait until 1st July 222 to apply for a Replacement visas. This is totally unfair and irrational decision because feelings of 30k visa holders are already degraded and humiliated. After suffering and crying for 21 months, we have been told to wait another 7 months to apply for a replacement visas and God know how long it would take for the visa to be processed.

We therefore ask the House to Australia for the 485 visa holders' suffering for the last 22 months. Replacement visa should be automatic process or else it should be forwarded with immediate available date and immediate extension etc.
from 386 citizens (Petition No. EN3732)
Skilled Migration Program

Non eligible New Zealanders who are no longer able to apply for PR, but who stayed in Australia during the pandemic continued to support the economy and work force and should be given an opportunity to apply for Permanent Residency in Australia.

We therefore ask the House to considers a pathway for non eligible New Zealanders, who resided in Australia during the pandemic a way to acquire Permanent Residency. We recommend that in order to be eligible for this new pathway, New Zealanders must first meet the same criteria that they otherwise would have had to, to be eligible for the (Subclass 189)
Skilled independent visa (New Zealand stream).
from 185 citizens (Petition No. EN3733)
Electoral Roll

I have been a New Zealand Citizen resident of Australia paying taxes and council rates for more than a decade, and my Filipino permanent Resident partner has been here for 20 years doing the same. We would like the right to vote in elections.

We therefore ask the House to open voting rights to all residents of Australia who have lived here for more than 5 years, so that we need not fear discrimination by the Australian government, due to our lack of voting rights.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN3735)
COVID-19: Vaccination

In the provision of healthcare, the bond of trust between the community and the healthcare provider is perhaps the most important element. The betrayal of this trust will have consequences to public health that are impossible to estimate and could take a generation to remedy.

Since the introduction of the various, experimental SARS COVID-19 vaccinations, the Therapeutic Goods Administration Database of Adverse Events Notifications have recorded 674 deaths and over 84,000 other adverse events related to the vaccines. It is outrageous that these experimental medications are still available. It is acknowledged that many adverse events are not reported to this database.

Many of us in the community are painfully aware of the damage these medications are causing and are dismayed at the lack of reporting, obfuscation and concealment. Healthcare professionals, (especially those who's wages are paid by the taxpayer) have a sacred duty to report any potential health risks to the public.
We therefore ask the House to
We therefore ask the house to:

1. Strengthen the reporting requirements of adverse events so a more complete picture of the risks associated with these experimental medications, thereby allowing the public to make an informed choice.
2. Investigate the reasons that adverse events are under reported and,

3. Any healthcare professional, who knowingly fails to report a serious adverse event is contributing to a systemic failure, has betrayed the trust of the community and should be deregistered immediately and permanently.
from 133 citizens (Petition No. EN3736)
Migration

International student graduates face many hardships and challenges to prove their value in order to become an Australian Permanent Resident or Citizen. The point-based skilled migration pathway is a fantastic opportunity for International students which gives them the chance to call Australia home for the rest of their life.

In recent years, this process has taken significant turns when it comes to inviting candidates. The minimum point required to be invited is 65, but prospective skilled immigrants with points around 95 to 100 are not even receiving invitations, keeping them in complete limbo about their future.
Prospective immigrants are losing their vital years from life while waiting on an immigration system that seems very much flawed.

There are candidates who are currently employed in their field of study, scored 8 + in all modules of the English Language test, cleared their NAATI exam, completed professional year, fulfilled time studied in Australia requirement and did everything right to get invited to apply for permanent residency, but seems to be the most ignored in the Australian migration ecosystem, thus raising questions on how the Department of Immigration conducts the invitation rounds from the Expression of Interest pool.
We therefore ask the House to discuss this issue of the point-based skilled migration invitation system and process.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN3737)
Skilled Migration Program
Dear Committee Members,
We are writing to you today seeking your urgent assistance and to draw your attention towards the current Departmental processing times for 887 visa applications.

The plight of tens of thousands of eligible provisional and bridging visa holders in Australia many of whom currently find themselves with limited or no access or support as a result of the coronavirus and Federal Government visa processing delays must be addressed urgently.

These are specifically those people who have legally met all the relevant eligibility criteria for the grant of an Australian permanent visa and include families with young children. Due to an unexplainable delay, they have found themselves in a seemingly never-ending and increasing queue. In the case of 887 visa applicants, the queue has mysteriously increased from weeks to now 18-19 months and is growing longer.

We have worked through COVID situation and completed the prerequisites for 887 visas. We are those people who are working full-time and paying our taxes and contributing strongly towards Australian economy.

We therefore ask the House to grant all eligible 887 applications immediately, keeping in mind that 887 applicants are not subject to any caps and the grant of their initial provisional visa has already been counted towards previous migration programs and permanent visa places. Please also note that these are the people who are skilled workers and will be great assets to the Australian economy.
We appreciate the steps taken by the government to quickly grant 887 visas to applicants who are offshore.
from 577 citizens (Petition No. EN3738)
Child Abuse

On 20th October 2015, Senator Heffernan brought to Parliament and Australias attention, official documents presented during the Wood Royal Commission and again during Royal Commission into Ritual and Sexual Abuse within Institutions. These documents include police documents, naming 28 high profile paedophiles, including one former Prime Minister. Investigation into these documents were stopped. The government and Judiciary have been noted suppressing these documents with orders for 90 years, choosing not to investigate as the public would 'lose faith in the judiciary'. The public have already lost faith in the Government and Judiciary. This is compounded by these suppression orders. We the Australians people stand against these people rescission orders to protect our children. We insist these people and institutions be fully investigated, and held to account, including those whom have chosen to cover and suppress any investigations.

We therefore ask the House to 1: Lift the 90 year Suppression Orders on these documents. 2: Create and support permanently, Independent Corruption and Integrity Commission to investigate ANY and ALL corruption exposed within Government, Judiciary and other formal Institutions. 3: Investigate these particular documents suppressed, and bring those guilty to account. 4: Bring justice to the victims and survivors, by exposing those people and systems in place that are corrupt and currently hidden. 5: Clean the institutions of all corruption, to start bringing the public's faith back, showing that our government and judiciary will be honest and work for the people of Australia, while protecting our children's future.
from 293 citizens (Petition No. EN3744)
Skilled Migration Program

People who got subclass 485 visa during lockdown either in 2019 or 2020 must be given more time to stay in Australia rather than 1.6 year visa as all new applicants are getting 2 years visa now and how about the people who already got before and was unable to work properly due to lockdowns and cannot complete their job ready and other necessary things on time . They must also be given more visa so that they can also reach their goal as they were unable to go anywhere due to lockdowns
We therefore ask the House to immigration to increase the stay for people who already got 485 visa during pandemic time . J
from three citizens (Petition No. EN3745)
Migration

Generally, if we are seeking for permanent resident in COVID 19 Pandemic their support of the economy has taken many form : Work, Study, Paying taxes, Supporting local Business and Australia online retailers ,etc disruptions by completing for migration program during pandemic couple limited or unattainable pathways to permanent Residency mean that future for many Temporary Residents in Australia is uncertain.
We therefore ask the House to establish a pathway to permanent Residency for Temporary Residents who have lived in Australia and supported its economy during the COVID 19 Pandemic.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN3754)
Diabetes

Since being off Lantus my son no longer has good control with his type 1 diabetes. He no longer sleeps well and wakes often during the night. The replacement insulin he has been put on is not as effective as Lantus was
We therefore ask the House to reinstate Lantus to the PBS
from four citizens (Petition No. EN3757)
Electric Vehicles
There is no valid reason for metropolitan, non utility vehicle at any level of government to be internal combustion engines.

Council rangers, fire and emergency services, utility required vehicles , remote and regional vehicle fleets where infrastructure cannot support it would excluded but all politicians, civil servants and other government provided, funded or pool vehicles should be changed out to electric vehicles and infrastructure installed for the use thereof to reduce the carbon footprint of the government.
We therefore ask the House to propose that all new governmental vehicles from 2023 to be electric unless included in a list of exempted vehicles/role requirements
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN3758)
Donations to Political Parties

It will start to spread the consistent non biased reporting that we all deserve to hear and perhaps will ease the current state of corruption allegations spreading around certain political parties and members of media will never face the pressures of political bias and will only report facts and figures pertaining to the political sectors of this great country of ours.
We therefore ask the House to Ban any ability for media corporations to donate to any political party and parliament members campaigns.
from 33 citizens (Petition No. EN3760)
Media
We all saw the photographs of victims of the Tasmanian tragedy posted by news outlets online. Even with faces blurred, this is distressing to families as well as parents Australia-wide.
News media are known to go to social media accounts of victims and take any photos they can find to post while simply blurring the faces of children under 18.

There is no benefit to a child being shown at the scene of a tragic accident even if they survived. It is distressing for everyone involved and we can all read or be told about what happened without that imagery attached to it.

We therefore ask the House to introduce a law where pictures of children involved in an accident, particularly at the scene of that accident, are not allowed to be shown in news media except with the express written consent of their parent or legal guardian.
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN3767)
Water Safety

Drowning is a leading cause of death for children. In Australia: More children ages 1-4 die from drowning than any other cause of death except birth defects. For children ages 1-14, drowning is the second leading cause of unintentional injury death after motor vehicle crashes.

Drowning is very quick and silent. Most parents and carers think they will hear if a child is drowning, but this isn't true. A young child's head is heavy compared to the rest of their body, so they can't lift themselves once they're underwater.
Children can drown in swimming pools, baths, spas, dams, rivers, creeks, garden ponds, water features, buckets or any source of water.
Children who survive drowning can suffer long-term brain damage, developmental delays and other health problems.

Swim skills add a layer of protection to prevent drowning incidents. Formal swimming lessons reduce the risk of drowning among children 1-4 years and should be continued into adolescence. This is the only sport that can actually save lives and can also reduce the risk of drowning among older individuals.

We therefore ask the House to pass a bill to implement a Nationwide Intensive School Swimming and Water Safety Program for both primary and secondary school children. This will ensure the quality and consistency of the programs across the commonwealth
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN3769)
Health Care

Each decade of the 21st century has seen increasing numbers and severity of pandemic and epidemics in the world. We have seen how the Covid-19 situation has demonstrated the danger viruses present to the Australian population. A national center of disease control would strengthen Australia's preparedness and lead the national response to future pandemics.

We therefore ask the House to Establish a Australian National Centre for Disease Control, with a national focus on current and emerging communicable disease threats, engaging in global health surveillance, health security, epidemiology and research.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN3770)
Housing Affordability
Stop/BAN "Student Only Housing" & Allow normal people to live in Studio Apartments currently reserved for Students only.
Allowing this has destroyed Housing Affordability and ruined the dreams of home ownership and affordable living of thousands of Australian Citizens
We therefore ask the House to make a new law to outlaw the real-estate industry and body-corporates practices of only allowing Students to live in their buildings.
Allow Australians to buy the cheap studio apartments
Stop non-Australians from buying them would be the icing on the cake to fix homelessness/home affordability
from four citizens (Petition No. EN3772)
Migration

Generally, if we are seeking for permanent Resident in covid pandemic their support of the economy has taken many forms: work, study, paying taxes, supporting local businesses and Australia online retailers, etc disruptions by completing for migration program during pandemic coupled limited or unattainable pathways to permanent Residency mean that the future for many Temporary Residents in Australia
We therefore ask the House to establish a pathway to permanent Residency for Temporary Residents who have lived in Australia and supported its economy during the covid 19 pandemic
from 35 citizens (Petition No. EN3777)
Migration
Works, Study, Paying Taxes, Supporting local businesses and Australia online retailers, etc

disruptions by completing for migration program during pandemic couple limited or unattainable pathways to permanent Residency mean that the future for many Temporary Residents in Australia is uncertain.
We therefore ask the House to establish a pathway to permanent Residency for Temporary Residents who live in Australia and supported its economy during the covid 19 Pandemic.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN3778)
Alcohol
Enforce the hospitality industry to display the alcohol content on all beer taps to eliminate dangerous consumption through lack of information provided by the brewers & hospitality venues.

We therefore ask the House to enforce the hospitality industry, to display the alcohol content on all beer taps. With the growing trend in the craft beer industry & the wild variations in beer strengths, low alcohol (2.4%) to very high strength (12.2%), I believe the hospitality industry should be held responsible for the safe supply of craft beer.

I am a 41 year old man whom recently had a very scary experience where the beer I was drinking was of 11.1% in lieu of the 5% I believed I was drinking. With craft beer, it is impossible to tell how strong the beer is while it is being consumed. I drank 3-4 glasses before I started to feel the full effects & by then it was too late. 4 glasses over a 2 hour period actually equated to 8 standard beers, & it is safe to say I was very sick for a few days following.

The outcome I am hoping for would go hand in hand with, or become part of, the Responsible Service of Alcohol & would provide some precaution & a safety net around the craft beer industry. I am terrified that the general public is not being provided the information required to make an educated decision should they choose to consume craft beer.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN3782)
Migration

Work ,study ,paying taxes, supporting local business and Australia online retailers ,etc disruption by completing for migration program during pandemic couple limited unattainable pathways to permanent Residency mean that the future for many temporary Residents in Australia is uncertain.
We therefore ask the House to establish a pathway Resident for Temporary Resident who live in Australia and supported its economy its economy during the Covid-19 pandemic
from one citizen (Petition No. EN3783)
Migration

Work, Study, paying taxes ,supporting local business and Australia online retailers , etc. disruption by completing for migration program during pandemic couples limited unattainable pathways to permanent Residency mean that the future for many Temporary Residents in Australia is uncertain
We therefore ask the House to establish a pathway to permanent Resident for Temporary Resident who live in Australia and supported it's economy during the covid-19 pandemic
from one citizen (Petition No. EN3784)
Migration

Work, Study, paying taxes ,supporting local businesses and Australia online retailers, etc. disruption by completing for migration program during pandemic couple limited unattainable pathways to permanent Residency mean that the future for many Temporary Residents in Australia is uncertain.
We therefore ask the House to establish a pathway to permanent Resident for Temporary Resident who live in Australia and supported it's economy during the covid 19 pandemic
from seven citizens (Petition No. EN3785)
Centrelink
- The current Centrelink payments for Jobseeker and Austudy is less than $900 fortnight.
- The average rent prices plus water and electricity is more than 50% this amount.
We therefore ask the House to collaborate with Centrelink economic management to ensure accommodation costs are less than 50% the Centrelink payment amounts.
from 11 citizens (Petition No. EN3789)
Child Nutrition
- Requesting Daycares Public Schooling provide both best quality pH tested water and green juice using organic produce if available to promote best quality foods and fresh enzyme organic foods.
- Children to have access to Nurses and items such as Combantrin as required to ensure best health Nurse promotion.
We therefore ask the House to collaborate with the Ministers of Education Ministers of Health to ensure legislation promotes and provides best quality pH fresh enzyme alkalinity foods to these areas.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN3792)
COVID-19: Testing

Rapid antigen tests are vital in protecting communities from COVID-19. Many have needed to rely on rapid antigen tests because of the extended wait times and inaccessibility of PCR (polymerase chain reaction) tests. Though the effectiveness varies between the tests, they are a crucial indicator and warning system that can help prevent the spread of infection.

However, the government's inability to subsidise and provide free rapid antigen tests has endangered the health, time and safety of all Australians. The United Kingdom and Germany are among the few countries that have benefitted their peoples from distributing free, subsidised rapid antigen tests.

The best uses for rapid antigen tests are as a warning system to alert people and their loved ones. The worst uses for rapid antigen tests are for profit and competition. And that is exactly what is happening right now.

While the government can stress the importance of getting tested, they cannot take opportunity from people to safely do so. Healthcare infrastructures are already destabilised by the pressure placed on them. Self-testing using rapid antigen test kits would alleviate some of this stress.

We therefore ask the House to subsidise and make rapid antigen tests, both oral and nasal, free to everyone in Australia. Without reliable contact tracing and overburdened healthcare facilities, it is important to minimise the spread and risk of infection. Funds must be allocated to consistent and accessible rapid antigen tests for people to protect themselves and each other.
from 2,606 citizens (Petition No. EN3796)
Lefevre Peninsula

The Lefevre Peninsula, is divided by ARTC Rail Tracks Freight Line operating 24 hours a day 7 days a week. The eastern side bounded by the Port River, is heavily polluted industrial land, the cause of many deaths, from cancer to asbestosis. The contamination also affects wildlife.
The western side is home to a community, with a high level of health conditions, breathing difficulties and forms of cancer, in particular Mesothelioma.

ARTC manages the Freight line on the Peninsula. Numerous documented community requests for a safe corridor, is difficult. ARTC is noncooperative and adopts a reactive approach. Poor maintenance of vegetation, leaves the Community exposed to a hazardous fire risk. Requests for appropriate action are ignored. The fence bounding the residential side is either not suitable for a safe domestic situation, or does not exist at all, leaving access to the ARTC land easily accessible by children who are seen playing on ARTC land.

There is no noise control for residents living opposite ARTC rail, and ARTC ignores pollution issues. It has poisoned numerous trees, leaving them dead. It does nothing to control the feral animals such as foxes, living on its land, who have no restriction to roam residential areas.

We therefore ask the House to instruct the Minister responsible for ARTC to develop a Community Safety and Livability Plan for residents, in consultation with the local council. The Minister should visit SA to see first hand the ARTC Community Safety fail on the Lefevre Peninsula.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN3797)
Somalia

Since its declaration as an independent state in 1991, the Republic of Somaliland has consistently demonstrated its ability to function as a democratic sovereign state, independent of its internationally recognised claimant, the Federal Republic of Somalia. As a champion of liberty and the democratic process, the Commonwealth of Australia should see it not as an option, but as a duty to promote and recognise political entities that demonstrate genuine abilities to function as legitimate, independent sovereign states. This is of particular importance, considering the ongoing instability and conflict in which many of Somaliland's neighbours are currently embroiled in. In a region of such critical importance for international trade and commerce, Australia must make decisive actions to embolden stable, politically compatible allies such as Somaliland. Such recognition will prove key to maintaining the integrity of Australia's foreign interests, in such a critical region.

We therefore ask the House to consider the mechanisms in which the Commonwealth of Australia may finally, as was done for the Republic of Kosovo in 2008, allow for the recognition of the sovereignty of the Republic of Somaliland as an independent state.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN3798)
Koalas

Victorian towns-such as Ballarat-once had thriving koala colonies, yet their crucial habitat has steadily declined due to weak conservation policies along with outdated and ineffective wildlife protection legislation- leaving the much-loved animals extremely vulnerable to car strikes, dog attacks and stress-related illnesses.
Wildlife rescuers and carers across the region recorded troubling numbers of koala deaths in 2021 and hold grave fears that if the situation continues then Victorian colonies will silently disappear.
It has prompted a call for legislation to be developed to protect all koalas across Australia.

This group believes koala abundance data reported by the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) is grossly inaccurate and has misrepresented the true conservation status of koalas in the region. Researchers who informed DELWPs modelling declared that Ballarat data specifically lacked accuracy. Anecdotally koalas are rarely seen in Ballarat and data collected by community groups reveals high fatality rates.
The group believe DELWP has failed in their responsibility to protect Victorian koalas and this has delayed crucial strategies to protect them from decline.
Koalas do not recognise borders and those in Victoria face exactly the same issues as those in NSW, ACT and QLD and yet Victoria has been left out of the National Koala Recovery Plan.

We therefore ask the House to fund and oversee research to establish accurate data on koala population, health and habitat in Victoria, and establish a National Koala Protection Act to protect koalas in all states with koala populations.
from 827 citizens (Petition No. EN3804)
COVID-19: Vaccination
Aviation staff have been injured after taking these provisional use 'vaccines', some losing their medical clearance to fly as a result.
Inflight cardiac related incidents involving flight and cabin crew in Australia and abroad are correlated with the use of these treatments, and this has not been adequately explained.
Lack of data concerning long term adverse aeromedical effects, rendering vaccine application irresponsible in aviation related safety roles.
No specific aeromedical studies were undertaken prior to these treatments being introduced.
Physicians in the USA have raised medical concerns about the effects of these treatments on crew and technicians, this represents an unacceptable risk to safety and the public.
Mandating of booster treatments at regular intervals may amplify these risks, and requires further study.
Rapid testing technologies and the prevalence of breakthrough infections, coupled with the reduced severity of the virus in the form of the Omicron variant has made employer mandates untenable.

There are discrepancies between the use of these treatments and guidance given in existing IATA and CASA aeromedical manuals; specifically, the use of drugs by staff in safety sensitive roles, and the incompatibility of cardiac risk with safety.

We therefore ask the House to require the Civil Aviation Safety Authority to address these issues, and any inflight incapacitation reports since the vaccine roll out began, as well as any medically related instances of a cardiac, pulmonary, thrombotic or neurological nature resulting in loss of license or long term sick leave since the beginning of the Covid vaccination program.
from 1,190 citizens (Petition No. EN3806)
Asylum Seekers

During the the unfortunate conditions of the pandemic, many businesses are facing worker shortages. This is a problem that is negatively affecting our economy as well as many local business owners. However, according to the Refugee Council of Australia there are about 1.5 thousand immigrants in Australian detention facilities. If these immigrants were integrated and welcomed into our society, they would be able to support Australian businesses by becoming employed in many of our struggling and understaffed businesses. Also, giving these people a place in Australia would promote acceptance and compassion, something we all need a little bit of in these trying times.

We therefore ask the House to release all immigrants that are currently in our detention centres, to let them live in Australia (particularly areas with understaffed businesses), and to properly provide them with welfare that typical refugees would normally receive in order to help them adjust to being in Australia.
from 31 citizens (Petition No. EN3807)
Fertility Treatment

Young women, particularly single women, have had difficulty in meeting potential partners and fostering romantic relationships over the past two years due to the pandemic. As a result, this has caused a delay in the potential of having children. Over the course of the pandemic, majority of Australians have received some form of pay reduction and/or lost their employment entirely, which also deters women from exploring their fertility options. This is an underlying repercussion of the pandemic that has not received much attention as it is not perceived as urgent compared with the economic implications of lockdowns or even the politics associated with the availability of rapid tests. If people don't have kids and there are no incentives to do so, the economy will suffer moreso in the next decade. This is especially important for Australia, as we are already an ageing population and need to have fertility treatments such as freezing eggs incentivised so that it is more accessible for women and so it can put our minds at ease for future fertility for when we eventually return to some form of normalcy.
We therefore ask the House to discount the cost of egg-freezing treatments by 50% for women aged between 28-37.
from 40 citizens (Petition No. EN3808)
Migration

Work,study,paying taxes, supporting local businesses and Australia online retailers, etc disruption by completing for migration program during pandemic couple limited unattainable pathways to permanent residentcy mean that the future for many temporary residents in Australia is uncertain
We therefore ask the House to establish a pathway to permanent resident for temporary resident who live in Australia and supported it's economy during the covid-19 pandemic.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN3809)
HomeBuilder Grant

When the Federal Government announced the Home Builder Grant (HBG), it was stated that anyone that signed a building contract between 04/06/2020 and 31/12/2020 and met the set requirements, would receive the grant. This was irrespective of completing the online application. This was further reiterated by Minister Sukkar in various interviews. The Minister also assured that applications were just a formality. The deadline was not mentioned in any media releases nor included in the requirements. Due to the high demand for construction and renovations, local councils were overwhelmed and resulted in long delays in building approvals. Also, a shortage of building supplies and Covid-19 restrictions has seen construction time frames extended significantly. Added to this a flawed HBG website and confusing information saw many hard-working Australians unable to apply for this grant even though, according to the Minister for Housing, they are eligible. Recently, the HBG portal has reopened for people who started their applications. However, this was not the case for people who met the requirements but did not start the application. This is because they were unaware of the closing date, caused by a lack of clarity. Missing out on the grant has severely affected my physical and mental health mental.
We therefore ask the House to reopen the application and comply with promises made by the Government and Minister for Housing and Homelessness per the National Partnerships Agreement.
from 86 citizens (Petition No. EN3810)
Migration

Work, study, paying taxes, supporting local businesses and Australia online retailers, etc disruption by completing for migration program during pandemic couple limited unattainable pathways to permanent residentcy mean that the future for many temporary residents in Australia is uncertain.
We therefore ask the House to permanent resident for temporary resident who live in Australia and supported it's economy during the covid-19 pandemic
from five citizens (Petition No. EN3811)
COVID-19: Vaccination

As I write this, 51,356 positive cases (in one day) have been announced in Victoria. We have a clearly exponential outbreak around the country. The virus is spread just as easily by the vaccinated (just look at the stats). The vaccinated were meant to essentially block transmission. Instead, we've created super spreaders.

Hypothetically, if the shot were a placebo, you would expect to see exactly what we are seeing now. It is clear that with over 90% of the population fully vaccinated, if the shots were in any way capable of stopping the spread, we wouldn't be having record breaking exponential case numbers.

The country is currently debating Novak Djokovic. The question must be asked, "what difference given the above would it make to cease all discrimination against the unvaccinated?". Honestly? In what way would allowing Novak's entry into Australia in any way harm a population now experiencing an exponential outbreak equally if not primarily (the vaccinated are the majority) spread by the vaccinated? Further, the variant is unquestionably far less severe.

If we must discriminate as a nation, let's look at the biggest risk factor we can alter (through lifestyle choices)? Obesity. If one of the primary risk factors to negative health outcomes (clogging up hospitals) is obesity, why aren't we taking away the rights of the obese? If we wish to get truly dystopian by discarding human rights, why not have BMI mandates? Oh, majority voters
We therefore ask the House to cease all coercion and discrimination. End vaccine apartheid.
from 170 citizens (Petition No. EN3812)
Migration

Work, study, paying taxes, supporting local businesses and Australia online retailers, etc disruption by completing for migration program during pandemic couple limited unattainable pathways to permanent residentcy mean that the future for many temporary residents in Australia is uncertain.
We therefore ask the House to establish a pathway to permanent resident for temporary resident who live in Australia and supported it's economy during the covid-19 pandemic.
from 264 citizens (Petition No. EN3813)
COVID-19: Vaccination

The Omicron variant of COVID-19 has proven to be infectious to people vaccinated against the earlier variants of COVID-19. Infection rates have jumped by more than 10 times the maximum recorded prior to Omicron reaching Australia.

Even though Omicron itself might be less lethal than other variants, the infection rate has outstripped the lethality buffer, so it is already more likely that an individual will die from Omicron than they would have from other variants if the infection rate remained low. Additionally, Omicron is likely to mutate into another, more lethal variant which also ignores vaccination.

We therefore ask the House to ensure the Omicron variant (and any future variants which are infectious despite previous vaccination) are treated as separate pandemics. This will include counting the vaccination rate as 0% until such time as a vaccine against Omicron is developed and administered.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN3814)

subdebateinfo.title: National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Cultural Precinct

p.span: National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Cultural Precinct
STOP THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE NEW ABORIGINAL PRECINCT IN CANBERRA
WHY ARE BUILDING THIS NEW SO CALLED ABORIGINAL PRECENTCT?
WHY ARE WASTING OUT TAX PAYERS MONEY ON AN ONLY ABORIGINAL ART PRECINCT & CEMETERY?
THE GOVERNEMENT HAS NO ATHORITY TO THIS UNLESS APPRVED BY ALL THE PEOPLE OF AUSTRALIA.
WE ARE SICK TO DEATH OF ALL THE WASTAGE OF MONEY ESPECIALLY NOW IN THESE HARD TIME OF COVI-19 (BUSINESSES SHUTTING DOWN & MANY AUSTRALIANS WHO LOST THEIR JOB)
ANOTHER TOKEN BEING SORRY?
WHAT FOR?
PUT ANY OF ABORIGINAL ART IN THE EXISTING ART CENTER AMONG ALL AUSTRALIANS NOT BUILDING ONLY FOR THE INDIGENOUS?
STOP SEPERATION OF OUR ONE COUNTRY ENOUGH IS ENOUGH!
RECOGNIZE OUR HYSTORY & LIVE TOGETHER & NOT BE NOW RACIST AGAISNT ALL OTHER RACES THAT BUILT THIS COUNTRY
THIS RACIST & WHITE APERTHEID NEEDS TO STOP NOW
We therefore ask the House to THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE ONLY ABORIGINAL NEW CENETER ON CABERRA!
THIS IS DIVISIVE & RACIST & COMPLETE WASTE OF ALL TAX PAYERS MONEY
STOP THE WHITE APERHTIED HITTING THIS COUNTRY!
WHAT IS THE POIT OF MULTICULTURISM WHEN ONE RACE IS ABOVE THE OTHER!
ENOUGH IS ENOUGH!
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN3818)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (10:01): I present the following ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Chair
Thank you for your petition EN2696—Stop repatriation from India.

Throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, the Australian Government is committed to the safety of the Australian people. We are also proud of the deep and enduring people to people links between Australia and India, consistent with our strong strategic ties reflected in the Australia-India Comprehensive Strategic Partnership signed by Prime Ministers Morrison and Modi in June 2020.

As at 18 October 2021 the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) has facilitated 69 flights to support the return of over 11,600 Australian citizens, permanent residents and their families in India during the COVID-19 pandemic. This more than double the number of faciliated flights we have organised to any other country. Since March 2020, 27,300 Australians registered with DFAT have already returned from India.
Between 27 April and 15 May 2021, the Australian Government announced a number of measures to in response to the increased risk of the COVID-19 outbreak in India.

Concurrently, Australia also providing significant support to assist the Indian Government in their humanitarian response to the outbreak, including the deployment of 37 tonnes of medical supplies. Reflecting our close relationship, Australians donated more than $12.2 million to support India's COVID response through the Australian Council for International Development (ACFID) member organisations.
Australia has welcomed the strong leadership role the Indian Government has taken through the pandemic in manufacturing and distributing vaccines to the region.

Restrictions on arrivals into Australia carefully balance the interests of Australians seeking to return while managing the risk to public health. The Australian Government's approach in response to the pandemic is based on health advice and outlined in the National Plan to Transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response (National Plan). The National Plan outlines the policy framework for reopening international borders and reducing restrictions gradually with each phase dependent on vaccination thresholds.

Phase C of the National Plan will be implemented when at least 80 per cent of the eligible Australian population is vaccinated. It will include gradually reopening inward and outward international travel with safe countries; reducing caps on returning vaccinated Australians; increasing the capped entry of student, economic and humanitarian visa holders; lifting restrictions on outbound travel for vaccinated Australians; and extending travel bubbles for unrestricted travel to new candidate countries.

Australia is ready to take its next steps to safely reopen to the world, with changes coming to the international border. The Government intended to remove COVID-related restrictions in November to enable fully vaccinated Australian citizens and permanent residents to travel internationally and to allow fully vaccinated Australians, including their parents to return to Australia outside of passenger caps.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) has published its initial assessment of the data on the protection offered by the Coronavac (Sinovac) and Covishield (AstraZeneca/Serum Institute of India) vaccines. The TGA has advised that these vaccines should be considered as 'recognised vaccines' for the purpose of determining incoming international travellers as being appropriately vaccinated. Declaring certain COVID-19 vaccines as 'recognised vaccines' is separate to a regulatory decision on whether they are approved for use for vaccination in Australia, which has not been made by the TGA. The recognition of these two additional vaccines is a major milestone towards more Australians vaccinated overseas getting home sooner, including those in India.
Consistent with our plan to reopen to the world and prioritise the return of Australians, I very much look forward to soon welcoming students, tourists and skilled workers from India to Australia.
I trust this information is of assistance.
I have sent a copy of this letter to the Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment, Minister for Health and the Minister for Home Affairs.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Cybersecurity
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 9 August 2021 to the Attorney-General, Senator the Hon Michaelia Cash, enclosing petition EN2698 with 8 signatures, regarding legislative amendments to capture ransomware payments to cybercriminals as an act of supporting terrorism. Your correspondence was referred to me on 14 September 2021, as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

The Australian Government is alert to the threat of ransomware, as it continues to grow in impact and remains one of the most disruptive cyber threats to Australian businesses. The Government shares the petition's objective of deterring the payment of ransoms and protecting Australians from the ransomware threat.

In response, the Government has released its Ransomware Action Plan to articulate the capabilities and powers that Australia will use to combat ransomware. The plan outlines operational, policy and legislative initiatives that will counter the threat of ransomware.

Initiatives include the development of a ransomware reporting regime which will enable Government to better support victims of ransomware and modernisation of Australia's criminal laws to ensure that cybercriminals are held to account and law enforcement is able to track, seize or freeze their ill-gotten gains.

The Ransomware Action Plan clearly states that the Government does not condone the payment or ransoms to cybercriminals. Any ransom payment, small or large, fuels the ransomware business model, putting other Australians at risk. Working in partnership with industry, the Government will make Australia a harder target for cybercriminals who are putting our businesses and communities at risk.
I have copied this letter to the Attorney-General. Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: Regional Skilled Worker Program
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 9 August 2021 enclosing Petition EN2791, with 2380 signatures. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention and apologise for the delay in responding.

Australia's current travel restriction policy has played a key foundational role underpinning management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia and was implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

I acknowledge the difficulties of Skilled Regional (Provisional) visa holders seeking to travel to, or return to Australia, however, the restrictions are in place to manage the health risks posed to the Australian community by international travellers.

Visa applications for occupations providing critical or specialist medical services, and other applications for occupations in critical sectors of the economy such as agriculture, food production and aged care, are prioritised ahead of all other applications. The Australian Government is also prioritising applications for any visa in non-critical categories for onshore applicants before offshore applicants.

You may be aware that on 6 August 2021, the National Cabinet agreed in full to a four-phase National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response. The National Plan provides a graduated pathway to reopen the international border with each phase triggered once Australia reaches key vaccination thresholds expressed as a percentage of the population who are vaccinated.

As Australia progresses through the key vaccination thresholds, the Government is finalising plans so Australian families can be reunited and temporary visa holders including those holding Subclass 489 and Subclass 491 visas can return.

The current travel restriction measures are temporary and are reviewed regularly. Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2791 to my attention. Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Diabetes
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence concerning petition EN2808 requesting to review the specific methods of how the Protheses List Advisory Committee and National Diabetes Services Scheme (NDSS) are approaching the application to list the Omnipod DASH Insulin Delivery System (Omnipod) to ensure that those living with diabetes have responsive and affordable access to diabetes insulin pump technology.

The Australian Government is aware of the significant impact diabetes has on people with diabetes and their families and is committed to working towards the broad prevention of the disease in the Australian community. The Omnipod system is a new style of insulin pump for which there are no directly comparable products currently subsidised through the NDSS. The product sponsor for Omnipod has submitted a request for subsidisation of this product and my Department is currently working with the sponsor to identify a potential funding pathway. Depending on the outcome of this process, a decision to list Omnipod on the NDSS product schedule may need to be considered through the Federal Budget process.

While the OmniPod DASH system is not currently included on the NDSS, a range of insulin pump consumables are currently subsidised. Further information about NDSS products, and more specifically insulin pump consumables, can be found at: www.ndss.com.au.

The Government provides considerable financial support to people with diabetes through the subsidy of essential medicines, like insulin, under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) and diabetes-related products, like blood glucose test strips, through the NDSS. In 2020-21, PBS expenditure on medicines for diabetes was over $709 million and expenditure on products for diabetes supplied through the NDSS was $186 million.

Not only does the NDSS provide subsidised syringes and needles, blood glucose test strips, urine ketone test strips and insulin pump consumables to people with diabetes, it also provides educational and information services to assist in the best use of products and self-management of diabetes.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Women's Sport
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 18 October 2021 regarding petition number EN2874, which asks the House of Representatives to progress multiple amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act I984 (Sex Discrimination Act).

The Australian Government believes all people are entitled to respect, dignity and the opportunity to participate in society regardless of their personal attributes, and recognises that to enjoy civil and political rights on an equal basis with others, people need to be able to do so free from discrimination. The Sex Discrimination Act prohibits discrimination on the grounds of gender identity, sexual orientation and intersex status in many areas of public life, including employment, education and in the provision of goods, services and facilities. In this context, the Australian Government recognises that individuals may identify and be recognised within the community as a gender other than the sex they were assigned at birth or during infancy, or as a gender which is not exclusively male or female.

In relation to competitive sporting activity, the Sex Discrimination Act provides that it is not unlawful discrimination on the grounds of sex, gender identity or intersex status to exclude a person from participating in competitive sporting activity in which the strength, stamina or physique of competitors is relevant.

The Guidelines for the inclusion of transgender and gender diverse people in sport were developed by the Australian Human Rights Commission in partnership with Sport Australia and the Coalition of Major Professional and Participation Sports. These Guidelines are non-binding. They provide information on the relevant provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act and guidance on creating and promoting an inclusive environment in sport. As the Australian Human Rights Commission is an independent statutory agency, the Guidelines are a matter for the Commission.

The government is not currently considering any changes to the Sex Discrimination Act in relation to these issues. We thank you again for bringing your concerns to the Government's attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN2919- Not mandatory for aged care workers to have COVID-19 vaccine.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.
At the same time, the Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Everyone maintains the option to choose.

The Government has made it mandatory for those working in residential aged care to receive a COVID-19 vaccination, which was advised by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) and accepted by the National Cabinet. This is enforced through state and territory public-health orders, effective 17 September 2021.

As the COVID-19 pandemic is a public-health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. In line with this, some states and territories have now issued public-health orders that require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Further information about public-health orders may be found on state or territory government websites.

COVID-19 can be a very serious illness and is especially dangerous for vulnerable people in the community. Vaccination in settings such as aged and health care helps protect workers, vulnerable Australians, and the broader community. Anyone subject to a public-health order must comply with the terms of that order, with significant fines possible for non-compliance.

Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there should be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical and other reasons. The measures set out in these public-health orders are based on expert health advice on how best to manage the disease in the local community, considering factors such as current and predicted levels of transmission.

Some employers have also started to mandate vaccinations for their employees. For individual businesses not covered by a public-health order, whether to require COVID-19 vaccinations for employees needs careful consideration, considering the relevant employment, discrimination, work health and safety, and privacy laws, and the circumstances of the workplace.
The Government encourages employers and employees to work together on workplace vaccination for COVID-19.

As part of its responsibility in mitigating emerging health threats related to infectious diseases, the AHPPC has already made statements and recommendations on the topic of mandating vaccines for several professions or work types. These can be found at: www.health.gov.au using the search term 'Australia Health Protection Principal Committee'.

The Pfizer, AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria) and Moderna vaccines have all been proven through the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) approval and safety monitoring processes to be very effective at reducing severe illness, hospitalisation and death.

As the safety of the Australian population remains the highest priority of the Government during the rollout, decisions regarding COVID-19 vaccines will continue to be guided by expert medical advice of groups such as the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation, TGA and AHPPC.

On 6 August 2021, National Cabinet agreed to a National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID response to a post-vaccination setting focused on prevention of serious illness, hospitalisation and fatality, similar to the public-health management of other infectious diseases. More information on the National Plan is available on the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet's website at: www.pmc.gov.au using the search terms 'national plan'.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter. Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Women, Senator the Hon Marise Payne concerning petition number EN2924, requesting the lifting of travel restrictions, quarantine arrangements and mask-wearing requirements. This matter has been referred to me as the Minister for Health and Aged Care.
Australia's National Plan to Transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response (National Plan) sets important vaccination targets to pave the way for Australia to safely reopen.
Implementation of the National Plan is well underway, with large parts of the country soon to move to Phase C.

Under Phase C, international travel is on track to reopen safely to fully vaccinated Australian travellers. Following completion ofhome quarantine pilots in New South Wales and South Australia, it is anticipated that states and territories that are ready to do so will roll out modified quarantine arrangements for Australian citizens and permanent residents fully vaccinated with a vaccine approved for use in Australia or 'recognised' by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA).

Several jurisdictions have recently announced that fully vaccinated international travellers arriving in those jurisdictions will not have to quarantine on arrival. Mandatory 14-day managed quarantine will still apply for anyone not vaccinated or vaccinated with a vaccine not approved or recognised by the TGA. Australian citizens and permanent residents who cannot be vaccinated- for example if they are under 12 or have a medical condition-will be treated as vaccinated for the purposes of their travel.

In line with the National Plan, the Australian Government is balancing the need to minimise the risk that the spread ofCOVID-19 presents to communities, with the need to live with the virus. The Government's intention is that once changes are made in November 2021, the current overseas restrictions related to COVID-19 will be removed and Australians will be able to travel subject to any other travel advice and limits as long as they are fully vaccinated and those countries' border settings allow.

State and territory governments have primary operational responsibility for emergency management and public health in their respective jurisdictions under their own public health legislation. Public health orders that implement measures including mask-wearing are determined by state and territory governments to manage outbreaks in their jurisdictions.

These decisions are informed by expert medical advice to reduce the risk of harm caused by disease, especially for those who are most vulnerable, and to protect the capacity of health systems to provide critical support to Australians in need.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning Petition EN2925 to stop vaccine trials.

The Australian Government wants everyone in Australia to have access to a safe, free, COVID-19 vaccine, if they choose to be vaccinated. The safety of the population has always been the highest priority of the Government. For these reasons, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI).
The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) formally assesses the safety, quality and efficacy of medicines, including vaccines, prior to their approval for use in Australia.

All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large clinical trials on thousands of people. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease.

This involves comprehensive review of clinical trial data, non-clinical and toxicological studies, chemistry, manufacturing, quality, risk management and other information by a large team of clinical and scientific experts. Advice is then sought from an independent expert committee before a regulatory decision is made.

All COVID-19 vaccines used in the rollout have been granted provisional approval following a complete assessment of all this available data. No part of the process has been rushed and the TGA does not have an 'Emergency Use Authorisation' pathway for COVID-19 vaccines.

The urgency of the global pandemic means that researchers, agencies such as the World Health Organisation and governments all over the world are prioritising the development, assessment and rollout ofCOVID-19 vaccines.
There is a combination of reasons why safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines have been able to be designed, researched and made available sooner than previously seen. For example:
unprecedented levels of funding—the pandemic is a global priority and governments around the world are investing in research and manufacturing facilities

technology—the evolution of technology has allowed vaccines to be developed at a faster pace than in the past. New technologies have helped scientists understand the coronavirus and its make up much easier, which has allowed them to start working on
combined clinical trials—in response to the pandemic, some pharmaceutical companies have combined clinical trial phases 1 and 2

expedited review process by regulatory agencies—the TGA is engaging early with pharmaceutical companies about their vaccines and is accepting rolling data. This means that the TGA can accept, review and assess clinical trial data as it becomes available, rather than all at once at the end of the three clinical trial phases.

All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes including clinical trials. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease.

The TGA requires robust scienti:6c data before supporting a vaccine candidate and will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is found to be safe and effective, following its complete assessment of data.

The TGA undertook an independent and rigorous assessment of the available data for the Pfizer and Moderna mRNA COVID-19 vaccines. The data provided to the TGA was comprehensive and included pre-clinical and clinical studies, non-clinical and toxicology studies, chemistry, manufacturing, risk management and other information. All data was carefully reviewed by a large team of TGA's technical and clinical experts before provisionally approving both vaccines.

Technology using Messenger RNA (mRNA) has been in development for decades, with clinical trials in humans being conducted as early as 2011. The COVID-19 pandemic provided funding and opportunity for researchers who have been studying and working with mRNA vaccines to produce safe and effective vaccines.·

The Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines use a fragment of mRNA to instruct the body to generate an immune response against COVID-19. One dose (0.3ml) of the Pfizer vaccine contains 30 micrograms of mRNA, and one dose (0.5ml) of the Moderna vaccine contains 100 micrograms of mRNA. More information concerning the ingredients ofCOVID-19 vaccines can be found in the Product Information, available at: www.tga.gov.au.

Based on the naturally occurring process for protein production in our body, mRNA for COVID-19 vaccines is synthetically designed and produced, containing only a short version of the viral mRNA that encodes for the spike protein. mRNA is fragile, which is why it is combined with lipids (fats) that protect it from being degraded until after it has been delivered to the cell. The mRNA enters the muscle cells which make the spike protein, displaying it so that it is recognised by our immune system. This allows the body's natural defences to develop immunity to the disease, so the body is able to rapidly create its own antibodies to prevent disease if it encounters the virus in the future. Once it has provided the instructions for the spike protein, the mRNA is broken down quickly by the body.

It never enters the nucleus and cannot affect or combine with our DNA in any way to change our genetic code or the body's cells. Real world data collated and analysed as part of the global rollout have shown that the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are highly effective and safe vaccines.

The TGA is also part of a network of international regulators that meet regularly to discuss the development ofCOVID-19 vaccines. This information, together with the potential to use already established work-sharing arrangements and collaboration with other international regulators, is assisting the TGA to expedite the evaluation of any new vaccines without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality, and effectiveness.

The Government also continues to meet regularly with a range of COVID-19 vaccine and treatment developers and manufacturers and continues to monitor ongoing clinical trials and review real world effectiveness of vaccine rollouts globally. There are over 400 trials for 140 vaccine candidates worldwide, including a number that are trialling the use of needle-free technology. These include nasal sprays, oral tablets, skin patches and jet injectors.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN2926—Introduction of Health Pass.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

As the COVID-19 pandemic is a public-health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. In line with this, some states and territories have now issued public-health orders that require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Further information about public-health orders may be found on state or territory government websites.
Some employers have also started to mandate vaccinations for their employees.

For individual businesses not covered by a public-health order, whether to require COVID-19 vaccinations for employees needs careful consideration, taking into account the relevant employment, discrimination, work health and safety, and privacy laws, and the circumstances of the particular workplace. The Government encourages employers and employees to work together on workplace vaccination for COVID-19.

In addition, the Government understands that some businesses are considering whether to require vaccination as a condition of service or entry. Businesses do have the right to make any service they provide subject to conditions, and can impose restrictions on who can enter their premises. However, anti-discrimination issues may arise where people are unable to be vaccinated, and privacy laws restrict the collection of sensitive information. In each case, businesses need to consider their legal obligations, and determine what is right for their business.

Australians can already provide voluntary proof of vaccination by accessing their immunisation history statement through Medicare Online, via the Express Plus Medicare mobile app or via their My Health Record. People can seek a hard copy of their immunisation history statement by contacting the Australian Immunisation enquiries line, or through their doctor or immunisation provider.

The Government, through Services Australia and my Department, has also developed a safe and secure COVID-19 Digital Certificate, which may help Australians provide proof of vaccination if it were required. For those who have had a confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection, they can apply for a temporary exemption from a COVID-19 vaccine that will enable them to generate a COVID-19 Digital Certificate.

On 6 August 2021, National Cabinet agreed to a National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID response from its current pre-vaccination settings, focusing on continued suppression of community transmission, to post-vaccination settings focused on prevention of serious illness, hospitalisation and fatality, and the public-health management of other infectious diseases.
More information on the National Plan is available on the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet's website at: www.pmc.gov.au using the search term 'national plan'.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
