COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN2936 to make COVID-19 vaccinations mandatory for all Australians.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.
The Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Everyone maintains the option to choose.

As part of its responsibility in mitigating emerging health threats related to infectious diseases, the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) has released statements on the topic ofCOVID-19 vaccines for several professions. These can be found at: www.health.gov.au using the search terms 'Australian Health Protection Principal Committee'.

While these statements may be considered best advice and practice, the Australian Government has only made COVID-19 vaccination mandatory for those working in residential aged care, which was accepted by National Cabinet and effective from 17 September 2021.

COVID-19 can be a very serious illness and is especially dangerous for vulnerable people in the community. Vaccination in high-risk settings helps to protect workers, vulnerable Australians, and the broader community.

As the COVID-19 pandemic is a public-health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. In line with this, some states and territories have seen fit to issue public-health orders that require COVID-19 vaccination for people in additional high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Further information about public-health orders may be found on state or territory government websites.

Individual businesses do have the right to make any service they provide subject to conditions and can impose restrictions on who can enter their premises. However, the choice to require COVID-19 vaccination for workers or customers needs careful consideration, considering the relevant employment, discrimination, work health and safety, and privacy laws, and the circumstances of the workplace.
The Government encourages employers and workers to work together on workplace vaccination for COVID-19.

The safety of the Australian population remains the highest priority of the Government during the rollout. As such, decisions regarding COVID-19 vaccines, including consideration of mandates, will continue to be guided by expert medical advice of groups such as the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation, Therapeutic Goods Administration and the AHPPC.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will continue to occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021, concerning petition EN2939 to prohibit mandatory vaccines.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.
At the same time, the Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Everyone maintains the option to choose.

However, the Government has made it mandatory for those working in residential aged care to receive a COVID-19 vaccination, which was advised by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) and accepted by the National Cabinet. This is enforced through state and territory public-health orders, effective 17 September 2021.

As the COVID-19 pandemic is a public-health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. In line with this, some states and territories have now issued public-health orders that require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Further information about public-health orders may be found on state or territory government websites.

Some employers have also started to mandate vaccinations for their employees. For individual businesses not covered by a public-health order, whether to require COVID-19 vaccinations for employees needs careful consideration, taking into account the relevant employment, discrimination, work health and safety, and privacy laws, and the circumstances of the particular workplace. The Government encourages employers and employees to work together on workplace vaccination for COVID-19.

The Government understands that some businesses are considering whether to require vaccination as a condition of service or entry. Businesses do have the right to make any service they provide subject to conditions, and can impose restrictions on who can enter their premises. However, anti-discrimination issues may arise where people are unable to be vaccinated, and privacy laws restrict the collection of sensitive information. In each case, businesses need to consider their legal obligations, and determine what is right for their business.
Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there should be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical and other reasons.

On 6 August 2021, National Cabinet agreed to a National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID response to a post-vaccination setting focused on prevention of serious illness, hospitalisation and fatality, like the public-health management of other infectious diseases. More information on the National Plan is available on the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet's website at: www.pmc.gov.au using the search term 'national plan'.

As part of its responsibility <in mitigating emerging health threats related to infectious diseases, the AHPPC has already made statements and recommendations on the topic of mandating vaccines for several professions or work types. These can be found at: www.health.gov.au using the search terms 'Australia Health Protection Principal Committee'.

Before a COVID-19 vaccine can be legally supplied in Australia, it must be approved for use by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) and it will be subject to well-established and rigorous assessment and approval process to determine if the benefits outweigh the risks. The TGA's vaccine safety monitoring system can rapidly detect, investigate and respond to any emerging safety issues identified for COVID 19 vaccines.

The Pfizer, AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria) and Moderna vaccines have all been proven through the TGA approval and safety monitoring processes to be very effective at reducing severe illness, hospitalisation and death.

As the safety of the Australian population remains the highest priority of the Government during the rollout, decisions regarding COVID-19 vaccines will continue to be guided by expert medical advice of groups such as the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation, TGA and AHPPC.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Family Law
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 18 October 2021 regarding Petition No EN2942, presented to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions. The petition requests legislative change to provide for a default position of 50/50 shared post-separation care arrangements in the absence of a Family Court Order and Apprehended Violence Order or abuse claims. As Attorney-General, the family law system falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

The Family Law Act 1975 provides a legal framework for resolving arrangements for children and prope1iy following a relationship breakdown. When couples separate they are encouraged to resolve issues themselves without going to court. This is more likely to save them time, money and stress. It also enables them to work out and, if necessary, vary care arrangements so that they can meet the needs of their children and also meet the demands and schedules of the parents.

The Australian Government has produced a handbook on parenting orders—'Parenting Orders- what you need to know'. The handbook aims to help separated parents agree on arrangements for their children, and support them to develop workable, child-focussed parenting orders. This handbook can be accessed at the website of the Attorney-General's Department.

The Family Law Act requires separated couples needing to resolve parenting arrangements to make a genuine effort at family dispute resolution before attending court, unless one of the exceptions applies—such as family violence, child abuse or urgency. Where the parties cannot reach agreement the matter may progress to the family law courts for resolution.

The 'best interests of the child' is the paramount consideration of the court when resolving parenting matters. This includes the need to protect children from harm and, in the absence of factors such as violence or abuse, for children to enjoy a meaningful relationship with each of their parents. The Family Law Act is gender neutral and does not predispose any gender or parent as a primary care giver. The Family Law Act focuses on the rights of children and the responsibilities that each parent has towards their children, rather than on parental rights. The court will give consideration to a range of factors when determining parenting arrangements that. are in a child's best interests, including the age and developmental needs of the child.

The Family Law Act recognises that each parent has parental responsibility for a child, unless specifically displaced by a parenting· order made by a court. If a parenting matter is before a court for determination, the court must apply a presumption in favour of 'equal shared parental responsibility', unless there are reasonable grounds to believe that a parent, or a person the child lives with, has engaged in family violence or child abuse. If the court proceeds to makes orders for parents to have equal shared parental responsibility, this means that both parents have an equal role in making decisions about major long-term issues affecting the child, such as where a child goes to school or major health issues.

The presumption of equal shared parental responsibility was a key feature of significant reforms to the family law system in 2006. In its response to the Australian Law Reform Commission's report, Family Law for the Future -An inquiry into the family law system (ALRC Report), the Government reaffirmed its commitment to the policy underlying the presumption, which is that children will generally benefit from both parents being involved in making important decisions affecting their lives post-separation, provided this is safe and consistent with their best interests.

Equal shared parental responsibility does not mean spending equal time with a child. Parents will only spend equal time with a child where they can agree to this outcome, or where a court finds that equal time is in the best interests of the child and reasonably practicable in the circumstances. Where parents have equal shared parental responsibility, the court must consider whether it is appropriate and reasonably practicable for the child to spend equal time with both parents. If it is not, the court must consider whether 'substantial and significant time' (including day-to-day routine—not just weekends or holidays) is in the best interests of the child and reasonably practicable. In its response to the ALRC Report, the Government also reaffirmed that it continues to suppo1i such a requirement that courts appropriately consider children spending equal time, or substantial and significant time, with each parent where an order for shared parental responsibility has been made.

I acknowledge that going through family law proceedings is a difficult experience and it is common for people to require professional support. As this petition raises the mental health impact of post separation care arrangements of children on men in particular, I note that the Australian Government funds Mensline Australia, a service which provides online counselling, info1mation and referrals. Mensline Australia is available to men, partners and families who are interested in learning more about how to access personal support or to support the men in their life. Information and support is also available through non-profit organisations such as Lifeline and Beyond Blue.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Charitable Organisations
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN2948, originally directed to the Treasurer, which requests churches of all denominations pay tax on the basis they are run as businesses. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

There is no general provision in Commonwealth tax legislation that exempts churches or other religious bodies from taxation. However, an entity registered with the Australian Charities and Not-for-profits Commission (ACNC) as a charity is eligible for tax concessions, including an exemption from income tax.

To become registered with the ACNC an organisation must be a charity which includes having only charitable purposes. Charitable purpose has a legal meaning, developed over 400 years by firstly, the United Kingdom, and later Australian, courts and Parliament. The courts have recognised many different charitable purposes, and as society changes new charitable purposes have been recognised. The Charities Act 2013, which defines what is a charity, recognises twelve such purposes.

One of the charitable purposes listed under the Charities Act is the purpose of advancing religion. Religion has been accepted as a charitable purpose since the 1600s and the current Charities Act is based on this substantial body of case law. Comparable international jurisdictions, including the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada and New Zealand also consider religion a charitable purpose that benefits the community.

This means that organisations with the purpose of advancing religion are eligible for registration with the ACNC provided they meet all the eligibility criteria. Likewise, registered religious charities may apply in the same way as all other charities to access charitable tax concessions, including the income tax exemption, provided they meet all the eligibility criteria. Organisations with the purpose of advancing religion have the same registration requirements as organisations that have one of many other charitable purposes. The test for charitable purpose is not specifically a religious one.

Importantly, registration with the ACNC requires an entity to operate on a not-for-profit basis. This means the assets and income of the entity are used only for the purposes for which the entity is established and not for the private benefit of the members of the entity. This is the core difference with a taxable for-profit business that operates for the private gain of its owners. A church that does not meet the not-for-profit test is not eligible for registration as a charity and is not exempt from income tax.

I note that charities can engage in commercial activities provided this is ancillary to, and in furtherance of, their charitable purposes rather than for private gain. An example is running a shop whose operating surplus is used to fund the activities of the charity.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar

Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Statistics
Dear Chair
1 refer to your correspondence of 19 October 2021 concerning Petition EN2966 asking the House to compel government and media sources to provide accurate data on COVID-19 related deaths.

I appreciate that the petitioners are concerned about the reporting of deaths in people who have contracted COVID-19 or received a COVID-19 vaccine. However, aspects of the request are not within the remit of my Department, including how state and territory governments and the media report COVID-19 deaths.
I will address the petitioners' concerns about reporting of vaccine-related deaths.
The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), which is part of my Department, is responsible for safety monitoring and reporting of adverse events following vaccination, including deaths.
The TGA has a well-established and robust system in place to capture reports of suspected adverse events for all vaccines. Many of these processes have been enhanced dramatically
for COVID-19 vaccines, making this the most intense safety monitoring of therapeutic goods ever conducted in Australia.

The TGA encourages people to report suspected vaccine adverse events, even if there is only a small chance that the vaccine caused them. This helps the TGA to identify signals (patterns or signs in the data) which may reveal potential safety issues. The TGA undertakes investigations of signals to assess whether the vaccine is causing certain types of adverse events.

In addition, the TGA reviews all deaths reported in people post-administration of a COVID-19 vaccine. Their analysis of individual reports and patterns of reporting does not suggest that the vaccines played a causal role in the vast majority of these cases.

Sadly, more than 3,000 people die in Australia every week. We are vaccinating almost an entire population, including people who are elderly and at risk of severe disease. It is inevitable that there will be people who experience a serious health issue or die in the days following vaccination for various reasons. These reasons will often be unrelated to vaccination.

The TGA reports on deaths related to COVID-19 vaccines transparently and accurately. Each week, they report on the COVID-19 vaccine safety monitoring at: www.tga.gov.au/periodic/covid-19-vaccine-weekly-safety-report.
This report includes details on the number of deaths reported to the TGA, as well as the outcomes of their assessment of those reports.

Since the beginning of the vaccine rollout to 24 October 2021, approximately 34.4 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines have been given. So far, the TGA has found nine reports of death which were linked to immunisation from 629 reports received and reviewed.

I assure you that, if the TGA suspects there is a safety issue with a COVID-19 vaccine, it will immediately conduct a thorough investigation. If the safety concern is confirmed, the TGA will respond appropriately, including communication to the Australian public.
Importantly, the latest worldwide safety data continues to show that the benefits of vaccination far outweigh the risks of the adverse effects caused by the vaccines.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition number EN2973 requesting transparency of vaccine safety information and choice of vaccines.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death. At the same time, the Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Everyone maintains the option to choose.

As the COVID-19 pandemic is a public-health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. Some states and territories have now issued public-health orders which require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there should be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical and other reasons. Further information about these public-health orders may be found on state or territory government websites.

The Government is working closely with the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisations and all state and territory health departments to ensure that monitoring of COVID-19 vaccine safety is of the highest possible standard in Australia.

The TGA formally assesses the safety, quality and efficacy of vaccines, prior to their approval for use in Australia. All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large clinical trials on thousands of people.

Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and/or disease. All COVID-19 vaccines used in the rollout have been granted provisional approval following a complete assessment of all this available data.

The TGA is open and transparent about safety information relating to COVID-19 vaccines, including any suspected side effects or potential safety issues. The TGA publishes a weekly safety report, including information about reported suspected side effects, as well as other safety alerts as required. More information can be found at: www.tga.gov.au using the search terms 'COVID-19-vaccine safety monitoring and reporting'.

The goal is to protect all people in Australia from the harm caused COVID-19 infection. The Pfizer, AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria) and Moderna vaccines have all been proven through approval and safety monitoring processes to be very effective at reducing severe illness, hospitalisation and death.

As a means of increasing choice of vaccines available in Australia, the Government has invested in a diverse portfolio of COVID-19 vaccines that use a variety of technical platforms, entering into five separate Advance Purchase Agreements for the supply of COVID-19 vaccines, if they prove to be safe and effective. These include agreements with Pfizer, AstraZeneca, Novavax, Moderna and the international COVAX. Combined, these agreements will ensure Australia has access to more than 280 million vaccine doses.

Currently the Pfizer, AstraZeneca and Moderna vaccines are being used in the rollout, while the TGA has granted the Novavax COVID-19 vaccine a provisional determination and the vaccine is currently under evaluation. Although it is not yet approved for use in Australia or elsewhere in the world, the evaluation of Novavax is being significantly expedited without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality and efficacy. Should the Novavax vaccine candidate be found to be safe and effective, it is expected the 51 million ordered doses will begin rollout as early as December 2021.

The Government continues to meet regularly with a range of COVID-19 vaccine developers and manufacturers. The nature of these discussions is commercial-in-confidence but considers the likely timing of supply, cost and recommendations from Government medical experts. To keep up-to-date with COVID-19 vaccines under evaluation, please visit: www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccines-undergoing-evaluation.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition number EN2988 requesting cancellation of the human biosecurity emergency period.

Emergency measures have been necessary to manage the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. With more than 4.9 million deaths globally in around 22 months, Australia's strong and decisive response has put Australia in a very fortunate position compared to so many other countries across the world.

In declaring the human biosecurity emergency period under section 475 of the Biosecurity Act 2015 (Act), Australia acted decisively to address a risk assessed under the Act as posing a severe and immediate threat to human health on a nationally significant scale.
The declaration of the emergency period enabled specific determinations to be made relating to key areas including:
mandatory pre-departure testing and mask wearing for international flights
restrictions on the entry of cruise vessels within Australian territory
restrictions on outbound international travel for Australians
restrictions on trade of retail outlets at international airports.

As a result of these and other measures implemented by states and territories, Australia has not experienced the widespread rates of infection, hospitalisation and deaths seen in many other countries.

Extensions of the emergency period have been informed by specialist medical and epidemiological advice provided by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee and the Commonwealth Chief Medical Officer.

The human biosecurity emergency period is due to lapse on 17 December 2021. Under section 476 of the Act, the emergency period can be extended for a further three months should the public health evidence support such a decision.

The Australian Government has not yet made any decision about whether the period will be extended again. The Government is continuing to closely monitor the evolving evidence relevant to the assessment of public health risk, including the impact of measures such as the vaccine rollout. A decision will be announced in due course.
It is important to note that state and territory governments have primary operational responsibility for emergency management and public health in their respective jurisdictions.

In the event that the human biosecurity emergency period is not extended the Commonwealth determinations will lapse, but states and territories will continue to have discretion to implement public health measures under their own legislation.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN2995 calling on the Government to hold a referendum to determine if the COVID-19 vaccine is safe.

The Australian Government wants everyone in Australia to have access to a safe, free, COVID- 19 vaccine, if they choose to be vaccinated. The safety of the population has always been the highest priority of the Government. For these reasons, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI).

The Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.
At the same time, the Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Everyone maintains the option to choose.

However, the Government has made it mandatory for those working in residential aged care to receive a COVID-19 vaccination, which was advised by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) and accepted by National Cabinet. This is enforced through state and territory public-health orders, effective 17 September 2021.

As the COVID-19 pandemic is a public-health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. In line with this, some states and territories have now issued public-health orders that require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Further information about public-health orders may be found on state or territory government websites.

Some employers have also started to mandate vaccinations for their employees. For individual businesses not covered by a public-health order, whether to require COVID-19 vaccinations for employees needs careful consideration, considering the relevant employment, discrimination, work health and safety, and privacy laws, and the circumstances of the particular workplace.
The Government encourages employers and employees to work together on workplace vaccination for COVID-19.

In addition, the Government understands that some businesses are considering whether to require vaccination as a condition of service or entry. Businesses do have the right to make any service they provide subject to conditions and can impose restrictions on who can enter their premises. However, anti-discrimination issues may arise where people are unable to be vaccinated, and privacy laws restrict the collection of sensitive information. In each case, businesses need to consider their legal obligations, and determine what is right for their business.
Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there should be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical and other reasons.

The Government has not taken any decision on whether an individual's vaccination status will facilitate changes to current public-health measures. States and territories may consider the potential future value of COVID-19 digital certificates when considering automatic travel exemptions for interstate travel during state-determined lockdowns and travel restrictions.

Australians can already provide voluntary proof of vaccination by accessing their immunisation history statement through Medicare Online, via the Express Plus Medicare mobile app or via their My Health Record. People can seek a hard copy of their immunisation history statement by contacting the Australian Immunisation enquiries line, or through their doctor or immunisation provider.

The Government, through Services Australia and my Department, has also developed a safe and secure COVID-19 Digital Certificate, which may help Australians provide proof of vaccination if it were required. The certificate is already available through the Medicare Express app for those who wish to use it.

Before a prescription medicine (including a COVID-19 vaccine) can be legally supplied in Australia, it must be approved for use by the TGA and it will be subject to well-established and rigorous assessment and approval process of the TGA to determine if the benefits outweigh the risks.

The TOA is also part of a network of international regulators that meet regularly to discuss the development ofCOVID-19 vaccines. This information, together with the potential to use already established work-sharing arrangements and collaboration with other international regulators, is assisting the TGA to expedite the evaluation of any new vaccines without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality, and effectiveness.

The Government also continues to meet regularly with a range of COVID-19 vaccine and treatment developers and manufacturers, and continues to monitor ongoing clinical trials and review real world effectiveness of vaccine rollouts globally. There are more than 400 trials for 140 vaccine candidates worldwide, including a number that are trialling the use of needle-free technology. These include nasal sprays, oral tablets, skin patches and jet injectors.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
