Some employers have also started to mandate vaccinations for their employees. For individual businesses not covered by a public-health order, whether to require COVID-19 vaccinations for employees needs careful consideration, taking into account the relevant employment, discrimination, work health and safety, and privacy laws, and the circumstances of the particular workplace. The Government encourages employers and employees to work together on workplace vaccination for COVID-19.
Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there should be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical and other reasons.

On 6 August 2021, National Cabinet agreed to a National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID response to a post-vaccination setting focused on prevention of serious illness, hospitalisation and fatality, similar to the public-health management of other infectious diseases. More information on the National Plan is available on the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet's website at: www.pmc.gov.au using the search terms 'national plan'.

As part of its responsibility in mitigating emerging health threats related to infectious diseases, the AHPPC has already made statements and recommendations on the topic of mandating vaccines for several professions or work types. These can be found at: www.health.gov.au using the search term 'Australia Health Protection Principal Committee'.

Before a COVID-I9·vaccine can be legally supplied in Australia, it must be approved for use by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) and it will be subject to well-established and rigorous assessment and approval process to determine if the benefits outweigh the risks. The TGA's vaccine safety monitoring system can rapidly detect, investigate and respond to any emerging safety issues identified for COVID-19 vaccines.

The Pfizer, AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria) and Moderna vaccines have all been proven through the TGA approval and safety monitoring processes to be very effective at reducing severe illness, hospitalisation and death.

As the safety of the Australian population remains the highest priority of the Government during the rollout, decisions regarding COVID-19 vaccines will continue to be guided by expert medical advice of groups such as the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation, TGA and AHPPC.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the rollout please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Gun Control
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 18 October 2021 regarding Petition EN3011, which requests a referendum to alter the Constitution to include a right for citizens to 'bear arms of any caliber or type' without a permit or background check. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition.

In Australia, responsibility for firearms matters is shared between the Commonwealth and state and territory governments. The Commonwealth Government is responsible only for matters relating to the import and export of firearms, while the state and territory governments have responsibility for all matters relating to possession, licensing and use of firearms. Any issues relating to the possession and licensing of firearms are therefore principally a matter for the relevant state or territory government.

So far as constitutional change is concerned, section 128 of the Constitution generally requires any proposed change to be approved by both houses of Parliament and by double majorities of electors (a majority overall and majorities in at least 4 of the 6 states). This mechanism ensures that only those referendum proposals with very widespread support can succeed.
The Government is not proposing any constitutional amendment involving the possession or use of firearms.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
COVID-19: Income Support Payments
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN3015 on reinstating the JobKeeper Payment and other financial supplements. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The JobKeeper Payment was always intended to be a temporary program designed to deliver support quickly and at scale. JobKeeper was just one part of the Government's economic response plan to support Australians during the pandemic.

The most recent funding package of up to $2.27 billion announced on 30 September 2021 on a 50/50 cost share basis between the Commonwealth and Victorian governments will support businesses most affected by restrictions as Victoria reaches the 70 per cent, then 80 per cent fully vaccinated thresholds on the state's Roadmap to Deliver the National Plan. With final payments being made 13 November 2021.

National Cabinet's Plan to Transition Australia's COVID-19 Response provides a graduated pathway to transition Australia's COVID-19 response from pre-vaccination settings, focused on continued suppression of community transmission, to post-vaccination settings focused on public health management consistent with other infectious diseases. We are encouraged by Victoria releasing their reopening roadmap in line with the plan agreed at National Cabinet.
Further detail on measures included as part of each jurisdictions' roadmap can be found by visiting the following website: www.premier.vic.gov.au/victorias-roadmap-delivering-national-plan.

The SME Recovery Loan Scheme is also supporting SMEs by increasing lenders' ability to provide cheaper credit, allowing many eligible SMEs to access additional funding to get through the impact of Coronavirus, recover and invest for the future. Until 31 December 2021, the Scheme is supporting loans to eligible SMEs on an unsecured or secured basis (excluding residential property), with an 80 per cent Government Guarantee, a maximum loan size of $5 million and a maximum loan term of up to ten years. The Scheme will allow lenders to offer a repayment holiday up to 24 months and will permit borrowers to refinance existing loans. While interest rates will be capped at 7.5 per cent, loan rates will be determined by lenders.

On 25 August, the Government announced that it would remove requirements for SMEs to have received JobKeeper during the March quarter of 2021 or to have been a flood affected business in order to be eligible under the SME Recovery Loan Scheme. Other criteria, including business turnover, guarantee coverage and closing date for the scheme date, remain unchanged. Lenders can continue to write loans under the existing JobKeeper and Flood Affected criteria until the changes come into effect.
For further information on the SME Recovery Loan Scheme visit: www.treasury.gov.au/coronavirus/sme-guarantee-scheme
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition number EN3023 Stop unlawfully mandating COVID vaccines in aged care, healthcare, & other industries.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective way to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.
The Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Everyone maintains the option to choose.

Recognising the far greater risk that COVID-19 presents to older Australians, the Government has made it mandatory for those working in residential aged care to receive a COVID-19 vaccination, which was advised by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee and accepted by the National Cabinet. This is enforced through state and territory public health orders, effective 17 September 2021.

As the COVID-19 pandemic is a public-health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, have implemented a range of measures using their own public-health and emergency-management legislation to contain the spread of COVID-19 and keep the community safe. In line with this, some states and territories have now issued public-health orders that require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities.
Some employers have also mandated COVID-19 vaccinations for their employees. Workplace health and safety is a matter for individual employers and employees.

Under model work health safety laws, employers are required to manage risks of viral exposure and infection, and persons at a workplace are required to comply, so far as they are reasonably able, with any reasonable instruction in that regard. Whether to require COVID- 19 vaccinations for employees needs careful consideration, considering the relevant employment, discrimination, work health and safety, and privacy laws, and the circumstances of the workplace. The Government encourages employers and employees to work together on workplace vaccination for COVID-19.
Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory in any setting, there should be exemptions in place for those unable to be vaccinated for medical and other reasons.

Some individuals may not be able to receive a COVID-19 vaccination due to a medical condition, or where their health, age or disability mean that the benefits of the vaccination do not outweigh the risk of adverse events. Additionally, some age cohorts may not yet have been able to receive the COVID-19 vaccine. Mandatory COVID-19 vaccination requirements that apply to everyone may indirectly discriminate against these cohorts. Indirect discrimination is not unlawful if it is reasonable in all the circumstances. Implications for Australia's anti-discrimination laws should be considered when mandating COVID-19 vaccinations without exemptions.

The Australian Human Rights Commission has published guidance on discrimination law considerations in relation to COVID-19 vaccine mandates, which is available via: www.humanrights.gov.au/about/covid19-and-human-rights/.

The Government takes its obligations under international human rights law seriously and implements those obligations in good faith. The Government considers that the measures it has adopted in response to COVID-19 are consistent with international human rights law.

Informed consent should be obtained for every COVID-19 vaccination, as per usual consent procedures for other vaccinations. To this end, the Government has made expert health advice from the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI) available to assist people with their decision-making, which is available at: www.health.gov.au/resources/collections/covid-19-vaccination-patient-resources.

The Government also continues to provide a wide range of guidance material to the public on COVID-19 vaccines and legal frameworks, and to encourage vaccination uptake by communicating about the safety, science, evidence, and benefits of COVID-19 vaccination.

Before any COVID-19 vaccine is approved for use in Australia, it is subject to the Therapeutic Goods Administration's (TGA) stringent assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large trials of thousands of people. These trials have shown that COVID-19 vaccines are safe and effective in preventing symptomatic COVID-19 and protecting individuals against severe illness or death associated with COVID-19.

These TGA approvals are subject to certain strict conditions, such as the requirement for sponsors to provide information to the TGA on longer-term efficacy and safety from ongoing trials and post-market assessment. More information on this TGA evaluation process can be found at: www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccines. Further, the ATAGI is closely monitoring reports of other rare adverse events following immunisation and updating their advice and recommendations as new evidence arises.

Most side effects from COVID-19 vaccinations are mild and go away in a couple of days. Serious reactions are extremely rare. The protective benefits of COVID-19 vaccination, including preventing hospitalisation and death from COVID-19, significantly outweighs any rare risks from COVID-19 vaccination.

While vaccination remains the best protection against COVID-19, the Government also continues work to ensure that Australians have early access to safe and effective treatments. Building on Australia's diverse and large portfolio of COVID-19 treatments (including remdesivir and sotrovimab) already being used to treat patients with COVID-19 across the country, the Government has recently secured access to additional COVID-19 treatments.
These promising treatments are Ronapreve, Molnupiravir, and Pfizer's COVID-19 oral antiviral drug (to be used in combination with the protease inhibitor drug ritonavir).
Anyone with questions on COVID-19 vaccination is encouraged to talk to a health professional.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN3025—Supplying AstraZeneca Vaccines to Australians/Permanent Residents stuck overseas.

Providing all Australians with access to effective COVID-19 vaccines is a key priority for the Australian Government. The rollout and distribution ofCOVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with Australia's COVID-19 Vaccine National Rollout Strategy. The rollout of the domestic Australian vaccination program does not include Australians overseas.

The Government has been closely following the situation across the world. We recognise the need to work with our neighbours and will provide support to ensure that their vaccine rollouts are safe, quick and effective and our region is able to return to normal as soon as possible and is engaged in a number of ways to enable this to occur.

Australia's five COVID-19 vaccine agreements with: Pfizer, AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria), Novavax, Moderna and COVAX Facility- allow us to support our Pacific and South East Asian neighbours, as vaccine doses can be donated or on-sold (with no mark-up) to other countries or international organisations should these vaccines prove safe and effective, and units are available above domestic needs.

Australians living overseas should consult a local health professional for advice on what vaccination choices are available locally. The Government cannot provide advice on the safety, quality or effectiveness of vaccines that have not been approved using Australia's regulatory processes. Work is underway to support the recognition of vaccines which people have received overseas.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) and the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation are working to identify the overseas vaccines currently available internationally and to assess the protection offered.

If people receive a TGA-approved COVID-19 vaccine overseas, they can register their vaccination on the Australian Immunisation Register (AIR) when they return to Australia. Currently, only COVID-19 vaccines registered for use in Australia by the TGA can be reported to the AIR.

As announced on 1 October 2021, the TOA has published its initial assessment of the data on the protection offered by the Coronavac (Sinovac) and Covishield (AstraZeneca/Serum Institute of India) vaccines and has advised that these vaccines should be considered as 'recognised vaccines' for the purpose of determining incoming international travellers as being appropriately vaccinated.

Declaring certain COVID-19 vaccines as 'recognised vaccines' is separate to a regulatory decision on whether they are approved for use for vaccination in Australia, which has not been made by the TOA.

The recognition of these two additional vaccines is a major milestone towards more Australians vaccinated overseas getting home sooner. Work is underway to permit these two vaccines to be recorded in the AIR.
The TOA will continue its assessment of other vaccines for the purpose of determining 'recognised vaccines' based on the available data and data that is provided.
The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the

Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield. Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence on 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN3026—No National Emergency Vaccinations, No Martial Law.
The Australian Government recognises that this is a challenging time for all Australians and understands the impact of these measures on individuals, families and businesses.
The Government acknowledges that many people will find that their faith or beliefs give them comfort in these difficult times.

The Constitution provides that every member of the Australian Parliament, before taking his or her seat, must make and subscribe an oath or affirmation of allegiance before the Governor-General, or some person authorised by the Governor-General. The oath is usually made on a Bible or on another holy book and ends with the words 'So help me God!'.
This is the main context in which oaths are made by members of the Parliament.

I note the petitioners are requesting that an oath rejecting COVID-19 vaccination and public-health measures be introduced to the Australian Parliament. I imagine that this request may be informed by feelings of anxiety about COVID-19 and by a desire for citizens to return to the routines they had prior to the pandemic.

The Government wants everyone in Australia to have access to a safe, free, COVID-19 vaccine, if they choose to be vaccinated. The safety of the population has always been the highest priority of the Government. For these reasons, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI).
At the same time, the Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Everyone maintains the option to choose.
The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) formally assesses the safety, quality and efficacy of medicines, including vaccines, prior to their approval for use in Australia.

All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large clinical trials on thousands of people. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease.

This involves comprehensive review of clinical trial data, non-clinical and toxicological studies, chemistry, manufacturing, quality, risk-management and other information by a large team of clinical and scientific experts. Advice is then sought from an independent expert committee before a regulatory decision is made.

All COVID-19 vaccines used in the rollout have been granted provisional approval following a complete assessment of all this available data. No part of the process has been rushed and the TGA does not have an 'Emergency Use Authorisation' pathway for COVID-19 vaccines.

The TGA is also part of a network of international regulators that meet regularly to discuss the development of COVID-19 vaccines. This information, together with the potential to use already established work-sharing arrangements and collaboration with other international regulators, is assisting the TGA to expedite the evaluation of any new vaccines without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality, and effectiveness.

As the COVID-19 pandemic is a public-health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice.

In line with this, some states and territories have now issued public-health orders that require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Further information about public-health orders may be found on state or territory government websites.

Some employers have also started to mandate vaccinations for their employees. For individual businesses not covered by a public-health order, whether to require COVID-19 vaccinations for employees needs careful consideration, considering the relevant employment, discrimination, work health and safety, and privacy laws, and the circumstances of the workplace. The Government encourages employers and employees to work together on workplace vaccination for COVID-19.

The Government has not taken any decision on whether an individual's vaccination status will facilitate changes to current public-health measures. States and territories may consider the potential future value of COVID-19 digital certificates when considering automatic travel exemptions for interstate travel during state-determined lockdowns and travel restrictions.

Australians can already provide voluntary proof of vaccination by accessing their immunisation history statement through Medicare Online, via the Express Plus Medicare mobile app or via their My Health Record. People can seek a hard copy of their immunisation history statement by contacting·the Australian Immunisation enquiries line, or through their doctor or immunisation provider.
For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021, concerning petition EN3029 No mandatory vaccine for disability workers or community service professionals.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.
At the same time, the Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Everyone maintains the option to choose.

However, the Government has made it mandatory for those working in residential aged care to receive a COVID-19 vaccination, which was advised by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) and accepted by the National Cabinet. This is enforced through state and territory public-health orders, effective 17 September 2021.

As the COVID-19 pandemic is a public-health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. In line with this, some states and territories have now issued public-health orders that require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Further information about public-health orders may be found on state or territory government websites.

Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there should be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical and other reasons. The measures set out in these public-health orders are based on expert health advice on how best to manage the disease in the local community, considering factors such as the levels of transmission.

Some employers have also started to mandate vaccinations for their employees. For individual businesses not covered by a public-health order, whether to require COVID-19 vaccinations for employees needs careful consideration, considering the relevant employment, discrimination, work health and safety, and privacy laws, and the circumstances of the workplace.
The Government encourages employers and employees to work together on workplace vaccination for COVID-19.

COVID-19 can be a very serious illness and is especially dangerous for vulnerable people in the community. Vaccination in all settings helps to protect workers, vulnerable Australians, and the broader community. Anyone subject to a public-health order must comply with the terms of that order, with significant fines possible for non-compliance.

As part of its responsibility in mitigating emerging health threats related to infectious diseases, the AHPPC has already made statements and recommendations on the topic of mandating vaccines for several professions or work types. These can be found at: www.health.gov.au using the search term 'Australia Health Protection Principal Committee'.

In their statement addressing vaccination recommendations for residential disability support workers, they noted the importance that had been placed on this population by the Government prioritising disability support workers in the early 1a and 1b phases of the rollout. Support has also been given to GPs in the form of remuneration for providing in-home vaccinations for individuals with disability. This has resulted in greater protection of both this population, their support workers and the broader community.

The Pfizer, AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria) and Moderna vaccines have all been proven through the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) approval and safety monitoring processes to be very effective at reducing severe illness, hospitalisation and death.

As the safety of the Australian population remains the highest priority of the Government during the rollout, decisions regarding COVID-19 vaccines will continue to be guided by expert medical advice of groups such as the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI), TGA and AHPPC.

On 6 August 2021, National Cabinet agreed to a National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID response to a post-vaccination setting focused on prevention of serious illness, hospitalisation and fatality, like the public-health management of other infectious diseases.
More information on the National Plan is available on the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet's website at: www.pmc.gov.au using the search term 'national plan'.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the vaccine rollout please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Statistics
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition number EN3035 requesting that the Australian Government and State Governments stop using the term 'case' for people who have tested positive for SARS CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19.

The Australian Government has coordinated an evidence-based response to the COVID-19 pandemic, informed by the latest public health advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) and its expert standing committees, including the Public Health Laboratory Network and the Communicable Diseases Network Australia (CDNA).

The CDNA has developed COVID-19 case definitions for epidemiological purposes in order to rapidly detect people infected with SARS-CoV-2, investigate the source of infection and ensure there are no unrecognised chains of transmission in the community. Case definitions are described in the Series of National Guidelines, available at: www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cdna-song-novel-coronavirus.htm.

Cases who meet the confirmed case definition are notified as COVID-19 cases to the National Interoperable Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System. It is important to note that a person can still be a confirmed case and not display any symptoms as some SARS-CoV-2 infections remain asymptomatic. All confirmed cases have potential for transmission irrespective of the presence of symptoms.

Laboratory-based Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) testing is the gold standard test used to diagnose acute COVID-19 infection. This test method is very sensitive and detects nucleic acid sequences specific to the virus. Although it is possible that a positive PCR test may occur in the absence of acute infection, the CDNA Series of National Guidelines addresses this issue by categorising infections that are historical in nature.
The Petitions Committee can be assured that the my Department, along with the states and territories, is taking an evidence-based approach to COVID-19 and is committed to keep Australians safe.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Iran
Dear Chair
Thank you for your recent email regarding petition number EN3041 on reprisals against protestors in Iran.

The human rights situation in Iran is concerning and one which the Australian Government takes seriously. Australia has been consistent in urging Iranian authorities to exercise restraint in response to protests. At the 46th session of the UN Human Rights Council in March 2021, Australia called on Iran to safeguard freedom of expression and ensure that activists did not face intimidation. On 10 August 2021 in a speech to the Senate, I publicly called on Iran to cease abuses of human rights.

On 25 October 2021, Australia made a statement to the UN General Assembly calling on Iran to improve compliance with international human rights law and uphold international standards including fair trials and due process. As co-sponsor of this year's annual UNGA Third Committee Resolution on the situation of human rights in Iran, Australia has worked with member states to ensure the resolution called on Iran to uphold the human rights of those involved in peaceful protests.
The Australian Government will continue to look for ways to join the international community in calling out Iran's troubling human rights record.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN3046, which seeks to stop the use of experimental COVID-19 vaccines in young people/students.

The Australian Government wants everyone in Australia to have access to a safe, free, COVID-19 vaccine, if they choose to be vaccinated. The safety of the population has always been the highest priority of the Government. For these reasons, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI).
The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) formally assesses the safety, quality and efficacy of medicines, including vaccines, prior to their approval for use in Australia.

All vaccines must pass the TGA' s rigorous assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large clinical trials on thousands of people. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease.

This involves a comprehensive review of clinical trial data, non-clinical and toxicological studies, chemistry, manufacturing, quality, risk management and other information by a large team of clinical and scientific experts. Advice is then sought from an independent expert committee before a regulatory decision is made.

All COVID-19 vaccines used in the rollout have been granted provisional approval following a complete assessment of all this available data. No part of the process has been rushed and the TGA does not have an 'Emergency Use Authorisation' pathway for COVID-19 vaccines.

The urgency of the global pandemic means that researchers, agencies such as the World Health Organization and governments all over the world are prioritising the development, assessment and rollout ofCOVID-19 vaccines.
There is a combination of reasons why safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines have been able to be designed, researched and made available sooner than previously seen. For example:
unprecedented levels of funding—the pandemic is a global priority and governments around the world are investing in research and manufacturing facilities

technology—the evolution of technology has allowed vaccines to be developed at a faster pace than in the past. New technologies have helped scientists understand the coronavirus and its make up much easier, which has allowed them to start working on vaccine design more quickly
combined clinical trials—in response to the pandemic, some pharmaceutical companies have combined clinical trial phases 1 and 2
expedited review process by regulatory agencies- the TGA is engaging early with pharmaceutical companies about their vaccines and is accepting rolling data.
This means that the TGA can accept, review and assess clinical-trial data as it becomes available, rather than all at once at the end of the three clinical trial phases.

All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes including clinical trials. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease.

The TGA requires robust scientific data before supporting a vaccine candidate and will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is found to be safe and effective, following its complete assessment of data.

The TGA has provisionally approved Pfizer and Moderna for use in people aged 12 years or older. In doing so, the TGA undertook an independent and rigorous assessment of the available data for the Pfizer and Moderna mRNA COVID-19 vaccines. The data provided to the TGA was comprehensive and included pre-clinical and clinical studies, non-clinical and toxicology studies, chemistry, manufacturing, risk management and other information.
All data was carefully reviewed by a large team of TGA's technical and clinical experts before provisionally approving both vaccines.

Technology using Messenger RNA (mRNA) has been in development for decades, with clinical trials in humans being conducted as early as 2011. The COVID-19 pandemic provided funding and opportunity for researchers who have been studying and working with mRNA vaccines to produce safe and effective vaccines.

The Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines use a fragment of mRNA to instruct the body to generate an immune response against COVID-19. One dose (0.3ml) of the Pfizer vaccine contains 30 micrograms of mRNA, and one dose (0.5ml) of the Moderna vaccine contains 100 micrograms of mRNA. More information concerning the ingredients ofCOVID-19 vaccines can be found in the Product Information (PI) available at: www.tga.gov.au.

Based on the naturally occurring process for protein production in our body, mRNA for COVID-19 vaccines is synthetically designed and produced, containing only a short version of the viral mRNA that encodes for the spike protein. mRNA is fragile, which is why it is combined with lipids (fats) that protect it from being degraded until after it has been delivered to the cell. The mRNA enters the muscle cells which make the spike protein, displaying it so that it is recognised by our immune system.
This allows the body's natural defences to develop immunity to the disease, so the body can rapidly create its own antibodies to prevent disease if it encounters the virus in the future.

Once it has provided the instructions for the spike protein, the mRNA is broken down quickly by the body. It never enters the nucleus and cannot affect or combine with our DNA in any way to change our genetic code or the body's cells. Real world data collated and analysed as part of the global rollout have shown that the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are highly effective and safe vaccines.

The TGA is also part of a network of international regulators that meet regularly to discuss the development ofCOVID-19 vaccines. This information, together with the potential to use already established work-sharing arrangements and collaboration with other international regulators, is assisting the TGA to expedite the evaluation of any new vaccines without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality and effectiveness.

The Government also continues to meet regularly with a range of COVID-19 vaccine and treatment developers and manufacturers and continues to monitor ongoing clinical trials and review real world effectiveness of vaccine rollouts globally.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN3049 for access to the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine for over 60s.
As the Australian Government continues to expand and accelerate the vaccine rollout, it is taking seriously the issue of ensuring all Australians have the opportunity to be vaccinated.

From 1 October 2021, all Australians aged 12 years and over, including those Australians aged 60 years and over, are now eligible to receive a Pfizer or Moderna COVID-19 vaccine. This means older Australians can now choose the Pfizer, Moderna, or AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria) vaccine.

There are now almost 10,000 sites where individuals can get a vaccine, and by mid-October 2021 we will have enough vaccine in the country for everyone who is eligible to be double-dosed. In addition, thousands of pharmacies are now active, providing a great opportunity for those aged 60 years and over, and their families, who will now be able to walk into their community pharmacy and have all family members aged 12 years and over vaccinated.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN3062 for the vaccination of all Australians including children under 16 years before relaxing restrictions.

The Australian Government wants everyone in Australia to have access to a safe, free, COVID-19 vaccine, if they choose to be vaccinated. Moreover, the safety of the population has always been the highest priority of the Government. For these reasons, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI).

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) formally assesses the safety, quality and efficacy of medicines, including vaccines, prior to their approval for use in Australia. All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large clinical trials on thousands of people. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease.

This involves comprehensive review of clinical trial data, non-clinical and toxicological studies, chemistry, manufacturing, quality, risk management and other information by a large team of clinical and scientific experts. Advice is then sought from an independent expert committee before a regulatory decision is made.
Australia's health product regulator, the TGA, has provisionally approved Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines for use in people aged 12 years and over.

Following this, the ATAGI has reviewed available data on the safety and efficacy of the Pfizer and Moderna vaccine in children aged 12 to 15 years, the risk of COVID 19 in this age group, and evidence of wider benefits and risks of vaccinating children.
ATAGI has also reviewed available evidence on specific medical conditions in children that have been identified to be associated with an increased risk of severe COVID-19.

However, the AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria) and Janssen (Johnson & Johnson) vaccines-the other COVID-19 vaccines provisionally approved for use in Australia-are not currently registered or recommended in Australia for use in children under 18 years. This is because, at this stage, there are limited clinical trial results showing that they are effective and safe in these age groups.

There is currently no evidence to suggest that children will not be able to receive these particular vaccines in the future. Guidance will be revised when evidence on the efficacy and safety of children receiving these COVID-19 vaccines becomes available.

On 20 September 2021 Pfizer and BioNTech announced top-line results from a Phase 2/3 trial for their mRNA COVID-19 vaccine Pfizer in participants aged 5 to 11 years. The results are the first from a pivotal trial (typically a Phase 3 clinical trial) of any COVID-19 vaccine in children under 12 years of age. In participants 5 to 11 years of age, the vaccine was safe, well-tolerated and showed robust neutralising antibody response, demonstrating a strong immune response one month after the second dose.

Companies plan to submit this data to the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), European Medicines Agency and other regulatory agencies around the world as soon as possible. Submission for full FDA approval is expected as they continue to accumulate the required safety and efficacy data under the existing 'Emergency Use Authorisation' (EUA) in this age group.
Pfizer and BioNTech plan to submit data from the full Phase 3 trial for scientific peer-reviewed publication. Results in children under 5 years of age are expected in late 2021.

All COVID-19 vaccines used in the rollout have been granted provisional approval following a complete assessment of all this available data. No part of the process has been rushed and the TGA does not have an 'EUA' pathway for COVID-19 vaccines.

The TGA is also part of a network of international regulators that meet regularly to discuss the development of COVID-19 vaccines. This information, together with the potential to use already established work-sharing arrangements and collaboration with other international regulators, is assisting the TGA to expedite the evaluation of any new vaccines without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality, and effectiveness.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition EN3070—Stop use of experimental COVID19 vaccines in young people/students.

The Australian Government wants everyone in Australia to have access to a safe, free, COVID-19 vaccine, if they choose to be vaccinated. Moreover, the safety of the population has always been the highest priority of the Government. For these reasons, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation.
The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) formally assesses the safety, quality and efficacy of medicines, including vaccines, prior to their approval for use in Australia.

All vaccines must pass the TGA' s rigorous assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large clinical trials on thousands of people. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease.

This involves comprehensive review of clinical trial data, non-clinical and toxicological studies, chemistry, manufacturing, quality, risk-management and other information by a large team of clinical and scientific experts. Advice is then sought from an independent expert committee before a regulatory decision is made.

All COVID-19 vaccines used in the rollout have been granted provisional approval following a complete assessment of all this available data. No part of the process has been rushed and the TGA does not have an 'Emergency Use Authorisation' pathway for COVID-19 vaccines.

The urgency of the global pandemic means that researchers, agencies such as the World Health Organization and governments all over the world are prioritising the development, assessment and rollout ofCOVID-19 vaccines.
There is a combination of reasons why safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines have been able to be designed, researched and made available sooner than previously seen. For example:
unprecedented levels of funding-the pandemic is a global priority and governments around the world are investing in research and manufacturing facilities

technology-the evolution of technology has allowed vaccines to be developed at a faster pace than in the past. New technologies have helped scientists understand the coronavirus and its make-up more easily, which has allowed them to start working on vaccine design more quickly
combined clinical trials-in response to the pandemic, some pharmaceutical companies have combined clinical trial phases 1 and 2
expedited review process by regulatory agencies-the TGA is engaging early with pharmaceutical companies about their vaccines and is accepting rolling data.
This means that the TGA can accept, review and assess clinical trial data as it becomes available, rather than all at once at the end of the three clinical trial phases.

All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes including clinical trials. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease.

The TGA requires robust scientific data before supporting a vaccine candidate and will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is found to be safe and effective, following its complete assessment of data.
Participation in clinical trials is a voluntary process with terms and conditions to which participants agree. Importantly:
The Australian Government is not involved in setting these terms and conditions
This is a contractual matter between individuals and clinical trial sponsoring companies.

The Australian Immunisation Handbook (Handbook) has information about 'valid consent', including criteria for consent to be legally valid. The Handbook states that, in general, a parent or legal guardian of a child has the authority to consent to that child being vaccinated. Some Australian states and territories have legislation that addresses the issue of a child's consent to medical treatment.

The common law applies in the states and territories that do not have specific legislation relating to children's consent to medical treatment. This common-law position is often referred to as Mature Minor or Gillick competence.

For certain procedures, including vaccination, a child or adolescent may be determined to be mature enough to understand the proposed procedure, and the risks and benefits associated with it. These young people may have the capacity to consent under certain circumstances.

The TGA has provisionally approved the Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines for use in people aged 12 years or older. In doing so, the TGA undertook an independent and rigorous assessment of the available data for the Pfizer and Moderna mRNA COVID-19 vaccines.

The data provided to the TGA was comprehensive and included pre-clinical and clinical studies, non-clinical and toxicology studies, chemistry, manufacturing, risk-management and other information. All data was carefully reviewed by a large team of TGA's technical and clinical experts before provisionally approving both vaccines.

The TGA is also part of a network of international regulators that meet regularly to discuss the development of COVID-19 vaccines. This information, together with the potential to use already established work-sharing arrangements and collaboration with other international regulators, is assisting the TGA to expedite the evaluation of any new vaccines without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality, and effectiveness.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN3073—Stop discrimination of Australians not taking the experimental COVID19 vaccine.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.
At the same time, the Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Everyone maintains the option to choose.

However, the Government has made it mandatory for those working in residential aged care to receive a COVID-19 vaccination, which was advised by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) and accepted by the National Cabinet. This is enforced through state and territory public-health orders, effective 17 September 2021.

As the COVID-19 pandemic is a public-health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. In line with this, some states and territories have now issued public-health orders which require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Further information about public-health orders may be found on state or territory government websites.
Some employers have also started to mandate vaccinations for their employees.

For individual businesses not covered by a public-health order, whether to require COVID-19 vaccinations for employees needs careful consideration, considering the relevant employment, discrimination, work health and safety, and privacy laws, and the circumstances of the workplace. The Government encourages employers and employees to work together on workplace vaccination for COVID-19.

In addition, the Government understands that some businesses are considering whether to require vaccination as a condition of service or entry. Businesses do have the right to make any service they provide subject to conditions and can impose restrictions on who can enter their premises.

However, anti-discrimination issues may arise where people are unable to be vaccinated, and privacy laws restrict the collection of sensitive information. In each case, businesses need to consider their legal obligations, and determine what is right for their business.
Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there should be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical and other reasons.

COVID-19 can be a very serious illness and is especially dangerous for vulnerable people in the community. Vaccination in settings such as aged care and health care helps to protect workers, vulnerable Australians, and the community. Anyone subject to a public-health order must comply with the terms of that order, with significant fines possible for non-compliance.

On 6 August 2021, National Cabinet agreed to a National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID-19 response to a post-vaccination setting focused on prevention of serious illness, hospitalisation and death, similar to the public-health management of other infectious diseases. More information on the National Plan is available on the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet's website at: www.pmc.gov.au using the search term 'national plan'.

As part of its responsibility in mitigating emerging health threats related to infectious diseases, the AHPPC has already made statements and recommendations on the topic of mandating vaccines for several professions or work types. These can be found at: www.health.gov.au using the search terms 'Australia Health Protection Principal Committee'.

The Government continues to provide guidance to businesses on vaccination matters to encourage uptake within the community. There is a wide range of guidance material available to clarify the legal framework around workplace vaccination and help businesses and workers make informed decisions. Various perspectives on the topic can be found on the Fair Work Ombudsman, Safe Work Australia, Office of the Australian Information Commissioner and Australian Human Rights Commission websites.

Before a COVID-19 vaccine can be legally supplied in Australia, it must be approved for use by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) and it will be subject to well-established and rigorous assessment and approval process to determine if the benefits outweigh the risks. The TGA's vaccine safety monitoring system can rapidly detect, investigate and respond to any emerging safety issues identified for COVID-19 vaccines.

The Pfizer, AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria) and Moderna vaccines have all been-proven through the TGA approval and safety monitoring processes to be very effective at reducing severe illness, hospitalisation and death.

As the safety of the Australian population remains the highest priority of the Government during the rollout, decisions regarding COVID-19 vaccines will continue to be guided by expert medical advice of groups such as the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI), TGA and AHPPC.
For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Maternal Health
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 19 October 2021 concerning petition number EN3080, requesting compassionate travel exemptions to facilitate perinatal support by grandparents and increased funding for perinatal services to ameliorate the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The Australian Government recently announced changes to international travel exemptions that will make it possible for overseas parents of Australian citizens and permanent residents to apply for an exemption to travel to Australia.

From 1 November 2021, the definition of 'immediate family member' will be broadened to include the parents of adult Australian citizens and permanent residents. This will make it possible for the parents of new and expecting parents to travel to Australia and provide support of the kind described in the petition. The broadened definition will include biological parents, legal (including adoptive) parents, step parents and parents-in-law. The new arrangements including requirements travellers would need to meet, are described on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: www.covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/immediate-family-australian-citizens-or-permanent-residents-or-new-zealand-citizens-usually-resident-australia.

For new or expecting parents seeking the support of their parents from elsewhere within Australia, where state-determined domestic border restrictions are in place, exemptions from those restrictions will continue to be a matter for the relevant state and territory governments, as would any quarantine requirements. State and territory governments remain responsible for emergency management and public health in their respective jurisdictions, under their own public health legislation.

The Government acknowledges the mental health impact both the COVID-19 pandemic and the measures needed to contain it have had on a wide range of individuals and communities including new and expecting parents. The Government recognised these severe impacts early in the pandemic and announced a range of emergency response measures to support the mental health and wellbeing of all Australians during this pandemic.

A number of services were introduced or scaled up to support early intervention among vulnerable groups, including new and expecting parents, Indigenous cohorts, older Australians and young people. Increased funding was provided for Perinatal Anxiety and Depression Australia to bolster its free helpline (1300 726 306) and to produce new toolkits and resources to support expecting and new parents cope with increased stress and anxiety.

Telehealth services were expanded to ensure that Australians can continue to access their mental health treatment services by videoconferencing or telephone. A targeted mental health communications campaign was undertaken to keep the conversation going about mental health as the full impacts of the pandemic emerged.
The resources provided on the Government's digital mental health gateway Head to Health were also expanded, giving people access to trusted mental health information and services.

Additionally, the Government in partnership with Beyond Blue established the Coronavirus Mental Wellbeing Support Service, a dedicated 24/7 phone counselling service led by Beyond Blue and staffed by accredited mental health professionals, specifically tailored to help people experiencing stress or anxiety associated with the impacts of the pandemic, such as health concerns, employment changes, business closures and family pressures.
The Government understands that no Australian has been untouched by the pandemic and continues to work closely with the mental health sector to monitor and respond to emerging mental health needs.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021, concerning petition EN3083 calling on the Australian Government to stop the rollout of COVID-19 vaccines.

The Government wants everyone in Australia to have access to a safe, free, COVID-19 vaccine, if they choose to be vaccinated. Moreover, the safety of the population has always been the highest priority of the Government. For these reasons, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation.
The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) formally assesses the safety, quality and efficacy of medicines, including vaccines, prior to their approval for use in Australia.

All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large clinical trials on thousands of people. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease.

This involves comprehensive review of clinical trial data, non-clinical and toxicological studies, chemistry, manufacturing, quality, risk management and other information by a large team of clinical and scientific experts. Advice is then sought from an independent expert committee before a regulatory decision is made.

All COVID-19 vaccines used in the rollout have been granted provisional approval following a complete assessment of all this available data. No part of the process has been rushed and the TGA does not have an 'Emergency Use Authorisation' pathway for COVID-19 vaccines.

The urgency of the global pandemic means that researchers, agencies such as the World Health Organization and governments all over the world are prioritising the development, assessment and rollout ofCOVID-19 vaccines.
There is a combination of reasons why safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines have been able to be designed, researched and made available sooner than previously seen. For example:
unprecedented levels of funding-the pandemic is a global priority and governments around the world are investing in research and manufacturing facilities

technology-the evolution of technology has allowed vaccines to be developed at a faster pace than in the past. New technologies have helped scientists understand the coronavirus and its make-up more easily, which has allowed them to start working on vaccine design more quickly
combined clinical trials-in response to the pandemic, some pharmaceutical companies have combined clinical trial phases 1 and 2

expedited review process by regulatory agencies-the TGA is engaging early with pharmaceutical companies about their vaccines and is accepting rolling data. This means that the TGA can accept, review and assess clinical trial data as it becomes available, rather than all at once at the end of the three clinical trial phases.

All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes including clinical trials. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease.

The TGA requires robust scientific data before supporting a vaccine candidate and will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is found to be safe and effective, following its complete assessment of data.

In relation to your concern about vaccination of pregnant women, global evidence shows that the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are safe for pregnant women. There is no evidence of increased risk of miscarriage or teratogenic risk. Pregnant women were not included in the first clinical trials for COVID-19 vaccines, so there was limited evidence confirming the safety of COVID-19 vaccines during pregnancy. This meant the initial advice from immunisation expert groups was cautious. But over time, 'real-world' evidence from other countries grew and showed that Pfizer and Moderna are safe to use in pregnancy.

The TGA is part of a network of international regulators that meet regularly to discuss the development of COVID-19 vaccines. This information, together with the potential to use already established work-sharing arrangements and collaboration with other international regulators, is assisting the TGA to expedite the evaluation of any new vaccines without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality, and effectiveness.

The Government also continues to meet regularly with a range of COVID-19 vaccine and treatment developers and manufacturers and continues to monitor ongoing clinical trials and review real world effectiveness of vaccine rollouts globally. There are more than 400 trials for 140 vaccine candidates worldwide, including a number that are trialling the use of needle-free technology. These include nasal sprays, oral tablets, skin patches and jet injectors.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
