from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Economy
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN3086—The Australian Government pass law reforms to prevent digital currency as being the only choice. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Australian banknotes are legal tender under the Reserve Bank Act (1959), and coins are legal tender for payment of certain amounts defined in the Currency Act (1965). However, while Australian banknotes and coins have legal tender status, a refusal to accept legal tender banknotes and/or coins is not unlawful. This means a business is free to make a commercial decision to refuse certain types of payment, regardless of whether this is legal tender such as notes and coins or another payment method such as cheque or credit card.

Providers of goods and services are able to specify what forms of payment they will accept prior to entering into a transaction. If a provider specifies other means of payment prior to the transaction, then there is no obligation for legal tender banknotes or coins to be accepted as payment. The recent trend towards cashless payments is the result of consumers and businesses choosing the payment method that works best for them, with an increasing number preferring the convenience, security and versatility of cashless payment methods.

The Government is aware that cashless payment methods are not suitable for everyone and there are no plans to force Australia to become a cashless society. The Government continues to monitor developments in the payment system to ensure it remains accessible for all Australians.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Research and Development
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning Petition number EN3088 requesting the banning of gain of function research.

'Gain of function' is a term used to describe a change to the genome of any organism (such as an animal, insect, plant, virus, bacterium or fungus) through any process that causes it to acquire a new function. Gain of function research involves a broad range of fundamental experimental techniques that have been used for decades in life sciences research. Gain of function research has led to new knowledge that benefits human health—for example, new knowledge about processes underlying human and animal health and disease, and about how pathogens spread, infect and cause disease. Gain of function research has also led to the development of new pharmaceuticals and vaccines, precision medicine and gene therapies.

Most gain of function research does not raise concerns. However, a small subset of gain of function experiments can raise concerns because of their potential to increase the danger posed to humans by an infectious agent, such as a virus. There are strong regulatory controls in Australia for all research, including gain of function research. These controls include ethics and biosafety approvals, which require consideration of the risks and benefits of the research. A ban of all gain of function research would also stop gain of function research that results in medical innovations and benefits to human health.

I have asked the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) to conduct a review of gain of function research in Australia. The Terms of Reference for this review are available on NHMRC's website at: nhmrc.gov.au/about-us/news-centre/gain-function-research-review.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Quarantine
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 to the Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Karen Andrews MP, concerning petition number EN3090 calling for the end of the hotel quarantine program, construction of multiple dedicated quarantine facilities, airports only accepting freight flights and aircrew not being permitted to leave airports. I am responding as the Minister for Health and Aged Care with portfolio responsibility for this matter.

On 27 March 2020, National Cabinet agreed that mandatory hotel quarantine should be implemented under state public health orders, reflecting the practicalities of an effective quarantine system, which needs to bring together healthcare, logistics and law enforcement. As such, quarantine arrangements are predominantly a matter for state and territory governments. Australia's hotel quarantine system is a critical intervention in managing the potential spread ofCOVID-19. As each jurisdiction is responsible for managing the COVID-19 response under its own public health legislation, decisions to implement lockdowns around the country are the responsibility of state and territory governments.

Australia's national quarantine policy is continuing to adapt based on emerging evidence and the best available medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee. Managed quarantine for international arrivals to Australia, including hotel quarantine and other highly controlled settings, has been Australia's first line of defence against COVID-19 and continues to play a vital role in Australia's public health response.

Decisions regarding quarantine requirements for both vaccinated and unvaccinated travellers continue to be considered as Australia progresses through the four-step National Plan to Transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response (National Plan). From 1 November 2021, fully vaccinated Australian citizens and permanent residents can travel overseas without an exemption. In some jurisdictions, such as New South Wales and Victoria, there are no quarantine requirements for fully vaccinated eligible travellers returning to or entering Australia. Some jurisdictions are also trialling modified quarantine arrangements, including home quarantine.

The National Plan will continue to provide a graduated pathway to transition Australia's COVID-19 response from its pre-vaccination settings focused on continued suppression of community transmission, to post-vaccination settings focused on prevention of serious illness and fatalities, whereby the public health management of COVID-19 is consistent with other infectious diseases.

You may note that the Australian Government is already funding dedicated quarantine facilities known as Centres for National Resilience in Melbourne, Perth and Brisbane, which will, alongside the highly successful Centre at Howard Springs, and the hotel quarantine system, provide quarantine accommodation for cohorts coming into Australia in line with state and territory requirements.

The safe operation of additional international passenger services as Australian vaccination rates continue to increase, remains critically important to maintaining connectivity and people to people links for Australians, as well as supporting our key tourism and education industries. International passenger services ·are also integral for the Australian economy by facilitating international two-way trade, with international passenger services also carrying a significant amount of international air freight in the belly hold of these aircraft.

Safe health practices will continue to apply to international aircrew upon their arrival and before their departure from Australia, having regard to their vaccination status. International airline and airport operators in Australia are also putting in place a range of measures to reduce the risk of COVID-19 on aircraft and at airport facilities to enable the staged return of an increase in international passenger arrivals into Australia.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Parliamentarians
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 18 October 2021 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, relating to a petition about the consumption of alcohol at Parliament House (Petition no. EN3099). The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf.

Australia's parliamentary democracy, like many others around the world, is based on the Westminster system. In such systems, it is up to the presiding officers, in our case the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate, to establish the Standing Orders that govern proceedings in each Chamber.

The current Standing Orders do not contain any provisions relating to drug or alcohol use for federal politicians. In my experience in the Parliament, it has been the case that the overwhelming majority of Members and Senators conduct themselves in an appropriate way.

It is important that everyone has an opportunity to have their say about the issues that matter to them. I agree with the constituents' view that it is incumbent on all parliamentarians to conduct themselves while undertaking our official duties without the influence of drugs or alcohol. The views of the constituents on this particular issue have been carefully noted and will be taken into account.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister and Cabinet Minister for the Public Service, Mr Morton
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition number EN3108, implementation of a COVID-19 vaccine passport.

The Australian Government has not made any decisions around the use of mandatory vaccination certificates. States and territories have primary operational responsibility for emergency management and public health measures within their jurisdiction. As such, states and territories may require proofofCOVID-19 vaccination when considering travel exemptions for interstate travel during state-determined lockdowns and travel restrictions.

Australians can already provide voluntary proof of vaccination by accessing their immunisation history statement through Medicare Online, via the Express Plus Medicare mobile app or via their My Health Record. People can seek a hard copy of their immunisation history statement by contacting the Australian Immunisation Register enquiries line, or through their doctor or immunisation provider.

Some employers and businesses have started to mandate vaccinations for their employees working in a high-risk workplace, and for their patrons. Businesses do have the right to make any service they provide subject to conditions and can impose restrictions on who can enter their premises.

Anti-discrimination issues may arise where people are unable to be vaccinated, and privacy laws restrict the collection of sensitive information. In each case, businesses will need to consider their legal obligations, and determine what is right for their particular workplace.

The Government continues to provide guidance to businesses on these matters, and to encourage vaccination uptake by communicating about the safety, science, and benefits ofCOVID-19 vaccination. Those who are unable to be vaccinated for a genuine medical condition may be granted an appropriate exemption certificate dependent on the rules in their state or territory.

It is important to note that apart from select high-risk workplaces and professions, COVID-19 vaccination in Australia largely remains voluntary and individuals may choose to vaccinate. The Government will continue to work with the states and territories to promote a nationally consistent approach for mandating COVID-19 vaccination.

Where COVID-19 vaccination has been mandated for identified high-risk groups through state and territory legislation, exemptions are available for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical reasons. It is important that everyone who can be vaccinated, does, to help keep themselves and others safe.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition number EN3115 requesting the cessation of mass vaccination against COVID-19 and the implementation of large-scale chemoprophylaxis treatment.

The Australian Government is taking a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, informed by the latest medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee and its expert standing committees, including the Public Health Laboratory Network and the Communicable Diseases Network Australia.
The Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective means of preventing the spread and development of diseases such as COVID-19 in the community.

COVID-19 vaccines are helping to prevent serious illness, hospitalisation, and fatality. Sitting under the Australian Health Emergency Response Plan for Novel Coronavirus—COVID-19 (COVID-19 Plan) is the COVID-19 Vaccine and Treatment Strategy.
This strategy supports the access to, and delivery of, safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines and treatments as soon as they become available.

The COVID-19 Plan, first released in February 2020, was developed to guide the Australian health sector response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The COVID-19 Plan provides guidance on the response actions, proportionate to the level of risk, required to minimise the health impacts of the pandemic on the Australian population. A review of the COVID-19 plan is currently underway which will incorporate updated information on the coronavirus vaccines and treatments available.

Currently, there is no cure or treatment to prevent COVID-19, although a number of medications can help people who are very seriously ill. The National COVID-19 Clinical Evidence Taskforce, consisting of a large group of Australian clinical experts, is continuously updating recommendations, and considering the effectiveness of therapeutics for both the prevention and treatment ofCOVID-19 infection based on the best available evidence.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration, part of my Department, is Australia's medicines regulator. For a medicine to be registered in Australia to treat a specific condition, a sponsor (usually a pharmaceutical company) is required to submit a comprehensive developmental dossier which consists of clinical studies, non-clinical/toxicology studies, chemistry, manufacturing, risk management and other information.

Any experimental medication used in the treatment of COVID-19 must be prescribed and administered either in a controlled health care setting or as part of clinical trial assessing the merits of treatments under research conditions with appropriate ethical oversight.

As the pandemic situation continues to evolve and new evidence emerges, the Government will continue to review its response strategies and provide Australians with the most up to date information and advice. A visit to the Government's website at: www.australia.gov.au will keep you well-informed about Australia's health response.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning Petition EN3127 asking the House to have ivermectin recognised as a legally accessible treatment for COVID-19.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that Australians have access to, and delivery of, safe and effective vaccines and treatment options for COVID-19 as soon as they are available, through our COVID-19 Vaccine and Treatment Strategy.
I have provided information below in response to the issues raised in Petition EN3127.

lvermectin is an anti-parasite medication which is used to treat a number of human and animal diseases. Oral ivermectin (Stromectol) is approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), part of my Department, for the treatment of river blindness (onchocerciasis), threadworm of the intestines (intestinal strongyloidiasis), and scabies.

On 10 September 2021, a senior medical officer at the TGA, acting on the advice of the Advisory Committee for Medicines Scheduling (ACMS), placed new restrictions on the prescribing of oral ivermectin. The ACMS is an independent advisory committee consisting of medical and pharmaceutical experts from across Australia.

General practitioners can continue to prescribe ivermectin for the TOA-approved conditions (indications). Certain specialists including infectious disease physicians, dermatologists, gastroenterologists, and hepatologists (liver disease specialists) may also prescribe ivermectin off-label for other unapproved indications if they believe it is appropriate for the treatment of a particular patient.

The TGA introduced these changes because of concerns with the off-label prescribing of oral ivermectin for the claimed prevention or treatment of COVID-19 in the context of insufficient evidence of safety and efficacy (see below). These concerns include the significant public health risks associated with taking ivermectin as an alternative to vaccination, unsafe dosages being promoted, and to ensure continued access for those who need the medicine for treatment of scabies and parasite infections.

Ivermectin is not approved for use.as a treatment for COVID-19 in Australia or in any other comparable country, and it is the consensus view of international regulators and top-tier journals that more evidence from large, prospective, and randomised controlled trials is required before it could be considered a safe and effective treatment. Although ivermectin may already be registered in Australia for other uses, it does not automatically mean that it is safe and effective when used to treat another condition.

The use of ivermectin as a COVID-19 treatment is also strongly discouraged by eminent organisations including the National COVID-19 Clinical Evidence Taskforce (an independent group of Australian clinical experts), the World Health Organization, the United States Food and Drug Administration, and the European Medicines Agency.

On 4 February 2021, Merck, one of the major manufacturers of ivermectin, publicly confirmed that, to date, there is no scientific basis for a potential therapeutic effect against COVID-19 from pre-clinical studies, no meaningful evidence for clinical activity or clinical efficacy in patients with COVID-19 disease, and a concerning lack of safety data in the majority of studies.

In addition, a recent analysis by the Cochrane Collaboration of published ivermectin trials concluded that ivermectin could not be recommended for COVID-19 treatment or prevention. The Cochrane Collaboration is one of the key independent international bodies responsible for assessing clinical evidence for medical treatments and therapies. The Cochrane study is titled Ivermectin for preventing and treating COVID-19 and can be found at: www.cochranelibrary.com.

The Cochrane Collaboration also found that the available evidence for ivermectin is of low to very low quality and insufficient to draw any clinically meaningful conclusions. In addition, several studies claiming to support the use of ivermectin have not yet been peer-reviewed, with one of the larger studies recently being withdrawn from preprint due to allegations of data manipulation (www.researchsquare.com/article/rs-100956/v3 and www.nature.com/articles/d41586-021-02081-w).

span.span: Registration process for new COVID-19 tr

p.span: I assure you that my Department is regularly meeting with researchers, developers and manufacturers about a wide range of medicines for the prevention and treatment of COVID-19 in a variety of clinical settings, and that the TGA welcomes and encourages discussions with prospective sponsors about the regulation process for potential COVID-19 treatments.

While evidence is still being gathered for potential COVID-19 treatments, I must emphasise that if a sponsor holds the appropriate evidence, they can make an application to the TGA at any time to register their medicine on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods. As is the case for all prescription medicines, the application must include a comprehensive data package to support the medicine's safety, quality, and efficacy, as well as a source of product manufactured to pharmaceutical Good Manufacturing Practice requirements.

This long-standing and well-established process provides rigorous safeguards to ensure that Australians have access to safe, effective and high-quality medicines. It must be noted, however, that the TGA is unable to commence assessment in the absence of an application, and neither the Government nor the TGA can compel a sponsor to make such an application.

To date, the TGA has provisionally approved three COVID-19 treatments via the provisional registration pathway: Remdesivir (VEKLURY), Sotrovimab (XEVUDY) and casirivimab/imdevimab (RONAPREVE). The TGA has also granted a provisional determination to four other COVID-19 medicines for evaluation through this pathway.
Up-to-date information about COVID-19 treatments available in Australia can be found on the TGA's website at: www.tga.gov.au/covid-19/covid-19-treatments.

span.span: COVID-19 vaccines are safe and effective

p.span: The COVID-19 vaccines which have received provisional approval in Australia have each been shown to be highly effective in preventing severe illness, hospitalisation, and death from COVID-19, caused by SARS-CoV-2. The risk of a person infected with the SARS-CoV-2 virus developing symptomatic illness and becoming seriously unwell with COVID-19 is significantly reduced if that person has received a COVID-19 vaccine. For each provisionally approved vaccine the TGA has established the acceptable safety, quality and efficacy of the vaccine based on a comprehensive evaluation of a wide range of information.
More information about COVID-19 vaccines and treatments, including those under evaluation, is available on the TGA's website at: www.tga.gov.au/safety-information/covid-19.

I am confident that the TGA continues to respond appropriately and with great priority to ensure the timely availability of new COVID-19 treatments without compromising on Australia's high standards of safety, quality and efficacy.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning EN3128 requesting the disclosure of the COVID-19 vaccine ingredients.

The safety of the Australian population has always been the highest priority of the Australian Government. For this reason, decisions regarding COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI).

The Government is working closely with the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), the ATAGI and all state and territory health departments to ensure that monitoring of COVID-19 vaccine safety is of the highest possible standard in Australia.

The TGA formally assesses the safety, quality and efficacy of medicines, including vaccines, prior to their approval for use in Australia. All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large clinical trials on thousands of people. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and/or disease.

All COVID-19 vaccines used in the rollout have been granted provisional approval following a complete assessment of all this available data. No part of the process has been rushed and the TGA does not have an 'Emergency Use Authorisation' pathway for COVID-19 vaccines.

The TGA is open and transparent about safety information relating to COVID-19 vaccines, including any suspected side effects or potential safety issues. The TGA publishes a weekly safety report, including information about reported suspected side effects, as well as other safety alerts as required. More information can be found at: www.tga.gov.au using the search terms 'COVID-19-vaccine safety monitoring and reporting'.
Although graphene oxide may serve as a potential vaccine carrier to help activate immunity, none of the COVID-19 vaccines approved and in use in Australia include graphene oxide.

The AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria), Pfizer, and Moderna COVID-19 vaccine Product Information (PI) leaflets are publicly available on the TGA website, listing the ingredients in each vaccine. The PIs are required as supporting documents for regulatory approval. None of the PI's for these vaccines list graphene oxide as an ingredient and is therefore not present.

The goal is to protect all people in Australia from the harm caused COVID-19 infection, through preventing serious illness and death, and where possible, disease transmission. The Pfizer, AstraZeneca and Moderna vaccines have all been proven through approval and safety monitoring processes to be very effective at reducing severe illness, hospitalisation and death.

From 1 October 2021, all Australians aged 12 years and over are now eligible to receive a COVID 19 vaccine. Australians aged 60 years and over are now eligible to receive a Pfizer or Moderna COVID-19 vaccine, while those aged 18 years or over can choose to have the AstraZeneca vaccine after providing informed consent.

It is important for Australians to have access to credible and timely information about COVID-19 vaccines. It is a large and complex project, and the information you are seeking may change over time- that is why we strongly encourage all Australians stay up-to-date on all news and announcements, by regularly checking my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au.
Vaccination remains the most effective way for people to protect themselves from the effects of COVID-19. The Government encourages everyone to be vaccinated as soon as they are eligible.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition number EN3132, requesting that the Biosecurity (Human Coronavirus with Pandemic Potential) Amendment (No. 1) Determination 2021 be rescinded.

The Australian Government regularly reviews determinations made under section 477 of the Biosecurity Act 2015 (Act) taking into account the latest expert medical advice to ensure their appropriateness in terms of global and local epidemiology.

The emergency requirements under section 477 of the Act, which include the Biosecurity (Human Biosecurity Emergency) (Human Coronavirus with Pandemic Potential (Overseas Travel Ban Emergency Requirements) Determination 2020 (Overseas Travel Ban), aim to control and prevent the entry, emergency, establishment and spread ofCOVID-19 into Australian territory.

The amendment determination (the subject of this petition), removed only the automatic exemption from outgoing travel restrictions that applied for Australian citizens who are usually residents in another country. This was an important change designed to reduce the burden on our quarantine and health systems by reducing frequent travel back and forth, freeing up more quarantine places for Australians who are already overseas and seeking to return home.

Individuals with a legitimate need to travel can still request an exemption from the Australian Border Force. Australians who are in Australia, or who travel to Australia and wish to return to their usual country of residence, are still able to apply for an exemption to travel on an exceptional basis, the same requirement as applies to every other Australian.

Specific emergency management determinations are made in the context of the human biosecurity emergency period declared under section 475 of the Act, and which is due to lapse on 17 December 2021. The Government has not yet made any decision about whether the emergency period will be extended. The Government is closely monitoring the evolving degree of public health risk, taking into account factors such as the impact of the vaccination rollout.

Australia's four-phase National Plan to Transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response outlines that once 80 per cent of Australians over the age of 16 years are fully vaccinated, and that target has also been reached by a jurisdiction, that jurisdiction would open to international travel for fully vaccinated Australian citizens with no requirements for exemptions.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Health Care
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning Petition EN3141 which asks to let all medical doctors prescribe ivermectin for people diagnosed with COVID-19.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring Australians have access to safe and effective options for the prevention and treatment ofCOVID-19. COVID-19 vaccines have been demonstrated to be safe and effective and as such are recommended for all Australians from 12 years of age. There are very few situations where a COVID-19 vaccine is contraindicated (e.g. the patient is allergic to an ingredient in the vaccine, has had a serious adverse event after the first dose, or has a history of certain blood clotting disorders) and these are detailed in the Product Information (for healthcare practitioners) and Consumer Medicine Information documents.

If a patient has a contraindication to one type ofCOVID-19 vaccine (e.g. mRNA) they may still be able to be immunised with the alternative type (e.g. viral vector). Medical exemptions are rarely required, and an individual's medical practitioner is best placed to discuss alternative options with the patient.

Ivermectin is an anti-parasite medication that is used to treat human and animal diseases. Oral ivermectin (Stromectol) is approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) for the treatment of river blindness (onchocerciasis), threadworm of the intestines (intestinal strongyloidiasis), and scabies.

On 10 September 2021, the TGA decision maker (delegate), acting on the advice of the Advisory Committee for Medicines Scheduling, placed restrictions on the prescribing of oral ivermectin through a change to its scheduling entry in the Poisons Standard. The Advisory Committee, which included senior medical officers and pharmacists as well as representatives from each state and territory, unanimously supported the change.

The change is also supported by the two peak bodies representing general practitioners—the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and the Australian Medical Association. In law, the TGA decision is independent from Commonwealth parliamentary processes and is given effect through state and territory law and regulation. It should be noted that there are a significant number of other medicines that either cannot be prescribed by general practitioners or alternatively require individual special authorisation (e.g. by the CEO of their state health department) to do so.

GPs can now only prescribe ivermectin for TGA-approved conditions (indications) such as scabies and certain parasitic infections. Certain specialists including infectious disease physicians, dermatologists, gastroenterologists, and hepatologists can prescribe ivermectin for other unapproved indications if they believe it is appropriate for a particular patient.

The TGA introduced these changes because of concerns with the prescribing of oral ivermectin for the claimed prevention or treatment of COVID-19. These concerns include the significant public health risks to an individual, and those around them, associated with taking ivermectin in an attempt to prevent COVID-19 infection rather than getting vaccinated, the unsafe dosages being promoted, and to ensure continued access for those who need the medicine for the treatment of scabies and parasitic infections.

Ivermectin is not approved for the treatment ofCOVID-19 in Australia, or in any other comparable Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development country. Its use by the general public for COVID-19 is strongly discouraged by the National COVID Clinical Evidence Taskforce, the World Health Organization, the United States of America's Food and Drug Administration, and the European Medicines Agency.

Merck, one of the major companies manufacturing ivermectin, publicly confirmed on 4 February 2021, that to date, there is no scientific basis for a·potential therapeutic effect against COVID-19 from pre-clinical studies, no meaningful evidence for clinical activity or clinical efficacy in patients with COVID-19 disease, and a concerning lack of safety data in the majority of studies.

In addition, a recent analysis of published ivermectin trials by the Cochrane Collaboration concluded that ivermectin could not be recommended for COVID-19 treatment or prevention. The Cochrane Collaboration is one of the key independent international bodies responsible for assessing clinical evidence for medical treatments and therapies. The Cochrane Collaboration also found that the available evidence for ivermectin is of low to very low quality, and insufficient to come to any clinically meaningful conclusions.

If a sponsor holds the appropriate evidence such as data demonstrating the safe and efficacious use of ivermectin for the treatment ofCOVID-19, they can make an application at any time to the TGA to register their medicine on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods. Any application must include a comprehensive data package to support the medicine's safety, quality, and efficacy for the intended end use.

My Department has published information on how evidence is used in the approach to COVID-19 treatments to keep Australians safe. To date, the TGA has provisionally approved three COVID-19 treatments: Remdesivir (VEKLURY), Sotrovimab (XEVUDY) and casirivimab/imdevimab (RONAPREVE) and has provisionally designated four other COVID-19 medicines for evaluation through the provisional pathway. Up-to-date information about COVID-19 treatments available in Australia can be found on the TGA's website.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Medicinal Cannabis
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 on behalf of petitioners concerning the request for a Cannabis Access Scheme to subsidise medicinal cannabis (petition number: EN3145).

It is a priority of the Australian Government to provide all Australians access to safe, effective and affordable medicines. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) is the main mechanism through which the Government subsidises the cost of medicines, including medicinal cannabis.
The Government has a policy to list all medicines on the PBS, following a recommendation to do so by the independent and expert Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC).

Since 2013, the Government has approved over 2,700 new or amended listings on the PBS. This represents an average of around 30 listings or amendments per month, or one each day, at an overall investment by the Government of$13.9 billion.
On 30 April 2021, I was delighted to announce the listing of cannabidiol (Epidyolex®) on the PBS effective from 1 May 2021, to provide Government-subsidised treatment to

Australians living with a rare form of epilepsy (Dravet syndrome). This means that eligible patients who might have otherwise paid more than $24,000 per year for the treatment now pay only $41.30 per script or $6.60 if they have a concession card.

Under legislation, the Government can only list a medicine on the PBS when the PBAC recommends such listing. Similarly, the Government requires the advice of the PBAC for a change to the circumstances of PBS listing to be made.
While the Government is responsible for listing medicines on the PBS, pharmaceutical companies that hold the relevant clinical evidence are responsible for applying to the PBAC for PBS subsidy.

Currently, nabiximols (Sativex®) and Epidyolex® are the only medicinal cannabis products approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), Australia's regulator of medicines and other therapeutic goods for use in Australia. Sativex® is approved for the treatment of moderate to severe spasticity due to multiple sclerosis.

Epidyolex® is approved for the treatment of Dravet syndrome and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (another severe form of childhood epilepsy). All other medicinal cannabis products and indications are considered 'unapproved', meaning that the TGA has not established that the product meets the required quality, safety and efficacy standards. Medicines are not generally made available on the PBS to treat conditions for which they have not been approved by the TGA.
Pharmaceutical companies are private entities that make their own decisions regarding their products and cannot be compelled by the Government to apply for TGA registration and PBS subsidy.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition number EN3169 requesting evidence of the existence of SARS-CoV-2 (the virus that causes COVID-19), including evidence of the Delta variant. I note the reasoning described in the request, including the premise that COVID-19 emergency restrictions are unjustified and unlawful.

The Australian Government is coordinating an evidence-based response to the COVID-19 pandemic, informed by the latest medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee and its expert standing committees, including the Public Health Laboratory Network and the Communicable Diseases Network Australia.

Multiple scientific studies across the world demonstrate that highly reputable laboratory medicine experts have isolated and sequenced SARS-CoV-2, demonstrating that the virus exists, that it exists in variant forms, that it is different from other respiratory viruses, and that it causes a disease, known as COVID-19, that has resulted in almost 5 million deaths worldwide. Attached to this letter is an article by Australia's Chief Medical Officer Professor Paul Kelly, titled 'The proof is in the facts' published in the Daily Telegraph on 13 August 2021 to address queries of this nature.

My Department is a government agency and does not conduct scientific studies in a laboratory. While my Department is not the custodian of the scientific studies establishing the existence of SARS-CoV-2 and that of its variants such as Delta, this research has informed the Government's response to the pandemic. Those scientific studies can be sourced in the public domain.

In Australia, scientists at the Victorian Infectious Diseases Reference Laboratory at The Peter Doherty Institute for Infection and Immunity were the first to isolate SARS-CoV-2 outside China, winning the 2020 MJA/MDA National Prize for Excellence in Medical Research. This critical information was immediately shared with local and overseas reference laboratories and major North American and European virus culture collections. These peer-reviewed, evidence-based publications provide scientific evidence for the existence of this deadly virus.

For more information, you may wish to refer to the article published in The Medical Journal of Australia, which describes the first isolation of SARS-CoV-2 from a person in Australia, the sequencing of the virus and rapid sharing of the isolate 'Isolation and rapid sharing of the 2019 novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) from the first patient diagnosed with COVID-19 in Australia', available at: www.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.5694/mja2.50569.

More evidence for the isolation and existence of SARS-CoV-2 and its variants, and the devastating impacts of the global COVID-19 pandemic caused by this virus, is widely available in the public domain.

All viruses, including SARS-CoV-2, change over time as part of their natural evolution. A change may or may not give the virus a biological advantage. Existing and emerging variants are constantly monitored using genomic surveillance to detect those that pose or may pose an increased risk to human health.

In Australia, whole genome sequencing (WGS) of the SARS-CoV-2 genome is the preferred way to determine the variant and mutation patterns of the virus e.g. Alpha, Delta, and Kappa variants. WGS is undertaken within specialist jurisdictional public health laboratories which then upload these sequences to a national, secure platform and to publicly available international databases for analysis. This analysis identifies specific variants and mutations, monitors virus evolution, and identifies new or emerging clusters.

These specialist laboratories are the custodians of the sequence information. Detailed scientific sequence files are not provided to the Department. In most states and territories an attempt is made to sequence all positive SARS-CoV-2 samples. In jurisdictions with widespread community transmission, sequencing prioritisation strategies are employed.

Some PCR tests have been designed to detect specific SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern. The performance of these tests is still being established, and they will not identify variants that they have not been designed for.

The World Health Organization (WHO) has also compiled a range of international multilingual scientific findings and information about COVID-19 in the 'WHO COVID-19 Database'. The database, which is updated regularly, is available at: www.search.bvsalud.org/global-literature-on-novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov.

In addition to emergency measures available under the Commonwealth's Biosecurity Act 2015, I note that state and territory governments have primary operational responsibility for emergency management and public health in their respective jurisdictions, which is based on the medical advice from their respective Chief Health Officers. The specific measures imposed to control the spread of COVID-19 in each state and territory, including managing restrictions on the movement of residents within a state/territory, is the responsibility of the respective jurisdiction.

I acknowledge that this has been, and continues to be, a very difficult time for all Australians with many impacts, including but not limited to, citizens being unable to visit friends and family interstate and overseas. As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, governments around the world have taken unprecedented steps to contain the outbreak and respond to its impacts, including through legislation where there are appropriate public health justifications.

The four-step National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response provides a graduated pathway to transition Australia's COVID-19 response to a post-vaccination setting focused on prevention of serious illness and fatalities, whereby the public health management of COVID-19 is consistent with other infectious diseases.

The Petitions Committee can be assured that the Government, along with the states and territories, is taking an evidence-based approach to COVID-19 and is committed to protecting the health of Australians.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN3179 calling on the Australian Government to immediately release all The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) submission documents for publicly funded vaccines.

The Australian Government wants everyone in Australia to have access to a safe, free, COVID-19 vaccine, if they choose to be vaccinated. Moreover, the safety of the population has always been the highest priority of the Government. For these reasons, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation.

The TGA formally assesses the safety, quality and efficacy of medicines, including vaccines, prior to their approval for use in Australia. All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large clinical trials on thousands of people. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease.

This involves comprehensive review of clinical trial data, non-clinical and toxicological studies, chemistry, manufacturing, quality, risk-management and other information by a large team of clinical and scientific experts. Advice is then sought from an independent expert committee before a regulatory decision is made.

All COVID-19 vaccines used in the rollout have been granted provisional approval following a complete assessment of all this available data. No part of the process has been rushed and the TGA does not have an 'Emergency Use Authorisation' pathway for COVID-19 vaccines.

The urgency of the global pandemic means that researchers, agencies such as the World Health Organization and governments all over the world are prioritising the development, assessment and rollout ofCOVID-19 vaccines. There is a combination of reasons why safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines have been able to be designed, researched and made available sooner than previously seen.
For example:
Unprecedented levels of funding-the pandemic is a global priority and governments around the world are investing in research and manufacturing facilities.
Technology-the evolution of technology has allowed vaccines to be developed at a faster pace than in the past. New technologies have helped scientists understand the
coronavirus and its make-up more easily, which has allowed them to start working on vaccine design more quickly.
Combined clinical trials-in response to the pandemic, some pharmaceutical companies have combined clinical trial phases 1 and 2.

Expedited review process by regulatory agencies-the TGA is engaging early with pharmaceutical companies about their vaccines and is accepting rolling data. This means that the TGA can accept, review and assess clinical trial data as it becomes available, rather than all at once at the end of the three clinical trial phases.

The TGA requires robust scientific data before supporting a vaccine candidate and will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is found to be safe and effective, following its complete assessment of data.

The TGA is also part of a network of international regulators that meet regularly to discuss the development of COVID-19 vaccines. This information, together with the potential to use already established work-sharing arrangements and collaboration with other international regulators, is assisting the TGA to expedite the evaluation of any new vaccines without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality, and effectiveness.

The Freedom of Information Act 1982 (Cwth) (FOI Act) provides a right to request access to documents held by Australian Government entities. The FOI Act recognises that facilitating access to documents held by Government entities increases public scrutiny of Government activities, processes and decisions.

Members of the public can request access to Government held documents, including documents that contain sensitive or exempt material, under the FOI Act, which generally requires entities to provide a decision within 30 days of receipt of the request.
The FOI Guidelines issued by the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner provide guidance on the application of the FOI Act for both entities and applicants.
This includes extensive commentary on exemptions and conditional exemptions and the application of a public-interest test.

The FOI Act includes provisions providing for the internal and external review of decisions. This includes mechanisms for seeking review by the Australian Information Commissioner and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition EN3193—Royal Commission to investigate into World Health Organisation (sic) into Depopulation.

The Australian Government wants everyone in Australia to have access to a safe, free, COVID-19 vaccine, if they choose to be vaccinated. Moreover, the safety of the population has always been the highest priority of the Government. For these reasons, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation.
