Technology—the evolution of technology has allowed vaccines to be developed at a faster pace than in the past. New technologies have helped scientists understand the coronavirus and its make-up more easily, which has allowed them to start working on vaccine design more quickly.
Combined clinical trials—in response to the pandemic, some pharmaceutical companies have combined clinical trial phases 1 and 2.
Expedited review process by regulatory agencies—the TGA is engaging early with pharmaceutical companies about their vaccines and is accepting rolling data.
This means that the TGA can accept, review and assess clinical trial data as it becomes available, rather than all at once at the end of the three clinical trial phases.

All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes including clinical trials. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease.

The TGA requires robust scientific data before supporting a vaccine candidate and will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is found to be safe and effective, following its complete assessment of data.

The TGA is part of a network of international regulators that meet regularly to discuss the development of COVID-19 vaccines. This information, together with the potential to use already established work-sharing arrangements and collaboration with other international regulators, is assisting the TGA to expedite the evaluation of any new vaccines without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality, and effectiveness.

The Government also continues to meet regularly with a range of COVID-19 vaccine and treatment developers and manufacturers and continues to monitor ongoing clinical trials and review real world effectiveness of vaccine rollouts globally. There are more than 400 trials for 140 vaccine candidates worldwide, including a number that are trialling the use of needle-free technology. These include nasal sprays, oral tablets, skin patches and jet injectors.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN3203 No Mandatory Covid19 Vaccinations for Government Workers.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in significant challenges for people across Australia, and the Government recognises the additional complexity for those who undertake such important work to educate and support our youngest Australians.
The position of the Government on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Everyone maintains the option to choose.

As the COVID-19 pandemic is a public-health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. In line with this, some states and territories have now issued public-health orders that require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Further information about public-health orders may be found on state or territory government websites.

The Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) provides advice on mitigating emerging health threats related to infectious diseases. The AHPPC has already made statements and recommendations on vaccination for several professions, including on those in the school environment, released 1 October 2021. This can be found at: www.health.gov.au using the search term 'Australian Health Protection Principal Committee'.

In its conclusions, the AHPPC notes that vaccination of all adults around children is the most effective way to protect children from disease. This will also safeguard against the requirement to potentially close a school to regain control of an outbreak for the benefit of the community.

COVID-19 can be a very serious illness and is especially dangerous for vulnerable people in the community. Vaccination in settings such as education, aged care and health care helps to protect workers, vulnerable Australians, and the broader community.
The current legal framework only allows employers to require their workers to be vaccinated where:
a specific law (such as a state or territory public-health order) requires a worker to be vaccinated
the requirement is permitted by an enterprise agreement, other registered agreement or employment contract
it would be lawful and reasonable for an employer to give a worker a direction to be vaccinated, which is assessed on a case-by-case basis.
Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there should be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical and other reasons.

Some states and territories have also ensured that there are fast-tracked vaccinations for teachers and childcare workers, providing priority access to these groups, with or without a mandate, highlighting the importance of COVID-19 vaccination.

On 6 August 2021, National Cabinet agreed to a National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID response to a post-vaccination setting focused on prevention of serious illness, hospitalisation and fatality, like the public-health management of other infectious diseases. More information on the National Plan is available on the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet's website at: www.pmc.gov.au using the search terms 'national plan'.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan, targeting the milestones contained within the National Plan. For specific information on the rollout please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Bill of Rights
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 18 October 2021 regarding petition number EN3205, requesting that a Bill of Rights to be included in the Constitution.

As noted in the petition, the Australian Constitution has no equivalent to the Bill of Rights found in the United States Constitution. Some express and implied protections, however, are given by the Constitution against legislative or executive action by the Commonwealth. Examples are section 51(xxxi) (acquisition of property must be 'on just terms'), section 80 (trial by jury is required in relation to some Commonwealth criminal offences), and section 116 (the Commonwealth cannot legislate for any religion).

The High Court has also recognised some implied restrictions on legislative power derived from the fundamental system of government established by the Constitution. For example, because of the separation of powers effected by the Constitution, only a court may exercise the judicial power of the Commonwealth. Accordingly, a law of the Commonwealth Parliament cannot confer judicial power on a body that is not a court.

Similarly, the High Court has recognised that there is an implied restriction on the legislative and executive power of the Commonwealth and of the States and Territories protecting freedom of communication on governmental and political matters. This implication arises from the system of representative government created by the Constitution.

Australia's federal system of government means that each jurisdiction has anti-discrimination legislation and a body dedicated to promoting human rights and equal opportunity. Protected attributes at the federal level include age, disability, sex, race, nationality, ethnic origin, sexual orientation, gender identity and intersex status. The Government considers that existing mechanisms to protect and promote human rights, including the protections in place under anti- discrimination legislation at the Commonwealth, state and territory levels, are appropriate. On this basis, the Government does not propose to introduce a charter or bill of rights at the federal level.

The Australian Human Rights Commission also plays an imp01iant role in protecting and promoting human rights in Australia. The Commission is an independent statutory authority, established under the Australian Human Rights Commission Act 1986. Although the Commission falls within the Attorney-General's portfolio responsibility, it is independent from the Government. The Commission has a defined statutory role to promote Australians' rights and freedoms and conciliate human rights and discrimination complaints. The Commission also has an important role as an independent national human rights institution.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
COVID-19
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition number EN3213 requesting papers describing the isolation ofCOVID-19.

The Australian Government is coordinating an evidence-based response to the COVID-19 pandemic, informed by the latest medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee and its expert standing committees, including the Public Health Laboratory Network and the Communicable Diseases Network Australia.

Multiple scientific studies across the world demonstrate that highly reputable laboratory medicine experts have isolated and sequenced the SARS-COV-2, the virus which causes COVID-19, demonstrating that the virus exists, that it exists in variant forms, that it is different from other respiratory viruses, and that it causes a disease that has resulted in almost 5 million deaths worldwide.

Enclosed to this letter is an article by Australia's Chief Medical Officer Professor Paul Kelly, published in the Daily Telegraph on 13 August 2021 to address queries of this nature, titled: The proof is in the facts.

My Department is a government agency and does not conduct scientific studies in a laboratory. While my Department is not the custodian of the scientific studies concerning the isolation and establishing the existence of SARS-CoV-2, this research has informed the Government's response to the pandemic. These scientific studies can be sourced in the public domain.

In Australia, scientists at the Victorian Infectious Diseases Reference Laboratory at The Peter Doherty Institute for Infection and Immunity were the first to isolate SARS-CoV-2 outside of China, winning the 2020 MJA/MDA National Prize for Excellence in Medical Research.
This critical information was immediately shared with local and overseas reference laboratories and major North American and European virus culture collections.
These peer-reviewed, evidence-based publications provide scientific evidence for the existence of this deadly virus.

For more information, you may wish to refer to the article published in The Medical Journal of Australia, which describes the first isolation of SARS-CoV-2 from a person, the sequencing of the virus and rapid sharing of the isolate:

The article, Isolation and rapid sharing of the 2019 novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) from the first patient diagnosed with COVID-19 in Australia, is available at: https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.5694/mja2.50569.
More evidence for the isolation and existence of SARS-CoV-2, and the devastating impacts of the global COVID-19 pandemic it has caused, is widely available in the public domain.
The Petitions Committee can be assured that the Government, along with the states and territories, is taking an evidence-based approach to COVID-19 and is committed to keep Australians safe.
Thank you for writing on this matter. Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Encl (1):

span.span: The proof is in the facts
Scientific studies around the world have categorically proven the existence of Covid and its effects

p.span: THE world has been changed by the spread of the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2, the virus which causes Covid-19, since late 2019. Australia recorded its first case on January 25, 2020.
Tragically, the virus has infected more than 200 million people and has resulted in the deaths of more than 4.3 million people worldwide.
In Australia Covid-19 had affected 36,630 people as at August 9 and 938 people had lost their lives.
These are undeniable facts. To say otherwise is extremely dam- aging and undermines our efforts to respond to the pandemic.
The virus is real and its heart- breaking consequences are real. The loss of life is felt across communities, families and workplaces here in Australia and right around the world.
The continued spread of misinformation makes the job of our health professionals on the front- line harder.

From those caring for gravely ill people in intensive care units, to those conducting Covid-19 testing, tracing contacts and the thousands of Australian health care workers providing vaccinations to prevent serious illness and death.
It undermines the efforts of all those Australians who have acted responsibly and compassionately to protect their community when restrictions are needed to stop outbreaks.
It also devalues the lives of those who have suffered from Covid-19, those who continue to feel its effects and every person who has died.
In 2020-21, the Department of Health received 633 requests under the Freedom of Information Act.
More than 250 were Covid-19 specific and among those were requests for ever more specific forms of 'scientific proof' of the existence of the Covid-19 virus.

I am aware that a letter advising that the department does not hold documents relevant to one of those requests is being shared on social media and used to support conspiracy theories that the virus does not exist.
The extract of that letter, shared via social media, is aimed at misleading Australians and has been, maliciously, taken out of context.

Multiple scientific studies have isolated and sequenced the virus that causes Covid-19, demonstrating that the virus exists, that it is different from the influenza virus, and that it causes a disease that has resulted in more than four million deaths world- wide in just over 18 months.

Such studies have been published in reputable medical journals around the world. It is this research which has informed the Australian Government and every health professional in our efforts to bring an end to the pandemic.

In Australia, the Victorian Infectious Diseases Reference Laboratory at the Peter Doherty Institute was the first to isolate SARS-CoV-2 outside China, winning the 2020 MJA/MDA National Prize for Excellence in Medical Research.
This critical information was immediately shared with local and overseas reference laboratories and major North American and European virus culture collections.

These peer-reviewed, evidence- based publications are where the scientific proof has been established for all to see. Despite this, the false claims that the virus does not exist and that the pandemic is a hoax per- sist, circulating on social media and putting everyone's health at risk.

Social media users face a daily deluge of false Covid-19 claims and unfortunately some people share reports and documents without checking the qualifications of those making the claims or the veracity of the claims themselves.

Social media platforms are taking action to deliver on their responsibility not to provide a forum for people to spread misinformation about Covid-19. The Department of Health works to correct much of the misinformation circulating and the Covid-19 vaccines—Is It True? web-page is a great resource addressing common questions and dispelling many of the myths.
I urge all Australians to do the right thing to protect themselves and others from this deadly virus.
Maintain physical distance and good hygiene.
Stay home and get tested if you have any symptoms, follow your local advice to stay safe. Get vaccinated as soon as you are able.
Importantly, stay informed using credible sources of information, including www.health.gov.au.
COVID-19: Health Care
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning Petitions EN3214 and EN3196 asking the House to request that the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) assess the use of ivermectin and hydroxychloroquine for the prevention and treatment of COVID-19.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that Australians have access to, and delivery of, safe and effective vaccines and treatment options for COVID-19 as soon as they are available, through our COVID-19 Vaccine and Treatment Strategy.

My Department, which includes the TGA, is regularly meeting with developers and manufacturers about a wide range of medicines for the prevention and treatment ofCOVID-19 in a variety of clinical settings. The TGA welcomes and encourages discussions with prospective sponsors about the regulation process for potential COVID-19 treatments.
If a sponsor holds the appropriate evidence, they can make an application to the TGA at any time to register their medicine on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG).

As is the case for all prescription medicines, the application must include a comprehensive data package to support the medicine's safety, quality and efficacy, as well as a source of product manufactured to pharmaceutical Good Manufacturing Practice requirements.

I note that the petition requested the TGA assess the products in the absence of a sponsor. However, it is not possible under the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 for a product to receive TGA approval in the absence of a sponsor. Following registration on the ARTG, the sponsor remains legally responsible for the product, including any safety, compliance and recall actions that may arise.

I can confirm that in August 2021 the TGA held a technical meeting with a company regarding a potential application for an ivermectin product for COVID-19 treatment. In this case the TGA treated this meeting with the highest priority and are now awaiting an application from the company. There have not been any approaches by any sponsors requesting a pre-submission meeting on hydroxychloroquine.

To date, the TGA has provisionally approved three COVID-19 treatments via the provisional registration pathway: Remdesivir (VEKLURY), Sotrovimab (XEVUDY) and casirivimab/imdevimab (RONAPREVE). The TGA has also granted a provisional determination to four other COVID-19 medicines for evaluation through this pathway.
Up-to-date information about COVID-19 treatments available in Australia can be found on the TGA's website at: www.tga.gov.au/covid-19/covid-19-treatments.
I strongly reject the assertion that the Government and the TGA has ignored the use of medicines such as ivermectin and hydroxychloroquine for the treatment of COVID-19.

Neither ivermectin nor hydroxychloroquine have received regulatory approval in Australia, or by any other comparable Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development regulator, for the treatment or prevention of COVID-19. It is the consensus view of international regulators and top-tier medical journals that more evidence is required before these medicines could be considered safe and effective treatment options.

I also strongly reject the petition's statement that COVID-19 vaccines being supplied in Australia were hastily approved and poorly tested. The Standing Committee on Petitions can be reassured that the TGA has comprehensively evaluated each of the provisionally registered COVID-19 vaccines, to ensure that they meet Australia's high standards of safety, quality, and efficacy. This formal regulatory approval by the TGA means they are not classified as experimental.

A large team of clinical and scientific experts at the TGA carefully review these data and seek advice from the Advisory Committee on Vaccines, an independent clinical expert committee, prior to a senior medical officer making a regulatory decision. Even though this is an expedited process, no element of the evaluation is rushed, and no data is overlooked.
This is also a similar process to that undertaken by other major regulators such as the European Medicines Agency and United States Food and Drug Administration.

The COVID-19 vaccines which have received provisional approval in Australia have each been shown to be highly effective in preventing severe illness, hospitalisation and death from COVID-19 caused by SARS-CoV-2. The risk of a person infected with the SARS-CoV-2 virus developing symptomatic illness and becoming seriously unwell with COVID-19 is significantly reduced if that person has received a COVID-19 vaccine.

The TGA has robust procedures in place to detect and investigate signals for potential safety concerns with COVID-19 vaccines. If the TGA detects a safety concern, rapid action will be taken to address the safety issue and promptly provide information to the public. The TGA also undertakes an independent quality assessment of every batch of vaccine supplied in Australia.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Horse Abattoirs
Dear Chair
Thank you for your representation of 11 February 2020 concerning petition EN1191 regarding the request to reform horse abattoirs.1 apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government takes the welfare of all animals seriously and is committed to high level animal welfare outcomes. The government provides a leadership role in the development of national animal welfare standards and guidelines through the Animal Welfare Task Group. This task group—comprising representatives of each of the state and territory governments, and the federal government—is the primary mechanism for the development and improvement of national animal welfare standards.

The task group is currently developing the Australian Animal Welfare Standards and Guidelines for Livestock at Processing Establishments, which includes horses, to replace the Model Code of Practice for Livestock at Slaughtering Establishments. Queensland is leading this review and is expected to finalise these standards in 2023. As part of this process Queensland will seek stakeholder feedback likely at some point next year.

Responsibility for the regulation and enforcement of animal welfare rests with the state and territory governments for all aspects of animal handling that occurs within their jurisdictions during production, transportation, and slaughter. The Australian Government's role in regulating animal welfare is limited to exports. All export registered establishments, including those that process horse meat for human consumption, must comply with the Export Control Act 2020. Export abattoirs are bound to comply with their Approved Arrangement, including animal welfare standard operating procedures, which is verified and audited by the Department of Agriculture, Water and Environment veterinarians. Where an export registered establishment fails to comply with the Act, the department has the power to suspend or revoke that establishment's Approved Arrangement.

On a related matter, the independent Thoroughbred Aftercare Welfare Working Group, established by the industry's Thoroughbred Welfare Initiative and chaired by the Hon Dr Denis Napthine AO, recently released its report The Most Important Participant: A Framework for Thoroughbred Welfare. The Thoroughbred Welfare Initiative was established by the national industry bodies including thoroughbred breeders, trainers, jockeys and other industry groups in February 2020 to examine the welfare of thoroughbred racehorses from retirement to end-of-life. The report contains 46 recommendations that provide a national approach to provide care to thoroughbred racehorses from birth to the end of their lives. You can find the report at thoroughbredwelfareinitiative.org.au.
Thank you again for bringing the petition to the government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture and Northern Australia, MrLittleproud
Medical Workforce
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Greg Hunt MP, concerning petition number EN1286 on the Modified Monash Model (MMM) 2019 classification of towns in Tasmania, in particular Lilydale. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister responsible for rural and regional health.

The Department of Health uses the MMM classification system to better target health workforce programs by categorising metropolitan, regional, rural and remote areas according to both geographical remoteness, as defined by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, and town size. The MMM was developed to recognise the challenges faced by smaller communities in attracting health professionals. The current MMM classification system was updated on 1 July 2020 with the latest available Census data (2016). As the next Census will be conducted in August 2021, the MMM will be updated when this data is available.
Lilydale is classified as MM 2 (Regional Centre). This is because Lilydale is within 20 kilometres of Launceston, which has a population of over 50,000 people.

The Department of Health established the Distribution Advisory Group (DAG) to provide independent advice regarding towns that raise concerns about their geographical classifications. The DAG consists of a number of peak bodies representing the rural health workforce, the National Rural health Commissioner and independent medical advisers chosen for their expertise in issues relating to rural health. At their first meeting on 6 December 2019, the DAG agreed that as the MMM is purely a data based geographical classification system, and discretionary changes cannot be made to the MMM classification of an area.

The Workforce Incentive Program (WIP) Practice Stream provides financial incentives to support general practices engage the services of nurses, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health practitioners and health workers, and eligible allied health professionals. Under the WIP Practice Stream, practices in all locations are eligible for incentive payments of up to $125,000 per annum to support the engagement of eligible health professionals.

The Government also funds a number of programs aimed at supporting practices to recruit, retain and upskill staff. As an MM 2 area, Lilydale continues to have access to a number of programs that encourage medical practitioners to practise in regional, rural and remote communities.
Practices in Lilydale can access the following benefits:

Rural Bulk Billing Incentives: Higher incentives are payable to medical practitioners in areas classified as regional, rural or remote (MM 2-7) who provide bulk billed services to vulnerable patient groups, such as people with concession cards and children under 16 years of age
Workforce Incentive Program—Practice Stream: eligible practices can receive incentive payments of up to $125,000 per year

Practice Incentive Program (PIP) payments: Under the PIP, geographic eligibility is determined by the Rural, Remote and Metropolitan Areas (RRMA) geographic classification system. Practices in Lilydale are classified RRMA 5 and can receive an additional 40 per cent rural loading on their PIP payments.

Further, the Government uses the Distribution Priority Area (DPA) system to identify and address the maldistribution of GPs in Australia. Lilydale is classified as DPA for both GPs and Bonded Medical Program participants. As such, practices can recruit doctors who are subject to location restrictions, such as International Medical Graduates and Australian bonded doctors with return of service obligations.

DPA status means medical practices in Lilydale can recruit from a larger pool of GPs and specialist doctors to improve access to medical services. The DPA classification system is updated annually, with the most recent update being on 1 July 2020.

To further attract and retain doctors to Launceston and across northern Tasmanian communities, the Government announced a $2 million incentive fund on 15 December 2020 to help address longstanding GP shortages in northern and north-western Tasmania.

The Government also funds Rural Workforce Agencies (RWAs), one in each state and the Northern Territory, to provide assistance to communities that experience difficulties attracting and retaining health professionals into regional, rural and remote areas. These agencies work with local practices, communities and other organisations to ensure that rural Australia is served by a skilled, well-supported health workforce. The RWA in Tasmania is HR+, and they can be contacted by telephone on (03) 6332 8600 or via their website at: www.hrplustas.com.au.
Thank you for raising this matter.
from the Minister for Regional Health, Regional Communications and Local Government, MrCoulton
Tobacco Regulation
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 30 November 2020 concerning petition number EN1984—Stop the new anti-smoking plan.

The Australian Government is not amending any regulations related to conventional cigarettes as inferred in the teams .of the petition at this time. The petition appears to refer to the announcement of an interim decision by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) in regards to the scheduling of nicotine.

On 23 September 2020 the TGA announced an interim decision that, if made final, would clarify the scheduling of nicotine in the Commonwealth Standard for the Uniform Scheduling of Medicines and Poisons (Poisons Standard). If confirmed by a final decision, the proposed changes would mean that e-cigarettes containing nicotine, and nicotine fluids for vaping, could only be supplied with a doctor's prescription in specific circumstances and subject to state and territory legislation. The interim decision was open for public consultation until 12 November 2020, and a final decision is expected before the end of 2020.
The proposed changes would not affect the current exemption from scheduling for nicotine in tobacco prepared and packed for smoking and nicotine replacement therapies like gums, sprays and patches.

The interim decision was made in accordance with the requirements of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989, informed by advice from the Advisory Committees on Medicines Scheduling and on Chemicals Scheduling. The final decision will be made after the TGA delegate has taken account of public submissions.

The TGA delegate found that restrictions on the availability of e-cigarettes are necessary to mitigate the potential uptake of smoking in young adults who would otherwise be at low risk of initiating nicotine addiction. The TGA delegate also considered that making nicotine a prescription-only medicine would require a medical practitioner to make an informed decision on whether it is in the patient's best interest to prescribe e-cigarettes as a smoking -cessation aid. This is consistent with the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP) guidelines on smoking cessation.

The decision to clarify the entry of nicotine in the Poisons Standard is one made by a senior medical officer in my Department in accordance with criteria, both set out in law and regulation. It is made independent of Ministers.

The RACGP guidelines recommend that all patients who smoke should be offered brief advice to quit smoking. In this regard GPs are well placed to support their patients to stop smoking. However the RACGP guidelines also state that nicotine-containing e-cigarettes are not first-line treatments for smoking cessation, and that the strongest evidence base for efficacy and safety is for TGA-approved smoking cessation therapies combined with behavioural support To date no e-cigarette product has been registered by the TGA.

At present smokers can seek support from their GP in quitting smoking and, when other cessation methods have been unsuccessful, consideration of whether a prescription for vaporiser nicotine may be appropriate. However a decision to prescribe medicines, including vaporiser nicotine, is a clinical judgement and the responsibility of the attending GP in consultation with the patient.

The Government continues to support a range of measures and services to help people to quit smoking that are evidence based. These include national media campaigns and support services such as the My QuitBuddy mobile app and online quit smoking information. Confidential support and advice about quilling is also available through Quitline on 13 78 48. Certain smoking cessation products that have been approved by the TGA are also subsidised on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme to provide financial support to help people quit smoking. These products include nicotine replacement therapies (in patch, gum and lozenge form) and other medications intended to assist those who are in the process of quitting smoking.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
COVID-19: Australians Overseas
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 17 February 2021 concerning petition number EN2029, calling on the Australian Government to introduce home quarantine for new arrivals and reconsider hotel quarantine fees.

The Government has taken a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, based on the latest and best medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee. Australia's strategy was based on the twin pillars of containment and capacity building. Our health emergency response measures were proportionate, scalable and tailored to the situation as it evolved. They have included closing borders and implementing quarantine periods; testing and contact tracing; physical distancing; and enhanced hygiene practices.

Our international travel restrictions control and manage the entry of COVID-19 in Australian territory and abroad. These travel measures also help lower the number of new cases to levels that can be effectively managed by our health and quarantine system. As part of Australia's strategy to combat the outbreak, hotel quarantine was mandated by the National Cabinet on 27 March 2020 and has proven to be highly successful—limiting the spread of COVID-19 in the Australian community when compared to many nations around the world. On 5 February 2021, the National Cabinet confirmed that hotel quarantine will continue to be the model used to quarantine returning Australians.

The Government is committed to bringing home Australians overseas who wish to return, including the most vulnerable Australians, and has worked hard to ensure both their safety and that of the broader Australian Community. The Government continues to review arrangements for quarantine facilities, including to work with states and territories on options to increase quarantine capacity at existing locations, such as the Centre for National Resilience in Howard Springs, to ensure that as many Australians can return home as is safely possible.

As described in the National Health Security Agreement, state and territory governments have primary operational responsibility for emergency management and public health in their respective jurisdictions. State and territory governments' actions, including any quarantine and self-isolation measures, are based on the medical advice from the respective Chief Health Officers and territories require returning Australians to pay a contribution to the cost of quarantine, and have processes in place for a fee waiver or reduction, upon application. An application for this will need to be made directly to the relevant state or territory government.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt

subdebateinfo.title: Mental Health: Medicinal use of Psychedelics

p.span: Mental Health: Medicinal use of Psychedelics
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 15 February 2021 concerning petition EN2067 to allow further scientific studies and trials of psychedelic substances within Australia.
The Australian Government is committed to supporting health and medical research and acknowledges the critical role research plays in contributing to a world-class health system.

As part of this commitment, the Government established the Medical Research Future Fund (MRFF) to provide grants of financial assistance to support health and medical research, improve health outcomes, quality of life and health system sustainability. In addition, mental health and suicide prevention is one of the Government's highest priorities.

The Government appreciates that while early results of trials of psychedelic substances in Australia and internationally are extremely encouraging, more research is needed before these approaches can be used by psychiatrists outside of controlled clinical trials.
The Government's $15 million Innovative Therapies for Mental Illness Grant Opportunity under the MRFF opened on 17 March 2021.

This grant opportunity will accelerate global efforts by supporting Australian-led research into the use of these approaches to combat resistant illnesses such as Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder, major depressive disorder, addiction disorders and eating disorders that are impacting the lives of so many Australians. More information about the grant opportunity is available through the GrantConnect website at: www.grants.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
Diabetes
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 15 February 2021 concerning petition EN2070—subsidy of Dexcom G6 (G6) continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) products.

The Australian Government is aware of the significant impact diabetes has on people with diabetes and their families, and is committed to working towards the broad prevention of the disease in the Australian community.
The CGM Initiative began in 2017, and provides fully subsidised CGM products to eligible people. Since that time, the eligibility criteria have been expanded to allow more people to benefit.
On 2 February 2020, I announced changes to the eligibility criteria that will result in more than 20,000 additional people having free access to CGM products.

The changes allow all people with type 1 diabetes aged 21 years or older who have concessional status to access CGM products, removing the requirement for these people to be assessed as having 'high clinical need'. This change will increase the total number of people eligible for CGM products to over 58,000.
The Government now provides fully subsidised CGM products to:
children and young people, under 21 years of age, with type 1 diabetes
children and young people with conditions very similar to type 1 diabetes, such as cystic fibrosis related diabetes and neonatal diabetes, who require insulin
women with type 1 diabetes who are planning for pregnancy, pregnant or immediately post-pregnancy
people with type 1 diabetes aged 21 years or older who have concessional status.

On 1 March 2020, the FreeStyle Libre Flash Glucose Monitoring system was added to the range of products subsidised under the CGM Initiative. This increases options for eligible people with diabetes in managing their condition.
Any decision to further expand the CGM Initiative would need to be considered against competing priorities in the Health Budget
A review of products subsidised under the CGM Initiative has recently commenced.

The review is being conducted to ensure that all CGM products are assessed on a consistent and transparent basis, and will inform future decision-making in relation to the CGM Initiative including consideration of new products. The review is expected to be completed in mid-2021.

G6 sensors and transmitters will be considered as part of this review. The Government provides considerable support to people with diabetes, including those people not eligible for the CGM Initiative. The Government subsidises essential medicines, like insulin, under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and diabetes-related products through the National Diabetes Services Scheme (NDSS).

The NDSS provides subsidised syringes and needles, blood glucose test strips, urine ketone test strips and insulin pump consumables to people with diabetes. It also provides educational and information services to assist in the best use of products and self-management of diabetes.
More information about the CGM Initiative is available on the NDSS website at: www.ndss.com.au/cgm.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
COVID-19: Australians Overseas
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 17 February 2021 concerning petition number EN2105 for alternative payments or options for quarantine.

The Australian Government is committed to bringing home Australians overseas who wish to return, including the most vulnerable Australians, and has worked hard to ensure both their safety and that of the broader Australian community.

To ensure the continued wellbeing and safety of all Australians, in line with the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee, all incoming travellers are required to undertake a 14 day supervised quarantine period in a designated hotel or accommodation facility at their port of entry. Quarantine arrangements are predominately a matter for state and territory governments as each jurisdiction is responsible for managing the COVID-19 response under its public health legislation.

To support returning Australians, the Government has provided funding for the Centre for National Resilience quarantine facility, located at Howard Springs Darwin, to increase the number of Australians who can return home, as well as providing funding under an agreement with Tasmania for the provision of repatriation quarantine services.

The Commonwealth is funding the full cost of quarantining vulnerable Australians on repatriation flights in the Northern Territory and Tasmania. It is estimated that these quarantine arrangements will cost approximately $8,000 per individual for their quarantine period. Travellers are asked to make a contribution towards the cost of their quarantine consistent with the fees applied by the relevant jurisdiction under their quarantine arrangements.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) have also made available a Hardship Program with emergency assistance for the most vulnerable Australian citizens overseas. The loans are intended to cover temporary accommodation and daily living expenses until they can return. Loans may also be available to help vulnerable Australians purchase tickets for commercial flights. Applications can be accessed on DFAT's website at: wwwsmarttraveller.gov.au using the search term `COVID-19/covid-19-overseas-financial¬assistance/application'.
The Government is in regular contact with states and territories on this important matter to ensure as many Australians can return home as is safely possible.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition EN2114 increasing Australia's donation and participation in the COVAX Facility.

The Australian Government has followed the situation across the world with great concern since the pandemic began and is taking active measures to help ensure that all countries have access to COVID-19 vaccines and are able to provide coverage to their populations.

Australia's three COVID-19 vaccine agreements (Pfizer/BioNTech, AstraZeneca/University of Oxford, and Novavax vaccines) allow us to support other countries as these vaccine doses can be donated or on-sold (with no mark-up) to other countries or international organisations (including the COVAX Facility) should these vaccines prove safe and effective, and units are available above domestic needs.

The petition details the amounts that Australia is providing to the COVAX Facility: that is $80 million to its Advanced Market Commitment (AMC) alongside an upfront payment of $123 million to enter into it as a self-financing economy. It is worth noting that Australia's contribution to the AMC puts us in the ten highest contributing countries. This will go a long way to supporting rapid, fair and equitable access to vaccines for 92 AMC-eligible lower and lower-middle countries.

The Government is strongly committed to ensuring that the COVAX Facility provides a global solution to the pandemic and is actively working with Gavi, the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations and the World Health Organization to ensure it succeeds. I was pleased to see the COVAX Facility commence its first delivery of COVID-19 vaccine doses on 24 February 2021 and am keenly following its progress as it makes its first distribution of doses across the world.

Further enhancing Australia's support for global solidarity in the face of the pandemic, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) on 31 October 2020 announced the creation of a regional vaccine access and health security initiative that will consist of a range of support mechanisms including supplying safe and effective vaccine doses and delivering technical support to our regional partners.

The Government has allocated $523.2 million to this initiative. The funding will help ensure that the countries of the Pacific and Timor-Leste are able to achieve full immunisation coverage, and will make a significant contribution toward meeting the needs of South East Asia. My Department is working closely with DFAT and appropriate overseas authorities in the Pacific and South East Asia to ensure that this funding ensures the best possible outcomes for health and wellbeing and that the vaccines are assessed rigorously to ensure that they are safe, efficacious and of a high quality.

The Government recognises the need for global cooperation. No country can truly emerge from this pandemic until all countries have access to safe, effective and affordable COVID-19 vaccines and we are committed to helping this occur.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
Medicinal Marijuana
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 15 February 2021 concerning a petition EN2122 requesting the rescheduling of medicinal cannabis from Schedule 8 to Schedule 4.

Medicinal cannabis products, including cannabidiol (CBD), can be legally accessed in Australia, but, as for all medicines, there are some regulatory controls around how this can occur to ensure safe and appropriate use.

Medicines and chemicals are classified into schedules according to the risk of harm and the level of access control required to protect public health and safety. Scheduling decisions are made by a senior medical officer at the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) within my Department, acting as a Delegate of the Secretary, and are not decisions of me as Minister for Health and Aged Care or the Australian Government. Scheduling decisions are published in the Poisons Standard. The implementation of the Poisons Standard, as it affects access and supply of medicines and poisons, is given legal effect through relevant state and territory drugs, poisons and controlled substances legislation.

The scheduling of medicinal cannabis has been frequently reviewed by the TGA and down-scheduled to facilitate access where appropriate, based on the risks to public health. CBD has been included under Schedule 4 (Prescription Only Medicine) of the Poisons Standard since 1 June 2015. In December 2020, the TGA Delegate made the decision to down-schedule low-dose CBD from Schedule 4 to Schedule 3, subject to a number of restrictions including dosage and pack size. As a result, since 1 February 2021, low-dose CBD products that have received TGA approval can be supplied over-the-counter by a pharmacist, without a prescription. There are currently no TGA approved products in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG) which meet the criteria for supply by a pharmacist. Any new over-the-counter CBD products would need to be individually evaluated by the TGA for quality, safety and effectiveness prior to inclusion in the ARTG.

The Schedule 4 entry for CBD in the Poisons Standard was also broadened to include use in research. Information concerning the reasons for these changes can be found at: www.tga.gov.au using the search term 'current poisons standard—cannabidoil'.
Cannabis and CBD that do not meet the Schedule 4 or Schedule 3 criteria are captured by entries in Schedule 8 (Controlled Drug) or Schedule 9 (Prohibited Substance) of the Poisons Standard.

Anyone wanting to make further changes to the scheduling of cannabis can make an application to the TGA to amend the Poisons Standard. There is no fee for lodging an application. The application form and information on how to lodge an application, with the required supporting evidence, can be found at: www.tga.gov.au using the search term 'amend poisons standard'. An email, letter or petition is insufficient to initiate the process to amend the Poisons Standard.
Further information concerning the scheduling process, including when and how matters are referred to the Advisory Committees, can be found at: www.tga.gov.au/scheduling-medicines-poisons.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning mandated medical interventions including mandatory COVID-19 vaccines: Petition EN2129. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is committed to providing a safe and effective vaccine to everyone living in Australia. The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with Australia's COVID-19 Vaccine National Rollout Strategy.

All decisions regarding the availability and rollout of COVID-19 vaccines and related policies are being taken based on expert advice and are contingent on any vaccine meeting all requirements with regard to testing and safety. The Therapeutics Goods Administration (TGA) rigorously assesses vaccines for safety, quality and effectiveness, before they can be legally supplied in Australia.

The TGA has now provisionally approved the Pfizer/BioNTech and Oxford/AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine for use in Australia. Both these vaccines have met the TGA's high standards for safety, quality and effectiveness, and are now being provided for free to Australia's priority groups.

The TGA is actively monitoring COVID-19 vaccine development that is occurring both in Australia and around the world and is meeting with pharmaceutical companies to discuss trial progress and the application process. The TGA is also part of a network of international regulators that meet regularly to discuss the development of COVID-19 vaccines.

After product registration, the TGA has an important role in batch release assessment and post-market surveillance to ensure the ongoing safety of the vaccine. Vaccines continue to be tested after their approval via additional clinical trials, surveillance and monitoring for side effects. Further information is available at: www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccines.

While there are no mandatory vaccines in Australia, it's possible that in the future, vaccination against COVID-19 might become a requirement for travel to certain destinations or for people working in certain high-risk workplaces. If this becomes the case, there will be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical reasons.

States and territories are able to issue public health directions requiring individuals to be vaccinated, as is the case where individuals entering aged care facilities must be vaccinated against influenza, except if vaccination is not available to the person or they have a medical contraindication. Similarly, workplace occupational health and safety is a matter for individual employers, providers and under model work health safety laws, employers are required to manage risks of viral exposure and infection, and persons at a workplace are required to comply, so far as they are reasonably able, with any reasonable instruction in that regard.
Australians are encouraged to rely on reputable sources of information to help them make informed choices and stay up-to-date.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning Petition number: EN2151 and the restrictions placed on those who decide not to receive the COVID-19 vaccine. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation in that it is a safe and effective way to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death. While the Government supports immunisation, it is not mandatory and individuals maintain the option to choose not to vaccinate.

We understand that some people in the community may be hesitant about vaccination, especially in these unprecedented times. We are listening to the concerns of Australians and will encourage uptake by communicating about the safety, science and benefits of immunisation.

The TGA has now provisionally approved the Pfizer/BioNTech and Oxford/AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine for use in Australia. Both these vaccines have met the TGA's high standards for safety, quality and effectiveness, and are now being provided for free to Australia's priority groups.

While there are no mandatory vaccines in Australia, it's possible that in the future, vaccination against COVID-19 might become a requirement for travel to certain destinations or for people working in certain high-risk workplaces. If this becomes the case, there will be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical reasons.

Workplace occupational health and safety is a matter for individual employers and providers. Employers are required by work health safety laws to manage risks of viral exposure and infection, and persons at a workplace are required to comply, so far as they are reasonably able, with any reasonable instruction in that regard. What is reasonably practical will depend on the particular workplace. The suitability of other control measures (e.g. physical distancing rules, hygiene and cleaning protocols, screens or other infrastructure, remote working arrangements) to eliminate or minimise risk would also need to be considered.
Australians are encouraged to rely on reputable sources of information to help them make informed choices and stay up-to-date.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning the discrimination against those who decline the COVID-19 vaccine Petition number: EN2167. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is committed to providing a safe and effective vaccine to everyone living in Australia. The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with Australia's COVID-19 Vaccine National Rollout Strategy.
COVID-19 vaccines will be voluntary and free and available to all people living in Australia.

While there are no mandatory vaccines in Australia, it's possible that in the future, vaccination against COVID-19 might become a requirement for travel to certain destinations or for people working in certain high-risk workplaces. If this becomes the case, there will be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical reasons.

If people choose not to have a COVID-19 vaccine, this will not affect their family's eligibility for Family Tax Benefit Part A or childcare fee assistance which only includes National Immunisation Program vaccines for those aged younger than 20.

States and territories are able to issue public health directions requiring individuals to be vaccinated, as is the case where individuals entering aged care facilities must be vaccinated against influenza, except if vaccination is not available to the person or they have a medical contraindication.

Similarly, workplace occupational health and safety is a matter for individual employers, providers and under model work health safety laws, employers are required to manage risks of viral exposure and infection, and persons at a workplace are required to comply, so far as they are reasonably able, with any reasonable instruction in that regard. What is reasonable for employers to do, and what is reasonable for someone to comply with, depends on the circumstances. For example, the suitability of other control measures (e.g. physical distancing rules, hygiene and cleaning protocols, screens or other infrastructure) to eliminate or minimise risk would need to be considered.

Where measures other than vaccination are appropriate to address work health and safety risks, or where there are medical reasons for refusing vaccination (e.g. for people whose health would be at risk from vaccination because of allergic reaction or adverse immune response), directions requiring vaccination may not be reasonable.
Australians are encouraged to rely on reputable sources of information to help them make informed choices and stay up to date.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning Petition number: EN2175 the right to choose medical interventions and personal choice to get the COVID-19 vaccine. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is committed to providing a safe and effective vaccine to everyone living in Australia. The Government is a strong supporter of immunisation in that it is a safe and effective way to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death. While the Government supports immunisation, it is not mandatory and individuals maintain the option to choose not to vaccinate.

We understand that some people in the community may be hesitant about vaccination, especially in these unprecedented times. We are listening to the concerns of Australians and will encourage uptake by communicating about the safety, science and benefits of immunisation.

The rollout of the COVID-19 vaccine in Australia is being guided by the medical experts of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI). ATAGI has developed resources for patients and providers to help with providing informed consent to get a COVID-19 vaccination, including an optional consent form. As with all other vaccines, valid consent is required before administering each dose of the COVID-19 vaccine

COVID-19 vaccines will not be mandatory in Australia, but it's important that everyone who can get it, does get it, to help keep themselves and others safe. Achieving community protection through immunisation would see people connecting with family and friends, transitioning back to their workplaces, and with time, a restart of our job market—all vital components to improving the lives of many Australians.

All decisions regarding the availability and rollout of COVID-19 vaccines and related policies are being taken based on expert advice and are contingent on any vaccine meeting all requirements with regard to testing and safety. The Therapeutics Goods Administration (TGA) rigorously assesses vaccines for safety, quality and effectiveness, before they can be legally supplied in Australia.

The TGA has now provisionally approved the Pfizer/BioNTech and Oxford/AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine for use in Australia. Both these vaccines have met the TGA's high standards for safety, quality and effectiveness, and are now being provided for free to Australia's priority groups.

While there are no mandatory vaccines in Australia, it's possible that in the future, vaccination against COVID-19 might become a requirement for travel to certain destinations or for people working in certain high-risk workplaces. If this becomes the case, there will be exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical reasons.
Australians are encouraged to rely on reputable sources of information to help them make informed choices and stay up-to-date.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
Medicinal Marijuana
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 15 February 2021 concerning a petition EN2188 requesting that medicinal cannabis be made more accessible and affordable.
Medicinal cannabis products, including cannabidiol (CBD), can be legally accessed in Australia. However, there are some regulatory controls to ensure safe and appropriate use.

In general, medicines marketed in Australia must be entered on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG) which is regulated by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), part of my Department. Currently, there are two medicinal cannabis products included on the ARTG. Sativex (nabiximols) is used to treat certain patients with multiple sclerosis and Epidyolex (CBD) is used for patients with certain epileptic conditions. All other medicinal cannabis products are considered 'unapproved' medicines.
Pharmaceutical companies make their own decisions about commercial matters.

The Australian Government cannot compel them to make submissions to the TGA for registration on the ARTG or to the PBAC for subsidy. The Government also has no control over the price charged for products supplied in the private market. A pharmaceutical company may be willing to supply it at a reduced cost through a 'compassionate access' program. Decisions to grant access to such programs are solely up to the company. Further to this, some states are subsidising the cost to some patients through access programs or clinical trials.

Importantly, unapproved medicinal cannabis products have not been assessed by the TGA with respect to safety, quality and effectiveness. Any Australian doctor (including GPs, specialists and non-specialists) can apply to the TGA, using a simple online form via the Special Access Scheme or the Authorised Prescriber pathways, to prescribe medicinal cannabis' if they feel it is appropriate for their patient.

SAS decisions are almost always made within 48 hours. Further information is available on the TGA website at: www.tga.gov.au/medicinal-cannabis, by phone on 1800 020 653 or email at: medicinal.cannabisk-thealth.gov.au.

Commonwealth funding for medicines occurs through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS). The Government cannot subsidise a medicine for a particular condition unless the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) makes a recommendation in favour of subsidy.
The PBAC only considers medicines which are registered on the ARTG for PBS listing.
The PBAC is an independent, expert advisory body comprising doctors, other health professionals and a consumer representative.

Encouragingly, the cost of medicinal cannabis products appears to be falling rapidly. In September 2020, a study conducted by FreshLeaf Analytics showed product prices have continued a rapid downward trend with the minimum recommended retail price sitting at one quarter of the market price in 2017. It is hoped that the increased number of growers being licensed by the Government will also improve affordability for patients. In November 2020, for the first time, a private health insurer announced that it would provide benefits for treatments using medicinal cannabis.

The circumstances under which medicines can be accessed by the Australian public are determined through a classification process known as 'scheduling'. Medicines and chemicals are classified into schedules, which are published in the Poisons Standard. Classification is based on the risk of harm and the level of access control required to protect public health and safety. Anyone can make an application to amend the current Poisons Standard.

My Department has recently taken steps to facilitate greater access to low-dose CBD through the scheduling process. On 15 December 2020, the decision was made to down-schedule certain low-dose CBD preparations from Schedule 4 (Prescription Medicine) to Schedule 3 (Pharmacist Only Medicine).

The decision allows pharmacists to supply TGA-approved low-dose CBD-containing products (up to a maximum of 150 mg/day) for use in adults over-the-counter, without a prescription. Currently there are no TGA-approved products on the ARTG that meet the Schedule 3 criteria, but companies can lodge an application for registration of such a product and I understand that companies are meeting with the TGA to discuss the potential applications.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning how the international travel ban has impacted the mental health of Australian residents and citizens: Petition EN2199. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government recognises that this is a challenging time for all Australians and understands the wish for a resumption of international travel. The Government recognises the impact of these measures on individuals, families and businesses.

The Government is committed to providing a safe and effective vaccine to everyone living in Australia. The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with Australia's COVID-19 Vaccine National Rollout Strategy that sets out the priority populations for the first vaccinations and the phases in which the vaccine doses will be made available in Australia.

While the Government is making every effort to vaccinate all Australians as quickly as possible global demand for vaccines is high. That's why the Government is prioritising certain population groups, ensuring the most vulnerable are protected first.

The priority groups were determined in line with advice from the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI). ATAGI has advised that quarantine and border workers, high-risk frontline healthcare workers, aged care and disability care residents, and residential aged care and disability care workers should be vaccinated as a priority.

A significant proportion of new COVID-19 cases in Australia are related to international travel. The number of new cases internationally continues to grow and the risk of cases being imported by Australians from international travel remains unacceptably high. The purpose of the outbound and inbound travel restrictions is to control and manage the entry of COVID-19 in Australian territory and abroad. While our health resources are prioritising a response to the domestic situation, we cannot risk adding an additional burden through an easing of international travel restrictions and potentially importing additional cases through returning Australians.

Nonetheless, the Government recognises citizens and permanent residents may have exceptional circumstances or compelling reasons for needing to leave Australian territory. The exemption process overseen by the Department of Home Affairs and ensures that the travel restriction is no more restrictive or intrusive than required in the current global pandemic. Further information about applying for an exemption can be found at: covid19.homeaffairs gov.au/leaving-australia.

Australians choosing to travel overseas should also be mindful that foreign countries may have diminished capacity as a result of the pandemic, including in relation to health systems and consular assistance. Australians overseas may not be able to access health care or diplomatic support. There is also risk of Australians being caught offshore for longer than planned, increasing their exposure to, and risk of, contracting COVID-19. This is a challenging time with significant uncertainty, particularly for people wishing to travel overseas.

The Government regularly reviews the emergency directions, including the international travel restrictions, to ensure their appropriateness in terms of global and local epidemiology and is committed to opening up both domestic travel within Australia and travel with other low risk countries as soon as the health advice says it is safe to do so. This will be based on an assessment of a country's current transmission status, as well as their ability to detect and manage cases.

The COVID-19 pandemic has greatly changed the way we live. To help keep us safe, it is likely that our lives will be different for a while. When we aren't able to see our friends and family regularly, it can be harder to keep on top of how we're feeling. Being aware of how you're feeling and knowing what you can do to look after your mental wellbeing is an important part of staying healthy during this challenging time. There are also a number of online and chat support services at: www.beyondblue.com.au and at: www.headtohealth.gov.au.
I also encourage you to monitor my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au to stay up-to-date on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout as well as updates on international travel restrictions.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
Health Care
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 16 March 2021 concerning Petition EN2276, to allow women to book surgical sterilisation through the public health system without a referral.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that all Australians are able to access timely and affordable, high quality health care by providing Medicare benefits for services listed on the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) and free hospital services for public patients in public hospitals.

I appreciate the concerns raised in the petition seeking to allow women to book surgical sterilisation through the public health care system without a referral. The responsibility for management of the public hospital system rests with the state and territory governments. As such you may wish to bring this petition to their attention.

Specialist services from all eligible Australians requires a referral from a GP and the Government has no plans to change these arrangements. This would apply to the range of items available within the MBS to assist with the payment for female sterilisation.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
Health Care
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence concerning petition number EN2334 to the House of Representatives, which requests that Medicare (or another public system) cover the costs of primary or essential dental care for all Australians.

The Australian Government understands the importance of good oral health and its role in supporting general health and wellbeing. The Government is aware of the barriers to accessing affordable dental services and supports a range of targeted programs for adults and children so they can access care.

The Government is assisting children to access basic dental services through the Child Dental Benefits Schedule (CDBS). Eligible children aged two to 17 years can access the CDBS for up to $1013 in benefits for basic dental services over two calendar years.

On 10 June 2020, the Government announced $107.8 million for a one year extension to the National Partnership Agreement on Public Dental Services for Adults (NPA). The extension will provide funding to states and territories to deliver additional services to around 180,000 public dental patients. The current NPA is providing the states and territories with $458.1 million from 1 January 2017 to 30 June 2021 for additional services to around 763,000 adult public dental patients.

Government support is designed to provide additional services on top of those funded by states and territories. States and territories are responsible for the delivery of public dental services including funding, planning, co-payments and management of waiting lists.

The Government also provides support to states and territories through the National Health Reform Agreement (NHRA). In 2018-19 the Commonwealth provided $193.3 million through the NHRA. This included $40 million for admitted dental services, and $153.3 million for specialist outpatient dental services. More detail on Government funding for dental services is provided in the table below.

p.span: Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
E-Cigarettes
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 22 March 2021 concerning Petition EN2369 seeking a 'reconsideration of the decision to implement a prescription-only model for access to e-cigarettes, and to allow for the easy importation of vaping liquids by nicotine addicts'.

The decision of the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) is independent of Australian Government and it is legally binding. The decision follows extensive public consultation, and it is consistent with the existing ban in all states and territories on the sale of nicotine e-cigarettes without a doctor's prescription (and the prohibition on possession in all states and territories except for South Australia). The TGA's reasons for its decision include the particular concern for the attractiveness of these products to adolescents, and the recent rapid increase in their use by adolescents and their susceptibility to nicotine dependence.

Having regard to the concerns expressed in the petition about its potential effects, I note that a number of steps are being taken to support the effective implementation of the TGA's decision. In addition to working with peak bodies including The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia, and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia to support the preparation of relevant clinical and practical guidelines, my Department is publishing other educative materials for health practitioners. The TGA will also publish communications for affected consumers including in social media channels, and in the form of animated videos. There are two tranches of communication activities planned for 2021—the first later this month, and the second in August about six weeks before the implementation of the TGA's decision.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
Health Care
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 22 March 2021 concerning petition EN2372—request to extend eligibility criteria for the Continuous Glucose Monitoring (CGM) Initiative to include all Australians with type 1 diabetes.

The Australian Government is aware of the significant impact diabetes has on people with diabetes and their families, and is committed to working towards the broad prevention of the disease in the Australian community.
The CGM Initiative began in 2017, and provides fully subsidised CGM products to eligible people. Since that time, the eligibility criteria have been expanded to allow more people to benefit.
On 2 February 2020, I announced changes to the eligibility criteria that will result in more than 20,000 additional people having free access to CGM products.

The changes allow all people with type 1 diabetes aged 21 years or older who have concessional status to access CGM products, removing the requirement for these people to be assessed as having 'high clinical need'. This change will increase the total number of people eligible for CGM products to over 58,000.
The Government now provides fully subsidised CGM products to:
children and young people, under 21 years of age, with type 1 diabetes
children and young people with conditions very similar to type 1 diabetes, such as cystic fibrosis related diabetes and neonatal diabetes, who require insulin
women with type 1 diabetes who are planning for pregnancy, pregnant or immediately post-pregnancy
people with type 1 diabetes aged 21 years or older who have concessional status.

On 1 March 2020, the FreeStyle Libre Flash Glucose Monitoring system was added to the range of products subsidised under the CGM Initiative. This increases options for eligible people with diabetes in managing their condition.
Any decision to further expand the CGM Initiative would need to be considered against competing priorities in the Health Budget.

A review of products subsidised under the CGM Initiative has recently commenced. The review is being conducted to ensure that all CGM products are assessed on a consistent and transparent basis, and will inform future decision-making in relation to the CGM Initiative including consideration of new products. The review is expected to be completed in mid-2021.

The Government provides considerable additional support to people with diabetes, including those people not eligible for the CGM Initiative. The Government subsidises essential medicines, like insulin, under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and diabetes-related products through the National Diabetes Services Scheme (NDSS).

The NDSS provides subsidised syringes and needles, blood glucose test strips, urine ketone test strips and insulin pump consumables to people with diabetes. It also provides educational and information services to assist in the best use of products and self-management of diabetes.
More information about the CGM Initiative is available on the NDSS website at: www.ndss.com.au/cgrn.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
COVID 19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 13 May 2021 concerning petition Number EN2463.

The Australian Government does not consider vaccination status to be a complete or sufficient substitute for other biosecurity measures, such as quarantine and testing requirements, which remain in place to minimise COVID-19 health risks associated with international travel.
This position aligns with the current advice provided by the World Health Organization (WHO) and takes into account the following key considerations:
there remains paucity of data as to whether the COVID-19 vaccines prevent vaccinated individuals transmitting the virus to others

until there is a better understanding on whether the vaccines can effectively minimise transmission, the purpose for rolling out vaccination in the short term is to protect individuals from developing disease
vaccination should not be viewed as a panacea or a complete substitute for other public health interventions, rather viewed as supplementary to other measures
Australia will continue to require other measures, such as quarantine, for international arrivals

national recommendations for air crew are based on the advice provided by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC), however the implementation of these recommendations is at the discretion of the relevant state/territory government.

This position is continually reviewed according to expert advice provided by AHPPC, and taking into consideration up-to-date international public health information outlined by WHO.
