If favourable data on vaccination continues to be published over time, then this may trigger a decision on a possible scale back of other public-health interventions.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, MrHunt
Food Labelling
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 24 May 2021 concerning a petition, numbered EN2612, requesting that the House of Representatives introduce an overseeing body to govern the issuance of halal certifications. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention and I apologise for the delay in providing this response.

I acknowledge that this petition, presented in the House of Representatives on 24 May 2021, received 83 signatures and that these signatories are concerned that halal certification for domestic red meat sale is being issued with inadequate scrutiny.

The Australian Government's only role in halal certification is in the export of red meat through the Australian Government Authorised Halal Program (AGAHP), which is administered by the Department of Agriculture, Water and the Environment and is underpinned by Federal legislation, operating in all export registered meat establishments producing halal meat. The government is not involved in domestic halal certification, which occurs through third-party certification.

Third-party certification is a mechanism employed by business owners to promote particular product attributes to consumers, such as red meat classed as halal. Certifiers can licence their logo or trademark to businesses that meet given standards, confirming that products bearing the mark possess the marketed attributes. It is the responsibility of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) to investigate claims of misleading or deceptive third-party certification of halal food under the Australian Consumer Law.

Australian and State and Territory Government Ministers for Consumer Affairs considered this issue in 2018 and agreed the Australian Consumer Law was capable of addressing misleading or deceptive third-party certification of food claims and that no further regulatory intervention was required.

Halal assurance processes for food are implemented by individual food production businesses and operate under commercial arrangements. The decision by a food company to obtain or display halal certification is a voluntary business decision.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture and Northern Australia, MrLittleproud
Immigration
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 9 August 2021 enclosing petition EN2681, with 11 signatures, concerning reducing permanent immigration levels to 70,000-80,000 migrants per year.

Australia's Migration Program settings are designed to maximise economic prosperity, national wellbeing and social cohesion by focussing on attracting and selecting highly skilled, young migrants, who deliver higher workforce participation rates, and productivity growth. This results in positive flow-on effects for the living standards of all Australians.

The Australian Government's Migration Program also considers the long-term population impacts on state and territory planning and infrastructure. To this end, in 2019, the Government made a series of changes to address the issue of sustainable population growth across Australia, including the establishment of a Centre of Population (the Centre) within the Department of the Treasury, in recognition of the need for a single point of analysis to assess, monitor and project changes to Australia's population.

These initiatives are further supported by the publication of Australia's first Population Statement, which can be accessed online: https://population.gov.au/publications/publications-population-statement.html.

The size and composition of Australia's permanent Migration Program is set on an annual basis. In designing the annual Migration Program, the Department of Home Affairs undertakes a planning process which involves a range of consultation activities with key stakeholders, Commonwealth agencies, state and territory governments, and the public. These consultations seek to better understand the needs and concerns of stakeholders and their views help inform the size and composition of the annual Migration Program.

To support the development of the 2021-22 Migration Program, the Department released a discussion paper titled Planning Australia's 2021-22 Migration Program in January 2021, and subsequently received and considered 193 public submissions.

In addition, formal discussions were undertaken with key stakeholders between December 2020 and January 2021, including participants in the migration advice industry, industry and community groups, academics and researchers, Government representatives, and state and territory government representatives.

I encourage the petitioner(s) to participate in Planning Australia's 2022-23 Migration Program through the current public consultation process and call for submissions. Further details about how to make a submission are available at: https://www.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-and-support/how-to-engage-us/consultations/australias-22-23-migration-program.
Thank you for bringing petition EN2681 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Russian Crimean Cannons
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 9 August 2021 concerning Petition Number EN2774 which requests the return of the stolen Crimean Cannons to the Russian Federation via Vladivostok. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

From the information provided, the Petition appears to relate to cannons captured by the British Army during the 1853-1856 Crimean War, and then brought to Australia prior to Federation by regiments of the British Army. The Petition also refers to diplomatic cables exchanged between the Australian and British Governments during the First World War, in which the Australian Government reportedly undertook to return the cannon in question. Unfortunately, the Petition identifies neither the cannons in question, nor the diplomatic cables that discuss the Australian Government's intended course of action during the First World War.

A number of cannons dating from the Crimean War are currently held on the Defence Estate as well as in state parks and gardens. However, without further information it is unclear if any of these are the cannon referred to in this petition. Should the

Petitioners be in a position to clarify that information, then the matter can be further investigated. Department of Defence's initial assessment indicates that any subsequent action will likely require wider government, including state authorities, determination regarding any Crimean War cannons in their possession.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Dutton
Housing Affordability
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 9 August 2021 to the Hon Michael Sukkar MP, Minister for Housing, regarding petition EN2793 about tiny homes. This petition was referred to me as I am responsible for building policy matters. I note the petition and acknowledge the increasing popularity of tiny homes to provide innovative and affordable housing solutions.

The Australian Government is delivering a range of measures to boost the supply of housing and create the right incentives to improve housing outcomes for all Australians, especially those most in need. Measures include $1 billion in funding for the National Housing Infrastructure Facility to fund critical infrastructure to unlock new housing supply, particularly affordable housing, and helping eligible home buyers to purchase their first home sooner through the First Home Loan Deposit Scheme.

While these measures from the Australian Government are helping make housing more affordable for Australians, specific regulatory responsibility for building matters rests directly with state and territory governments. This includes regulatory responsibilities for tiny homes, given that the planning and land use regimes of state, territory and local governments play a role in determining what buildings can be built and the nature of their use.

The Commonwealth facilitates state and territory cooperation on building matters through the Building Ministers' Meeting (BMM), which I chair. The BMM supports greater national consistency in building standards by co-funding the Australian Building Codes Board which maintains the National Construction Code implemented by all states and territories.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Industry Development, Senator Duniam
Veterans
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 23 August 2021 concerning Petition EN2829—the use of epidemiological literature in the determination of the Statements of Principles (SOPs) by the Repatriation Medical Authority (RMA).

The SOP system was created in 1994 to overcome non-experts such as tribunals making uninformed judgements about complex medical-scientific evidence. The SOPs contain factors setting out the causal links between the circumstances of service and a medical condition, be it a disease or injury. These factors are drawn in reliance on the totality of the sound medical scientific evidence (SMSE) concerning the causes of the particular condition. The significant benefit is that claimant veterans or members merely have to establish the facts of service consistent with any cause outlined in the SOP factors in order to succeed with their claim.

Section 5AB of the Veterans Entitlements Act 1986 limits SMSE to medical science that has been published in peer review medical or scientific publications or is in accordance with generally accepted medical practice, and in respect of the causes of a particular medical condition, to information that, 'meets the applicable criteria for assessing causation currently applied in the field of epidemiology'.

This means the RMA currently has regard to standard epidemiological criteria to assess causation. A good example is the criteria under the Bradford Hill formulation which are used in assessing the relationship between an exposure and the development of a condition. They include matters such as the strength of an association, its biological plausibility and the dose-response relationship. All these criteria involve inherent qualitative judgements and always require consideration of whether any suggested relationship is the result of chance, bias or confounding.

The RMA considers these matters relying on studies in peer reviewed journals. Those studies range from systematic reviews of previous research and studies involving a cohort of subjects over a long period down to individual case reports. The RMA considers and evaluates the effect of the entirety of these studies in determining the factors included in the SOPs.

The use of epidemiology to create binding criteria for medical causation in a compensation system was a novel concept in 1994 and the inaugural Chairperson of the RMA, Professor Ken Donald, opined about this matter in a 1998 forum. However, he concluded that:

span.span: there are many more social purposes for the use of epidemiology than epidemiologists thought of when they were building up this literature, and actually I think that we
re dealing with a model here that
s going to become used and used and used over the dec

p.span: From its inception to 30 June 2021, the RMA has determined some 2,703 SOPs, and there are now 712 SOPs for 356 diseases and injuries extant on the Federal Register of Legislation. They are specifically referred to in the New Zealand Veterans' Support Act 2014 and they are used extensively by the Canadian Veterans Review and Appeal Board.
The Productivity Commission in its review of veterans' compensation, A Better Way to Support Veterans, 27 June 2019, endorsed the SOP system as 'robust and effective' and concluded that:

span.span: it promotes consistency, predictability and transparency and draws a clear line between accepted and non-accepted conditions, based on sound medical scientific evidence

p.span: The use of epidemiological criteria to review material otherwise published under a standard of peer review, to determine SOP factors consistent with sound medical practice, results in a 'fit for purpose' outcome for veterans and members.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans Affairs, Mr Gee
Veterans
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 23 August 2021 regarding petition number EN2835. The petition suggests the power of the Repatriation Medical Authority (the Authority) to determine Statements of Principles (SOPs) is unfairly weighted against those with entitlements under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA) and the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004 (MRCA), and that the Authority should be required to issue a statement of reasons for each SOP which it determines.

1 disagree there is an unfair weighting as suggested, and neither do I believe extending the requirement to publish reasons would add to the Authority's decision making processes. 1 have confidence the Authority's processes when determining SOPs are transparent and open to scrutiny. I take this view on the basis of the considerations which follow.

The Authority is open and transparent about the evidence on which it relies when determining SOPs. I am advised whenever the Authority determines a SOP, it publishes an updated reference list on its website for the relevant condition. Each reference list sets out the sound medical-scientific evidence which the Authority has considered in determining the SOPs for that condition.

Moreover, I am advised under section 1961 of the VEA, a person eligible to claim a Disability Pension under either the VEA or the MRCA, or an organisation which represents veterans and their families, is entitled to reasonable access to any document containing information considered by the Authority for the purposes of an investigation. This access is provided free of charge. When the proactive publication of reference lists and the legal right to access information are considered together, it is apparent the veteran community is readily able to obtain and scrutinise the material and evidence upon which the Authority relies in determining SOPs.

I am advised before making its decisions, the Authority actively seeks input from the veteran community, as well as those with expertise in various fields of medical science. There are various ways in which the Authority invites contributions from stakeholders. The Authority maintains an up-to-date website (www.rma.gov.au) with information about its activities, investigations and decisions, as well as a subscriber service and 'contact us' facility on the website, through which feedback and comments can be provided. It is recommended that any person wishing to be informed about the Authority's investigations or decisions, register for the subscriber service through the website.

For those who do not wish to register for the subscriber service, the 'What's New' page of the website is updated with details of the decisions made at the most recent meeting of the Authority, including new investigations which the Authority will undertake. Updates from previous meetings are also available on this page.

In addition to the extensive information available on the Authority's website, a notice of investigation is advertised in the Government Notices Gazette available at www.legislation.gov.au for each new investigation the Authority commences. Each notice of investigation invites submissions from members of the veteran community or people who have expertise in a field relevant to the investigation.

When commencing and finalising investigations, I am advised the Authority formally writes to each of the major national ex-service organisations (ES0s), as well as the Repatriation Commission, Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission, Veterans' Review Board, Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Specialist Medical Review Council. Further, whenever the Authority proposes to repeal and not reissue a particular SOP, or to remove one or more factors from a SOP, the Authority formally consults with the same group of ES0s, the Repatriation Commission and the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission. The purpose of this consultation is to provide these organisations with an opportunity to be heard in relation to the repeal of the SOPs, or the removal of factors, as the case may be.

In making its decisions, Authority upholds the principles of natural justice. Natural justice requires an opportunity for a fair and unbiased hearing be given to a person before a decision is made which affects that person. As noted above, members of the veteran community and experts in fields relevant to the Authority's investigations are invited to provide submissions for consideration during an investigation. I am advised these submissions are taken into account in a fair and unbiased way_

SOPs are legislative instruments which must be tabled, along with explanatory statements, in both the House of Representatives and the Senate. The instruments are subject to disallowance under section 42 of the Legislation Act 2003, and in this way, the Authority's determinations are subjected to parliamentary scrutiny.

In closing, I draw to your attention there are a number of situations in which the Authority is currently required to provide a written statement of reasons. In particular, the Authority must give reasons when it decides:
not to determine a SOP (subsection 1968(6), VEA);
not to determine a SOP for a condition which it has previously investigated or amend an existing SOP (subsection 196B(9), VEA);
not to carry out an investigation for a condition which it has investigated within the preceding 12 months (subsection 196C(4), VEA); or
not to carry out an investigation for lack of grounds or lack of sufficient relevant information (section 196CA, VEA).

It may be seen the obligation to give reasons only arises when the Authority declines to exercise its powers. This is entirely appropriate. By contrast, when the Authority exercises its powers, the result is a legislative instrument which facilitates veterans access to entitlements for service-related conditions. In light of the transparent way in which the Authority exercises its powers when determining SOPs, it is not apparent there would be any additional benefit in extending the obligation to give reasons, as suggested by the petitioners.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of the petitioners to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
from the Minister for Veterans Affairs, Mr Gee
Housing Affordability
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN2854 to eliminate all taxes and stamp duties for modular, prefabricated, fold-out engineered homes.

The majority of property taxation is state-based taxation including stamp duties and land taxes. State taxes are a matter for the state and territory governments. The Australian Government does not have the authority to change these taxes or to direct the state and territory governments to do so.

The Goods and Services Tax (GST) may apply to modular, prefabricated, fold-out engineered homes. The GST applies broadly to goods and services with a limited number of exemptions in areas such as food and education. Every additional exemption adds to the complexity of the GST system and increases the compliance costs of taxpayers, which are passed on to consumers. Additional exemptions would create new anomalies and lead to calls for further exemptions.

The GST is levied by the Australian Government on behalf of the states and territories. The revenue from the GST goes to the states and territories and provides a secure source of funding to assist them in providing essential services, such as health and education.

Under the Intergovernmental Agreement on Federal Financial Relations and Commonwealth legislation, a change to the rate or base of the GST would need to be supported by all of the states and territories. It may also require the passage of relevant legislation by both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 23 August 2021 enclosing Petition EN2856 with 8240 signatures, seeking prioritisation of family members of those living in Australia for travel to Australia as part of the National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response.

Australia's current travel restriction policy has played a key foundational role underpinning management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia and were implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

As announced by the Australian Government on 22 October 2021, parents of adult Australian citizens and permanent residents will be considered immediate family for travel exemption purpose. Parental relationships for the purpose of a travel exemption to travel to Australia include biological, adoptive, legal, step-parent, and parents-in-law.

Applications for a travel exemption to have the relationship confirmed can be submitted through the Department of Home Affairs' Travel Exemption Portal. Further information about travel exemptions for parents is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/immediate-family-australian-citizens-or-permanent-residents-or-new-zealand-citizens-usually-resident-australia.

Additionally, before travelling, parents must also have a valid passport, a valid visa for travel to Australia and be fully vaccinated with a recognised vaccine. These requirements will be checked by the airline before boarding.

In line with the National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response, as Australia progresses through the key vaccination thresholds, the Government is finalising plans so Australian families can be reunited, temporary visa holders including family members of those in Australia can return, and we can work towards welcoming tourists back to our shores.

I acknowledge that since the travel restrictions were introduced in March 2020, many people with immediate and extended families overseas have missed significant life events and therefore would like to extend my thanks to these families for their patience and their sacrifice over this period.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2856 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Asylum Seekers
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021 enclosing Petition EN2921, with 19 signatures, concerning the situation in South Africa. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Australia has a long tradition of resettling refugees and people in humanitarian need from around the world and is one of the world's most generous contributors to international refugee resettlement efforts, successfully settling more than 920,000 refugees and others in humanitarian need since the end of the Second World War.

Australia's offshore Humanitarian Program is designed primarily to assist people who have left their home country because of persecution or severe human rights abuses, and who have no options for return or for resettlement in another country. In limited circumstances, resettlement places may also be available for people subject to persecution who have remained in their home country. Any person who believes they meet the requirements for a humanitarian visa and wishes to seek Australia's assistance can make an application. Each application is considered on its individual merit using current and comprehensive information on circumstances in the relevant country.

While most applicants have suffered some form of discrimination or persecution, the limited number of visas available and the high demand for these places means that priority is given to those people outside their home country, assessed as refugees by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and formally referred to Australia for resettlement, and applicants proposed by a close family member in Australia.

In addition to the Humanitarian Program, the Australian Government operates a Migration Program for people who wish to migrate on the basis of their skills or family relationships in Australia. The Migration Program seeks to facilitate the reunification of family members of Australian citizens, permanent residents and eligible New Zealand citizens (Australian sponsors). Some categories of visas, including Family visas, require sponsorship from eligible Australian citizens, permanent residents and eligible New Zealand citizens. For further information on temporary or permanent migration to Australia, please refer to the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/bringing-someone/bringing-partner-or-family.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2921 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Eczema
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN2934—requesting to fund research into Topical Steroid Withdrawal (TSW) in Australia.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of health and medical research. Through the $20 billion Medical Research Future Fund (MRFF), the Government is improving the health and wellbeing of Australians by providing a long-term, sustainable source of funding for research that aims to improve health outcomes, quality of life and health system sustainability. Research into TSW may align with several existing MRFF grant opportunities.

Through the MRFF 2020 Quality, Safety and Effectiveness of Medicine Use and Medicine Intervention by Pharmacists Grant Opportunity, the Government is investing $11.7 million in medical research for pharmacists to support patients with the safe use of medicines. This support recognises that all Australians will take some form of medication during their lives, but using medicines are not without risk. Research funded will tackle some of the common prescription drug issues and improve the use of medicines.

Under the MRFF, $614 million has been committed to the Clinical Trials Activity initiative. A significant proportion of this funding is allocated to research on rare cancers, rare diseases and unmet medical needs, of which TSW could be considered. Information on MRFF grant opportunities is available at: www.health.gov.au/mrff, including a list of MRFF funded research projects.

Outside of research, several topical corticosteroid formulations are currently subsidised through the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) as Restricted and Authority Required benefits. The current PBS listings restrict the use of topical corticosteroids to the treatment of corticosteroid-responsive dermatoses and moderate to severe scalp psoriasis under certain conditions. Where increased quantities of these formulations are required, the PBS listings limit the maximum quantity that may be supplied based on the proportion of body surface area affected by the condition.

The PBS listing of topical corticosteroids reflects the evidence that has been considered by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) to date. The PBAC is an independent expert body which advises the Government about PBS matters. The Government cannot list a medicine on the PBS unless PBAC makes a recommendation in favour of listing.

Medication safety is a core component of the Quality Use of Medicines objective of Australia's National Medicines Policy. To help support the quality use of medicines in Australia, the Government provides funding to NPS MedicineWise to provide education and support for health professionals and consumers to promote the safe and effective use of medicines in Australia.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) assesses and approves therapeutic goods for use in Australia. The TGA applies a risk-based approach to ensure medicines supplied in Australia meet high standards of quality, safety, and efficacy, and that the benefits to consumers outweigh any risks associated with the use of medicines. The TGA considers the benefit-risk balance for the intended population of the medicine. At the population level, when used appropriately, evidence supports the overall benefits of topical corticosteroids in treating inflammatory skin conditions such as atopic eczema. However, all medicines have risks. Decisions around the benefit-risk balance of using a particular medicine for an individual person should be informed by the advice of a health professional and take into account the known benefits and risks of the medicine and additional factors relevant to the individual's circumstances.

To assist prescribers, information about the known risks and benefits of prescription medicines is presented in the Product Information (PI) document. For prescription corticosteroids such as prednisolone, extensive warnings and precautions are included that specifically target adrenocortical insufficiency and the risks of withdrawal. Guidelines on the duration of treatment are also included in the PI which can be found on the TGA website at: www.tga.gov.au.

Information for consumers about appropriate use and safety of medicines can be found in the Consumer Medicines Information (CMI) document. This document is available for all prescription medicines and some over the counter products. Consumers can request a copy from doctors, pharmacists or via the TGA website. The CMI includes information about how to use the product and when to seek advice. Topical corticosteroids are available in Australia both with and without prescription. Non-prescription topical corticosteroids are of lower potency (strength) than prescription corticosteroids. Labels for non-prescription topical corticosteroids must include warning statements about maximum duration of use of the medicines (usually seven days). These advisory statements are set out in the TGA document Required Advisory Statements for Medicine Labels. There are guidelines to assist pharmacists to make appropriate decisions about the best product to recommend for an individual patient. Pharmacists have a duty of care to ensure that the product choice is appropriate, and that counselling about correct use, potential side effects, and when to seek medical attention is communicated at the time of purchase.

Noting the pain aspect of TSW, the National Strategic Action Plan for Pain Management presents a whole-of-care approach, with a focus on self-management, to reduce the burden of chronic pain on the individual and the community, and increase quality of life for people living with this condition. Some of the key priorities are around greater awareness of pain and pain management, more timely access to consumer-centred interdisciplinary services and research to underpin greater knowledge of pain.
I hope the above information provides some comfort to patients who have suffered because of TSW and knowledge Of work underway that may address the issues raised in the petition.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Gun Control
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021 enclosing Petition EN2946, with 5 signatures, which requests that the House of Representatives abolish the National Firearms Agreement (NFA).

Australia's firearms laws are designed to strike an appropriate balance between community safety and providing access to firearms for those with a genuine need. The Commonwealth, states and territories are committed to the NFA which sets out a national approach to firearms regulation.

In 2017, following a recommendation of the Joint Commonwealth-New South Wales Martin Place Siege Review, the NFA was reviewed and updated. In addition to incorporating advice from all Commonwealth, state and territory law enforcement and justice agencies, the review involved extensive consultation with the firearms community (industry and recreational groups), community safety organisations and individuals.

The NFA remains a critical part of the effective regulation of firearms in Australia. While Australia has some of the strongest firearm controls in the world, illicit firearms continue to remain a threat to community safety.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2946 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Climate Change
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 18 October 2021 regarding House of Representatives Petition EN2970—provide access to euthanasia and/or assisted suicide for climate collapse.

Under Australia's federal system of government, the Commonwealth, states and territories have different areas of responsibility. Euthanasia/assisted dying is generally a matter for state governments. Currently, voluntary assisted dying is available in Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia through state laws. Tasmania's End of Life Choices (Voluntary Assisted Dying) Act 2021 passed on 22 April 2021 and is expected to be implemented from 2022. South Australia's Voluntary Assisted Dying Bill 2021 passed on 24 June 2021 and will be implemented within 18 to 24 months.

The Australian Government is responding to climate change by investing in new technologies that will lower emissions and support jobs and growth. The Australian Government will act in a practical, responsible way to deliver net zero emissions by 2050 while preserving Australian jobs and generating new opportunities for industries and regional Australia.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Welfare
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your Petition (EN2971), dated 19 October 2021, concerning the Cashless Debit Card (CDC).

In September 2017, the Bundaberg and Hervey Bay region was announced as the fourth CDC site. The selection of the participant group in the Bundaberg and Hervey Bay region occurred following significant consultation with the impacted communities in the area. Two Community Reference Groups (the Groups) of experts from a broad range of backgrounds were formed in the Bundaberg and Hervey Bay region. On 1, 2, 7 and 8 November 2018, the department held 4 community information sessions in Bundaberg, Childers, Hervey Bay and Howard. The sessions provided a platform for individuals and service providers to ask questions and receive information about the CDC program prior to its implementation in the Bundaberg and Hervey Bay region in early 2019.

A person is only placed on the CDC if their permanent address registered with Services Australia is in the Bundaberg or Hervey Bay region, which is defined by the boundaries of the Federal Division of Hinkler. Once a person is participating in the program, they will remain on it so long as they continue to meet the payment and age criteria. People aged 35 years and under who receive JobSeeker Payment, Youth Allowance, Parenting Payment Single or Parenting Payment Partnered will receive the card. By focusing on welfare recipients 35 and under, the program can address key social problems identified during consultation, including high youth unemployment and intergenerational welfare dependence. In the Bundaberg and Hervey Bay region, 90 per cent of people 25 and under on JobSeeker Payment or Youth Allowance residing in this region as at 30 June 2016, had a parent or guardian who received income support at some point in the last 15 years.

Under the CDC, a percentage of a participant's welfare payment is placed on a card that can be used at most shops that accept Visa, including online and overseas. The card looks and operates like a regular bankcard. It is a useful budgeting tool and only restricts the purchase of alcohol, gambling products, cash-like gift cards and cash withdrawal.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
Brisbane Airport
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 18 October 2021, regarding the petition presented to the House of Representatives in relation to flight operations at Brisbane Airport (EN2983).

Managing aircraft noise is a difficult issue. The Australian Government supports minimising the impact of aircraft noise on the community through a combination of airspace design, noise abatement procedures and land use planning. However, some level of aircraft noise is unavoidable in major cities, such as Brisbane, particularly in areas close to the airport.

The Air Services Act 1995 requires Airservices Australia (Airservices) to regard the safety of air navigation as the most important consideration, while also ensuring that, as far as practicable, the environment is protected from the effects of, and the effects associated with, the operation of aircraft. The Australian Government has no current plans to review the Air Services Act 1995.

Under the Airspace Act 2007, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) is responsible for the administration and regulation of Australian airspace, including the amendment of airspace and air routes. Airspace changes required to implement the new flight paths at Brisbane Airport were approved by CASA on 31 October 2018 and 26 August 2019.

On 20 July 2021, Airservices commenced a Post-Implementation Review (PIR) of the flight path and airspace changes required for Brisbane Airport's New Parallel Runway. The PIR is reviewing the outcomes of the flight path changes for the community, environment and industry, and provides an opportunity to identify possible improvements to minimise noise impacts on the community as a whole, where safe and feasible to do so.

In addition, the Australian Government announced the Brisbane Airport Post Implementation Review Advisory Forum (the Forum) on 24 September 2021 in recognition of the significant community interest in aircraft operations around Brisbane Airport. The Forum is an independent, community-oriented body that complements existing engagement mechanisms. The Forum has been established specifically to provide advice and feedback to Airservices on matters relating to its PIR of Brisbane Airport's new runway operations. The Chair will also provide me with a quarterly report.

Through the PIR, Airservices will consider community suggestions for improvement of Brisbane's airspace arrangements, as well as look for improvements to noise outcomes based on a review of operations since the opening of the runway. Proposed changes to airspace architecture must be approved by CASA via an airspace change proposal. Further information on the airspace change process can be found at www.casa.gov.auJairspace/airspace-regulation/airspace-change-process.

Construction of a new runway and design of new airspace arrangements are inherently complex projects that take many years to develop, during which time aviation technology continues to improve. The approval of the major development plan for the New Parallel Runway at Brisbane Airport in 2007 by the then Minister for Transport and Regional Services under the Airports Act 1996 related only to the construction of the runway. Operational aspects, including airspace operations, required separate approval from CASA once these aspects were finalised. Enhanced aviation navigation technology has been developed since the approval, endorsed by the International Civil Aviation Organization and included in the design as international best practice.

The 2007 Environmental Impact Statement for the New Parallel Runway, which included the implementation of a plan for aviation airspace management, was approved by the then Minister for the Environment under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). The EPBC Act is administered by the Department of Agriculture, Water and the Environment and the Minister for the Environment. As the New Parallel Runway project is completed, Airservices cannot be directed to complete a new Environmental Impact Statement, however this does not mean that the issues being raised are unable to be addressed by alternative mechanisms, which I understand are being considered through the Airservices' PIR.
Thank you for referring this petition to me and I trust this information is of assistance. I have copied this letter to the Hon Sussan Ley MP, Minister for the Environment.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, Mr Joyce
Broadband
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 18 October 2021, concerning Petition EN2989 requesting the provision of reliable and consistent internet service for Moore Creek, Daruka and Moonbi Gap in New South Wales.

I can well understand the frustration from residents of these regional areas with their online experience through ADSL technology. It's important to understand that the supply and repair of ADSL services are commercial decisions by internet providers.

In December 2018 the Government announced its approach to its new Universal Service Guarantee (USG) for telecommunications. The USG provides people across Australia with reasonable access to broadband as well as voice services.

Under the USG, NBN Co Limited (NBN Co) is the default wholesale provider of broadband services. NBN Co's role is underpinned by new statutory infrastructure provider (SIP) legislation, which took effect from 1 July 2020.

Under the SIP legislation, NBN Co is the default SIP for Australia, but other carriers must be the SIPs for developments they are contracted to serve. SIPs are required to connect premises to high-speed networks in their areas of responsibility, and supply wholesale services that allow retail providers to supply high-speed broadband to end-users with peak download and upload speeds of at least 25/5 megabits per second (Mbps). SIPs must deploy fixed-line networks unless it is not reasonable to do so, in which case they must deploy either fixed wireless or satellite networks.
The Government will continue to work with consumers and industry to see if there are better ways to deliver USG services over the long term.

NBN Co has completed the construction of the National Broadband Network (NBN) using a range of technologies. This has included the use of fixed wireless and satellite to provide services in locations that are technically and financially challenging to serve due to low population densities and the topography of the area.

NBN Co's website indicates that NBN fixed wireless or satellite services are available in Moore Creek and Daruka areas, and NBN satellite services are available in the Moonbi Gap area. To connect to an NBN service, residents need to contact an internet retailer and choose a plan that suits their needs. Further information about the NBN, including a list of providers for the area, is available at www.nbnco.com.au.

NBN Co's satellite broadband service has been designed to bring a step-change in the experience of broadband users in regional and remote Australia, offering peak wholesale download speeds of 25 Mbps and upload speeds of 5 Mbps, which is much faster than ADSL connections on average.
The company has continued to invest in new products and technologies to better meet the connectivity needs of communities served by NBN Co's satellites. This includes:

Sky Muster Plus (launched August 2019) which provides satellite users with access to unmetered data for all online content and applications, with the exception of video streaming and VPN (Virtual Private Network) traffic, which continue to be metered. Approximately 70 per cent of all data use is unmetered and does not contribute to a household's monthly data allowance.

The NBN Business Satellite Service (launched October 2019) provides businesses in rural and remote areas of Australia with access to business-grade broadband, with products offering tailored solutions for a range of speed, capacity and service support requirements.

NBN Co currently invests around $200 million annually to optimise the performance of its fixed wireless network. As a result, fixed wireless customers on a 50 Mbps plan are experiencing average download speeds of approximately 35 Mbps during the busy hour period (between 7pm and 1 lpm) and approximately 43 Mbps across all hours. NBN Co is continuing to investigate options to enhance the fixed wireless network over time such as through the use of 5G technology and mmWave spectrum.

Importantly, in the fixed wireless and satellite footprints, existing copper lines will not be disconnected and consumers will still have the option to use their existing landline telephone. ADSL services may also be available where broadband retailers choose to offer them.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher

subdebateinfo.title: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

p.span: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 18 October 2021 regarding a petition on the prohibition of 'Gain of Function' research (EN3017). I appreciate you referring this important petition to me. The Australian Government is committed to ensuring all research in Australia is conducted responsibly, ethically and with integrity.

Gain of Function is a research tool that has been used in life sciences for many decades and includes research designed to learn how organisms gain new properties through scientific interventions or through natural selection, including for example, research to understand new strains of influenza for vaccine manufacturing. Gain of Function research has led to new knowledge such as how pathogens spread and cause disease as well as the development of new pharmaceuticals and vaccines, precision medicine and gene therapies.

The Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Greg Hunt MP, has asked the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) to undertake a review of Gain of Function research in Australia and the regulatory framework that controls such research. The terms of reference for this review are available on the NHMRC website (www.nhnirc.gov.au). This review is expected to be completed by December 2021.

I would also like to draw your attention to the Commonwealth Science and Industrial Research Organisation's (CSIRO) response to a Question on Notice in the context of the 2021 Budget Estimates process (BI-75, Query—Written Prohibition refers). CSIRO's response to this Question on Notice addresses some of the issues raised in this petition and is available publicly at www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Senate_Estimates/eqon.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Science and Technology, Ms Price
COVID-19: Law Enforcement
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021, enclosing petition EN3031 with 13 signatures, concerning the introduction of special laws relating to the arrest and detention of protestors involved in self-described 'Freedom Marches' relating to COVID-19 health restrictions.

The Australian Constitution does not grant the Commonwealth the power to make laws for matters relating to health, including laws that criminalise breaches of public health orders. Rather, states and territories have reserve jurisdiction to make laws on the subject of health. Therefore, the Commonwealth is not authorised to create a new Federal offence for these matters, as this would violate the division of powers articulated in the Constitution, and encroach upon the powers granted to states and territories.

It is a matter for the relevant law enforcement agencies to investigate the commission of any offences within their relevant jurisdictions and obtain evidence for prosecution purposes. If you continue to have concerns about alleged offences that relate to unlawful protests, state and territory police are the appropriate authorities to investigate and prosecute such matters.

The role of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (AS 10) is to identify and investigate threats to security, and provide advice to Government to protect Australia, including its people and interests. ASIO's functions do not include law enforcement activities and the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979 (Cth), explicitly protects the right of persons to engage in lawful advocacy, protest or dissent. As an intelligence agency, ASIO also does not have any detention powers.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
National Education Standards
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 18 October 2021 regarding Petition number EN3043. In response to the issues raised in the Petition, I can provide the following advice.

The Australian Curriculum, Assessment and Reporting Authority (ACARA) is a Statutory Authority and corporate Commonwealth entity established under the Australian Curriculum, Assessment and Reporting Authority Act 2008 (ACARA Act). The ACARA Act states that ACARA must perform its functions and exercise its powers in accordance with the ACARA Charter, including the development of a national curriculum, which is agreed by Education Ministers. The ACARA Act also sets out the requirements for establishing the Board.

While ACARA's work is set by Education Ministers, its Board has the authority to decide the activities necessary to carry out this work. Advice on key activities is provided through an advisory structure that incorporates government and non-government school sector representation and expertise in specific related fields.

The Aboriginal and Tones Strait Islander Advisory Group (ATSIAG) was established in 2009 and provides ACARA with expert guidance and advice about the representation of Aboriginal and Tones Strait Islander histories and cultures in the Australian Curriculum.
In line with the governance of all advisory groups, issues relating to ATSIAG's composition is a matter for ACARA's Board.
I have copied Mr Norm Hart, Acting Chair of the ACARA Board into this letter for the attention of ACARA.
I trust this information is of assistance.
from the Minister for Education and Youth, Mr Tudge
Migration
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 18 October 2021 concerning Petition EN3053, with 514 signatures, which requests permanent residency pathways for New Zealand minors on a Special Category Visa.

The Australian Government values the unique bilateral relationship between Australia and New Zealand. Under the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement, Australian and New Zealand citizens, who present no health or character concerns, can visit, live and work in either country indefinitely and without restrictions—a benefit Australia has not conferred on any other nation.

Children may be able to apply for a permanent Child (Subclass 802 or Subclass 101) visa if their sponsor (generally their parent, or step-parent) is an Australian citizen, Australian permanent resident or eligible New Zealand citizen.
An eligible New Zealand citizen is:
a New Zealand citizen who is a 'protected SCV holder' as described in Section 7 of the Social Security Act 1991 (the Act).
Protected SCV holders are those who arrived in Australia on a New Zealand passport and were:
in Australia on 26 February 2001; or
in Australia for 12 months in the 2 years immediately before this date; or
otherwise assessed as 'protected SCV holders' under the Act—in which case they must provide us with written confirmation from Centrelink.
An eligible New Zealand citizen can apply for citizenship (by conferral) or sponsor family members for Australian visas.

In recognition of our special bilateral relationship, the Government also created an additional pathway to permanent residence for New Zealand citizens who are long-term residents in Australia. Access to this pathway is contingent upon demonstrating a contribution to Australia through income tax returns which show taxable income at least equivalent to the Temporary Skilled Migration Income Threshold. The Government has agreed to review the pathway to permanent residence for New Zealand citizen temporary visa holders in 2022, to determine whether any further improvements to the stream should be made.

Like all nationalities, New Zealand citizens seeking an option to apply for a permanent visa can also explore the range of visa options available under the Family and Skill streams of the Australia's annual Migration Program.
Whether New Zealand citizens apply for an Australian permanent visa is ultimately a decision for each person to make based on their individual circumstances.
The Department of Home Affairs remains committed to supporting and maintaining positive bilateral relationships with New Zealand by facilitating the entry and stay of individuals in Australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3053 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Age Pension
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 19 October 2021 concerning a petition (EN3058) presented to the House of Representatives on 18 October 2021 on Age Pension.

The Australian Government appreciates the important economic and social contribution senior Australians make to our community and is keen to ensure pensioners' living standards are safeguarded by the Age Pension. Pensions such as the Age Pension are funded by taxpayers and targeted through the means test to those who need them most.

Pensions are paid at the highest legislated rate of income support in the social security system because recipients are not expected to work to support themselves. Under social security law, base pension rates are indexed twice a year to ensure they keep up with increases in the cost of living, as measured by the Consumer Price Index (CPI) and the Pensioner and Beneficiary Living Cost Index. These rates are calculated according to provisions in legislation and are not a decision of government. Base pension rates are also benchmarked to Male Total Average Weekly Earnings (MTAWE) to align them with community living standards. Base pension rates are currently above the MTAWE benchmark.

On 20 September 2021, the maximum total pension rate for single pensioners increased by $14.80 to $967.50 a fortnight, or $25,155 a year. The maximum rate for pensioner couples combined increased by $22.40 to $1,458.60 a fortnight, or $37,923.60 a year. Pension rates will continue to be reviewed twice a year, as set out in legislation.

In addition to their main payment, pensioners can also receive a range of benefits and concessions that increase their economic security, including subsidised prescription medicines under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, subsidised health care and related products, and subsidised aged care.
As part of the Government's economic response to the COVID-19 pandemic, each eligible pensioner also received a total of $2,000 through four Economic Support Payments.

Commonwealth Rent Assistance (CRA) is available to assist eligible individuals or households receiving income support, family assistance payments or veterans' service pensions with the costs of private rent. The Government expects to spend around $5.3 billion on CRA in 2021-22, to assist around 1.5 million eligible individuals and families with the cost of their rent. CRA is adjusted each year in March and September, in line with CPI.

Wage earners, including those receiving the minimum wage, pay income tax on their earnings. In the personal income tax system, senior Australians receive tax relief through the seniors and pensioners tax offset (SAPTO). The SAPTO is available to taxpayers in receipt of a taxable government pension, as well as to Australians who are of Age Pension qualifying age and who meet the Age Pension eligibility criteria (age and residency) but do not receive a pension due to the income or asset tests. In 2021-22, eligible single senior Australians with incomes up to $33,898 (or $30,592 for each member of a couple) pay no income tax. Currently, senior single Australians with incomes up to $36,705 also pay no Medicare levy. By way of comparison, most people below Age Pension age start to pay income tax and the Medicare levy once their annual taxable income exceeds $23,226.
Thank you again for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition number EN3078.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in significant challenges for people across Australia, and the Australian Government recognises the additional complexity for those who undertake the important work in the hospitality sector.

The Government's highest priority has always been the health and safety of the community. As the Government continues to expand and accelerate the vaccine rollout, it is taking the issue of vaccinations for all Australians very seriously. To this end, Australia's rollout has taken another step forward, with all Australians aged 12 years and over, including those working in the hospitality sector, now eligible for COVID-19 vaccination with either the Pfizer, Moderna or Astra Zeneca vaccines.
Australians can therefore book in for their vaccination now through participating general practices, pharmacies, and state vaccination hubs.

The Government is a strong supporter of immunisation and has always stated that receiving a COVID-19 vaccination would be voluntary. Immunisation is a safe and effective way to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

Operation COVID Shield aims to get as many Australians who want to be vaccinated a vaccine by the end of this year. More than 36 million vaccine doses have been administered across the country, with more than 85 per cent of the eligible population aged 16 years and over protected with two doses of a COVID-19 vaccine.
We encourage all eligible Australians to come forward and receive a vaccine. Our advice is that you do not wait—vaccination protects you, your loved ones and the greater community.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021, enclosing Petition EN3079 with 153 signatures, concerning travel exemptions for fully vaccinated parents of Australians to travel to Australia, and for fully vaccinated Australians to depart.

Australia's current travel restriction policy has played a key foundational role underpinning management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia and were implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

As announced by the Australian Government on 22 October 2021, parents of adult Australian citizens and permanent residents will be considered immediate family for travel exemption purpose. Parental relationships for the purpose of a travel exemption to travel to Australia include biological, adoptive, legal, step-parent, and parents-in-law.

Applications for a travel exemption to have the relationship confirmed can be submitted through the Department of Home Affairs' Travel Exemption Portal, for travel to Australia from 1 November 2021. Further information about travel exemptions for parents is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/immediate-family-australian-citizens-or-permanent-residents-or-new-zealand-citizens-usually-resident-australia.

Additionally, before travelling, parents must also have a valid passport, a valid visa for travel to Australia and be fully vaccinated with a recognised vaccine. These requirements will be checked by the airline before boarding.

On 26 October 2021, the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Greg Hunt MP, amended the Biosecurity Determination 2020 so that fully vaccinated Australian citizens and permanent residents would be exempt from Australia's travel restrictions for departing Australia.

From 1 November 2021, fully vaccinated Australian citizens and permanent residents aged 12 and over will be exempt from the travel restrictions and would not need to apply for, and be approved an exemption to depart Australia.

International travel without needing to apply for an exemption will be a 'vaccination advantage' for those Australian citizens and permanent residents who are fully vaccinated. Further information on travel for vaccinated Australians is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-vaccinated-australians.
The Department's website provides guidance for travellers on the requirements prior to undertaking their travel. This information is available at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/before-i-travel.

In line with the National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response, as Australia progresses through the key vaccination thresholds, the Government is finalising plans so Australian families can be reunited, temporary visa holders can return, and we can work towards welcoming tourists back to our shores.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3079 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 19 October 2021 enclosing Petition EN3094 with 485 signatures, seeking inclusion of parents of Australians and permanent residents as an exempt category from the travel restrictions for travel to Australia.

As you know Australia's current travel restriction policy has played a key foundational role underpinning management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia and were implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

As announced by the Australian Government on 22 October 2021, parents of adult Australian citizens and permanent residents will be considered immediate family for travel exemption purpose. Parental relationships for the purpose of a travel exemption to travel to Australia include biological, adoptive, legal, step-parent, and parents-in-law.

Applications for a travel exemption to have the relationship confirmed can be submitted through the Department of Home Affairs' Travel Exemption Portal, for travel to Australia from 1 November 2021. Further information about travel exemptions for parents is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/immediate-family-australian-citizens-or-permanent-residents-or-new-zealand-citizens-usually-resident-australia.

Additionally, before travelling, parents must also have a valid passport, a valid visa for travel to Australia and be fully vaccinated with a recognised vaccine. These requirements will be checked by the airline before boarding.

I acknowledge that since the travel restrictions were introduced in March 2020, many families with parents overseas have missed significant life events and therefore would like to extend my thanks to these families for their patience and their sacrifice over this period.

In line with the National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response, as Australia progresses through the key vaccination thresholds, the Government is finalising plans so Australian families can be reunited, temporary visa holders can return, and we can work towards welcoming tourists back to our shores.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3094 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021, enclosing Petition EN3102 with 105 signatures, concerning recent policy changes for Australians citizens ordinarily resident overseas, and who cannot enter and leave without an exemption.

As of 1 November 2021, the outbound travel exemption requirement has been lifted for all fully vaccinated Australians and permanent residents. This means Australians can leave and enter the country without restriction, subject to any local State or Territory health and quarantine requirements on return.
Returning Australians and permanent residents will still be subject to the quarantine arrangements of the State or Territory into which they arrive.

Australian citizens and permanent residents who do not meet the vaccine eligibility requirements will continue to be bound by Australia's outwards travel restrictions and must apply for an exemption if they wish to travel overseas.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3102 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021, enclosing Petition EN3107 with 16 signatures, seeking reconsideration of the travel exemption policy change for Australian citizens ordinarily resident overseas, to depart Australia.

Australia's current travel restriction policy has played a key foundational role underpinning management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia and were implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

As of 1 November 2021, the outbound travel exemption requirement has been lifted for all fully vaccinated Australians and permanent residents. This means Australians can leave and enter the country without restriction, subject to any local State or Territory health and quarantine requirements on return.
Returning Australians and permanent residents will still be subject to the quarantine arrangements of the State or Territory into which they arrive.

Australian citizens and permanent residents who do not meet the vaccine eligibility requirements will continue to be bound by Australia's outwards travel restrictions and must apply for an exemption if they wish to travel overseas.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3107 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

I refer to your correspondence of 19 October 2021, enclosing Petition EN3116, concerning travel exemptions for people who are vaccinated and hold certain types of temporary visa, to enter Australia. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

Australia's current travel restriction policy has played a key foundational role underpinning management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia and were implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

Under the current travel exemptions policy settings, the circumstances and cases where travel exemption requests from people holding a Student visa, Prospective Marriage (subclass 300) visa, skilled and other work visa, are considered for approval are limited and outlined on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-restrictions.

On 6 August 2021, the National Cabinet agreed in full to a four-phase National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response. The National Plan provides a graduated pathway to reopen the international border with each phase triggered once Australia reaches key vaccination thresholds expressed as a percentage of the population who are vaccinated. The broader approach to the entry of temporary visa holders will be in accordance with the National Plan.

As Australia progresses through the key vaccination thresholds, the Australian Government is finalising plans so Australian families can be reunited, temporary visa holders can return, and we can work towards welcoming tourists back to our shores.
Further information on travel exemptions is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3116 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Sport
Dear Mr O'Dowd

I refer to your email of 18 October to the Minister for Sport, Senator the Hon Richard Colbeck, regarding Petition EN3122—Granting Taxpayer Funds to Exhibit Niche Sports Content. Your email has been forwarded to me for reply as I have portfolio responsibility for this matter.
The petitioners are concerned about the tender process for the Under-represented sports grant to Foxtel.

In the 2017-18 Budget the Australian Government provided $30 million over four years for Foxtel to increase television and online coverage of women's, niche, and emerging sports. This formed part of the comprehensive package of reforms put in place by the Coalition Government in 2017 to support Australia's broadcast and content sector. Foxtel was well placed to administer this grant as a leading sports broadcaster.

On 22 July 2020, the Government announced a further $10 million in funding to continue support for coverage of women's, niche and other under-represented sports, bringing total funding for the under-represented sports grant to $40 million over six years.

The additional funding was provided to enable prioritisation of broadcasting of under-represented sports as sports resumed play following COVID-19-related shut-downs. This funding formed part of the Government's COVID-19 Response Package.

The Australian Government is committed to supporting sport in Australia from grassroots to elite; increasing participation in physical and recreational activities to promote physical and mental health, staging world class major sporting events and protecting the integrity of sport.

This grant funding supports the profile of under-represented sports in Australia, providing them the foundation to boost engagement, participation and commercial opportunities. The grant is supporting increased coverage for sports including: Australian Women's cricket, AFLW, Wheelchair Rugby, Women's Basketball, lawn bowls, Women's surfing, softball and Women's Baseball. In 2020-21, Foxtel broadcast more than 4,700 hours of content under the funding agreement (including 1,400 live hours) across 25 different sporting competitions.

The Under-represented sports grant opportunity concludes on 30 June 2022. My Department will commence an evaluation of the program following its conclusion. I also note that a request to examine this grant activity has been presented to the Auditor General—and that as a result, this grant is within scope for an Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) audit.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
South Africa
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021 enclosing Petition EN3129, with 52 signatures. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Australia has a long tradition of resettling refugees and people in humanitarian need from around the world and is one of the world's most generous contributors to international refugee resettlement efforts, successfully settling more than 920,000 refugees and others in humanitarian need since the end of the Second World War.

Australia's offshore Humanitarian Program is designed primarily to assist people who have left their home country because of persecution or severe human rights abuses, and who have no options for return or for resettlement in another country. In limited circumstances, resettlement places may also be available for people subject to persecution who have remained in their home country. Any person who believes they meet the requirements for a humanitarian visa and wishes to seek Australia's assistance can make an application. Each application is considered on its individual merit using current and comprehensive information on circumstances in the relevant country.

While most applicants have suffered some form of discrimination or persecution, the limited number of visas available and the high demand for these places means that priority is given to those people outside their home country, assessed as refugees by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and formally referred to Australia for resettlement, and applicants proposed by a close family member in Australia.

In addition to the Humanitarian Program, the Australian Government operates a Migration Program for people who wish to migrate on the basis of their skills or family relationships in Australia. The Migration Program seeks to facilitate the reunification of family members of Australian citizens, permanent residents and eligible New Zealand citizens (Australian sponsors). Some categories of visas, including Family visas, require sponsorship from eligible Australian citizens, permanent residents and eligible New Zealand citizens. For further information on temporary or permanent migration to Australia, please refer to the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/bringing-someone/bringing-partner-or-family.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3129 to my attention.
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Residency for the Murugappan family
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 20 October 2021 enclosing Petition EN3130, concerning the Sri Lankan family.

As a signatory to the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol (the Refugee Convention), I can assure you that Australia takes its international obligations seriously and provides protection to refugees consistent with the obligations set out in the Refugee Convention, and other relevant international treaties to which Australia is a party. Unlawful non-citizens are only removed if the Department of Home Affairs is satisfied they do not engage Australia's non-refoulement obligations and that removal would not breach Australia's international obligations.

Home Affairs Portfolio Ministers have personal intervention powers under the Migration Act 1958 (the Act) that allow them to grant a visa to a person, if they think it is in the public interest to do so. The public interest powers are non-compellable, that is, the Ministers are not required to exercise these powers. It is for the Ministers to define what is in the public interest.

I exercised my non-compellable power under section 197AB of the Act to place the family into a residence determination arrangement in Perth, Western Australia. I also exercised my non-compellable power under section 195A of the Act to grant further bridging visas to three members of the family.
As this matter is before the courts, it would be inappropriate to comment further.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3130 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN3158 calling on the Australian Government to introduce or import China's COVID-19 vaccines as soon as possible.

The Government wants everyone in Australia to have access to a safe, free, COVID-19 vaccine, if they choose to be vaccinated. Moreover, the safety of the population has always been the highest priority of the Government. For these reasons, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) formally assesses the safety, quality and efficacy of medicines, including vaccines, prior to their approval for use in Australia. All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large clinical trials on thousands of people. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease.

This involves comprehensive review of clinical trial data, non-clinical and toxicological studies, chemistry, manufacturing, quality, risk-management and other information by a large team of clinical and scientific experts. Advice is then sought from an independent expert committee before a regulatory decision is made.

The Pfizer, AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria), Moderna and Janssen COVID-19 vaccines have been provisionally approved after a complete assessment of all the available data and the Novavax vaccine is currently under evaluation. The Pfizer, AstraZeneca and Moderna vaccines have subsequently been used in Australia's national vaccine rollout, while the Janssen vaccine has not been utilised, though it is provisionally approved.

This approval process is the same process as any vaccine approved in this country. The TGA will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is safe and effective, and its benefits outweigh any risks. No part of the Process has been rushed, and there was no emergency authorisation granted as the TGA does not have an 'Emergency Use Authorisation' pathway for COVID-19 vaccines.

The urgency of the global pandemic means that researchers, agencies such as the World Health Organization and governments all over the world are prioritising the development, assessment, and rollout of COVID-19 vaccines.

The TGA requires robust scientific data before supporting a vaccine candidate and will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is found to be safe and effective, following its complete assessment of data. Information regarding COVID-19 vaccines under evaluation can be found at: www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccines-undergoing-evaluation.

With rolling submission, collaboration with international regulators, and proactively working with sponsors, the evaluation of COVID-19 vaccines including Novavax is being significantly expedited without compromising on our strict standards of safety, quality and efficacy. However, the timeframe will ultimately depend on when the complete data package is provided by sponsors to enable the required regulatory processes.

The Government also continues to meet regularly with a range of COVID-19 vaccine and treatment developers and manufacturers and continues to monitor ongoing clinical trials and review real world effectiveness of vaccine rollouts globally.

There are more than 400 trials for 140 vaccine candidates worldwide, including a number that are trialling the use of needle-free technology. These include nasal sprays, oral tablets, skin patches and jet injectors.

Future investments in COVID-19 vaccine candidates and manufacturing options are subject to the advice of the COVID-19 Vaccines and Treatments for Australia—Science and Industry Technical Advisory Group, and assessment of clinical evidence, including portfolio diversification and risk.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID-19 Vaccine Campaign Plan.
