For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-progyams/operation-covid-shield.
Yours Sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Afghanistan
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021 enclosing petition EN3161, with 34 signatures, on the situation in Afghanistan. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

As you are aware, Afghan citizens are a prominent caseload in Australia's offshore Humanitarian Program and have been in the top five countries of origin over the last five years. The Australian Government announced on 18 August 2021 that Afghan citizens will be prioritised for processing within the offshore Humanitarian Program. An initial 3,000 humanitarian places have been allocated to Afghan nationals within Australia's 13,750 annual program. Particular priority will be given to persecuted minorities, women and children, and those who have close links to Australia.

The Government anticipates this initial allocation will increase further over the course of 2021-22. We are working with Afghan community leaders here in Australia, and the United Nations High Commission for Refugees to identify and resettle those Afghan refugees most in need. The Government established an Advisory Panel on Australia's Resettlement of Afghan Nationals on 25 August 2021 to provide advice and support to the Government and the Department of Home Affairs to ensure that that resettlement planning, service provision, and goodwill across communities is harnessed for the Afghan cohort.

As you would appreciate, the Government is focussed on ensuring that the Australian response, including further consideration of Humanitarian Program settings, is well considered and meets the needs and priorities of the Afghan community. The Government will make further announcements on the composition and priorities in due course.

The Government has allocated new funding of $27.1 million over two years for a tailored Afghan settlement support package, to help recent evacuees from Afghanistan settle successfully into their new lives in Australia.
The Afghan settlement support package is informed by advice from the Government's Advisory Panel on Australia's Resettlement of Afghan Nationals and includes:

$8.0 million over two years to further strengthen the capacity of community and grass roots organisations to continue to play a critical role in supporting the evacuees to begin their lives in Australia;
$6.4 million to support those evacuees on subclass 449 Temporary Humanitarian Stay visas to transition to permanent visas;
$4.8 million to help new arrivals navigate skills recognition and education pathways to quickly secure a suitable entry into the Australian labour market; and
$7.9 million to the Program of Assistance for Survivors of Torture and Trauma (PASTT) to support evacuees and the Afghan community in accessing targeted mental health support.

The petitioners raise concerns regarding Afghan nationals who were granted a Humanitarian Stay (Temporary) (subclass 449) visa. These visas were granted due to the rapidly changing security circumstances in Afghanistan, the urgent and exceptional humanitarian nature of the evacuation operation and the limited window for people to depart Afghanistan.

On 18 November 2021, the Government announced that the subclass 449 visas granted to Afghans who supported Australia's mission in Afghanistan and their families, who have not yet arrived in Australia, will be extended on an ongoing basis. Those outside of this group who previously held a temporary humanitarian visa will be prioritised within Australia's Refugee and Humanitarian intake.

For those subclass 449 visa holders in Australia, on 12 November 2021, the Government announced changes to migration legislation to support Afghan nationals recently evacuated from Afghanistan to undertake permanent visa processes in Australia. These changes support the evacuees through permanent visa processes through the provision of a 12 month extension of their temporary subclass 449 visas. During this time they will also retain access to Commonwealth settlement, health, welfare and income supports.

These changes also provide a clear pathway to permanent residence for those Afghan evacuees located in Australia on subclass 449 visas—either continuing on their existing migration visa pathways, or through the Humanitarian Program. These changes allow Afghan subclass 449 visa holders in Australia to make a valid application for a Refugee and Humanitarian (Class XB) visa in Australia and align to a practicable extent, visa outcomes for this group with what they would likely have received through the Humanitarian Program, if they did not need urgent evacuation from Afghanistan.

In addition, the Government is working to ensure that visa options continue to be available to Afghan nationals, both within Afghanistan and those who have been displaced from their home country. All visa applications will be processed in accordance with Government announcements and within program priorities, and assessed on an individual basis. All visa applicants must also meet visa criteria and satisfy public interest criteria for character, security and health.

Visa processing times can vary according to the particular circumstances of the applicant, their location (be it inside or outside their home country), and their ability to travel, provide documents or access Australian government officials. The Government understands this is a distressing time for many people, including the Australian Afghan community, and request patience with the application process.

With regards to the provision of aid, on 13 September 2021, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator the Hon Manse Payne, announced that Australia will contribute $100 million in humanitarian assistance to respond to the Afghanistan crisis from 2021-24. This includes around $65 million in immediate lifesaving assistance and support to the neighbouring countries hosting Afghan refugees and around $35 million to address the protracted nature of the humanitarian crisis out to 2024. The Government will work through United Nations humanitarian partners, with a specific focus on supporting women and girls.

For those remaining in Afghanistan, the situation remains highly volatile, and travel throughout Afghanistan is extremely dangerous. Some borders are closed or may close without notice (as outlined in Smartraveller advice). We urge all people remaining in Afghanistan to prioritise their safety and carefully consider the risks should they attempt to leave by any route.

Afghan Australians are an integral part of Australian society and the Australian community. The Government is endeavouring to do all we can to continue to assist those affected through our ongoing humanitarian, whole-of-government and collaborative efforts.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3161 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Afghanistan
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021 enclosing Petition EN3174, with 423 signatures, concerning the situation in Afghanistan. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government is supporting those impacted by the crisis through our humanitarian response. Australia evacuated around 4,100 people on 32 flights from Kabul from 8 to 26 August 2021. The Government is committed to providing holistic support for Afghan evacuees, who will receive immediate settlement support to access essential services and integrate into Australian life.

Australia is one of only a small number of countries that operate well-established and successful resettlement programs, and continues to offer one of the largest resettlement programs on both an absolute and per capita basis. The Government anticipates this initial allocation will increase further over the course of 2021-22. The Government are working with Afghan community leaders here in Australia, and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to identify and resettle those Afghan refugees most in need.

The Government is working to ensure that visa options continue to be available to Afghan nationals, both within Afghanistan and those displaced from their home country, through Australia's long-standing Humanitarian and Migration Programs.

Afghan nationals who need to lodge or enquire about a visa or citizenship application can contact +61 2 6196 0196 or visit the Department of Home Affairs website, which provides clear information on visa lodgement channels and requirements. If people are having difficulty accessing communications to apply, another person can apply on their behalf. All visa applications will be processed in accordance with Government announcements and within program priorities, and assessed on an individual basis. All applicants for the Humanitarian Program must meet the visa criteria and satisfy public interest criteria for character, security and health.

Visa processing times can vary according to the particular circumstances of the applicant, their location (be it inside or outside their home country), and their ability to travel, provide documents or access Australian government officials. The Government understands this is a distressing time for many people, including the Australian Afghan community, and request patience with the application process.

Afghan Australians are an integral part of Australian society and the Australian community. The Government is endeavouring to do all we can to continue to assist those affected through our ongoing humanitarian, whole-of-government and collaborative efforts.
Thank you bringing Petition EN3174 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke

COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN3182 calling on the Australian Government to immediately Approve and Rollout Novavax.

The safety of the Australian population has always been the highest priority of the Government. For this reason, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is safe and effective, and its benefits outweigh any risks. With rolling submission, collaboration with international regulators, and proactively working with sponsors, the evaluation of COVID-19 vaccines including Novavax is being significantly expedited without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality and efficacy. In January 2021 the TGA granted provisional determination to Novavax. The next step in the approval process is for the sponsor to submit an application for provisional registration in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG). This submission includes a comprehensive dossier that includes specific information on clinical studies, non-clinical/toxicology studies, chemistry, manufacturing, risk-management and other information.

Novavax submitted initial data in February 2021 and, as part of their rolling submission, provided its initial quality data tranche in November 2021. The TGA is currently evaluating this data and is in the process of obtaining further information and clarification from the sponsor as the evaluation progresses, as well as being informed by the advice of the Advisory Committee on Vaccines, an independent committee of external experts. More information can be found on the TGA website at: www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccines-undergoing-evaluation.

The Government has invested in a diverse portfolio of COVID-19 vaccines that use a variety of technical platforms, entering into five separate Advance Purchase Agreements for the supply of COVID-19 vaccines, if they prove to be safe and effective. These include agreements with Pfizer, AstraZeneca, Novavax, Moderna and the international COVAX. Combined, these agreements will ensure Australia has access to more than 280 million vaccine doses.

All COVID-19 vaccines used in the rollout have been granted provisional approval following a complete assessment of all this available data. No part of the process has been rushed and the TGA does not have an 'Emergency Use Authorisation' pathway for COVID-19 vaccines.

The TGA is open and transparent about safety information relating to COVID-19 vaccines, including any suspected side-effects or potential safety issues. The TGA publishes a weekly safety report, including information about reported suspected side-effects, as well as other safety alerts as required. More information can be found at: vvww.tga.gov.au using the search terms 'COVID-19-vaccine safety monitoring and reporting'. Product information and consumer medicines information including ingredient listings for all provisionally approved vaccines can also be located on the TGA's website.

The goal is to protect all people in Australia from the harm caused COVID-19 infection, through preventing serious illness and death, and where possible, disease transmission. The Pfizer, AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria) and Moderna vaccines have all been proven through approval and safety monitoring processes to be very effective at reducing severe illness, hospitalisation and death.

From 1 October 2021, all Australians 12 years of age and over, including those Australians 60 years of age and over, are now eligible to receive a Pfizer or Moderna COVID-19 vaccine. This means older Australians can now choose the Pfizer, Moderna, or AstraZeneca vaccine.

It is important for Australians to have access to credible and timely information about COVID-19 vaccines. It is a large and complex project, and the information you are seeking may change over time—that is why we strongly encourage all Australians stay up-to-date on all news and announcements, by regularly checking my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt

JobKeeper Payment
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning Petition EN3207, which requests that businesses be required to return JobKeeper payments in certain circumstances. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The JobKeeper Payment was designed during a period when widespread public health restrictions were being imposed to control the spread of COVID-19. The purpose of JobKeeper was to support business and job survival, keep employees connected to their employers, and provide income support to individuals. It achieved these purposes.

Given the uncertainty at the time, eligibility for JobKeeper was initially based on a prospective decline in turnover test. A prospective test allowed eligibility to be determined almost immediately for businesses, which in turn allowed for JobKeeper payments to quickly be passed through to employees. Once a business had qualified, support was guaranteed for six months to provide certainty to businesses and this was based on the health advice at the time regarding the possible duration and nature of restrictions.

The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) is administering the payment and provided guidance to businesses on the test, including the evidence they needed to retain in support of their eligibility. The ATO has established that the vast majority of JobKeeper businesses reasonably estimated their projected decline in turnover. For those JobKeeper businesses which the ATO determined did not reasonably estimate their projected the decline in turnover, the ATO was either able to prevent these claims prior to payment or take compliance action to recover these payments.

Some businesses were able to recover more quickly than others. The JobKeeper Payment did not include a mechanism to claw back payments from businesses that performed better than they expected, reflecting a desire to avoid any disincentives for businesses to adapt and recover. The introduction of such a mechanism would likely have reduced the overall level of economic activity and slowed the recovery.

Whilst some businesses may not have experienced a 30 per cent decline in turnover during the first six months of JobKeeper, this does not necessarily mean the business was not adversely affected by COVID-19 restrictions. There are a variety of reasons that some businesses that were eligible for JobKeeper but did not end up experiencing their projected decline in turnover including the early easing of health restrictions or because JobKeeper allowed them to adapt their business model and remain operating during the health restrictions.
In the JobKeeper extension phase, eligibility was retested in both extension periods based on actual declines in turnover in the previous quarter.

JobKeeper payments were required to be passed through to eligible employees and there is no legal obligation for businesses who received JobKeeper in accordance with the rules to repay those amounts. However, a business may choose to voluntarily pay an amount which is equivalent to some or all of the JobKeeper payments that they received. A number of businesses have made voluntary repayments and the ATO has provided guidance on how businesses can repay some or all of their JobKeeper payments.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Fridge Magnets
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning petition number EN3208 on banning mass distribution of fridge magnets.

The Australian Government takes the issue of waste and its impacts on the environment very seriously. Our National Waste Policy Action Plan includes ambitious national targets to make Australia a world leader in resource management and recovery. For plastic waste, these include a ban on plastic waste exports and a phase-out of problematic and unnecessary plastics through sustainable design, innovation or the introduction of sustainable alternatives by 2025.

We are also driving a $1 billion transformation of our waste and recycling industry. The government created the $190 million Recycling Modernisation Fund (RMF) to supercharge investment in recycling infrastructure so that Australia can take responsibility for its own waste. As the waste export ban is phased in, Australia must shift to recycling 645,000 tonnes of waste plastic, paper, glass and tyres domestically. Additional recycling infrastructure is required to achieve this. The government has already contributed over $106 million towards 78 RMF projects, that will process over 1.3 million tonnes of plastics, tyres, glass and paper each year. This funding is currently on track to leverage more than $800 million in waste and recycling manufacture infrastructure.

The government is also taking action to reduce waste through its $26 million National Product Stewardship Investment fund (NPSIF). The NPSIF aims to increase the number of industry-led product stewardship schemes in Australia. The program's intended outcomes include:
an increase in new, and expansion of, existing industry-led product stewardship schemes
increased availability, access to, and use of product recycling schemes
increased rates of recycled materials and reduced waste to landfill
contributing to the national target of 80 per cent resource recovery by 2030 under the National Waste Policy Action Plan.

The government is also committed to improving the recyclability of plastics and reducing the impacts of plastic waste on our environment. The government launched the nation's first National Plastics Plan on 4 March 2021. As outlined in the National Plastics Plan, taking responsibility for our waste will, in some instances, mean phasing out problematic and unnecessary single-use plastics, including through design, innovation or by using alternative materials. We are attacking the plastic problem on five key fronts: legislation, investment, industry targets, research and development, and community education. You can read more about the Plan at environment.gov.au/plastics-plan.

Since the release of the Plan the government has also been working with industry on steps to phase out problematic materials including expanded polystyrene (EPS) in loose fill and moulded consumer packaging by July 2022, EPS in food and beverage containers, non-certified compostable packaging as well as PVC labels by December 2022.

At the recent Environment Ministers Meeting, Environment Ministers identified eight `problematic and unnecessary' plastic product types for industry to phase out nationally by 2025 (or sooner in some cases) under the National Waste Policy Action Plan. These are lightweight plastic bags, plastic products misleadingly termed as `degradable', plastic straws, plastic bowls and plates, plastic utensils and stirrers, EPS consumer food containers (e.g. cups and clamshells), EPS consumer goods packaging (loose fill and moulded) and microbeads in personal health care products.

The government is also investing over $20 million through a special round of the Cooperative Research Centres Projects to find new and innovative solutions to plastic recycling and waste, including new ways of incorporating recycled plastics in manufacturing and construction.

There are also range of measures at all levels of government to ensure waste is managed effectively. State and territory governments have primary responsibility for regulating and administering waste, including planning for waste management and waste avoidance, minimisation, and reuse; resource recovery and disposal; and managing the impacts of waste management activities.

The responsibility for legislating the phase-out of problematic and unnecessary single use plastics, including composite materials such as magnets, belongs to state and territory governments. As the parties who submitted the petition are seeking to make the mass distribution of fridge magnets illegal, they may wish to contact their state or territory government representatives.

I hope this information serves to demonstrate that tackling waste and plastic pollution in all forms is a major priority for the government. We are committed to addressing this significant national challenge in close collaboration with industry and state and territory governments.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Waste Reduction and Environmental Management, Mr Evans
Diabetes
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition EN3240 requesting the Omnipod DASH Insulin Delivery System (Omnipod) be added to the National Diabetes Services Scheme (NDSS).

The Australian Government is aware of the significant impact diabetes has on people with diabetes and their families and is committed to working towards the broad prevention of the disease in the Australian community. The Omnipod system is a new style of insulin pump for which there are no directly comparable products currently subsidised through the NDSS. The product sponsor for Omnipod has submitted a request for subsidisation of this product and my Department is currently working with the sponsor to identify a potential funding pathway. Depending on the outcome of this process, a decision to list Omnipod on the NDSS product schedule may need to be considered through the Federal Budget process.

While the OmniPod DASH system is not currently included on the NDSS, a range of insulin pump consumables are currently subsidised. Further information about NDSS products, and more specifically insulin pump consumables, can be found at: www.ndss.com.au.

The Government provides considerable financial support to people with diabetes through the subsidy of essential medicines, like insulin, under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) and diabetes-related products, like blood glucose test strips, through the NDSS. In 2020-21, PBS expenditure on medicines for diabetes was over $709 million and expenditure on products for diabetes supplied through the NDSS was $186 million.

Not only does the NDSS provide subsidised syringes and needles, blood glucose test strips, urine ketone test strips and insulin pump consumables to people with diabetes, it also provides educational and information services to assist in the best use of products and self-management of diabetes.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Australian Society
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 23 November 2021 regarding Petition EN3241.

Australia is a party to the seven core international human rights treaties, including the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR). Australia's obligations under these treaties are implemented through a range of laws, policies and programs at the federal and state and territory levels.

International human rights law recognises that restrictions on rights, such as the right to freedom of movement and explusion of aliens in articles 12 and 13 of the ICCPR respectively, may be limited in certain circumstances. However, to strike an appropriate balance, such measures must be necessary and proportionate to the evaluated risk, must respect people's dignity, human rights and fundamental freedoms and be in place for the shortest time possible.

The Australian Government takes its obligations under international human rights law seriously, and implements those obligations in good faith. Under the Human Rights (Parliamentary Scrutiny) Act 2011, the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights is empowered to scrutinise all legislation for compatibility with human rights, including the ICCPR. All government non-legislative proposals are also informed by appropriate legal advice.
The Government considers that mechanisms to protect and promote human rights are appropriate. On this basis, the Government does not propose to ban identity cards in any form.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Hindus
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 22 November 2021 regarding Petition Ministerial Referral (EN3280).

Australia is home to a diversity of faiths, united by tolerance, mutual respect and a commitment to democratic traditions. All Australians are free to choose their religion, and are entitled to express and practise their religion and their beliefs, without intimidation or interference within the framework of Australian law. This means that Australians who hold religious views should not face discrimination on the basis of those views.

The Australian Government does not support prejudice or bias towards any religious group and takes the issue of discrimination against Australians on the grounds of their religious beliefs very seriously. In saying this, the Government does not intend on imposing a ban on certain terminology but encourages the use of language that is non-discriminatory and appropriate for the purpose of those communications.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Dental Health
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition number EN3282 concerning the addition to Medicare of wisdom tooth extraction.

The Australian Government understands the importance of good oral health and its role in supporting general health and wellbeing. States and territories have primary responsibility for public dental services—including, funding, management of waiting lists and determining the scope and availability of services.

The Government has supported states and territories through a National Partnership Agreement (NPA) on Public Dental Services for Adults. Between 1 January 2017 and 30 June 2021 the NPA provided $458.1 million in funding and supported services to around 763,000 public dental patients.

In the 2021-22 Budget, the Government announced $107.8 million to extend support for adult public services through a Federation Funding Agreement (FFA) until 30 June 2022. The FFA will provide services to an additional 180,000 public dental patients while the Australian Government and state and territory governments negotiate on options for long-term funding arrangements for public dental services.

The Government also supports the provision of dental services for children through the Child Dental Benefits Schedule (CDBS). Since its commencement on 1 January 2014, the CDBS has provided over $2.4 billion in benefits and delivered over 39 million services to more than three million children.

Through the National Health Reform Agreement, the Government contributes funds to the states and territories for dental services delivered through public hospitals. This includes services provided through emergency departments, hospitals, and community health settings. Between 2017-18 and 2019-20 the Government provided approximately $541 million in funding for these services.

The Government also supports access to private sector dental services through the Private Health Insurance (PHI) rebate. In the 2021-22 Budget $6.7 billion ($27.8 billion between 2021-22 and 2024-25) was committed for the PHI rebate, to make private health insurance more affordable. In 2018-19, $718 million was provided to support dental services through the PHI Rebate.

With concerns to pathways for assistance with the cost of treatment for the removal of wisdom teeth, private health insurance products may provide some support for services delivered in an ambulatory or admitted in-hospital setting. The scope and degree of this assistance will depend on the type of cover and the policy of the insurer. Patients may wish to contact their private health insurer to check what services are covered under their policy.

The public sector may also provide some access to services for the removal of wisdom teeth. Specific arrangements depend on the policies of state and territory government and may be limited to complex cases and high needs patients. Patients may wish to contact their state or territory government to check their eligibility for public dental services and what options may be available to them.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition number EN3311 requesting cancellation of the human biosecurity emergency status of COVID-19.

The human biosecurity emergency period declared under the Biosecurity Act 2015 (Act), which has been in place since 18 March 2020 to protect Australians during the COVID-19 pandemic, will continue until 17 December 2021 unless extended by the Governor-General.

The original declaration of the human biosecurity emergency, and every extension made by the Governor-General, is informed by specialist medical and epidemiological advice provided by expert medical bodies, such as the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee, and the Commonwealth Chief Medical Officer. The declaration has been extended several times since commencing in March 2020 because, based on the available public health evidence, I was satisfied with the criteria set out in the Act. At every stage, the Australian Government's priority has been the health and safety of Australians.

The human biosecurity emergency period is due to lapse on 17 December 2021. An extension for a further three months will be considered in due course, particularly noting the new variant of concern 'Omicron'. The Government is closely monitoring the evolving evidence relevant to the assessment of public health risk to Australia.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Child Abuse
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 22 November 2021 regarding Petition EN3351. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition.

The petition raises concerns about '90 year suppression orders' that were purportedly made over documents provided to the Royal Commission into the New South Wales Police Service (Wood Royal Commission) and the Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse. The Wood Royal Commission was established by New South Wales, the state to which any concerns should be directed.

I am advised that no such suppression orders have been made by Commonwealth Parliament or any federal court. This Government did bring forward amendments to the Royal Commissions Act 1902 to exclude information obtained at a private session from public access for 99 years. These relate to section 60M of that Act. The personal and sensitive nature of people's accounts of how they have been affected by child sexual abuse justified this action.

The petition also raises concerns about alleged corruption in public institutions. The Australian Government is committed to ensuring our federal integrity framework is as robust as possible and is delivering on its promise to establish a Commonwealth Integrity Commission (CIC). The CIC will be an independent investigative agency with strong powers to target the most serious types of criminal corruption that threaten good public administration. The CIC will have broad jurisdiction over all Commonwealth entities, including law enforcement and public sector agencies, parliamentarians and their offices, higher education providers and research bodies. It will complement, rather than duplicate, other mechanisms that already exist to deal with misconduct at the Commonwealth level.

The CIC will not have jurisdiction over the judiciary or judicial conduct. It is an essential feature of the Australian system of government that our courts are independent and free from interference from the executive arm of government. Consistent with this independence, the federal courts are each responsible for their own operation and management, including the handling of complaints
regarding the judiciary and judicial conduct.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition number EN3353 COVID-19 vaccine freedom to choose for people aged 59 years and over.

My Department is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

The safety of the Australian population has always been the highest priority of the Australian Government. For this reason, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI).

In following this advice, all Australians aged 12 and over, including those Australians aged 60 and over, are now eligible to receive either the AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria), Pfizer or Moderna vaccines. Informed consent will always be gained prior to vaccination.

It is important for Australians to have access to credible and timely information about COVID-19 vaccines. It is a large and complex project, and the information you are seeking may change over time. We strongly encourage you to stay up-to-date on all news and announcements, by regularly checking my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning request to increase the age of consent to 16 for COVID-19 vaccinations (petition number EN3359).
Anyone under 18 years is considered a child for the purposes of medical treatment. In general, a parent or legal guardian of a child has the authority to consent to that child being vaccinated.
However, some states and territories have legislation that addresses the issue of a child's consent to medical treatment. The common law applies in jurisdictions that do not have such legislation.

Under this common law often referred to as Mature Minor or Gillick competence, all medical practitioners are permitted to assess an adolescent's competence and maturity to consent to medical care including vaccination.

For certain procedures, including vaccination, a child or adolescent may be determined to be mature enough to understand the proposed procedure, and the risks and benefits associated with it. These young people may have the capacity to consent under certain circumstances. If a child or adolescent refuses a vaccination that a parent or guardian has given consent for, the child or adolescent's wishes are respected.

My Department has developed a consent form for COVID-19 vaccination as an example for vaccination providers to obtain patient consent prior to COVID-19 vaccination. However, the use of the form is not mandatory. Informed consent should be obtained as per usual consent procedures for other vaccinations. Verbal or implied consent is acceptable and written consent is not required.
As states and territories manage consent to medical treatment for children differently, I encourage you to work with jurisdictional health authorities on this matter.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt

from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition number EN3413 and can provide the following advice in response.

Before any COVID-19 vaccine is approved for use in Australia it is subject to the stringent assessment and approval processes of the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA), after being tested in large clinical trials on thousands of people. The TGA rigorously assesses all vaccines for safety, quality and effectiveness. The approvals are subject to certain strict conditions, such as the requirement for sponsors to continue providing information to the TGA on longer term efficacy and safety from ongoing clinical trials and post-market assessment. Emerging clinical trial evidence, as well as real world data, continues to be monitored by technical experts.

The TGA provisionally approved the Comirnaty (Pfizer), Spikevax (Moderna) and Vaxzevria (AstraZeneca) vaccines after a complete assessment of all the available data. This is the same process as any vaccine approved in this country. The TGA will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is safe and effective, and its benefits outweigh any risks.

While the Government encourages all eligible Australians to receive the COVID-19 vaccine as soon as they are eligible, vaccination in Australia is voluntary, and individuals need to undertake appropriate individual risk-benefit analysis and give informed consent before being vaccinated against COVID-19. There is a wide range of resources available to the general public to inform their decision-making.

As part of a vaccine's provisional approval process, the TGA requires that a comprehensive Consumer Medicine Information (CMI) leaflet and Product Information (PI) document be available for healthcare professionals and consumers for all prescription medicines. These documents are available at: www.tga.gov.au using the search term `COVID-19 vaccines: information for consumers and health professionals'.

The CMI leaflet contains information for consumers on the safe and effective use of a vaccine, including side effects. It also contains a list of all ingredients found in the vaccine. The PI provides information for healthcare professionals to guide their prescribing, dispensing and administering decisions and to assist them to provide patient education, and also includes a list of all ingredients found in the vaccine.

The TGA monitors the safety of vaccines after they are registered in Australia so that any safety concerns can be detected and responded to. TGA publishes weekly COVID-19 vaccine safety reports that include information about reported suspected side effects and other safety information from Australia and overseas. These reports are available at: www.tga.gov.au using the search term `COVID-19 vaccine weekly safety report'.

Active surveillance is also undertaken through the AusVaxSafety surveillance system, which sends follow up messages to recipients of COVID-19 vaccines to ask if they have experienced any potential side effects. The results of this surveillance monitoring are available at: www.ausvaxsafety.org.au.

Informed consent for COVID-19 vaccines should be obtained as per usual consent procedures for other vaccinations. This can depend on the state or territory in which the vaccine is being obtained. Verbal or implied consent is acceptable and written consent is not required.

Vaccination providers can use the 'Consent form for COVID-19 vaccination', which is available on my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au using the search term `COVID-19 vaccination provider resources'. The form is provided as an example and use of the form is not mandatory. Vaccination providers are welcome to use the form as presented or adapt the content for their unique requirements.

All COVID-19 vaccination providers must undertake a mandatory online COVID-19 Vaccination Training Program. The program is comprehensive and is informed by the latest advice from the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI), the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee , the TGA, the World Health Organisation, and clinical experts across my Department.

The COVID-19 Vaccination Training Program outlines specific questions that need to be discussed with patients prior to COVID-19 vaccination. This supplementary screening includes questions that cover contraindications and precautions, pregnancy and breastfeeding, age, immunocompromised individuals, and current symptoms or illness, and is in addition to the standard pre-screening checklist in the Australian Immunisation Handbook, the
COVID-19 vaccination consent form and the corresponding 'Information for providers and Frequently Asked Questions' which is available at the link above.

Specific precautions for each COVID-19 vaccine are covered within focussed training modules for each COVID-19 vaccine. Providers are required to complete each vaccine-specific module for the vaccines they administer. Updates are regularly provided to health professionals to ensure that best practice clinical information is available and followed. These updates reflect the latest findings of global clinical trials and research regarding risks, benefits and efficacy of vaccines for various cohorts.

My Department continues to provide accurate, evidence-based information on COVID-19 vaccines to the public, and clinical guidance for the administration of COVID-19 vaccines to health practitioners. Consumer resources on COVID-19 vaccines are available on my Department's website to ensure people can be informed about COVID-19 vaccines. These resources cover the different COVID-19 vaccines available in Australia and include information on preparing for vaccination and what to do after vaccination. These resources are available at: www.health.gov.au using the search term `COVID-19 vaccination patient resources'.

My Department's COVID-19 communications materials strongly encourage individuals to seek expert medical advice from their GP if they have any questions or concerns about COVID-19 vaccination. GPs and other healthcare providers are able to provide advice specific to the circumstances of each individual.

ATAGI has developed a number of resources to assist people with their decision-making and to inform their discussions with their GP or other healthcare provider. Resources include ATAGI's clinical guidance, shared decision-making guides and statements on use of COVID-19 vaccine in outbreak settings. These resources are available at the above links (provider or patient resources). All resources include a reference list with links to the research, studies and other information that have informed the development of that advice.

ATAGI meets weekly to consider emerging evidence and information (including safety monitoring information and weekly safety data published by the TGA) and recommendations may be updated as required. ATAGI publishes statements following these meetings to ensure the general public has access to the most up-to-date information, including rare but potentially serious adverse events following immunisation. These statements are available at: www.health.gov.au using the search term 'ATAGI' and clicking on the link to 'Statements'.

I note that the Nuremberg Code, developed in 1947, primarily applies to scientific experimentation on unwilling participants, outside the definition of 'Permissible Medical Experiments' established through the Nuremberg Trials in 1945 and 1946. As the vaccine is not mandatory and has been approved by a regulatory body for use in the general population, it is considered that the Nuremberg Code does not apply to the COVID-19 vaccine rollout.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Climate Change: Agriculture Industry
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning a petition requesting the House to develop a national minimum standard to use food additives-such as seaweed when farming ruminant livestock.

The Australian Government has committed to reducing emissions and meeting its commitments under the Pads Agreement. The agriculture sector will continue to play an important role, including through technology and supporting Improvements in biodiversity. The government's Technology Investment Roadmap has established a framework for Identifying and accelerating deployment of low emissions technologies and will be the foundation for Australia's Long-Term Emissions Reduction Strategy. The Roadmap's first annual statement identifies soil carbon measurement as a priority technology to lower emissions and livestock feeds and supplements as an emerging technology.

The government has committed $30.7 million from 2020 to 2026 to support the development and deployment of livestock feed technologies that reduce emissions and have the potential to increase productivity. This includes:
The $6 million Methane Emissions Reduction in Livestock program which supports research Into the abatement potential and productivity benefits of livestock feed technologies.
The $23 million Low Emissions Supplements to Grazing Animals at Scale program which will help develop technologies to deliver low emissions feed supplements to grazing animals.
$1.7 million to scale-up production of the red seaweed, Asparagopsis, including:
$1 million Accelerating Commercialisation grant under the Entrepreneurs' Program awarded to Tasmanian-based Sea Forest Pty Ltd to scale-up production and support the commercialisation of Asparagopsis
$675,000 grant from the $30 million Commercialisation Fund to Sea Forest to establish a processing and manufacturing facility for this seaweed product.

The government, industry and universities have also invested $270 million towards a new Marine Bioproducts Cooperative Research Centre, which will aim to develop high-protein seaweed for use as a low emissions livestock feed.

The Department of Industry, Science, Energy and Resources is also developing a livestock emissions framework for feed technologies. This framework could inform possible updates to the National Greenhouse Gas Inventory and enable the development of future Emissions Reduction Fund method and carbon neutral certifications.
The government will continue to progress the development of livestock feed technologies that reduce emissions and increase productivity.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture and Northern Australia, Mr Littleproud
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning your request to examine COVID-19 vaccine side effects (petition number EN3430).

Before any COVID-19 vaccine is approved for use in Australia, it is subject to the Therapeutic Goods Administration's (TGA) stringent assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large clinical trials. These trials, involving tens of thousands of participants, have shown that Australia's COVID-19 vaccines are safe and effective in preventing people from developing symptomatic COVID-19 and protect individuals against severe illness or death associated with COVID-19 infection. The TGA collects and evaluates reports of suspected side effects and has been doing so since the start of Australia's COVID-19 vaccine program.

This adverse event reporting is collected directly from health professionals and consumers, as well as through state and territory health departments, other Australian vaccine safety organisations and vaccine sponsors. Adverse events reported to the TGA are not necessarily caused by the vaccine. TGA reviews adverse event reports to look for any patterns that indicate a possible safety issue that should be investigated and thoroughly investigates these issues to determine what action is required, if any, to maintain public safety. TGA publishes the weekly outcomes of its ongoing monitoring and safety investigation of COVID-19 vaccines at: www.tga.gov.au/periodic/covid-19-vaccine-weekly-safety-report.

Decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines are based on the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI). ATAGI closely monitors local and international epidemiological data in relation to COVID-19 and vaccines and is currently meeting weekly to consider emerging evidence and information, including safety monitoring information and data from the TGA.
Australians can therefore be confident that the safety of the Australian population has always been the Australian Government's highest priority.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Commonwealth Integrity Commission
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 22 November 2021 regarding Petition EN3442, which requests the establishment of a federal anti-corruption body. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring our federal integrity framework is as robust as possible and is delivering on its promise to establish a Commonwealth Integrity Commission (CIC). The Government committed ongoing funding to the CIC in the 2019-20 Budget. Total funding over the next four financial years from 2021-22 would be $165.6 million.

The CIC will be an independent investigative agency with strong powers to target the most serious types of criminal conduct that threaten good public administration. The CIC will have broad jurisdiction over all Commonwealth entities, including law enforcement and public sector agencies, parliamentarians and their offices, higher education providers and research bodies. It will complement, rather than duplicate, other mechanisms which already exist to deal with issues of misconduct at the Commonwealth level. It will also complement integrity agencies that have been established by states and territories to deal with alleged corruption that falls within their areas of responsibility under Australia's federal system of government, including allegations relating to councils and state and territory government agencies and parliamentarians.

This is significant legislation that must be implemented effectively, both because of the scale of the reforms and because it is vital that Australians can have confidence that the CIC will operate fairly and effectively.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Women's Sanitary Products
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition EN3454 to make basic sanitary products available free of charge for people who menstruate Australia wide, in both public and government bodies.

The Australian Government supports the health and wellbeing of all women and girls, with improving access to essential health services and information a key focus of the National Women's Health Strategy 2020-2030 (Strategy). Acknowledging that women and girls should be supported throughout the life course, including change of life transitions, the Strategy identifies maternal, sexual and reproductive health as a key priority area.

In 2019, the Treasurer, the Hon Josh Frydenberg MP, the then Minister for Women, the Hon Kelly O'Dwyer MP, and myself announced the removal of the 10 per cent Goods and Services Tax from tampons, pads and other period products to improve accessibility and reduce period poverty.

The Government appreciates receiving suggestions from the community to better improve health outcomes, which are used to inform the development of future policy, noting any changes to policy will have an impact on Government outlays and therefore need to be considered carefully in a Budget context.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Workplace Relations
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 22 November 2021 regarding Petition Number EN3457 relating to the 'right to disconnect'.

Australia's industrial relations system has existing flexible and adaptable mechanisms for employers and employees to cooperatively respond to emerging issues. Modern awards, a unique feature of Australian industrial relations, are instruments that set employment conditions that recognise different needs across industries and occupations. The Fair Work Commission can hear applications from employees, employers and their representatives to vary awards to meet emerging needs or changing conditions at any time. Enterprise bargaining can also set terms and conditions at the workplace level that respond to emerging issues, for example the 'right to disconnect' clause in Victoria Police's recent enterprise agreement as highlighted in the petition. Other individual companies, such as BMW, Volkswagen and Daimler, are also adopting policies limiting out-of-hours communication.

In relation to 'burnout' as a work health and safety (WHS) issue, under the model WHS laws, persons conducting a business or undertaking, such as an employer, have a duty to ensure that all persons in the workplace, including workers, are not exposed to health and safety risks as far as reasonably practicable. A failure to comply with WHS duties can result in severe penalties and prosecution. In acknowledging the importance of managing mental health in the workplace, on 20 May 2021, WHS Ministers agreed to amend the model WHS Regulations to deal with psychological injury and protect workers.
The Government will continue to monitor developments in Australia and overseas in response to this issue.
I trust this information is of assistance. Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Commonwealth Integrity Commission

from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Medicare
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition EN3480 requesting all concession card holders be bulk billed automatically.

The Australian Government is committed to supporting all Australians to access quality and affordable health care by providing rebates for services listed on the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS). Through the 2021-22 Budget, the Government is investing $125.7 billion over the forward estimates, an increase of over $6 billion, as part of its ongoing commitment to guarantee Medicare for all Australians.

While the Government is responsible for setting the level of Medicare rebates available to patients, it has no authority to set the fees that specialists and GPs charge for their services. Medical practices are private businesses and determine their own fee arrangements, including whether they bulk bill their patients or charge co-payments.

The latest Medicare data shows that more Australians than ever are getting the medical care they need at no cost to themselves. For example, GP bulk billing rates reached an all-time high of 88.7 per cent for the period July 2020 to March 2021. This is three percentage points higher than the same period last year (85.7 per cent) and 6.7 percentage points higher than the same period in 2012-13 (82 per cent). Across all Medicare services, the bulk billing rate reached 80.9 per cent, an increase of 4.4 percentage points since 2012-13.

The Government's rapid and effective response to COVID-19 is reflected in these figures. Telehealth changes to Medicare introduced for the COVID-19 pandemic contributed to high bulk billing, while also reducing the risk of spreading the disease in the community.

Since the COVID-19 telehealth items were introduced in March 2020, almost 86.5 million telehealth services have been delivered to 16.1 million patients, with almost $4.4 billion in benefits paid. Over 89,110 providers have used telehealth services.

Patients should speak to their medical provider regarding fees or the possibility of bulkbilling. Doctors are encouraged to consider the personal circumstances of their patients when determining the fee they charge, and many do so.

To encourage GPs to bulk bill, the Government provides financial incentives for bulk billed services provided to Commonwealth concession card holders and patients under the age of 16. Currently the incentives are set at $6.55 per bulk billed service in metropolitan areas, and $9.90 per bulk billed service in regional, rural and remote areas.

To assist patients with out-of-pocket costs the Extended Medicare Safety Net provides additional Medicare benefits for Australians who have out-of-pocket costs for Medicare eligible out-of-hospital services once an annual threshold has been met.

As of January 2021, the general annual threshold is $2,184.30. For Commonwealth concession cardholders, including those with a Pension Concession Card, the annual threshold is $697.00. Medicare keeps a tally of out-of-pocket medical expenses and will increase the rebates once the threshold is reached.
If any of the signatories require a bulk billed health service, you may like to recommend the 'find a service' feature of the healthdirect website at: www.healthdirect.gov.au.
Healthdirect is funded by the Australian and state and territory governments, and helps patients identify a range of local health services, by location, with a range of filters.
The search results include information about a practice's billing policy—whether fees apply, if bulk billing is available for some patients, or if all services are bulk billed.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Commonwealth Integrity Commission
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 22 November 2021 regarding Petition EN3486, which requests the establishment of a federal anti-corruption body, and that parliamentarians found guilty of corruption be dealt with according to the law. I welcome the opportunity to respond to this petition.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring our federal integrity framework is as robust as possible and is delivering on its promise to establish the Commonwealth Integrity Commission (CIC). The Government committed ongoing funding to the CIC in the 2019-20 Budget. Total funding over the next four financial years from 2021-22 would be $165.6 million.

The CIC will be an independent investigative agency with strong powers to target the most serious types of criminal conduct that threaten good public administration. The CIC will have broad jurisdiction over all Commonwealth entities, including parliamentarians and their offices, law enforcement and public sector agencies, higher education providers and research bodies. It will complement, rather than duplicate, other mechanisms which already exist to deal with issues of misconduct at the Commonwealth level.

If the CIC uncovers evidence of criminal corruption, it will refer this evidence to the appropriate law enforcement or prosecutorial authorities. This will ensure that the courts appropriately remain the arbiter of whether a person is innocent or guilty.

This is significant legislation that must be implemented effectively, both because of the scale of the reforms and because it is vital that Australians can have confidence that the CIC will operate fairly and effectively.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Mount Compass: General Practitioners
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 21 February 2021 concerning petition number PN0498 on the Modified Monash Model (MMM) 2019 classification of Mount Compass, South Australia.

Please note I have previously responded in April 2020 to the Mount Compass Medical Centre in relation to their classification under the MMM 2019. There has been no change to the classification of the Mount Compass Medical Centre, since it was classified as MM 2 in 2015 upon introduction of the MMM.

I understand the Minister for Regional Health, Regional Communications and Local Government, the Hon Mark Coulton MP, has also provided information to the Mount Compass Medical Centre on their MMM classification as well as supporting Australian Government programs and incentives available to the community.

As advised to the Mount Compass Medical Centre, my Department uses the MMM to better target health workforce programs by categorising metropolitan, regional, rural and remote areas according to both geographical remoteness, as defined by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS), and town size. The MMM is a well-established geographical classification system providing further support to rural and remote Australia. It provides the basis for scaling incentives for medical practices to encourage doctors to remain in more rural and remote areas.

The MMM defines towns and cities by using the ABS Urban Centres and Localities (UCL) geographic data set. Under the ABS definition, Adelaide extends south to include the area of Sellicks Beach and the calculation used for distance measures from the edge of the larger UCL of Adelaide to the geographical midpoint of the Statistical Area Level 1 of Mount Compass.

The address of the Mount Compass Medical Centre is within 20 km of the edge of the Adelaide UCL. This means the location of Mount Compass is a MM 2 classification. The surrounding towns of Yankalilla and Keith and are classified as MM 5 as they are greater than 20 km from the boundary of Adelaide.

The Government established the Distribution Advisory Group (Group) to provide advice on towns raising concerns about their geographical classifications. In December 2019, this Group agreed that the MMM is a data based geographical classification system, and discretionary changes cannot be made to the classification of an area as a result. The Group agreed that any discretion as to program eligibility should be made within the context of individual programs and areas raising concerns should contact individual program administrators in relation to this.

The Government also uses the Distribution Priority Area (DPA) system to identify and address the maldistribution of the medical workforce in Australia. The DPA takes into consideration where patients access their services, as well as the services required by the community. Mount Compass has been classified as non-DPA meaning the area has been assessed as receiving adequate GP services for the needs of the community.

The DPA is reviewed and updated annually to reflect the latest available data. An annual update ensures any significant changes, including growth in population or significant reduction in services are accurately reflected. The next annual update to the DPA is scheduled for July 2021.

DPA status supports other programs. For example, recruitment can be targeted at new entrant International Medical Graduates and/or Bonded Doctors with return of service obligations. While I acknowledge that practices located in non-DPA areas may face recruitment challenges, there are many areas in greater need of GPs and the Government is committed to addressing this inequality.

The Government provides funding for a network of seven Rural Workforce Agencies (RWA), to assist communities that experience difficulties attracting and retaining health professionals into regional, rural and remote areas. These agencies work with local practices, communities and other organisations to ensure that a skilled, well-supported health workforce serves rural Australia.

My Department has been in contact with the RWA in South Australia, the Rural Doctors Workforce Agency, who have advised that they are aware of the issues the Mount Compass Medical Centre have been having with recruitment and have been providing assistance. The Rural Doctors Workforce agency can be contacted on (08) 8234 8277, or via their website at: www.ruraldoc.com.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
cc. The Hon Mark Coulton MP, Minister for Regional Health, Regional Communications and Local Government
Immigration Detention
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 26 October 2021 enclosing Petition PN0519, with 20 signatures, concerning the Australian Government's regional processing arrangements.

Australia is committed to providing protection to refugees consistent with the obligations set out in the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol. Regional processing arrangements provide illegal maritime arrivals an opportunity to have their protection claims assessed, and for those found to be refugees, resettlement in a third country, without compromising Australia's strong border protection policies.

Regional processing is a key pillar of Operation Sovereign Borders and supports the Government's strong border protection policies. These policies have successfully stemmed the flow of illegal maritime ventures to Australia, disrupted people smuggling activities in the region and prevented loss of life at sea.
The Government's policy that persons who arrive in Australia illegally by boat will not be settled in Australia, remains steadfast.

No transitory persons under regional processing arrangements in Nauru or Papua New Guinea (PNG) are detained. Transitory persons reside in community accommodation arrangements and have no restrictions on their movement. Transitory persons receive a range of services to support their residence in Nauru or PNG, including health and welfare, accommodation, education and employment opportunities.

Implementing a strong border policy requires commitment and financial investment. Australia has committed to meet all costs associated with regional processing in Papua New Guinea (PNG) and Nauru. Australia is working with regional processing countries to support durable migration pathways for all transferees.

Transitory persons under regional processing arrangements, including those temporarily in Australia, have permanent resettlement options and are being resettled. Transitory persons can seek to resettle in the United States or another third country, settle in PNG, or voluntarily return home or to another country in which they have a right of entry. Transitory persons are encouraged to engage in third country resettlement options and take steps to start the next phase of their lives.

People who were transferred to Australia for a temporary purpose are subject to return to a regional processing country when they no longer need to remain in Australia. Transitory persons are precluded from seeking protection in Australia and will have their protection claims assessed by either PNG or Nauru. This will continue while they are in Australia.

In all its dealings with detainees, the Department of Home Affairs remains committed to ensuring that detainees receive fair and reasonable treatment and an efficient standard of service that is sensitive to each of their needs.
Thank you for bringing Petition PN0519 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Safety, Compensation and Rehabilitation Act
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 25 October 2021 enclosing Petition PN0520 regarding the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 (SRC Act).

The Petition contends that the Parliament has allowed an Australian Government department to change the wording of the SRC Act. I can assure the Committee that the SRC Act has not been, and cannot be, amended outside of the Australian Parliament given that Commonwealth laws can only be amended by, or under, the authority of the Parliament. Of relevance to this petition, section 36(1) of the SRC Act, which provides for an assessment of an employee's capability of undertaking a rehabilitation program, has remained unchanged since the Act commenced operation on 24 December 1992.

Comcare was established by the SRC Act as an independent statutory agency responsible for managing and determining workers' compensation claims under the Act. If the petitioner disagrees with a decision made under the SRC Act, the Act provides for the reconsideration and review of determinations and decisions, including by application to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The SRC Act does not allow me to issue directions in relation to particular claims or intervene in individual workers' compensation claims.

The petitioner has requested that the House of Representatives issue a direction that Services Australia, Comcare and my department provide written assurance to comply with the Legal Services Directions 2017 (Legal Services Directions), waiving reliance on subsections 55ZG(2), 55ZG(3) and 55ZI(2) of the Judiciary Act 1903. The Legal Services Directions apply to Services Australia and my department as non-corporate Commonwealth entities. Components of the Legal Services Directions, such as the requirement to comply with the model litigant obligations set out in Appendix B, apply to Comcare as a corporate Commonwealth entity.

The Legal Services Directions are legally binding and enforceable, therefore a direction from the House to comply with them is unnecessary. The Legal Services Directions are not intended to provide a remedy, cause of action or any personal rights in addition to those already available through administrative or judicial review. This was confirmed in Caporale v Deputy Commissioner of Taxation [2013] FCA 427. A direction purportedly waiving reliance on subsections 55ZG(2), 55ZG(3) and 55ZI(2) of the Judiciary Act would be inconsistent with this position.
I trust this information is of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence concerning Petition EN1384 calling on the Australian Government for closure of Australia's borders and the shutdown of large gatherings. I regret the delay in responding.

I note Australia's situation concerning the pandemic has changed significantly since the petition was initiated. The Government continues to take a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, based on the latest medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

On 18 March 2020, the Governor-General, His Excellency General the Honourable David Hurley AC DSC (Retd), declared a human biosecurity emergency (Declaration) in relation to COVID-19 under section 475 of the Biosecurity Act 2015 (Act). In response to the Declaration, the Government introduced strict border and quarantine measures to protect the health of the Australian community, in particular the Overseas Travel Ban, and limiting most indoor and outdoor non-essential gatherings, with rules on essential gatherings also in place.

State and territory governments have primary operational responsibility for emergency management and public health in their jurisdictions, based on the medical advice from their respective Chief Health Officers. The specific measures imposed to control the spread of COVID-19 in each state and territory, including managing domestic border closures and restrictions on social gatherings within a state/territory, is the responsibility of the respective jurisdiction.

The Government regularly reviews the emergency directions, to ensure their appropriateness in terms of global and local epidemiology. The Government is considering when and how to reopen our borders safely. However, this will be a step-by-step process underpinned by the latest medical advice and based on robust risk assessments.
The Petitions Committee can be assured that the Government, along with the states and territories, is taking an evidence-based approach to COVID-19, and is committed to keeping Australians safe.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning Petition EN1386—to immediately ban international flights, except freight. I regret the delay in responding.
The Australian Government continues to take a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, based on the latest medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

On 18 March 2020, the Governor-General declared a human biosecurity emergency (Declaration) in relation to COVID-19 under section 475 of the Biosecurity Act 2015. In response to the Declaration, the Government introduced strict border and quarantine measures to protect the health of the Australian community. Australia's health protocols at international airports and seaports are consistent with the World Health Organization's International Health Regulations (2005) and the Biosecurity Act 2015. The purpose of the outbound and inbound travel restrictions is to control and manage the entry of COVID-19 in Australian territory and abroad through Australia's international ports. Since the restrictions were first executed, they continue to be effective in achieving this purpose.

The inbound and outbound travel restrictions do not apply to freight. Australia values engagement and continued trade with our economic partners in the Asia-Pacific region and beyond. If we closed our national borders to all incoming trade through freight, the impact to our Australian economy, small businesses, communities and trading partners would be significant. In response to the Declaration, Australia has maintained import and export activities and operations under strict border and quarantine measures at various state and territory ports of entry. These measures have slowed progress of trade within our borders and while these measures are regrettable, they are necessary to protect the health of Australian citizens and maintain the stability of the Australian economy.

It is important to note that state and territory governments have primary operational responsibility for emergency management and public health in their jurisdictions, which is based on the medical advice from their respective Chief Health Officers. The specific measures imposed to control the spread of COVID-19 in each state and territory, including managing the movement of freight within a state/territory, is the responsibility of the respective jurisdiction.
The Government is committed to bringing home Australians stranded overseas who wish to return, and has worked hard to ensure both their safety and that of the broader Australian community.

On 8 January 2021, National Cabinet agreed to a range of measures to further mitigate the risk of emerging COVID-19 variants arising from international and domestic air travel. International passenger caps in New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia will be temporarily halved from no later than 15 January 2021 to manage the flow of returning Australians and other travellers who have been potentially exposed to the new variants. Current international passenger caps in Victoria and South Australia and arrangements in the Northern Territory are considered manageable and will remain in place. The Government also introduced new measures to minimise the risk of importing COVID-19 via travellers. From 22 January 2021 all international travellers must provide proof of a negative COVID-19 test before flying, and travellers must wear masks on all international and domestic flights and in domestic airports.

The Government regularly reviews the emergency directions, including the international travel restrictions, to ensure their appropriateness in terms of global and local epidemiology. The Government is considering when and how to reopen our borders safely. However, this will be a step-by-step process underpinned by the latest medical advice and based on robust risk assessments.
The Government, along with the states and territories, is taking an evidence-based approach to COVID-19, and is committed to keeping Australians safe.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence concerning petition number EN1396, calling on the Australian Government to implement an immediate lockdown and strong social distancing measures. I apologise for the delay in responding.
I note Australia's situation concerning the pandemic has changed significantly since the petition was initiated.

Australia is fortunate to have an excellent health system with strong capacity and capability to respond to health emergencies such as communicable disease outbreaks and pandemics. The Government took a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, based on the latest medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee and the Communicable Diseases Network Australia. The relatively low number of COVID-19 cases in Australia is the result of the swift and successful implementation of public health measures.

The Government, along with state and territory governments, has continued to pursue an 'aggressive suppression' approach in Australia. This means that Governments have taken all necessary measures to shut down community transmission where it occurs. This strategy is based on the public health actions of early identification of cases through widespread testing, isolation of cases, rapid contact tracing and quarantine of close contacts. It relies on the community adhering to necessary measures, such as widespread testing, practicing good hygiene, maintaining physical distancing and staying home and getting tested if unwell.
These emergency response arrangements are flexible and scalable, enabling my Department to take a tailored response to the evolving COVID-19 situation.

As described in the National Health Security Agreement, state and territory governments have primary operational responsibility for emergency management and public health in their respective jurisdictions. State and territory governments' actions are based on the medical advice from their respective Chief Health Officers.
