State and territory governments' responsibility for on-the-ground measures has allowed an appropriate response adapted to each jurisdiction's local conditions and pandemic response stage. The specific measures imposed to control the spread of COVID-19 in each state and territory, enacted through respective jurisdictions' local public health and emergency legislation, includes quarantine and self-isolation, closing of non-essential businesses, and imposing requirements to wear Personal Protective Equipment (such as face masks).

I wish to mention that the Australian, state and territory governments are working together to coordinate an evidence-based response to COVID-19, based on the latest medical advice. Together these actions have placed us in a good position globally.

All levels of government regularly review the impact of changes to determine the pace at which restrictions are relaxed and to enable a prompt response to any resurgence. The Government is committed to opening up in a COVIDSafe way, alongside strategies of widespread testing, isolation of cases, contact tracing and quarantining of people who are close contacts.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence concerning petition number EN1398, calling on the Australian Government to introduce mandatory quarantine for all new arrivals, along with other mitigating strategies such as closing, universities and potentially more. I regret the delay in responding.

My Department is responsible for Australia's COVID-19 health response, as such the petition has been referred to me. I note Australia's situation concerning mandatory quarantine has changed substantially since the petition was initiated.

The Government took a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, based on the latest and best medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee. Australia's strategy was based on the twin pillars of containment and capacity building. Our health emergency response measures were proportionate, scalable and tailored to the situation as it evolved. They included closing borders and implementing quarantine periods; testing and contact tracing; physical distancing; and enhanced hygiene practices.

The Australian Government, along with state and territory governments, has continued to pursue an 'aggressive suppression' approach in Australia. This means that governments have taken all necessary measures, including introducing restrictions and closing borders, to shut down community transmission where it occurs. This has led to periods of elimination in parts of the country.

The effective response to COVID-19 has been underpinned by strong governance; collaborative arrangements with the states and territories and other Government agencies; surveillance systems; public health laboratory testing capability; the National Medical Stockpile; Australian Medical Assistance Teams; investment in research; and border measures implemented under the Biosecurity Act 2015.

Our international travel restrictions control and manage the entry of COVID-19 in Australian territory and abroad. These travel measures also help lower the number of new cases to levels that can be effectively managed by our health and quarantine system. As part of Australia's strategy to combat the outbreak, hotel quarantine was mandated by the National Cabinet on 27 March 2020 and have proven to be highly successful—limiting the spread of COVID-19 to the Australian community when compared to many nations around the world.
Other key measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19 include:

Ongoing review and implementation of public health measures such as social distancing policies, transmission risk and prevention strategies, noting state and territory governments have primary operational responsibility for emergency management and public health in their jurisdictions.

The Government's $16.5 billion emergency health response includes guaranteeing Medicare and access to medicines; supporting our hospitals; ageing and aged care; medical research and vaccines; and prioritising mental health and preventive health.

Community engagement strategies and targeted national media campaigns to reach Culturally and Linguistically Diverse groups, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, older Australians and people with disabilities.
Australia stands as a model for many nations on how to navigate the COVID-19 crisis. The above response has placed Australia in a good position globally.

The Government, along with the states and territories, is taking an evidence-based approach to COVID-19, and is committed to keeping Australians safe. All levels of government regularly review the impact of changes to determine the pace at which restrictions arc relaxed and to enable a prompt response to any resurgence. It is vital all Australians continue to take personal responsibility to protect themselves and others.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Trade and Tourism
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN1416—Release an economic stimulus package. Your correspondence has been referred to me and I apologise for the delay in responding to you.

The Australian Government recognises that those in the travel and tourism industries were among the first affected by the COVID 19 pandemic, through the closure of international borders and domestic restrictions to keep Australians safe. The Government provided more than $20 billion in assistance to the tourism sector, including through JobKeeper, the Cash Flow Boost, and a number of targeted sectoral support programs. These included the $258 million Consumer Travel Support program for travel agents and tour operators, the $139.6 million Supporting Australia's Exhibiting Zoos and Aquariums program, and the $56 million Business Events Grants program. The Government's support helped preserve jobs in the tourism sector and put it in a position to take advantage of domestic and international tourists now that borders are reopening and restrictions have eased.

The Government also partnered with state and territory governments to provide additional targeted support to tourism businesses in response to the most recent lockdowns. Measures included JobSaver in NSW, the Business Costs Assistance Program in Victoria, and the Tourism and Hospitality Sector Hardship Program in Queensland.

The SME Recovery Loan Scheme is also supporting tourism businesses by increasing lenders' ability to provide cheaper credit, allowing many SMEs to access additional funding to get through the impact of COVID-19, recover and invest for the future. The Government announced on 13 December 2021 that it proposes to amend the Scheme Rules to extend the SME Recovery Loan Scheme to provide support to SMEs adversely economically affected by the pandemic.

Under the existing SME Recovery Loan Scheme, loans are available from 1 April 2021 until 31 December 2021 with a Government guarantee of 80 per cent. Under the proposed Scheme extension, loans will be available from 1 January 2022 until 30 June 2022, with a Government guarantee of 50 per cent. Further information, including a list of participating lenders, can be found at: www.treasury.gov.au/coronavirus/sme-recovery-loan-scheme

On 25 November, the Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment released for consultation a proposed strategy to rebuild and reimagine Australia's visitor economy. THRIVE 2030 (The Re-Imagined Visitor Economy) will be the national long-term plan for the sector's recovery and sustainable growth. The draft strategy sets the target of returning the industry to its pre-COVID levels of visitor expenditure by 2024 by diversifying markets, experiences and destinations, modernising supply side enablers, and collaborating across all stakeholders to achieve success. More information about the strategy is available at the following link: www.austrade.gov.au/news/publications/national-visitor-economy-strategy-thrive-2030-consultation-draft.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Live Animal Exports
Dear Chair

Thank you for referring the petition of 19 October 2020, calling for the end of the live animal export trade (Petition number: EN1696). I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention and apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government takes the welfare of all animals very seriously and understands its importance to the Australian community. It is important to note that the majority of livestock export voyages are undertaken without incident. Publicly available data indicates that more than 99 per cent of livestock exported from Australia arrive at their destination with good animal welfare outcomes.

Australia's livestock export industry is strongly regulated. The Department of Agriculture, Water and the Environment (the department) plays an important role in regulating the export of live animals and remains strongly committed to ensuring high welfare standards are maintained in this trade. The Australian Standards for the Export of Livestock (ASEL) sets the minimum animal health and welfare requirements the livestock export industry must meet throughout the supply chain, from sourcing to completion of disembarkation overseas. For further information visit agriculture.gov.au/export/controlled-goods/live-animals/livestock/australian-standards-livestock.

When feeder and slaughter livestock arrive in an importing country, exporters must ensure they are handled and slaughtered in accordance with the Exporter Supply Chain Assurance System (ESCAS). ESCAS is a set of regulatory conditions placed on exporters, requiring them to have arrangements in place with supply chain partners to ensure humane treatment and handling of livestock is provided from the time the animals arrive in the importing country up to and including the point of slaughter. Australia is the only country in the world with such a regulatory system in operation. Any non-compliance with ESCAS requirements is taken seriously by the department and fully investigated.

The export of Australian livestock plays an important role in providing high quality nutrition to countries where inadequate infrastructure or consumer reluctance impede the growth of fresh meat imports. They also provide high quality breeding animals for those countries seeking to improve their self-sufficiency and economic growth through agricultural diversity. The live export trade generates significant income for the Australian economy and supports thousands of people employed across associated industries throughout rural and regional Australia. Whilst I appreciate the petitioner's view that live export should be banned, I am committed to facilitating continual improvement in the live export trade and supporting an economically and socially sustainable industry.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture and Northern Australia, Mr Littleproud
Voting
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter to the former Assistant Minister for Finance, Charities and Electoral Matters, Senator the Hon Zed Seselja, dated 19 October 2020, referring to petition number EN1703. As the recently appointed Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters, I am responding to the Committee's request.

I note the petition, which requests an abolition of preference votes and the examination of the reimbursement of electoral expenditure to eligible political parties, candidates and Senate groups who receive four percent of the vote.

Since 1918, Australia has conducted full preferential voting in the House of Representatives in accordance with the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. Preferential voting systems require a candidate to build a wider base of support from an electorate than rival candidates could achieve, as compared to the support they require under a first past-the-post method.

In 2016, significant reform to Australia's Senate voting system occurred with the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 2016. This reform placed the control of preference allocation back into the hands of the voter. This amendment has given greater control to the voter by allowing the voter to select and preference the parties or candidates that best represent their interests. This system no longer facilitates the exchange of preferences between parties or candidates but leaves the voter in full control of determining which party or candidate will get their Senate vote.

Since 1984 there has been a Commonwealth reimbursement scheme funding electoral expenditure. With the intention to contribute to creating a more 'level playing field' and to reduce the potential for both real and perceived undue influence and corruption. In 2018 the Electoral Legislation Amendment (Electoral Funding and Disclosure Reform) Act 2018 was introduced and placed a cap on per-vote funding for elections to the amount spent by the party or candidate. The amendment limits public election funding to demonstrated electoral spending, without creating cash flow issues for smaller parties and independent candidates.
Thank you for bringing the concerns referred to in the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Electoral Matters, Mr Morton
Aged Care
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021concerning Petition EN2051 to legislate mandatory nurse staffing ratios in residential aged care facilities, amongst other reforms.

The Australian Government is mindful of calls for staffing ratios, including for nurses, in residential aged care facilities. A proposed future funding model, the Australian National Aged Care Classification, is under development to potentially replace the current Aged Care Funding Instrument as an improved method of assessing the level and type of care required by residents. This is one of many reforms the Government is planning to assist providers to meet the community's high expectations of care for our senior Australians.

Approved providers of aged care homes are required to meet the Aged Care Quality Standards (Standards) to ensure quality care and services are provided to all residents. In relation to staffing levels, this includes a requirement that aged care providers have a workforce that is sufficient, and is skilled and qualified to provide safe, respectful and quality care and services. Providers are expected to regularly review staffing levels and the mix of skills of their workforce, and adapt these to respond to the changing needs and situations of residents.

In the 2020-21Budget, the Government announced $10.8 million over five years to support and encourage more nurses to choose aged care as a clinical specialty. This funding has expanded the Australian College of Nursing scholarship program.

The Government is also in the process of establishing an Aged Care Transition to Practice Program and a skills development program for nurses in aged care. With this funding, aged care nurses will have enhanced access to important training opportunities while also increasing the pool of nurses to care for our older Australians.

In relation to the aged care complaints process, the Aged Care Quality and Safety Commission (Commission) assesses and monitors the performance of residential aged care homes against the Standards. Created by the Government in 2018, the Commission is more than just a hotline or a body to resolve complaints about services.

Through their engagement and education work, the Commission aims to build confidence and trust in aged care, empower consumers, support providers to comply with the Standards, and promote best practice service provision.

Additionally, the Older Peron's Advocacy Network (OPAN) has been funded by the Government to deliver the National Aged Care Advocacy Program (NACAP) nationally since 2017. The NACAP provides free, independent and confidential advocacy support and information to older people (and their representatives) receiving or seeking to receive

Government funded aged care services. Advocacy services ensure the needs of older people are supported and they are empowered to make informed decisions about their care. NACAP also educates Government-subsidised aged care service providers about advocacy and consumer rights.

Advocacy services ensure that consumers are placed at the centre of the process and the advocate acts at the consumer's direction. Older people and their representatives can connect with their local OPAN member organisation by calling 1800 700 600 between 6am -10pm 7 days a week or through OPAN's website at: www.opan.com.au/opan-network/. This includes the regular provision of face-to-face support to the individual and with families and service providers, within the OPAN office network locations. Some outreach services are provided within the scope of the current NACAP program. Further, advocates can support families in-person in cases of serious incidents in residential care.

OPAN organisations offer free education and information sessions to consumers and potential consumers of Commonwealth funded aged care services, and their families, carers or representatives. OPAN offers these education sessions to a range of consumers and settings, including:
groups of people receiving Commonwealth funded aged care services in their home or retirement village
people residing in residential aged care, often at resident meetings
community based respite groups
social interest groups such as Probus
support groups such as those for carers, pain, dementia and diabetes.
Aged care advocates come from diverse professional backgrounds including aged care, community services and the disability sector.
Ensuring quality care for older Australians is a key priority for the Government, and we will carefully consider the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aged Care Quality and Safety.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Senior Australians and Aged Care Services, Mr Colbeck

subdebateinfo.title: Coeliac Disease: Availability of Gluten Free Food

p.span: Coeliac Disease: Availability of Gluten Free Food
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Greg Hunt MP, concerning petition EN2083 calling on the Australian Government to regulate the price of gluten free foods for Australians with gluten intolerance or coeliac disease. Your correspondence has been referred to me as Minister for Senior Australians and Aged Care Services and Minister for Sport with portfolio responsibility for this matter.

I appreciate that adhering to a gluten free diet to manage conditions such as coeliac disease or gluten intolerance can be difficult for some Australians. However, the Australian Government is not currently considering adjusting the price of gluten free foods.

The Australian Dietary Guidelines (Guidelines) provide evidence-based advice on the types and amounts of foods that Australians should eat for good health, meeting nutrient requirements, and the prevention of diet-related diseases (such as diabetes and heart disease).

While the Guidelines are not designed specifically for individual conditions such as coeliac disease or gluten intolerance, many of the foods recommended in the Guidelines in the five food groups are naturally gluten free. These foods are often more affordable than specialised gluten free substitutes. For example:
rice and polenta are naturally gluten free foods within the 'Grain (cereal) Foods' food group and contain many of the same nutrients (such as vitamins minerals) associated with other grain foods
all unprocessed foods in the remaining four food groups are naturally gluten free (e.g. milk, fruits and vegetables, meat, poultry, eggs)
fruit and vegetables, particularly leafy greens, provide many of the same nutrients, including fibre, that are provided in the 'Grain (cereal) Foods' food group.
More information on healthy food choices is available on the Eat for Health website at: www.eatforhealth.gov.au.

Consultations with an Accredited Practising Dietitian (APD) are available for patients who meet criteria under the Medicare funded Chronic Disease Management program. An APD can provide individualised advice on how to prepare gluten free meals on a budget, referrals for this program can be provided by medical practitioners such as a GP.

Eligible Australians can find the contact details for local APDs via the Dietitians Australia website at: www.dietitiansaustralia.org.au/find-an-apd or by telephoning the national office on (02) 6189 1200 or 1800 812 942.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Senior Australians and Aged Care Services, Mr Colbeck
Sport
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 15 February 2021 concerning Petition EN2204 calling on the House of Representatives to cease Australian Government funding to the state of Queensland for the 2032 Queensland Olympic and Paralympic Games (Games) bid.

The Government is committed to ensuring all Australians have an opportunity to participate in sport and physical activity. Sport improves the health and wellbeing of millions of Australians and brings communities together when our athletes take on the best in the world. Australia is experienced in hosting major sporting events, and we are proud of our track record of delivering spectacular events responsibly.

The Government is supporting South East Queensland's bid to host the 2032 Games, and has committed up to $10 million towards developing a compelling Australian Bid. Australia remains committed to sport and hosting major events such as the Games, and views this bid as an opportunity to engage all Australians in a common purpose to reinforce unity, enhance our performance and reputation in international sport, and come together to celebrate our enduring love of sport as a nation.

The 2019 Queensland Government's Value Proposition Assessment identified the Games would result in a positive economic return for Queensland, including job creation; supporting around 130,000 jobs directly and tens of thousands of jobs indirectly. The Games will also provide tourism and trade opportunities, including an estimated uplift of $20.2 billion in international visitor expenditure between 2020 and 2036, and increased export opportunities of up to $8.6 billion. More than 50 per cent of the international visitor expenditure ($10.1 billion) would also be expended in regional Queensland.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Sport, Mr Colbeck
Aged Care
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence on behalf of the signatories to the EN2222 petition concerning Home Care Package (HCP) funding. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is investing more in HCPs so that senior Australians can access the care they need to live in their own homes for longer, by reducing wait times for HCPs and connecting older Australians to essential care sooner. I am pleased to advise that the Government announced a record $6.5 billion for an additional 80,000 HCPs in the 2021-22 Budget. These HCPs commenced release in July 2021, with 40,000 being released in 2021-22 and a further 40,000 in 2022-23.

The Government has now invested a record $11.9 billion in an additional 163,105 HCPs since the 2018-19 Budget, taking the total number of HCPs from 59,300 in 2011-12 to 275,597 in 2024-25. Overall, the Government's record investment in aged care has increased from $12.6 billion in 2011-12 to $24.6 billion in 2020-21.

For people in urgent need of care, assessed as a high priority, the Government's investment has enabled a significant reduction in wait times. Currently, people assessed as a high priority can access their approved level HCP within one month. Importantly, around 99 per cent of senior Australians waiting for a HCP at their assessed level also have been offered support from the Government, including an interim HCP or through the Commonwealth Home Support Programme, and they continue to have access to Australia's world-class health care system.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence on behalf of petitioners concerning access to hyoscine butylbromide (Buscopan®) on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) (petition number EN2235). I regret the delay in responding.

Since 2013, the Australian Government has approved more than 2,800 new or amended listings on the PBS. This represents an average of around 30 listings or amendments per month, or one each day, at an overall investment by the Government of $14 billion.

It is a priority of the Government to provide all Australians access to safe, effective and affordable medicines. The Government has a policy to list all medicines on the PBS, following a recommendation to do so by the independent and expert Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC). While the Government is responsible for listing medicines on the PBS, pharmaceutical companies that hold the relevant clinical evidence are responsible for applying to the PBAC for PBS subsidy.

Buscopan® is available in a tablet and an injection form. Buscopan® injection is currently available on the PBS to treat palliative and repatriation patients. Further information about the PBS listing of Buscopan® injection and the specific criteria for PBS access is available on the PBS website at: www.pbs.gov.au/medicine/item/3473T-4279F-5317W. Buscopan® tablets are not subsidised through the PBS. Patients may be interested to know Buscopan® tablets are available in pack sizes of 10, 20 and 100. The packs of 10 and 20 tablets are available over the counter at pharmacies, while the 100-tablet pack requires a prescription from a prescriber.

To date, the PBAC has not received an application requesting listing of Buscopan® tablets from Sanofi-aventis Healthcare Pty Ltd (Sanofi-aventis), the pharmaceutical company responsible for Buscopan®. Patients may wish to contact Sanofi-aventis to ask whether it intends to request the PBS listing of Buscopan®. Sanofi-aventis can be contacted by telephone on 1800 640 791. Pharmaceutical companies are private entities that make their own decisions regarding their products and cannot be compelled by the Government to apply for PBS subsidy.

As with all consumer goods, price competition applies to pharmacy and private (non-PBS) prescription medicines. Patients may wish to compare the prices of their medicines at different pharmacies to identify the best price.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Working Holiday Maker Program
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 March 2021 enclosing Petition EN2360 concerning decreasing the amount of specified work required for second Working Holiday Maker (WHM) visa holders to become eligible for a third WHM visa. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The main purpose of the WHM Program is to build people-to-people and cultural links between Australia and partner countries. While WHMs can supplement their holiday with short-term employment, work is not the primary objective of the visa and WHMs are not required to work at all while in Australia.

The Australian Government recognises the role of WHMs as an important source of labour, particularly in remote and regional Australia, but is also aware of concerns about the Program being used solely as a work visa or potentially displacing Australian workers.

While in Australia, WHMs are free to work in any industry, location and occupation they choose. They can also choose to undertake three and six months of 'specified work' in certain regions, industries and roles in order to qualify for a second and third visa. The current specified work arrangements have been set by the Government after extensive consultation, and aim to address identified skill shortages and maximise the benefit for specified regions and industries, while minimising the impact on local job opportunities for Australians.
The Government appreciates that WHMs, and the role they play filling critical skills shortages across Australia, are important to Australia's economic recovery.

A range of changes to visa arrangements announced during 2020-21 have been made to ensure WHMs continue to support COVID-19 critical sectors of the economy. These measures will help with existing labour shortages and the recovery effort and include:

WHMs working in critical sectors, such as agriculture; food processing; health, aged care, disability and child care; and tourism and hospitality are exempt from the six-month limitation with one employer;
a visa pathway for temporary visa holders employed in critical sectors is available within the existing COVID-19 Pandemic event (subclass 408) visa;

a replacement WHM visa with nil visa application charge (VAC) is available from 1 July 2021 for WHMs offshore who were unable to use their visa fully during COVID-19, to enable them to come to Australia once borders are open; and
a replacement WHM visa with nil VAC will be available from March 2022 for WHMs who remained in Australia during COVID-19, allowing them to stay longer in Australia.

The Government will continue to explore further options for the WHM visa, noting that the Program is reviewed on a regular basis with stakeholder views taken into consideration. When considering potential changes to WHM visa policy settings, immigration risks, labour market impacts and protections for vulnerable workers are primary considerations.

In June 2020, the former Acting Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Alan Tudge MP, asked the Joint Standing Committee on Migration (JSCM) to inquire into and report on the WHM Program. The JSCM released its report on 30 November 2020 and this will inform future developments in the Program. The Government is considering all the recommendations and will provide a response to be tabled in Parliament.

On 22 June 2021, I was pleased to announce that from March 2022, all WHM visa holders (both subclass 417 and subclass 462) will be able to count tourism and hospitality work carried out in Northern, remote and very remote areas of Australia as 'specified work' for the purpose of applying for a second or third WHM visa.

The legislative and systems changes to enable application lodgements will come into effect in March 2022, but applicants can start their specified work in tourism and hospitality in these areas immediately.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2360 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
Road Safety
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 13 May 2021, regarding a petition proposing a royal commission to investigate truck driver fatalities (Petition Ministerial Referral EN2410).

I acknowledge the desire for a royal commission to investigate the deaths of essential heavy vehicle drivers. While this serious issue would not fall within the parameters required for a royal commission, the Australian Government recognises and supports the role of our truck drivers as essential to the delivery of freight and goods across our country.

The death of any heavy vehicle driver in the course of their employment is a tragedy. The Government is committed to reducing the number of heavy vehicle fatalities on our roads and ensuring our heavy vehicle drivers have a safe work environment that allows them to return home to their families.

The primary purpose of the Road Safety Remuneration Act 2012 (the Act) was the establishment of the Road Safety Remuneration Tribunal (Tribunal). The decision to abolish the Act was informed by two independent reviews and extensive feedback received from industry participants. The independent reviews and industry consultation recommended the Tribunal be dismantled as there was no definitive link between safety outcomes and rates of remuneration.

In 2016, the Government redirected funds from the abolished Tribunal to the National Heavy Vehicle Regulator to deliver the Heavy Vehicle Safety Initiative (HVSI). The Government provides approximately $5.5 million each year for the HVSI, which funds heavy vehicle safety projects delivered across Australia. Projects have included the development of innovative heavy vehicle safety technologies, the delivery of driver training and the provision of wellbeing initiatives such as "Healthy Heads in Trucks and Sheds". To date, five HVSI rounds have provided more than $22 million across 89 grants.

The HVSI is one of many programs the Government has in place to help ensure heavy vehicle drivers stay safe. Although the Act has ceased, the Government's investment in heavy vehicle safety is helping to reduce the number of heavy vehicle driver fatalities. Between 2016 and 2020, the number of fatalities involving heavy vehicles declined by a total of 10 per cent. I have attached further information on some of the Government's programs and investments.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Road Safety and Freight Transport, Mr Buchholz
cc The Hon Barnaby Joyce, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development

In 2019, the Government established the Office of Road Safety to coordinate a national approach to reduce road trauma, and lead the Commonwealth actions towards zero deaths and serious injuries on Australian roads by 2050.

The soon-to-be-released National Road Safety Strategy 2021-30 identifies both heavy vehicle safety and workplace road safety as key priorities for the next decade of action on road safety. Actions to be taken to-address road safety for heavy vehicle drivers will be contained in the National Road Safety Action Plan 2021-25, due for release in the coming months following agreement by infrastructure and transport ministers.

The Office of Road Safety provides funding to raise awareness and encourage innovation in road safety through the $4 million Road Safety Awar ness and Enablers Fund and the $12 million Road Safety Innovation Fund. These programs are in addition to the $3 billion Road Safety Program which has funded over 1,000 projects around Australia since it commenced in January 2021. The types of projects being funded under the Road Safety Program include the construction and upgrade of rest stops, widening of roads, installation of audible tactile line marking and better separation of vehicles from cyclists and pedestrians.

In 2018, infrastructure and transport ministers initiated a 'back to basics' review of the HVNL. The primary purpose of the HVNL is to ensure a safe and efficient heavy vehicle journey. The HVNL review will deliver a more modem, outcomes focused law that will improve safety for all road users and support productivity.

In May 2021, infrastructure and transport ministers agreed to a forward program of work for the HVNL Review. The program will develop options spanning duties and driver health, fatigue management, vehicles and access, the operator assurance scheme and technology and data. The NTC will deliver more detailed advice to ministers over the next 12 months, with final legislation to be presented to ministers in mid-2023.

The Government's record $110 billion 10-year infrastructure pipeline is supporting and securing jobs, helping meet our national freight challenge and getting Australians home sooner and safer. Some of the Government's key infrastructure investments that are making roads safer for truck drivers include:

$4.9 billion to upgrade key freight routes through the Roads of Strategic Importance (ROSI) initiative which will ensure our key freight roads efficiently connect agricultural and mining regions to ports, airports and other transport hubs.
Over $10 billion for the Bruce Highway Upgrade Program, leading to a 49% reduction in fatalities, a 21% reduction in crashes and a 13% reduction in serious injuries since 2013.
$5.6 billion for the Pacific Highway from 2013, halving fatalities from more than 40% prior to the commencement of the upgrade in 1996 to less than 20 per year in recent years.
Further programs under the infrastructure pipeline supporting heavy vehicle safety outcomes include:
$6.2 billion for the Roads to Recovery Program from 2013-14 to 2023-24; 50% of which will go to supporting rural and regional councils.

$1.1 billion to the Black Spot Program from 2013-14 to 2023-24 to target road locations where crashes are occurring, reducing the risk of crashes through funding safety measures such as traffic signals, roundabouts, turning lanes, safety barriers and lighting.
$760 million to the Bridges Renewal Program from 2015-16 to 2024-25 to upgrade and replace bridges to enhance access for local communities and facilitate higher productivity vehicle access.

$607 million for the Heavy Vehicle Safety Productivity Program from 2013-14 to 2024-25 to fund infrastructure projects that improve the productivity and safety outcomes of heavy vehicle operations across Australia.

To further assist with reducing truck driver and other road user fatalities, the Government has also committed $20 million for the Strategic Local Government Asset Assessment Project (SLGAAP). The SLGAAP is helping local government road managers across Australia to undertake capacity assessments of their road assets.
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 13 May 2021 to the Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon Karen Andrews MP concerning petition EN2453 calling for the ban on international travel to be revoked. As my portfolio is responsible for Australia's COVID-19 health response, your letter has be referred to me.

On 18 March 2020, the Governor-General declared that a human biosecurity emergency exists under section 475 of the Biosecurity Act 2015 (Biosecurity Act) in relation to the listed human disease 'human coronavirus with pandemic potential' (COVID-19). The existence of a human biosecurity emergency period allows me, as the Health Minister, to determine requirements and give directions under the Act that are necessary to prevent or control the entry, emergence, establishment or spread of COVID-19 in Australian territory or part of Australian territory. The Biosecurity (Human Biosecurity Emergency) (Human Coronavirus with Pandemic Potential) (Overseas Travel Ban Emergency Requirements) Determination 2020 (Overseas Travel Ban) is one off our emergency Determinations currently in place.
The Act requires my satisfaction that the emergency requirements are:
likely to be effective in, or contribute to, achieving its purpose
appropriate and adapted to the purpose
no more restrictive or intrusive than required in the circumstances
are applied in a manner that is no more restrictive or intrusive than required in the circumstances
in place for only as long as necessary.

The Overseas Travel Ban moderates the volume of Australians travelling overseas and thus seeking to return home, reducing the risk posed to Australia's quarantine capacity, health systems, and the Australian community, as well as the risks to those individuals who may otherwise be in a country with high COVID-19 prevalence. The Overseas Travel Ban greatly assists the Australian Government's efforts to prevent and control the entry and spread of COVID-19 in Australian territory.

The Government recognises citizens and permanent residents may have exceptional circumstances or compelling reasons for needing to leave Australian territory. The exemption process overseen by the Department of Home Affairs ensures that the travel restriction is no more restrictive or intrusive than required in the circumstances of the current global pandemic.

The Government and the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee review the emergency period and its response measures, including the Overseas Travel Ban, to ensure ongoing appropriateness and proportionality in terms of global and local epidemiology, including the emergence of more highly transmissible variants.
Opening Australia's borders too soon could see a resurgence in cases, undoing progress and placing strain on Australia's healthcare resources and quarantine systems.

The Government continues to consider when and how to reopen our borders safely. This is a step-by-step process underpinned by the latest medical advice and based on robust risk assessments. Positively, eligible travellers to New Zealand are exempt from the Overseas Travel Ban, under the quarantine free safe travel arrangements between the Australian and New Zealand Governments.

Although Australia has approved COVID-19 vaccines to prevent development of serious disease if an individual becomes infected, the vaccination program should not be viewed as a panacea or a complete substitute for other public health interventions. All Australians must continue with COVID safe practices.

There remains insufficient data as to whether the vaccines also prevent vaccinated individuals transmitting the virus to others. A person could be vaccinated but still be able to transmit. Until there is a better understanding of this, the purpose for rolling out vaccination in the short term is to protect individuals from developing disease. It should be assumed, until proven otherwise, that vaccinated individuals remain potentially infectious to others.
Thank you for bringing this petition and its concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Paid Parental Leave Scheme
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email dated 24 November 2021 to the Minister for Government Services and Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Senator the Hon Linda Reynolds CSC, concerning petition number EN2516 regarding the Paid Parental Leave scheme. As the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your email was referred to me for reply.

In Australia, Paid Parental Leave is fully funded through general taxation revenue. The Australian Government provides nearly $2.5 billion each year in support to families through Parental Leave Pay and Dad and Partner Pay. This is a non-contributory system, which means that all parents who are eligible for government-funded Paid Parental Leave can access this support when needed. In contrast, most OECD countries fund parental leave payments through contributory schemes or social insurance models. Under these schemes, only people who have paid contributions to a social insurance fund can access parental leave payments.

Parental Leave Pay has an income test to maintain fairness in the overall support provided to families with considerations of the cost of the scheme to taxpayers. To meet the income test for Parental Leave Pay, a claimant must have an individual adjusted taxable income that does not exceed the income limit in the financial year prior to the date of birth or adoption, or the date of claim, whichever is earlier. The income limit for the 2019-20 financial year was $150,000, and for the 2020-21 financial year it is $151,350.

As Parental Leave Pay is primarily designed to assist working women, the income test was designed so that the least number of women would be precluded from the scheme. As such, only the woman's income counts toward the income test, not the household income, so that working women will not be excluded from the scheme on the basis of their partner's income.

The income test also recognises that women who are on a higher income, and are primary carers, are generally in a stronger position to obtain paid parental leave and other family-friendly benefits as part of their conditions of employment. The Government acknowledges that, unfortunately, this will not be the case for all families, and a small number of women will find they are unable to meet the income test.

The Government continues to monitor the effect of its family assistance programs to ensure they are efficient, effective and appropriately targeted to give children the best start in life. The issues raised in Petition EN2516 will be considered in future reviews of paid parental leave arrangements.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
Gender and Sexual Orientation
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence to Senator the Hon Linda Reynolds CSC, Minister for Government Services, concerning Petition EN2668, which requests the listing of gender affirmation procedures on the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS). This matter has been referred to me as the Minister for Health. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that all Australians are able to access timely and affordable, high quality health care by providing Medicare rebates for services listed on the MBS and free hospital services for public patients in public hospitals.

While there is no specific MBS item for gender affirmation surgery, MBS rebates are available for patients to cover a range of surgical procedures and specialist consultations that may be performed as part of the gender affirmation process, if the services are deemed by the treating practitioner to be clinically relevant.

Before a new medical procedure or treatment can be publicly funded on the MBS, an application would need to be assessed by the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC). MSAC is an independent, expert advisory group which provides advice to the Government on whether a new medical service or technology should be publicly funded, based on an assessment of the comparative safety, clinical effectiveness and cost effectiveness, using the best available evidence. To date, no application has been submitted to MSAC to list specific gender affirmation surgery items on the MBS. More information about the MSAC process is available on the MSAC website at: www.msac.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Food Imports
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 9 August 2021 concerning a petition on the inspection and testing of imported foods. I note that this matter has been referred to me under Standing Order 209(a) and (b) of the Petitions Committee as it falls within my portfolio responsibilities as the Minister for Agriculture and Northern Australia. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Department of Agriculture, Water and the Environment is responsible for administering the Imported Food Control Act 1992 (the IFC Act). The IFC Act provides for the Imported Food Inspection Scheme (IFIS) that refers food at the border for inspection and testing to monitor that it complies with the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code (the Code) and does not pose a risk to public health and safety. The operation of the IFIS is set out in the Imported Food Control Regulations 2019 (the Regulations) which include the frequency of inspection and testing that can be applied to imported foods, based on how they are classified.

Imported foods are referred for inspection under the IFIS based on whether they are classified as risk, compliance agreement, or surveillance food and their history of compliance. Food is classified as risk based on advice from Food Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ) that it has the potential to pose a medium or high risk to public health for a particular hazard or hazards and is scheduled in the Imported Food Control Order 2019. Foods that are imported under a compliance agreement are classified as compliance agreement food and are not referred to the IFIS, but rather the department audits the importer's food safety management system for compliance. All other foods are classified as surveillance food.

The regulations specify the frequency of inspection that can apply to imported food. Food classified as risk is referred for inspection and testing under the IFIS at a rate of 100 per cent of consignments. This rate of inspection is reduced to 25 per cent and then 5 per cent if consignments are compliant. Surveillance food is monitored at a rate of 5 per cent of consignments. If an imported food fails inspection subsequent imports (based on the product, producer and country of origin) they are referred under the IFIS at 100 per cent until a history of compliance is demonstrated.

Imported food may be analysed for microbiological contaminants, natural toxicants, metal contaminants (such as tin, lead and arsenic), food additives and chemical contaminants (including pesticides) to check compliance with limits set in the Code. The tests applied change periodically based on the analytical data obtained over time and as new information becomes available. Information on the tests applied is provided on the department's website.

In relation to pesticides, a residue screen of around 108 chemicals is applied to imported fruit and vegetable products referred to the IFIS. Any failure is reported in monthly failing food reports available at awe.gov.au/biosecurity-trade/import/goods/food/inspection-compliance/failing-food-reports. Annual imported food inspection data reports are also published at awe.gov.au/biosecurity-trade/import/goods/food/inspection-compliance/inspection-data. Data for January to December 2020 shows a 97.9 per cent compliance rate for all food inspected during this period, including for pesticides and metal contaminants.

In addition to the IFIS, all food available for sale within Australia is subject to the relevant state or territory food legislation and monitoring activities implemented by the relevant government authority within that jurisdiction. This includes the monitoring of food for residues of agricultural chemicals, heavy metals and other environmental contaminants.

These regulatory activities are supported by FSANZ's role in monitoring Australia's food supply for levels of contaminants through focussed surveys and the Australian Total Diet Study (ATOS). The ATOS covers both domestically produced and imported food. Outcomes from the ATOS inform government regulatory activity, such as the types of testing undertaken on imported food. In addition, FSANZ monitors and reports on emerging food safety issues, available at:
foodstandards.gov.au/science/surveillance/Pages/default.aspx.
The matter of formaldehyde in fish has not been identified as a food safety issue.
Thank you again for referring this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture and Northern Australia, Mr Littleproud (Petition No. EN2679)
COVID-19: Skilled Migration Program
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 9 August 2021 enclosing Petition EN2685, seeking to allow skilled workers and their dependents into Australia.
The Australian government remains committed to support businesses and individuals employed in critical sectors or with skills critical to Australia's response to COVID-19 and economic recovery.

From 15 December 2021, fully vaccinated eligible visa holders can come to Australia without needing to apply for a travel exemption. Eligible visa holders include skilled and student cohorts, as well as humanitarian, working holiday maker and provisional family visa holders.

Under these arrangements, travellers must be fully vaccinated with a completed dosage of a vaccine approved or recognised by Australia's Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA). Eligible visa holders are required to provide proof of their vaccination status and present a negative COVID-19 Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) test taken within three days of departure.

Travellers to Australia must comply with the quarantine requirements in the state or territory of their arrival, and any other state or territory to which they plan to travel. Further information on eligible visa subclasses can be found on the Department's website at: https://covid 19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-restrictions
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Home Ownership
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN2714 on the First Home Loan Deposit Scheme. Your correspondence has been referred to me for a response.

The Australian Government understands the importance of being able to buy your first home. The Government's Home Guarantee Scheme—comprising the First Home Loan Deposit Scheme, the New Home Guarantee and the Family Home Guarantee—provide an accelerated pathway into home ownership for first home buyers and single parents with dependants.

The New Home Guarantee was introduced to also support activity as part of the Government's economic response to the Covid-19 pandemic, helping to stimulate the economy and jobs in the residential construction sector. Given the need to support activity in the near term, the New Home Guarantee requires that a supported loan must enable construction to commence within a certain period.

For any New Home Guarantees issued prior to 30 June 2021, the required start date for construction was 6 months from the date the construction contract was entered into. More recently, and in light of pressures on the availability of labour and materials in the construction industry, the Government has extended the requirement for reservations made after 1 July 2021 to 12 months.
This initiative will help to improve housing outcomes for Australians who want to own their home. Once again, thank you for taking the time to write.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Housing, Mr Sukkar
Home Ownership

Thank you for your correspondence of 9 August 2021 to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator the Hon Marise Payne, enclosing Petition EN2731 with 2,108 signatures, concerning extensions for the Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa holders stuck overseas. Your correspondence has been referred to me as I am the Minister responsible for the matter you have raised.

The Australian Government recognises the importance of Temporary Graduate visa holders and the contribution they make in Australia. The primary objective of the Temporary Graduate visa is to provide international students who have spent significant time studying in Australia with the opportunity to work, study and stay for a further period. In normal circumstances, applicants are limited to just one initial Temporary Graduate visa in a lifetime and a further visa is only available on the basis of regional work and study.

On 25 November 2021, I jointly announced with the Minister for Education and Youth, the Hon Alan Tudge MP, visa holders who lost time in Australia due to COVID-19 international travel restrictions will be able to apply for a replacement visa. This includes people who were outside Australia at any time between 1 February 2020 and 1 December 2021, while they held a Temporary Graduate visa.

Fully-vaccinated Temporary Graduate visa holders outside Australia will be able to travel to Australia from 15 December 2021. Those graduates whose visas have expired will be able to apply for a replacement visa from 1 July 2022.
There will also be other changes to Temporary Graduate visa settings to ensure Australia remains a competitive and attractive destination for international students:
the stay period on the Temporary Graduate visa for Masters by Coursework graduates, will increase permanently from two to three years, to match the stay period for Masters by Research graduates;

as a concession during the COVID-19 pandemic, the stay period on the Temporary Graduate visa, Graduate Work stream, will increase from 18 to 24 months, and application requirements will be streamlined by removing the requirement for graduates to nominate an occupation from the skills occupation list; and

these changes to Temporary Graduate visa stay periods will be implemented from 1 December 2021, and the removal of skilled occupation list requirements from 1 July 2022, for the duration of the 2022-23 financial year.
Further details are available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2731 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence to the Hon Karen Andrews MP, concerning petition number EN2751 requesting a cease on international flights and more support for Australians who wish to return from overseas. This matter has been referred to me as the Minister for Health and Aged Care. I regret the delay in responding.

Australia has reopened its borders to vaccinated travellers as part of the Australian Government's step-by-step and safe reopening to the world, in line with the National Plan to Transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response (National Transition Plan). This is a result of the success Australia has achieved through the vaccine rollout.

As of 4 January 2022, more than 91 per cent of people in Australia aged 16 and over are fully vaccinated with a COVID-19 vaccine. All Australian jurisdictions now have an 84 per cent (or more) double dose vaccination rate for those aged 16 and over.

As we continue to implement the National Transition Plan, and subject to the latest medical advice, there will be a gradual reopening of inward and outward international travel. To support the next steps of reopening, proportionate testing, tracing, quarantine and isolation measures will be implemented within the Australian jurisdictions.

Australia continues to monitor the latest international and domestic evidence and developments regarding the Omicron COVID-19 variant. Additional border measures that are in place, or have been in place, to protect Australians from Omicron are necessary, appropriate and proportionate to the risk presented by Omicron, and are considered consistent with actions being considered by other countries.

The Government continues to provide facilitated commercial flights and financial assistance for Australians impacted by COVID-19 border measures, and those unable to access vaccines approved or recognised by the Therapeutic Goods Administration.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
National Disability Insurance Scheme
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 9 August 2021 regarding House of Representatives Petition EN2760 requesting to backdate supports, similar to Centrelink, to National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) participants.

The NDIS is an insurance-based scheme in which the National Disability Insurance Agency (NDIA) makes evidence-based decisions on individuals' access. It is not considered a welfare system and is underpinned by the fundamental proposition that by taking a lifetime approach and investing in people early, the opportunity for individuals to live their best life is increased.

Ensuring NDIS participants have the reasonable and necessary supports they require is a priority for the NDIA. As at 30 September 2021, approximately 484,700 participants are receiving supports from the NDIS, with approximately 13,600 children receiving initial supports through their NDIS Early Childhood partner.

When identifying the types and amount of reasonable and necessary supports to provide, NDIA planners will review all information provided at the 'time of planning and make decisions based on the National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013 and any relevant operational guidelines.

When a support is approved, funding is included in a participant's NDIS plan. Supports can be claimed from the participant's NDIS plan start date. In most cases the NDIS does not reimburse or back pay for services provided to a participant, prior to funding being approved in a participant's plan.

The NDIA helps participants or their nominee implement their plan and works with participants to ensure they continue to receive the disability-related supports they need. This may include support from a Local Area Coordinator who assist participants to find community activities and engage with mainstream services to help them pursue their goals.

Further, if a participant's plan reaches its end date and their new plan hasn't been finalised yet, the current plan will be automatically extended for up to 12 months. This allows current funding to automatically continue for up to 12 months, or until the participant's new plan can be finalised. This is part of the NDIA's commitment to deliver a quality experience for NDIS participants and ensure there are no gaps in a participant's funding or supports.
I trust this information will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Senator Reynolds
Electoral Act
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email referring petition EN2766 relating to the voting age in Australia. I am responding as the Special Minister of State and apologise for the delay in my response.

As you know, it is important that the right to vote applies from an appropriate age, to ensure that electors can adequately understand parliamentary representation, enrolment and the electoral process. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 provides that persons aged 16 years and over may enrol provisionally, ahead of becoming eligible to vote when they are 18 years of age. This is one way of encouraging people to start thinking about their future rights and responsibilities as voters, before they become qualified to vote.

Young people who have an interest in politics can also participate in public debates in various ways including by making submissions to parliamentary committees, such as the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, or by writing to members of Parliament. The Government also provides funding for a range of educational programs and resources, including the Museum of Australian Democracy, to help young Australians build their understanding of how Australia's system of government works.

The Government has no plans to change the voting age, noting that while 16 years olds do take on significant responsibilities, in most cases this is under parental guidance. Voting, like most other social and legal norms, does not and should not apply until the age of 18.
Thank you for bringing the matters referred to in this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Special Minister of State, Mr Morton
Shoalhaven: Health Care
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 23 August 2021 concerning petition number EN2810 presented to the House of Representatives. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that Australians have access to timely and high-quality medical care no matter where they live. I share the frustration of practices in the Shoalhaven region of NSW which are experiencing difficulty recruiting suitable GPs. As a former gastroenterologist who spent most of my career practicing in regional and rural parts of Australia, I appreciate and understand the concerns of Australians living outside the major metropolitan areas of our capital cities.

Our greatest challenge is overcoming the significant maldistribution of the medical workforce so that all Australians can access the services they need, when and where they need them. It frustrates me that not enough young doctors are choosing to become GPs and of those that do enter general practice, many are picking the bright lights of our capital cities over practicing in regional and rural areas.

As the Minister for Regional Health, I am focused on improving the capacity, quality, and distribution of health services to meet the needs of families and communities. This involves significant investment and effort along the medical workforce pipeline from helping rural students study medicine through to the incentives provided to attract and retain doctors in the bush. This is not a challenge the federal government can do alone, and I am talking to my state health minister counterparts and the medical professional bodies about ways we can address the problem together.

The Distribution Priority Area (DPA) indicator is used to identify distribution challenges in Australia's medical workforce. The DPA is an impartial mechanism which relies on the most recently available Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) demographic data (including age, gender and socio-economic status) as well as Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) billing data to assess levels of medical service provision throughout Australia. The DPA mechanism is intended to ensure that timely and high-quality GP services are available to Australians living in regional, rural and remote areas of the country.

The DPA mechanism uses the Modified Monash Model (MMM) geographical remoteness classification system to help determine where location restricted doctors should be distributed. Until recently, the DPA mechanism's automatic rules meant that MM 5-7 locations were automatically DPA. From 1 January 2022, the Government has expanded the DPA mechanism's automatic rules to include all MM 3 and MM 4 locations as well.

In the Shoalhaven region, the towns of Nowra, Bomaderry and surrounding areas are classified MM 3. The towns of Huskisson, Vincentia, Sanctuary Point and Sussex Inlet to the south of Nowra are classified MM 4. From 1 January 2022, all of these areas are automatically classified DPA and exempt from service testing against benchmarks in the annual DPA update. This means that practices in these areas will now be able to recruit from a larger pool of doctors, including International Medical Graduates (IMG) subject to location restrictions under s19AB of the Health Insurance Act 1973, as well as Australian-trained Bonded Medical Program (BMP) participants with return of service obligations. The Shoalhaven region will also be eligible for the non-Vocationally Registered Fellowship Support Program, the More Doctors for Rural Australia Program (MDRAP) and the Visas for GPs program.

As Minister for Regional Health, I am confident that these changes to the DPA mechanism's automatic rules will prove highly beneficial to practices and doctors in the Shoalhaven region, and thereby help to improve the Shoalhaven community's access to timely and high-quality GP services.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Regional Health, Dr Gillespie
Law Enforcement
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 10 December 2021 to the Attorney-General, Senator the Hon Michaelia Cash, enclosing Petition EN2825 with 15 signatures, concerning the Australian Government's approach to managing non-citizens who pose an unacceptable risk to the community through acts of violence and crime. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister responsible for the matter you have raised.

Ensuring the safety and good order of the Australian community is a key Government priority. In order to be granted a visa, all non-citizens must meet the character requirements set out in the Migration Act 1958 (the Act) and the public interest criteria in the Migration Regulations 1994. Visa holders must continue to meet character requirements and abide by the conditions imposed on their visa while they remain in Australia. For instance, visa condition 8303 ("The holder must not become involved in activities disruptive to, or violence threatening harm to, the Australian community or a group within the Australian community") which is imposed on most temporary visas, provides the Minister with the power to cancel a visa if there is evidence of the visa holder engaging in activities that endanger or threaten the Australian community.

Visa cancellation powers in the Act enable the Government to respond to threats posed by individuals and organised crime groups or risks to the integrity of the migration program. Information on character requirements is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-support/meeting-our-requirements/character.

You may also be interested to note that the Migration Amendment (Strengthening the Character Test) Bill was introduced to the Parliament on 24 November 2021 and is currently before the House of Representatives. When passed, these amendments, will ensure that non-citizens who are convicted of certain serious offences, including those of a violent or sexual nature, are appropriately considered for visa refusal or cancellation, regardless of the length of sentence imposed. The amendments will provide an objective basis for refusing or cancelling the visa of a non-citizen whose offending has not resulted in a sentence of 12 months or more, but who nonetheless poses an unacceptable risk to the safety of the Australian community.
Further information on the Bill is available at:
https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Bills_Legislation/Bills_Search_Results/Result?bld=r6349.
The Department regularly reviews migration legislation and visa framework settings to review their efficiency in addressing emerging risks to the community.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2825 to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Veterans
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 23 August 2021 regarding Petition EN2832—amendment to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

Petition EN2832 requests the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004 be amended to include provisions consistent with certain provisions in the Repatriation Act 1920 (Repealed). This would enable veterans to appeal questions of law arising from decisions of the Veterans' Review Board to the Federal Court of Australia, and either have their associated costs paid by the Commonwealth, or receive legal or financial assistance from the Attorney-General.

span.span: Relevant history of decision-making and appeals process

p.span: Petition EN2832 suggests that repealed sections 107VZZH, 107VZZJ, 107VZZK and 107VZZL of the Repatriation Act 1920 (Repealed) allowed for these Commonwealth-funded appeals, but they were not included in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 when it repealed and replaced the Repatriation Act 1920 (Repealed). In fact, these sections of the Repatriation Act 1920 (Repealed) were repealed by the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Act 1984, which commenced on 1 January 1985, before the Repatriation Act 1920 (Repealed) was repealed in its entirety by the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 commenced on 22 May 1986.

The changes were prompted by the Administrative Review Council Report to the Attorney-General on Review of Pension Decisions under Repatriation Legislation No. 20 (16 September 1983). The Administrative Review Council identified deficiencies in the system of primary decision making and review of decisions in place at that time, noting one of the problems with determining and reviewing decisions under the Repatriation Act 1920 (Repealed) was the "multiplicity of avenues of appeal", which resulted in substantial delays in disposing of claims, was both "unnecessary and wasteful of resources".

The Administrative Review Council found decisions were not always adequately considered at either the primary or review stages of decision making, and the then Repatriation Review Tribunal was not able to fulfil its role adequately as a final review authority because of the number of cases it was called on to determine. The Administrative Review Council considered the system did not serve the best interests of veterans and their families.

The Administrative Review Council therefore recommended abolishing Repatriation Boards and making delegates of the Repatriation Commission responsible for primary decisions on service and disability pension claims and claims for pension increases, as well as reviewing decisions on primary claims for the service pension. The Administrative Review Council also recommended the Veterans' Review Board be established to replace the Repatriation Review Tribunal as the intermediate level of review of decisions of the Repatriation Commission on disability pensions. Finally, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal would become the ultimate merits review body, due in part to the fact it was independent from the Repatriation Commission, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, and ex-service organisations.

In amending the legislation, the Australian Government essentially adopted this three-tiered framework for decision-making. It also made clear appeals to the Federal Court would be limited to questions of law arising from decisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal only, in accordance with the provisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975.

The amendments therefore removed the previous mechanism allowing appeals directly from the Repatriation Review Tribunal to the Federal Court of Australia, Commonwealth-funded or otherwise. The then Minister for Veterans' Affairs commented it was believed many appeals would be resolved at the Veterans' Review Board by relatively expeditious, economical and informal means of review.

span.span: Representation of the parties in Veterans' Review Board proceedings and associated legal costs

p.span: Petition EN2832 also suggests the provision in the Repatriation Act 1920 (Repealed) allowing for costs to be borne by the Commonwealth was included to: "balance out the fact that under EA s107VU [sic] Parliament had decided to deprive an applicant from representation by a legal practitioner at the review proceedings ... ".

It has long been the case parties to Veterans' Review Board proceedings, and before that the Repatriation Review Tribunal, could not be represented by legal practitioners. This remains the position. The intention of these provisions is not to deprive applicants of legal representation, but to ensure proceedings before the Veterans' Review Board are not adversarial, but inquisitorial. This is consistent with the three-tiered merits review framework outlined above.

Veterans may engage legal practitioners to act for them in proceedings before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which is well-equipped to support self-represented applicants. The Repatriation Commissioner and the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission as model litigants also have a duty to assist the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and self-represented applicants where appropriate.

Subsection 357(2) of the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004 and subsection 67(8) of the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation (Defence-related Claims) Act 1988 provide that if the Administrative Appeals Tribunal makes a decision favourable to the applicant, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal may order the costs of those proceedings incurred by the applicant are to be paid by the Commonwealth, and subsections 357(3) and 67(8A) provide respectively the Administrative Appeals Tribunal may order the costs of the applicant in proceedings instituted by the Commonwealth be paid by the Commonwealth. Veterans who are successful in proceedings before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal are therefore likely to have their legal costs paid by the Commonwealth.

The Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 does not have equivalent provisions, but the Australian Government is in the process of considering the Productivity Commission's Inquiry Report titled A Better Way to Support Veterans, Recommendation 12.5 of which includes that the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 should be amended to permit costs awards for cases that reach the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Section 44 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act provides a party to a proceeding before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal may appeal to the Federal Court of Australia on a question of law from a decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Section 43 of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 provides the Federal Court of Australia or a Judge may award costs in all proceedings before the Federal Court of Australia at their discretion.

Accordingly, veterans who are successful in proceedings before the Federal Court of Australia are likely to have their costs paid by the Commonwealth, and there is scope for the Federal Court of Australia to make costs orders even if the veteran is unsuccessful.

Veterans who are unable to pay for legal representation may still secure pro-bona legal representation, legal aid funding, assistance from veterans' advocacy services, or legal financial assistance from the Attorney-General's Department.
Thank you again for bringing these concerns to my attention. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Personnel, Mr Gee
COVID-19: Taxation
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN2834, individual tax residency rules. I apologise for the delay in responding to you.

The 2021-22 Budget included a measure to modernise the individual tax residency rules by introducing a new framework that is easier to understand and apply in practice, provides greater certainty, and reduces compliance costs for globally mobile individuals and their employers.

The new framework will be based on the model recommended by the Board of Taxation in its 2019 report: Reforming Individual Tax Residency- a model for modernisation. The Board's report recommended a simple 'bright line' test as the primary test: a person who is physically present in Australia for 183 days or more in any income year will be an Australian tax resident. Individuals who do not meet the primary test would be subject to secondary tests that depend on a combination of physical presence and measurable, objective criteria.

The Board's report recommended that the secondary tests incorporate a test for individuals who were not residents in the preceding income year to determine whether they commence residency, and a test for individuals who were residents in the preceding income year to determine whether they cease residency.

The Australian Government will consult on the new framework to ensure there are no unintended consequences. The measure will take effect from 1 July in the year after Royal Assent of the enabling legislation.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2834 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Genetically Modified Crops
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 23 August 2021 to the Minister for Agriculture and Northern Australia, the Hon David Littleproud MP, concerning Petition EN2846 to examine Genetically Modified (GM) crops. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Senior Australians and Aged Care Services, with portfolio responsibility for gene technology.

The Gene Technology Act 2000 (Act) has now been operational for over 20 years. Under this Act, the environmental release of all GM crops and other GM organisms (GMOs) in Australia must first be authorised by the Gene Technology Regulator (Regulator). Any proposal to release a GMO into the environment receives intense scrutiny by both the Office of the Gene Technology Regulator (OGTR) and the wider community'.
