The Regulator must not issue a licence authorising GMO dealings involving release to the environment unless satisfied that any risks posed by the GMO are able to be managed in a way that protects the health and safety of people and the environment.

The licensing system is centred on a rigorous process of risk assessment based on scientific evidence. The Regulator conducts a comprehensive and consultative process to decide whether or not to issue a licence to work with the GM crops. This comprehensive and consultative process is governed by the Act, the Gene Technology Regulations 2001 (Regulations), and corresponding state and territory law.

The legislation requires the Regulator to prepare a risk assessment and risk management plan (RARMP) as part of the decision-making process on whether to issue or refuse to issue a licence. The Act also requires consultation with a wide range of experts, agencies and authorities, as well as the public. These include the Gene Technology Technical Advisory Committee, state and territory governments, Australian Government agencies prescribed in the Regulations, the Environment Minister, and relevant local councils.

The RARMP is finalised based on the advice received on the licence application and consultation with the above-mentioned experts, agencies, authorities and the public. The finalised RARMP and proposed licence conditions inform the Regulator's decision on whether to issue or refuse to issue a licence. If the Regulator does decide to issue a licence, the RARMP informs the conditions that apply to it.
It is important to note that the OGTR has monitoring powers to ensure compliance with licence conditions, and the Regulator has the power to vary, suspend or cancel licences if deemed necessary.

Currently, only three GM crops are grown commercially in Australia: cotton, canola and safflower. Other crops are undergoing field trials, subject to strict licencing conditions, to prevent spread and persistence of the GMO In the environment. The GM canola, cotton and safflower crops grown in Australia were approved for environmental release only after the Regulator found that they were as safe for human health and the environment as non-GM versions.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Senior Australians and Aged Care Services, Mr Colbeck
Australian Currency
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN2864 which requests a change to the name of Australian currency to dollarbucks. I apologise for the delay in responding to you. I have received a large number of emails and requests information and have not been able to respond as quickly as I would like.

The Currency Act 1965 governs the use of currency in Australia. It specifies that the monetary unit, or unit of currency, of Australia is the dollar and that the denominations of money in the currency of Australia are the dollar and the cent (Part II, section 8).
I note that, notwithstanding the formal naming of Australian currency, nothing precludes individual citizens from referring to Australian currency in terms such as those outlined in the petition.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Census
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence regarding Petition EN2870 requesting that the "compulsory Census" be stopped. I apologise for the delay in responding to you.

The Census of Population and Housing is the most comprehensive snapshot of Australia's people and housing and tells the story of how we are changing. The accuracy and quality of the data produced is dependent on ensuring the Census counts as many people and households as possible. The Census has a target response rate of over 95%.

The ABS always asks for willing cooperation, however if someone refuses to participate in the Census, the Australian Statistician may direct that person to complete a form through a formal written notice. If a person continues to refuse, they can be fined and get a criminal conviction. Only a very small number of people are fined for not completing the Census, however the knowledge that the Census is compulsory is important for ensuring high response rates and high-quality data.

The Census is an important opportunity for Australians to tell us about themselves and help make a difference for their community. Critical decisions are made by governments, businesses and local community groups that depend on knowing the age and sex of the population located in each part of Australia. Researchers are provided controlled access to Census data, including Census data integrated with other data, in a way that protects an individual's privacy.

The data from the 2021 Census will be more important than ever as it will provide valuable insights into how the Covid 19 pandemic has changed life in Australia. The 2021 Census also has new questions on long-term health conditions and service with the Australian Defence Force. These are the first significant changes to the information collected in the Census since 2006 and will provide valuable information.

High quality Census data is also a critical component of the population estimates for each state and territory that the ABS produces every quarter. These population estimates are used for a number of important purposes including the setting of electoral boundaries and distribution of government funding.

The Australian Statistician is required to conduct the Census every five years (s 8(1) of the Census and Statistics Act 1905) and to collect the statistical information prescribed by the Australian Government.

Information collected during the Census is protected by the provisions of the Census and Statistics Act 1905 and the Privacy Act 1988. Under these Acts, the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) cannot release personal information in a way that can identify an individual or their household, including to other government departments, Federal and state courts.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar

subdebateinfo.title: Declaration on Children, Youth and Climate Action

p.span: Declaration on Children, Youth and Climate Action
Dear Chair
Thank you for referring a copy of petition EN2947 presented to the House of Representatives on 18 October 2021, regarding the Intergovernmental Declaration on Children, Youth and Climate Action.

The Australian Government recognises the importance of a safe, clean, and sustainable environment for the realisation of a range of existing human rights. However, the Government does not consider there is a universally accepted, standalone right to a safe, clean, and healthy environment under international human rights law (please refer to paragraph 1 of the Declaration).

Although the Government is not able to sign the declaration, promoting international climate engagement by Australian youth is a priority for the Government. Australia signed the Kwon Gesh pledge at the 2019 United Nations Climate Action Summit, in which we committed to involving youth in our implementation of the Paris Agreement and the achievement of its goals.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) is advancing this agenda through the DFAT—Australian Youth for International Climate Engagement (AYFICE) Network Working Group, the Action for Climate Empowerment (ACE) dialogue, and the development cooperation program.

In 2020, DFAT established a working group with the AYFICE Network. This working group provides a formalised connection between Australian youth delegates who attend United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) events and the official Australian Delegation. The objective of the working group is to mainstream youth engagement through the Delegation's work and facilitate sharing of views, knowledge, and experiences.

In preparation for, and during, COP26 in Glasgow, DFAT engaged regularly with youth. On 12 October 2021, the Australian Ambassador for the Environment and Head of Delegation hosted a roundtable with 22 Australian youth climate leaders and participated in two public events hosted by the AYFICE Working Group. Seven youth delegates attended COP26 on Australian Party Overflow badges and have been in regular contact with the Australian delegation throughout the Conference.

Australia also supports the Action for Climate Empowerment (ACE) workstream and its ability to enhance youth empowerment and voice. At COP26, Australia worked actively and constructively across groups to complete the review of the Doha Work Programme (DWP) (2012-2020) and define further actions to enhance implementation of ACE activities. We are pleased that Parties were able to agree the new Glasgow Work Programme and look forward to its implementation and defining further short-term actions at future sessions.

Finally, the Australian development cooperation program funds a range of partners to strengthen the capacity of youth to engage in climate change action. For example, through the Australian non-government organisation cooperation program (ANCP), Plan International Australia is empowering and equipping youth, especially adolescent girls, to lead climate resilient disaster preparedness actions in 59 communities across Fiji, Kiribati, Solomon Islands, and Papua New Guinea. DFAT also provides core funding to UNICEF, which has an environment and climate change focus.
We remain committed to engaging youth on climate change policy and supporting them to take action on climate change.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Veterans' Entitlements Act
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning Petition No EN2961 seeking amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to enable expert medical evidence available to Courts pursuant to the Evidence Act 1995 (Cth) to be used in conjunction with the factors in Statement of Principles to determine the relationship between a disease and the circumstances of service when deciding a compensation claim under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 or the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004.

The Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 was amended in 1994 to create the Repatriation Medical Authority and the Statement of Principles system—the Statements of Principles being legislative instruments which set out the factors connecting particular medical conditions, be they injuries or diseases, with the circumstances of military service. The system was introduced as lay tribunals and had significant difficulty dealing with conflicting medical opinions about whether the facts of service could cause a relevant disease or injury.

Statements of Principles are determined by the Repatriation Medical Authority which is a body of medical and epidemiological experts who are required to rely only on 'sound medical-scientific evidence' in formulating the factors. Sound medical-scientific evidence is defined in s5AB Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and requires the Repatriation Medical Authority to rely on its expert medical knowledge and up to date epidemiological studies in determining the factors in the Statements of Principles for the causes of the various medical conditions. A review of the Repatriation Medical Authority conducted in 1997 confirmed that its decision making was 'generous' to claimants, while remaining within the bounds of scientific credibility.[1]

Sections 120A and 1208 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 provide for the Statements of Principles to be the point of reference in assessing whether any hypothesis connecting a medical condition to service is reasonable or whether a decision-maker can be reasonably satisfied about the connection between a condition and service. Sections 338 and 339 of the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004 are to identical effect for all service on or after 1 July 2004. In order to succeed, a claimant merely has to establish the facts of service consistent with the cause outlined in the factors in the Statement of Principles for the particular medical condition. The claimant does not have to gather separate expert evidence to prove military service is linked with that medical condition.

The petition seeks to have such expert medical evidence not provided to the Repatriation Medical Authority to be to be considered by the compensation decision-maker in conjunction with the factors in the Statement of Principles in deciding whether any hypothesis about the cause of a medical condition is reasonable.

Currently, any person, including a qualified medical expert, can submit an opinion with supporting sound medical-scientific evidence and the Repatriation Medical Authority as the expert medical body is obliged to consider it. The proposed change would have a non-expert compensation decision-maker being given the task of evaluating expert medical opinion about disease causation which could have been considered by the Repatriation Medical Authority as part of their investigation.

The petition, as presented, refers to ordinary expert evidence admissible in a Court pursuant to s79 of the Evidence Act 1995 (Cth), and capable of being the subject of an expert certificate pursuant to s177 of that Act, being considered by the compensation decision-maker. It is suggested that this change would make the Repatriation Medical Authority's processes more consistent with "natural justice".

This however is to misunderstand the role of expert evidence in ordinary litigation. Section 79 of the Evidence Act 1995 does not require a Court to accept an opinion of a medical specialist given without supporting medical-scientific evidence that a particular exposure is a cause of a particular medical condition. The usual process in a curial setting includes an examination of whether the expert has a relevant expertise and whether an opinion is wholly or substantially based on their specialised knowledge and then, what weight can be given to such evidence. The proposed change would require the compensation decision-maker to do likewise. This would require additional expert assistance and complicate and lengthen the evaluation of compensation claims.

It should be noted that the requirement for the Repatriation Medical Authority to focus on the up to date epidemiology is consistent with the developments in the Courts. In Amaca v Booth [2011] HCA 53 the High Court endorsed the use of epidemiological criteria in considering the causal connection between exposure to asbestos and the onset of mesothelioma. As Chief Justice French noted (44), these criteria which include matters such as the strength of an association, its biological plausibility and the dose-response relationship are not necessary conditions of a cause and effect relationship but have the character of circumstantial evidence of such a relationship. In this regard the Repatriation Medical Authority's process mirrors curial practice and is consistent with natural justice.

The current Statement of Principles system has wide support amongst the veteran community and its use is expanding. The Productivity Commission in its review of veterans' compensation, A Better Way to Support Veterans, noted that support for that system and endorsed it as 'robust and effective' concluding that:-

span.span: "it promotes consistency, predictability and transparency and draws a clear line between accepted and non-accepted conditions, based on sound medical scientific evidence". [p.349]

p.span: Under an arrangement with the Australian Government, the Statements of Principles are now specifically referred to in the New Zealand Veterans' Support Act 2014 and are used extensively by the Canadian Veterans Review and Appeal Board.

The Statement of Principles system is also transparent with the reasoning of the Repatriation Medical Authority including all medical research being available to interested parties under s196I of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

As well, the Statement of Principles are legislative instruments under the Legislation Act 2003 and required to be regularly reviewed lest they sunset and s196E of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 enables any veteran, member or ex-service organisation to request a review of a Statement of Principles to insert a new factor or vary an existing one.

It is to the overall benefit of veterans and members of the Australian Defence Force that the Repatriation Medical Authority, as the expert medical science body, has the role of determining factors connecting the causes of injuries, diseases or deaths with military service. It provides an objective system based on the best evidence related to the causes of particular kinds of injuries, diseases and deaths and assists claimants in developing their claims for compensation.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Personnel, Mr Gee
[1] Pearce D, Holman D (1997) Review of the Repatriation Medical Authority and Specialist Medical Review Council, Commonwealth of Australia, p. 101-103.
South China Sea
Dear Chair
Thank you for your representation of 18 October 2021 on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions concerning petition number EN2992.

The strategic trends challenging Australia are accelerating, a reality laid out in the 2020 Defence Strategic Update. The Prime Minister has made clear that the Australian Government is committed to intensifying our efforts and cooperation with others to meet this complex new environment.

Australia has a substantial interest in the stability of the South China Sea and the norms and laws that govern it, particularly the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. Australia has maintained its robust program of international engagement with countries in and around the South China Sea for decades. This includes unilateral, bilateral and multilateral activities as part of routine Australian Defence Force (ADF) deployments.

Our deployments to the region are consistent with the high priority the Government places on Indo-Pacific engagement, as reaffirmed by the 2020 Defence Strategic Update. They are demonstrations of our shared resolve for an open, inclusive and resilient Indo-Pacific and are valuable means for strengthening practical cooperation with regional partners and enhancing interoperability. ADF vessels and aircraft will continue to exercise rights under international law to freedom of navigation and overflight, including in the South China Sea and Australia will support others doing the same.

Defending Australia, its people and its interests is the Government's highest priority. The Government's ability to deploy members of the ADF beyond Australia's territorial limits is an essential prerogative of the Executive exercisable under section 61 of the Constitution. Long-standing Westminster convention allows executive government to exercise the discretion to commit forces to operations.
The exercise of constitutional power to deploy the ADF does not prevent the testing of Government decisions in the Parliament.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Dutton
Missing Persons
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter on 18 October 2021 on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions regarding Gordon Copeland who went missing near Moree on 10 July 2021 (Petition EN3018). The body of Mr Copeland was found on 7 October 2021, before the petition was presented to the House. I offer my condolences to his family and friends for their loss.

Defence assistance to the civil community typically follows a request from state and territory emergency services. Defence can provide a range of services and specialist capabilities when the nature and scale of an emergency exceeds the capability of the requesting organisation. The process for requesting Defence assistance is outlined at
https://www.defence.gov.au/programs-initiatives/support-australian-community.
Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Dutton
Veterans' Entitlements Act
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 18 October 2021 regarding Petition number EN3037.

I am advised by the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the request put forward in this petition appears to be based on a misapprehension, albeit understandable, of the significance of the term 'statements of principles' as it is used in s138(2) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

'Statements of principles' is a term which now has a specific meaning within the Veterans' Entitlements Act, and refers to legislative instruments established by an independent statutory body, the Repatriation Medical Authority, which define the causal factors for conditions and which must be applied by decision-makers when making determinations accepting or refusing liability for medical conditions under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. Similar terminology was used in the context of the recommendations of external reviews which led to the foundation of the Repatriation Medical Authority and the commencement of the first Repatriation Medical Authority Statements of Principles in 1994.

The term 'statements of principles' described in Petition EN3037, was introduced in s138(2) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act in order to set out a legislative basis for providing to the Veterans' Review Board non-binding guidance material on the causation of medical conditions pending the establishment of the Repatriation Medical Authority, is not accurate. The section which is the subject of the petition and the form of words used in s138(2) existed prior the commencement of the Repatriation Medical Authority Statements of Principles. This suggests the intended meaning of 'statements of principles' as used in s138(2) was and is unrelated to the specific and separate meaning which it now has under the legislative provisions setting out the power and functions of the Repatriation Medical Authority.

Section 138(2)(a) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act itself specifies the Repatriation Commission may furnish 'statements of principles' applied by the Commission in deciding claims for pension, applications for pension, attendant allowance, increased pension and in conducting reviews under s31 Veterans' Entitlements Act. The Statements of Principles now administered by the Repatriation Medical Authority have only one purpose—the determination of whether a claimed condition is caused by service. They have no role in claims for increase in pension or attendant allowance.

The term 'statements of principles' as it appears in s138(2) has its origins in the amendments made to the Repatriation Act 1920. For example, the Repatriation Acts Amendment Act 1979 used the term 'statements of principles' to describe principles derived by the Commission from decisions of the then Repatriation Review Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Given the very similar terminology and context to which the term applied under earlier legislation since the 1970s, it is a reasonable conclusion the provisions which now exist in the Veterans' Entitlements Act were modelled on those in the earlier legislation.

As such, the use of the term 'statements of principles' long predated, and is clearly distinct from its application, as a proper noun, in the Veterans' Entitlements Act to the instruments administered by the Repatriation Medical Authority. As it is used in s138(2) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act, the term clearly refers more broadly to policy and procedural guidance material provided to decision makers to assist them in exercising their relevant functions under the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

This interpretation is borne out by the Explanatory Memorandum to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill 1985, which states, in relation to clause 137 (which corresponds to what is now Veterans' Entitlements Act s138), the "combined effect of sub-clauses 137(2) and (3) will be that the Commission may make available to the Board material which may aid in encouraging consistency in decision making but will not be able to direct the Board in the consideration of a particular review." This indicates the intention of this provision was to enable the Repatriation Commission to furnish the Veterans' Review Board with the guidance material used in deciding certain claims, while also making clear this material would not bind the Board.

In this light, I am informed the removal of these provisions would not have the effect presumed by the Petition EN3037. Such action may in fact have a negative impact, in that the ability of the Repatriation Commission to provide its policy and procedural material to the Board may be restricted. This could result in the Board not being able to form a clear understanding of how the Commission arrived at a decision in a particular case, slowing the review process and conceivably increasing the risk of adverse or inconsistent outcomes for veterans. Therefore, there are no plans to repeal this provision.
Thank you for bringing the concerns set out in Petition number EN3037 to my attention. I trust this· information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Personnel, Mr Gee
Australian Constitution
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN3042 on Indigenous funding and the Indigenous Voice.
Indigenous Australians have lived and cared for the land and seas across Australia for over 60,000 years and hold a unique and enduring place in our nation's story.

Indigenous Australians are also amongst the most disadvantaged communities in our nation. The Australian Government is committed to work with Indigenous Australians in partnership and shared decision-making to address this disadvantage, including through the National Agreement on Closing the Gap, and the Indigenous Advancement Strategy.

In relation to an Indigenous Voice, I acknowledge there are many views, approaches and ideas on an Indigenous Voice. The overarching purpose of an Indigenous Voice is to ensure that Indigenous Australians are able to have their say about laws, policies and services that impact them. It is only fair that where governments discuss and adopt policies specifically related to Indigenous Australians, they have a say on this. As a result we will benefit from better decisions, programs and policies that reflect a broader, richer and more diverse· Australia.
That is why the Morrison Government considered it important to commission a co-design process with extensive consultation to ensure that the views of all Australians were considered on this issue.

In December 2021, the Morrison Government released the Indigenous Voice Co-design Final Report to the Australian Government. The Report is the result of a robust 18-month co-design process to develop proposals for an Indigenous Voice. Co-design groups made up of 52 members from around the country, primarily Indigenous people, led this process and over 9,400 people have had their say on the proposals.

The Final Report recommends establishing Local & Regional Voices as the first step. Strong local and regional arrangements will build a foundation for legitimacy at the community level as well as helping to ensure sustainability and long-term success. The report made it very clear that for Local & Regional Voices to be successful, they must speak to all levels of government—federal, state and local.

This is why the Morrison Government will now commence discussions with states, territories and local governments to encourage their participation in the 35 Local & Regional Voices to be established nationally.

The Morrison Government will also continue the co-design approach during implementation and will work with the other levels of government to set up a Local & Regional Voice Establishment Group to work with governments and other stakeholders to progress this historic initiative. You can access the Final Report online at voice.niaa.gov.au.
Thank you for sharing these views.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Indigenous Australians, Mr Wyatt
Paid Parental Leave
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 19 October 2021 concerning petition number EN3045 regarding extending paid leave for mothers of premature babies.

The Australian Government recognises that the period following the birth of a child can be a challenging time, and remains committed to helping parents balance their work and family responsibilities through a range of programs and payments.

In Australia, Paid Parental Leave is fully funded through general taxation revenue. The Australian Government provides nearly $2.5 billion each year in support to families through Parental Leave Pay and Dad and Partner Pay. This is a non-contributory system, which means that all parents who are eligible for government-funded Paid Parental Leave can access this support when needed. In contrast, most OECD countries fund parental leave payments through contributory schemes or social insurance models. Under these schemes, only people who have paid contributions to a social insurance fund can access parental leave payments.

Parental Leave Pay is intended to complement employer-provided leave entitlements. The Paid Parental Leave scheme also currently allows a primary carer to remain eligible for Parental Leave Pay if they return to work during the period their child remains in hospital, if the child is required to remain in hospital or is hospitalised immediately after birth. This is particularly helpful for families with a child born prematurely, allowing them to return to work and delay their Parental Leave Pay until the child has been discharged from hospital. More information on the Parental Leave Pay return to work and keeping in touch provisions can be found at:
www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/services/centrelink/parental-leave-pay.
The Government continues to monitor family assistance arrangements to ensure they are efficient, effective and appropriately targeted to give children the best start in life.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
Internet Content
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 17 October 2021, on behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions, concerning Petition EN3048—Royal Commission to Examine OnlyFans and Other Services.

The Morrison Government is committed to addressing child abuse material. Child sexual abuse and dealings with child abuse material online or via a postal service, by Australian citizens or residents overseas is illegal. Some of these offences carry penalties of up to 25 years' imprisonment, which reflects the seriousness of the crime and the degree of harm face by victims.

The Crimes Legislation Amendment (Sexual Crimes against Children and Community Protection Measures) Act 2020, increased maximum penalties and introduced mandatory minimum sentences for the most serious and repeat Commonwealth child sex offences. The Act has also introduced a new offence to target administrators of websites that distribute online child abuse material with a maximum penalty of 20 years' imprisonment. This new legislation builds on the offence of possessing or controlling online child abuse material, which came into force in September 2019 and attracts a maximum penalty of 15 years' imprisonment.

The Government is also committed to enhancing online safety for all Australians by ensuring there are proper regulatory controls and support systems in place to mitigate risks and allow Australians to confidently take advantage of the benefits of the digital environment.

The Online Content Scheme, currently set out in the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, regulates prohibited and potentially prohibited online content in Australia based on the National Classification Scheme. Content is assessed on the basis of public complaints to the eSafety Commissioner. If the eSafety Commissioner finds content hosted in Australia to be prohibited content, the Commissioner will direct the content provider to remove or prevent access to the content. For content hosted overseas found to be prohibited, the URL to the material is added to the Commissioner's prohibited URLs list. The eSafety Commissioner's list of prohibited URLs is distributed to PC filter vendors accredited under an Industry Code of Practice. This is more commonly known as the 'family friendly filter' scheme. Internet service providers offer these filters to their customers. However, it is the customer's decision to purchase and use them.

span.span: will come into force. The Act will provide the eSafety Commissioner with additional powers to investigate and address 'seriously harmful content' on overseas hosted sites, including child se
xual abuse material, abhorrent violent material and content that promotes, incites or instructs in serious crime.

p.span: If individuals are of the view that content on Only Fans is prohibited, they can report the matter to the eSafety Commissioner. Complaints may be lodged by completing the online form at:
www.esafety.gov.au/complaints-andreporting/offensivc-and-illcgal-content-complaints.

The eSafety Commissioner also provides useful information about the latest games, apps and social media through the eSafety Guide, including how to protect personal information and report inappropriate content. Specific guidance on OnlyFans can be found on the eSafety Commissioner's website at
www.esafcty.gov.au/keyissues/esafety-guide/onlyfans.

The eSafety Commissioner's core functions are designed to assist people who have been negatively affected by online experiences. eSafety takes mental health seriously and works collaboratively with government and non-government organisations to ensure that people reporting to eSafety are appropriately referred to support services.

eSafety coordinates an Online Safety Mental Health Steering Group and has developed an 'online safety and wellbeing directory' which is available through eSafety's website. eSafety offers tailored training workshops to frontline domestic and family violence workers and mental health and social workers to raise awareness of online safety issues and to provide tools to help the support sector to protect people at risk of online abuse.

The Government has also recently announced a new Parliamentary Inquiry into the harmful effects of digital platforms on children and young people. The Select Committee on Social Media and Online Safety will provide an opportunity for the tech industry, community sector, government and the public to have their say on a range of issues, including on the online harms that may be faced by Australians on social media and other platforms, such as harmful content or harmful conduct. The Committee will also inquire into evidence of the potential impacts of online harms on the mental health and wellbeing of Australians, which was also a concerned raised by the petitioners.

If
you
remain concerned about these issues, or any other issues related to online safety, I encourage you to make a submission to the Inquiry.

More information on how this can be done is available on Parliament of Australia website. -Visit www.aph.gov.au and select 'Committees', 'Current Inquiries', 'House of Representatives Committees and then choose 'Inquiry into Social Media and Online Safety'.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Euthanasia
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter of 18 October 2021 regarding the petition to repeal section 50A of the Northern Territory (Self Government) Act 1978 (the NT Self Government Act) to allow the Northern Territory to enact laws dealing with voluntary assisted dying (EN3052).

The Australian Government recognises members of the community have strong views about dying with dignity, compassion and with minimal pain. The Australian Government believes people should have access to quality palliative care and relief from pain and suffering and, where possible, people should be able to choose the extent of active medical treatment they receive. The underlying principle of our investment in health services is quality of life, and this includes during end of life care.

The Australian Government does not intend to introduce legislation to repeal the Euthanasia Laws Act 1997 (Cth) that inserted provisions preventing the Northern Territory from legislating to permit euthanasia. I note on 4 August 2021, Senator Sam McMahon introduced the Ensuring Northern Territory Rights Bill 2021 into parliament. This private members bill seeks to amend the NT Self Government Act to remove limits on the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly's powers to make laws in relation to a range of matters, including voluntary assisted dying. The Bill is currently before the Senate.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Territories, Mrs Marino
Australian Currency
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN3055 which requests that the spoken name and written name of the $50, $10 and $5 dollar notes be changed. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Reserve Bank Act 1959 governs the issuance of Australian banknotes. It specifies that Australian notes may be issued in any of the following denominations, namely, One dollar, Two dollars, Five dollars, Ten dollars, Twenty dollars, Fifty dollars or One hundred dollars (section 35). This provision implicitly requires the specification of the denomination, or face value, of the note.

Since moving to decimal currency in 1966, Australia's banknotes have always featured the denomination of the note in Arabic numerals and the Australian Government has no intention to change this approach. A new banknote series was released recently and there are no plans to make changes of any kind at this stage. However, the Reserve Bank of Australia welcomes suggestions in relation to Australia's banknotes.

I note that, notwithstanding the formal naming of Australian banknotes, nothing precludes individual citizens from referring to the banknote denominations in terms such as those outlined in the petition.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
HomeBuilder Program
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN3071 and the HomeBuilder program.

HomeBuilder is a time-limited program designed to assist the residential construction sector by encouraging the commencement of new home builds and substantial renovations. On 29 November 2020, the Government announced that the HomeBuilder program was extended for all new build contracts signed between 1 January 2021 to 31 March 2021. Applications for HomeBuilder closed at midnight, Wednesday 14 April 2021, and this deadline will not be further extended. Unfortunately, applications cannot be submitted after this date.

The National Partnership Agreement (NPA) on HomeBuilder outlines the application eligibility criteria for the HomeBuilder program. In administering HomeBuilder on behalf of the Commonwealth, States and Territories determine the evidentiary requirements to satisfy themselves that an applicant has met the criteria. The definition and assessment of an eligible contract is in the remit of each jurisdiction.

The States and Territories have sole discretion to determine whether an application has been validly submitted by the deadline. Any questions about HomeBuilder applications should be referred to the relevant State Revenue Office.

In addition, the Commonwealth Government announced on 17 April 2021 that for all eligible contracts signed between 4 June 2020 and 31 March 2021 (inclusive), the construction commencement requirement would be extended from six months to 18 months.

The Government's decision to provide existing applicants with an additional 12 months to commence construction was taken in response to unanticipated delays in the construction industry caused by supply and labour constraints including delays in global supply chains, the impact of COVID-19 lockdowns and natural disasters.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Immigration Detention
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021, enclosing Petition EN3082, with 11 signatures, concerning smoking at the Melbourne Immigration Transit Accommodation (MITA). Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

In each immigration detention facility (IDF), detainees are only permitted to smoke under strict rules in outside smoking areas. Within each IDF there is signage to indicate where smoking is permitted and signage to indicate where smoking is prohibited. If there is an area without either signage in place it is considered a non-smoking area.
Cigarette lighters are not permitted in IDFs. Detainees are to use fixed electric lighters that are placed in all designated smoking areas.

There are measures in place to ensure that detainees only utilise the permitted smoking areas and fixed electric lighters. Facilities and Detainee Service Provider (FDSP) staff are continually reminding detainees to smoke in designated smoking areas and utilise the provided fixed lighters. Detainees are advised that continued non-compliance with facility regulations may result in an incident raised against them with the possibility of a Behavioural Management Plan (BMP).
BMPs are used as an intervention to manage and monitor the behaviour of a detainee and to maintain the safety and security for all other detainees and persons in the IDF.
In such cases where detainees utilise an unauthorised appliance to light a cigarette, the appliance is removed from the area and used the under supervision of the FDSP.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3082 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021, concerning petition EN3104, which asks for action to deliver the Novavax COVID-19 vaccine candidate to the Australian people.

The safety of the Australian population has always been the highest priority of the Australian Government. For this reason, decisions regarding COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI).

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is safe and effective, and its benefits outweigh any risks. With rolling submission, collaboration with international regulators, and proactively working with sponsors, the evaluation of COVID-19 vaccines including Novavax is being significantly expedited without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality and efficacy. In January 2021, the TGA granted provisional determination to Novavax. The next step in the approval process is for the sponsor to submit an application for provisional registration in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods. This submission includes a comprehensive dossier that includes specific information on clinical studies, non-clinical/toxicology studies, chemistry, manufacturing, risk-management, and other information.

Novavax submitted initial data in February 2021 and, as part of the company's rolling submission, provided its initial quality data tranche in November 2021. The TGA is currently evaluating this data and is in the process of obtaining further information and clarification from the sponsor as the evaluation progresses, as well as being informed by the advice of the Advisory Committee on Vaccines, an independent committee of external experts. More information on these evaluations can be found on the TGA website at: www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccines-undergoing-evaluation.

The Government has invested in a diverse portfolio of COVID-19 vaccines that use a variety of technical platforms, entering into five separate Advance Purchase Agreements for the supply of COVID-19 vaccines, if they prove to be safe and effective. These include agreements with Pfizer, AstraZeneca, Novavax, Moderna and the international COVAX. Combined, these agreements will ensure Australia has access to more than 280 million vaccine doses.

All COVID-19 vaccines used in the rollout have been granted provisional approval following a complete assessment of all this available data. No part of the process has been rushed and the TGA does not have an 'Emergency Use Authorisation' pathway for COVID-19 vaccines.

The TGA is open and transparent about safety information relating to COVID-19 vaccines, including any suspected side effects or potential safety issues. The TGA publishes a weekly safety report, including information about reported suspected side-effects, as well as other safety alerts as required. More information can be found at: www.tga.gov.au using the search term 'COVID-19-vaccine safety monitoring and reporting'. Product information and consumer medicines information, including ingredient listings for all provisionally approved vaccines, can also be located on the TGA's website.

span.span: The goal is to protect all people in
Australia from the harm caused by COVID-19 infection, through preventing serious illness and death, and where possible, disease transmission.
The Pfizer, AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria) and Moderna vaccines have all been proven through approval and safety monitori
ng processes to be very effective at reducing severe illness, hospitalisation and death.
The Government strongly encourage all Australians stay up to date on all news and announcements, by regularly checking my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au.
hank you for writing on this matter.
Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt

p.span: Afghanistan
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021 enclosing petition EN3159 with 525 signatures, concerning the situation in Afghanistan. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Afghan citizens are a prominent caseload in Australia's offshore Humanitarian Program and have been in the top five countries of origin over the last five years. The Australian Government announced on 18 August 2021 that Afghan citizens will be prioritised for processing within the offshore Humanitarian Program. An initial 3,000 humanitarian places have been allocated to Afghan nationals within Australia's 13,750 annual program. Particular priority will be given to persecuted minorities, women and children, and those who have close links to Australia.

The Government anticipates this initial allocation will increase further over the course of 2021-22. We are working with Afghan community leaders here in Australia, and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) to identify and resettle those Afghan refugees most in need. One 25 August 2021, the Government established on 25 August 2021 an Advisory Panel on Australia's Resettlement of Afghan Nationals to provide advice and support to the Government and the Department of Home Affairs to ensure that that resettlement planning, service provision, and goodwill across communities is harnessed for the Afghan cohort.

The Government is focussed on ensuring that the Australian response, including further consideration of Humanitarian Program settings, is well considered and meets the needs and priorities of the Afghan community. The Government will make further announcements on the composition and priorities in due course.

The Government recognises the importance of family reunion for refugees and humanitarian entrants. A key aim of Australia's Humanitarian Program is to reunite refugees and people who are in refugee-like situations overseas with their family in Australia through 'split family' provisions and the Special Humanitarian Program. Immediate family of people who have been resettled under the Humanitarian Program are given highest priority in processing.

Individuals who arrive lawfully in Australia seeking asylum, who are found to engage Australia's non-refoulement (non-return) obligations may be granted permanent protection, subject to fulfilling relevant visa criteria and the health, character and security requirements that apply to all Australian visas.

Unlawful arrivals who engage Australia's protection obligations are only eligible for temporary protection, that is, either a Temporary Protection visa (TPV) valid for three years or a Safe Haven Enterprise visa (SHEV) valid for five years. TPV holders are not eligible to propose relatives through the Humanitarian Program. This is in line with the Government's Operation Sovereign Borders policy that no one who comes to Australia illegally by boat will settle here—established to safeguard vulnerable people from exploitation by people smugglers, prevent the loss of life at sea, and ensure the integrity of Australia's borders. These settings have successfully stemmed the flow of people smuggling ventures to Australia and saved countless lives at sea.

In addition to the Humanitarian Program, the Government operates a Migration Program for people who wish to migrate on the basis of their skills or family relationships in Australia. Further information on this Program is available on the Department of Home Affair's website at: https://www.homeaffairs.gov.au.

Visa processing times can vary according to the particular circumstances of the applicant, their location (be it inside or outside their home country), and their ability to travel, provide documents or access Australian government officials. We know this is a distressing time for many people, including our Australian Afghan community, and request patience with the application process.

With regard to Afghan nationals who were granted a Humanitarian Stay (Temporary) (subclass 449) visa, these visas were granted due to the rapidly changing security circumstances in Afghanistan, the urgent and exceptional humanitarian nature of the evacuation operation and the limited window for people to depart Afghanistan. We made every effort we could to get everyone out, with the top priority being to evacuate Australians, visa holders and former locally engaged employees. Following the formal evacuation phase, Australia has continued to facilitate, where possible, the ad hoc movement of smaller number of Afghan nationals, including subclass 449 visa holders who have fled Afghanistan.

For those subclass 449 visa holders in Australia, on 12 November 2021 the Government announced changes to the migration legislation to support Afghan nationals recently evacuated from Afghanistan to undertake permanent visa processes in Australia. These changes support the evacuees through permanent visa processes through the provision of a 12 month extension of their temporary subclass 449 visas. During this time they will also retain access to Commonwealth settlement, health, welfare and income supports.

These changes also provide a clear pathway to permanent residence for those Afghan evacuees located in Australia on subclass 449 visas—either continuing on their existing migration visa pathways, or through the Humanitarian Program. These changes allows Afghan subclass 449 visa holders in Australia to make a valid application for a Refugee and Humanitarian (Class XB) visa in Australia. This change aligns to a practicable extent, visa outcomes for this group with what they would likely have been eligible through the Humanitarian Program, if they did not need urgent evacuation from Afghanistan.

Further, on 18 November 2021, the Government announced that the subclass 449 visas granted to Afghans who supported Australia's mission in Afghanistan and their families, who have not yet arrived in Australia, will be extended on an ongoing basis. This includes subclass 449 holders who are:
certified Locally Engaged Employees of the Department of Defence, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and the Australian Federal Police, and
other persons with working relationships with the Australian Government.
Those outside the LEE program who were granted a subclass 449 visa, which will expire, are to receive priority in Australia's Humanitarian and Refugee intake.

In addition, the Government is working to ensure that visa options continue to be available to Afghan nationals, both within Afghanistan and those who have been displaced from their home country. All visa applications will be processed in accordance with Government announcements and within program priorities, and assessed on an individual basis. All visa applicants must also meet visa criteria and satisfy public interest criteria for character, security and health.

For those remaining in Afghanistan, the situation remains highly volatile, and travel throughout Afghanistan is extremely dangerous. Some borders are closed or may close without notice (as outlined in Smartraveller advice). We urge all people remaining in Afghanistan to prioritise their safety and carefully consider the risks should they attempt to leave by any route.

Afghan Australians are an integral part of Australian society and the Australian community. The Government is endeavouring to do all we can to continue to assist those affected through our ongoing humanitarian, whole-of-government and collaborative efforts.
Thank you for bringing petition EN3159 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
COVID-19: Income Support Payments
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 18 October 2021 to the Treasurer, the Hon Josh Frydenberg MP, regarding petition EN3206 calling on the amount of the COVID-19 Disaster Payment to be raised and for the payment to be extended to the end of January 2022. As this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your correspondence has been referred to me for a response.

The Australian Government has ensured support is available for people affected by the public health response to COVID-19. As at the 2021-22 Budget, the Australian Government had committed $311 billion, or about 15.7 per cent of 2019-20 GDP, in direct economic and health support to Australian households and businesses since the onset of the pandemic. The Australian Government continues to provide direct economic support to Australian households and businesses impacted by the recent COVID-19 outbreaks with over $11.7 billion (as at 29 October 2021) paid in business support. Since it was introduced in mid-2021, the COVID-19 Disaster Payment has supported over 2 million people, to a total of over $12.5 billion (as at 29 October 2021).

Under the National Plan, the Government announced that as vaccination rates increase, there is an expectation lockdowns and movement restrictions will ease. As states and territories reach 70 per cent and 80 per cent full vaccination of their population 16 years or older, more people are able to go back to work.
When a state or territory reaches the 80 per cent vaccination target, the payment will decrease over a two week period before it stops and is no longer available in that jurisdiction.

People whose income is still affected after this period or have lost their job entirely, may be able to access other support such as JobSeeker Payment, and should test their eligibility through the Services Australia website.
Thank you for bringing your concerns to my attention and I trust this is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Emergency Management and National Recovery and Resilience, Senator McKenzie
Migration
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 18 October 2021, enclosing Petition EN3212, with 123 signatures, concerning the operation of the SkillSelect system and the Expressions of Interest (EOI) that have been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

The Department of Home Affairs is closely monitoring migration and visa settings to ensure they are consistent with public health measures, are flexible and do not displace job opportunities for Australians, so that Australia can effectively respond to the immediate and subsequent impacts of COVID-19. Targeted invitation rounds have occurred in SkillSelect since May 2020 for Skilled Independent (subclass 189) visas. The number of invitations issued each round is also impacted by Migration planning levels and the number of on-hand applications for this visa. For the 2021-22 Program Year planning levels for this visa are 6,500 places.

Given the number of places available in this program are limited, not all intending migrants with an EOI points score will be issued an invitation to apply. Extending the validity of an EOI, beyond the two year period, may result in applicants failing the requirements to be granted a visa. It is open to applicants to submit a new EOI, with updated information, should they still wish to be considered.

The EOI process is a key component of the Skilled Migration Program and is used to enable skilled workers or business persons from overseas to express their interest in migrating to Australia. Applicants submit their EOI through the SkillSelect system. An EOI is not a visa application and there is no fee to create or submit an EOI in SkillSelect. Once an EOI has been completed and submitted, it is stored in SkillSelect and is valid for two years.

Points Tested Skilled Visas require the applicant to undertake skills and English assessments which must be valid at the time an invitation is made. SkillSelect is a dynamic system, which updates an applicant's score throughout the lifetime of an EOI based on information provided in the EOI. SkillSelect ranks intending migrants on their notional points score which SkillSelect determines using criteria in Schedule 6D of the Migration Regulations. An applicant can update their EOI information at any time until they are invited, and should do so if their circumstances change.

Invitations for Skilled Independent (subclass 189) visas are issued from SkillSelect via an automated process and use the ranking system of the highest points score followed by the earliest 'Date of Effect'.
Once invited to apply for a visa, the intending migrant has 60 calendar days to lodge an application for the visa specified in the invitation. The validity period of an invitation cannot be extended.

Applicants who have not received an invitation for a Skilled Independent visa may wish to explore alternative options, such as submitting an EOI for a state and territory Nominated visas (such as the Skilled Nominated (subclass 190) visa) which are invited under a different process from that outlined above. SkillSelect candidates for Skilled Nominated visas are not issued a direct invitation via SkillSelect. Rather, relevant state and territory government agencies can view EOIs in SkillSelect and decide whether to nominate them for a visa. When a state and territory government agency nominates in SkillSelect, it triggers an invitation to be issued.
Applicants may also choose to contact a state and territory government agency to discuss their nomination process and requirements, and request possible consideration for nomination.
Contact details for state government agencies can be found on their website at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/skilled-nominated-190#Eligibility.
Other skilled migration options are also outlined on the Department's website at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/working-in-australia/permanent-work-visas.
Further information on SkillSelect invitation rounds can be found at:
https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/working-in-australia/skillselect/invitation-rounds.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3212 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition EN3233 requesting legislation against mandatory COVID-19 vaccination passports.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

The Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Everyone maintains the option to choose. However, as the COVID-19 pandemic is a public-health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. In line with this, some states and territories have now issued public-health orders which require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Further information about public-health orders may be found on state or territory government websites.

Some employers have also started to mandate vaccinations for their employees. For individual businesses not covered by a public-health order, whether to require COVID-19 vaccinations for employees or needs careful consideration, taking into account the relevant employment, discrimination, work health and safety, and privacy laws, and the circumstances of the workplace. The Government encourages employers and employees to work together on workplace vaccination for COVID-19.

In addition, the Government understands that some businesses are considering whether to require vaccination as a condition of service or entry. Businesses do have the right to make any service they provide subject to conditions and can impose restrictions on who can enter their premises. However, anti-discrimination issues may arise where people are unable to be vaccinated, and privacy laws restrict the collection of sensitive information. In each case, businesses need to consider their legal obligations, and determine what is right for their business.
Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there are exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical reasons.

Before a prescription medicine (including a COVID-19 vaccine) can be legally supplied in Australia, it must be approved for use by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) and it will be subject to well-established and rigorous assessment and approval process of the TGA to determine if the benefits outweigh the risks.

The TGA is responsible for the ongoing monitoring of all vaccines approved for use in Australia and has robust procedures in place to investigate any potential new safety issues. The TGA's vaccine safety monitoring system can rapidly detect, investigate and respond to any emerging safety issues identified for COVID-19 vaccines.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning the petition EN3234 Safety, COVID-19 vaccine, avoid vascular injection to prevent thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome (TTS).

The Australian Government is following the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI) on the use of COVID-19 vaccines in Australia. The ATAGI have published clinical guidance on the use of COVID-19 vaccines in Australia, which is available to view at: www.health.gov.au using the search terms 'ATAGI Clinical Guidance'.
According to the ATAGI clinical guidance, TTS is a newly described serious condition, with unusual blood and low platelet levels following receipt of AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria) COVID-19 vaccine.

The exact mechanism leading to TTS is not yet fully understood, but is thought to be immune-mediated, involving antibodies against platelet factor 4. However, based on what we currently know, there is little evidence to suggest TTS is caused by accidental intravascular administration of the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine.

To ensure all our COVID-19 vaccination providers are competent in the safe management and administration of COVID-19 vaccines, the Government has partnered with the Australian College of Nursing to develop the COVID-19 Vaccination Training Program. The free and accredited training program is mandatory and provides comprehensive information on the administration of COVID-19 vaccines in Australia for providers.

The training program draws on the latest advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee, the ATAGI, the Communicable Diseases Network Australia and the World Health Organization. For more information, please visit my Department's website at:
www.health.gov.au/covid-19-vaccination-training-program.

On the correct administration techniques for COVID-19 vaccinations, the training draws on advice from the Australian Immunisation Handbook (AIH). The AIH is developed by ATAGI and provides clinical advice for health professionals on the safest and most effective use of vaccines in their practice. For more information on the AIH please visit:
immunisationhandbook.health.gov.au.

I note your petition proposes that aspiration prior to injection (pulling back the plunger to draw blood into needle, thereby avoiding incorrect vascular injection), could be a potential preventive measure to avoid TTS after the administration of COVID-19 vaccines.
The training modules and the AIH provides the following advice on aspiration:

span.span: "It is not necessary nor encouraged to draw back on the

syringe prior before injecting a vaccine. If aspiration is performed and a flash of blood appears in the needle hub, the needle needs to be withdrawn and replaced, and a new site for injection selected "

p.span: These vaccine administration instructions are consistent with the Product Information (PI) for the COVID-19 vaccines. The PI are available on the Therapeutic Goods Administration website at: www.tga.gov.au. Similarly, these instructions also recommend against needle aspiration prior to administration of COVID-19 vaccines.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Law Enforcement
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 enclosing Petition EN3250 with 282 signatures, concerning the Surveillance Legislation Amendment (Identify and Disrupt) Act 2021 (the Act).

The Act forms part of the Australian Government's response to the challenges posed by the increasing use of the dark web and anonymising technologies, which allows criminals, including terrorists and other malicious actors to hide from law enforcement. This has made committing serious crimes at volume and across borders easier than ever before.

The Act provides the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and the Australian Criminal Intelligence Commission (ACIC) with new powers to identify and disrupt serious criminal activities online. Data disruption warrants enable the AFP and the ACIC to frustrate the commission of serious offences online by modifying, adding or deleting data. Network activity warrants enable the AFP and ACIC to collect intelligence on serious criminal activity carried out by criminal networks online. Account takeover warrants allow the AFP and ACIC to take control of a person's online account to gather evidence about criminal activity.

The powers authorised under a warrant cannot be used for unauthorised purposes. It does not permit the AFP or the ACIC to engage in criminal activity on behalf of other persons. Each of these warrants are issued by an independent issuing authority and must relate to an offence carrying a maximum penalty of imprisonment of three years or more. Before a warrant can be issued, the issuing authority must be satisfied that there are reasonable grounds founding the application for the warrant and have regard to certain matters, including the nature and gravity of the conduct constituting the offence, privacy and the impact on innocent third parties.

The powers are accompanied by strong safeguards which protect the privacy of Australians and ensures that the powers are used only where necessary, proportionate and reasonable. The Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security and the Commonwealth Ombudsman will oversee the AFP and ACIC's use of these powers.

The operation, effectiveness and implications of these powers will be subject to review by the Independent National Security Legislation Monitor and the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security.

These new powers are highly targeted, only able to be obtained in relation to the investigation of serious criminal offences and only once an independent issuing authority is satisfied all relevant criteria are met. The strong safeguards that form part of these powers ensure they will be used appropriately.

The Government has designed these new laws very carefully to ensure the Act strikes the appropriate balance between respecting individual privacy and the rule of law on which our democracy is based, while still giving our Australian law enforcement agencies the vital powers they need to keep the community safe.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3250 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Law Enforcement
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 enclosing Petition EN3253 with 326 signatures, concerning the Surveillance Legislation Amendment (Identify and Disrupt) Act 2021.

The Act forms part of the Australian Government's response to the challenges posed by the increasing use of the dark web and anonymising technologies, which allows criminals, including terrorists and other malicious actors to hide from law enforcement. This has made committing serious crimes at volume and across borders easier than ever before.

The Act provides the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and the Australian Criminal Intelligence Commission (ACIC) with new powers to identify and disrupt serious criminal activities online. Network activity warrants enable the AFP and ACIC to collect intelligence on serious criminal activity carried out by criminal networks online. Account takeover warrants allow the AFP and ACIC to take control of a person's online account to gather evidence about criminal activity. For example, using an account takeover warrant, an agency could access the account belonging to a member of a terrorist group.

Each of these warrants are issued by an independent issuing authority and must relate to an offence carrying a maximum penalty of imprisonment of three years or more. Before a warrant can be issued, the issuing authority must be satisfied that there are reasonable grounds founding the application for the warrant and have regard to certain matters, including the nature and gravity of the conduct constituting the offence, privacy and the impact on innocent third parties.

The new powers are accompanied by strong safeguards which protect the privacy of Australians and ensures that the powers are used only where necessary, proportionate and reasonable. The Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security and the Commonwealth Ombudsman will oversee the AFP and ACIC's use of these powers.

The operation, effectiveness and implications of these powers will be subject to review by the Independent National Security Legislation Monitor and the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security.

These new powers are highly targeted, only able to be obtained in relation to the investigation of serious criminal offences and only once an independent issuing authority is satisfied all relevant criteria are met. The strong safeguards that form part of these powers ensure they will be used appropriately.

The Government has designed these new laws very carefully to ensure the Act strikes the appropriate balance between respecting individual privacy and the rule of law on which our democracy is based, while still giving our Australian law enforcement agencies the vital powers they need to keep the community safe.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3253 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition EN3260, calling on the Australian Government to introduce, or import, China's COVID-19 vaccines as soon as possible.

The Government wants everyone in Australia to have access to a safe, free, COVID-19 vaccine, if they choose to be vaccinated. Moreover, the safety of the population has always been the highest priority of the Government. For these reasons, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) formally assesses the safety, quality and efficacy of medicines, including vaccines, prior to their approval for use in Australia. All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large clinical trials on thousands of people. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease.

This involves comprehensive review of clinical trial data, non-clinical and toxicological studies, chemistry, manufacturing, quality, risk-management and other information by a large team of clinical and scientific experts. Advice is then sought from an independent expert committee before a regulatory decision is made.

The Pfizer, AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria), Moderna and Janssen COVID-19 vaccines have been provisionally approved after a complete assessment of all the available data and the Novavax vaccine is currently under evaluation. The Pfizer, AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria) and Moderna vaccines have subsequently been used in Australia's national vaccine rollout, while the Janssen vaccine has not been utilised, though it is provisionally approved.

This approval process is the same process as any vaccine approved in this country. The TGA will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is safe and effective, and its benefits outweigh any risks. No part of the process has been rushed, and there was no emergency authorisation granted as the TGA does not have an 'Emergency Use Authorisation' pathway for COVID-19 vaccines.

The urgency of the global pandemic means that researchers, agencies such as the World Health Organization and governments all over the world are prioritising the development, assessment, and rollout of COVID-19 vaccines.

The TGA requires robust scientific data before supporting a vaccine candidate and will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is found to be safe and effective, following its complete assessment of data. Information concerning COVID-19 vaccines under evaluation can be found at:
www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccines-undergoing-evaluation.

With rolling submission, collaboration with international regulators, and proactively working with sponsors, the evaluation of COVID-19 vaccines including Novavax is being significantly expedited without compromising on our strict standards of safety, quality and efficacy. However, the timeframe will ultimately depend on when the complete data package is provided by sponsors to enable the required regulatory processes.

The Government also continues to meet regularly with a range of COVID-19 vaccine and treatment developers and manufacturers and continues to monitor ongoing clinical trials and review real world effectiveness of vaccine rollouts, globally. There are more than 400 trials for 140 vaccine candidates worldwide, including a number that are trialling the use of needle-free technology. These include nasal sprays, oral tablets, skin patches and jet injectors.

Future investments in COVID-19 vaccine candidates and manufacturing options are subject to the advice of the COVID-19 Vaccines and Treatments for Australia—Science and Industry Technical Advisory Group, and assessment of clinical evidence, including portfolio diversification and risk.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID-19 Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at:
www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator the Hon Marise Payne, enclosing Petition number EN3262 with 314 signatures, concerning travel exemptions for immediate family members (spouse and/or dependent children) of international Student visa holders to travel to Australia. Your correspondence was referred to me on 24 November 2021 as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

Australia's current travel restriction policy has played a foundational role underpinning management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia and was implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

You may be aware that on 6 August 2021, the National Cabinet agreed in full to a four-phase National Plan to transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response. The National Transition Plan provides a graduated pathway to reopen the international border with each phase triggered once Australia reaches key vaccination thresholds expressed as a percentage of the population who are vaccinated.

In line with the National Plan, on 22 November 2021 the Australian Government announced that from 1 December 2021, fully-vaccinated eligible visa holders including those holding a Student visa, either primary, or as a dependent based on the relationship with the onshore student as a spouse or dependent child, will be exempt from the travel restrictions for travel to Australia. However, based on caution, whilst more is learnt about the nature and impact of the Omicron variant of concern, on 29 November 2021, the Government announced a temporary pause to safely reopen Australia to fully-vaccinated eligible visa holders from 1 December 2021 until 15 December 2021.

Immediate family members of those international students in Australia, who hold a Student visa, listed as an eligible visa under these new arrangements will now be able to avail themselves of the 'vaccination advantage' for travel without the need to apply for an exemption after 15 December 2021.

A full list of eligible visa subclasses and information on how to access this arrangement is available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/vaccinated-travellers.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3262 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Law Enforcement
