from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition EN3305 to fast-track the approval and supply of the Novavax vaccine.

The Australian Government is committed to providing all Australians with access to safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines as soon as available. The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is safe and effective, and its benefits outweigh any risks. With rolling submission, collaboration with international regulators, and proactively working with sponsors, the evaluation of the Novavax COVID-19 vaccine is being significantly expedited without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality and efficacy. The Novavax vaccine has been granted provisional determination by the TGA and is currently under evaluation.

The next step in the approval process is for the sponsor to submit an application for provisional registration in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods. This submission includes a comprehensive dossier that includes specific information on clinical studies, non-clinical/toxicology studies, chemistry, manufacturing, risk-management, and other information.

Novavax submitted initial data in February 2021, and, as part of the company's rolling submission, provided its initial quality data tranche in November 2021. The TGA is currently evaluating this data and is in the process of obtaining further information and clarification from the sponsor as the evaluation progresses, as well as being informed by the advice of the Advisory Committee on Vaccines-an independent committee of external experts.

The Government continues to meet regularly with a range of COVID-19 vaccine and treatment developers and manufacturers and continues to monitor ongoing clinical trials and review real-world effectiveness of vaccine rollouts, globally. The nature of these discussions is commercial-in-confidence but considers the likely timing of supply, cost and recommendations from Government medical experts.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Health Care
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 23 November 2021 concerning petition EN3307 requesting that gender affirming and gender reassignment services be eligible for Medicare benefits.

I appreciate the many challenges faced by transgender people and those who have gender dysphoria. The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that all Australians are able to access timely and affordable, high quality health care by providing Medicare rebates for services listed on the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) and free hospital services for public patients in public hospitals.

While there is no specific MBS item for gender affirmation surgery, MBS rebates are available for patients to cover a range of surgical procedures and specialist consultations that may be performed as part of the gender affirmation process, if the services are deemed by the treating practitioner to be clinically relevant.

Before a new medical procedure or treatment can be publicly funded on the MBS, an application would need to be assessed by the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC). MSAC is an independent, expert advisory group which provides advice to the Government on whether a new medical service or technology should be publicly funded, based on an assessment of the comparative safety, clinical effectiveness and cost effectiveness, using the best available evidence. To date, no application has been submitted to MSAC to list specific gender affirmation surgery items on the MBS. More information about the MSAC process is available on the MSAC website at: www.msac.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccinations
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition EN3310, requesting legislation against mandatory COVID-19 vaccination passports.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

The Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Everyone maintains the option to choose. However, as the COVID-19 pandemic is a public-health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. In line with this, some states and territories have now issued public-health orders which require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Further information about public-health orders may be found on state or territory government websites.

Some employers have also started to mandate vaccinations for their employees. For individual businesses not covered by a public-health order, whether to require COVID-19 vaccinations for employees needs careful consideration, taking into account the relevant employment, discrimination, work health and safety, privacy laws, and the circumstances of the workplace. The Government encourages employers and employees to work together on workplace vaccination for COVID-19.

In addition, the Government understands that some businesses are considering whether to require vaccination as a condition of service or entry. Businesses do have the right to make any service they provide subject to conditions and can impose restrictions on who can enter their premises. However, anti-discrimination issues may arise where people are unable to be vaccinated, and privacy laws restrict the collection of sensitive information. In each case, businesses need to consider their legal obligations, and determine what is right for their business.
Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there are exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical reasons.

Before a prescription medicine (including a COVID-19 vaccine) can be legally supplied in Australia, it must be approved for use by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) and it will be subject to well-established and rigorous assessment and approval process of the TGA to determine if the benefits outweigh the risks.

The TGA is responsible for the ongoing monitoring of all vaccines approved for use in Australia and has robust procedures in place to investigate any potential new safety issues. The TGA's vaccine safety monitoring system can rapidly detect, investigate and respond to any emerging safety issues identified for COVID-19 vaccines.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition EN3313—Freedom of Vaccine Choice in Australia.

The Australian Government wants everyone in Australia to have access to a safe and free COVID-19 vaccine if they choose to be vaccinated. Moreover, the safety of the population has always been the highest priority of the Government. For these reasons, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) formally assesses the safety, quality and efficacy of medicines, including vaccines, prior to their approval for use in Australia. All vaccines must pass the TGA's rigorous assessment and approval processes, after being tested in large clinical trials on thousands of people. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials and test for safety at every phase, as well as the vaccine's efficacy at protecting against infection and disease.

This involves comprehensive review of clinical trial data, non-clinical and toxicological studies, chemistry, manufacturing, quality, risk management and other information by a large team of clinical and scientific experts. Advice is then sought from an independent expert committee before a regulatory decision is made.

All COVID-19 vaccines used in the rollout have been granted provisional approval following a complete assessment of all this available data. No part of the process has been rushed, and the TGA does not have an 'Emergency Use Authorisation' pathway for COVID-19 vaccines.

The urgency of the global pandemic means that researchers and agencies such as the World Health Organization, and governments all over the world, are prioritising the development, assessment and rollout of COVID-19 vaccines.
There is a combination of reasons why safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines have been able to be designed, researched and made available sooner than previously seen. For example:
Unprecedented levels of funding—the pandemic is a global priority and governments around the world are investing in research and manufacturing facilities.

Technology—the evolution of technology has allowed vaccines to be developed at a faster pace than in the past. New technologies have helped scientists understand the coronavirus and its make-up more easily, which has allowed them to start working on vaccine design more quickly.
Combined clinical trials—in response to the pandemic, some pharmaceutical companies have combined clinical trial phases 1 and 2.
Expedited review process by regulatory agencies—the TGA is engaging early with pharmaceutical companies about their vaccines and is accepting rolling data.

This means that the TGA can accept, review and assess clinical trial data as it becomes available, rather than all at once at the end of the three clinical trial phases. The TGA will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is safe and effective, and its benefits outweigh any risks. With rolling submission, collaboration with international regulators, and proactively working with sponsors, the evaluation of COVID-19 vaccines, including Novavax, is being significantly expedited without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality and efficacy. In January 2021, the TGA granted provisional determination to Novavax. The next step in the approval process is for the sponsor to submit an application for provisional registration in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods. This submission includes a comprehensive dossier that includes specific information on clinical studies, non-clinical/toxicology studies, chemistry, manufacturing, risk-management, and other information.

Novavax submitted initial data in February 2021 and, as part of the company's rolling submission, provided its initial quality data tranche in November 2021. The TGA is currently evaluating this data and is in the process of obtaining further information and clarification from the sponsor as the evaluation progresses, as well as being informed by the advice of the Advisory Committee on Vaccines-an independent committee of external experts. More information on these evaluations can be found on the TGA website at: www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccines-undergoing-evaluation.

The Government continues to meet regularly with a range of COVID-19 vaccine and treatment developers and manufacturers, and continues to monitor ongoing clinical trials and review real-world effectiveness of vaccine rollouts, globally. The nature of these discussions is commercial-in-confidence, but considers the likely timing of supply, cost and recommendations from Government medical experts.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at:
www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Alzheimer's Disease
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions concerning petition number EN3314 which seeks further funding and resources into the research of Alzheimer's disease.

Alzheimer's disease is the most common form of dementia. The Australian Government recognises the significant impact it has on Australians and remains committed to funding quality health and medical research to find better treatments and cures. Health and medical research has been identified as one of the key pillars supporting the health system and is essential to building a stronger, sustainable health system.

The Government has established the $20 billion Medical Research Future Fund (MRFF) to support health and medical research, improve health outcomes and quality of life. Since its inception through to 31 October 2021, the MRFF has invested $18.8 million in Alzheimer's disease research.

The Dementia, Ageing and Aged Care Mission (DAAC Mission) is a research program under the MRFF that is investing $185 million from 2018-19 to 2028-29. The DAAC Mission aims to reduce the impact of dementia by improving detection, prevention, assessment and treatment and care and support for people living with dementia. More information on the DAAC Mission can be found at:
www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/dementia-ageing-and-aged-care-mission.

The DAAC Mission is supported by an Expert Advisory Panel (EAP) formed to provide advice to the Minister for Health and Aged Care about the research priorities for the DAAC Mission. The EAP has developed a strategic plan for research investment from the DAAC Mission, communicated through a Roadmap and Implementation Plan, identifying priority objectives for the DAAC Mission and a research plan to address those objectives.

One of the first projects funded under the DAAC Mission was the 'Clem Jones Centre for Ageing Dementia Research', which was awarded $10 million in 2019. This centre brings together Australia's largest group of researchers focusing on areas such as Alzheimer's disease.

The DAAC Mission is underpinned by a Roadmap and Implementation Plan which outlines priority areas for investment over the short, medium and long-term. The 2020 DAAC Mission Grant Opportunity awarded $3.9 million to accelerate the use of blood tests in clinical settings that can help to diagnose, and predict the onset of, Alzheimer's disease. The grant will also examine the impact of having a diagnostic blood test for Alzheimer's disease on health and management outcomes.

The Mission will generate measurable improvements for those living with dementia, increasing the healthy lifespan experienced by older Australians and improving care for older Australians across all care settings.

Under the MRFF 10 Year Plan announced in the 2019-20 Budget, $614 million is committed over 10 years under the Clinical Trials Activity Initiative. A significant proportion of the Clinical Trials Activity initiative budget is dedicated to supporting clinical trials that focus on rare cancers, rare diseases and unmet need (RCRDUN). The MRFF RCRDUN grant opportunities support clinical trials research that investigates new drugs, devices or treatments for rare cancers/diseases or for areas of unmet medical need, such as Alzheimer's disease.

Information on MRFF grant opportunities is available on the Government's GrantConnect website at: www.grants.gov.au. If they haven't already done so, researchers are strongly encouraged to register with GrantConnect to receive alerts for upcoming MRFF grant opportunities. In addition to these investments, since 2014, the National Health and Medical Research Council has awarded over $466 million in direct funding to 429 dementia research projects. This includes funding through the Boosting Dementia Research Initiative (2014--2019).

The Government is also committed to improving the quality of life and care for people living with dementia. In response to the Royal Commission into Aged Care Quality and Safety, an investment of over $229 million is being made to improve support for people living with dementia and their carers at every stage of a dementia journey. Together this will ensure people living with dementia are connected with the support they need post-diagnosis, are enabled to remain in their home for longer, and able to access high quality, dementia informed aged care services.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination

I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition EN3315 Freedom of choice—COVID Vaccine, requesting legislation against mandatory COVID-19 vaccination passports.

In addition, the Government understands that some businesses are considering whether to require vaccination as a condition of service or entry. Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there are exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical reasons.

Before a prescription medicine (including a COVID-19 vaccine) can be legally supplied in Australia, it must be approved for use by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) and it will be subject to well-established and rigorous assessment and approval process of the TGA to determine if the benefits outweigh the risks.

The TGA is responsible for the ongoing monitoring of all vaccines approved for use in Australia and has robust procedures in place to investigate any potential new safety issues. The TGA's vaccine safety monitoring system can rapidly detect, investigate and respond to any emerging safety issues identified for COVID-19 vaccines.

from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Quarantine
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021, enclosing petition EN3318 with 83 signatures, concerning rules to mandatory hotel quarantine imposed on incoming/returned travellers to Australia, being replaced with home quarantine.

Quarantine arrangements have been an ongoing and critical feature of Australia's border management since March 2020. In accordance with the National Plan to Transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response (National Transition Plan), Australia is reopening its international border in a phased and careful way. Under Phase C of the National Transition Plan, there has been a gradual reopening of inward and outward international travel with safe countries and reduced quarantine requirements for fully vaccinated inbound travellers.

Quarantine arrangements including the type and duration, are a matter for the states and territories in accordance with the National Transition Plan. Quarantine-free arrangements for fully vaccinated travelers, including Australian citizens and permanent residents returning to Australia from overseas, have been introduced in some states and territories. All states and territories now either have reduced or modified quarantine arrangements in place for fully vaccinated travellers, or plans to introduce them once vaccination targets are met.

Travellers who are not eligible for vaccination or who are unable to be vaccinated on medical grounds, can also access modified quarantine arrangements with appropriate evidence. Arrangements are also in place to support the travel of unvaccinated and partially vaccinated 12-17 year olds.

All international travellers are required to follow and comply with quarantine and COVID-19 testing arrangements of the state they enter. People who are wishing to travel onwards to another state or territory may also be subject to a quarantine period or may not be allowed to enter. Information on all of these arrangements is available on the respective state or territory health website.
Thank you for bringing petition EN3318 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator the Hon Marise Payne, enclosing Petition EN3332 with 332 signatures, seeking to include parents of Australian citizens including those who migrated to Australia, and permanent residents, as immediate family for the purposes of Australia's travel restrictions. Your correspondence was referred to me as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

Australia's current travel restriction policy has played a foundational role underpinning the management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia and was implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

As announced by the Australian Government on 22 October 2021, parents of adult Australian citizens and permanent residents will be considered immediate family for travel exemption purpose. Parental relationships for the purpose of a travel exemption to travel to Australia include biological, adoptive, legal, step-parent, and parents-in-law.

Applications for a travel exemption to have the relationship confirmed can be submitted through the Department of Home Affairs' Travel Exemption Portal. Further information about travel exemptions for parents is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/immediate-family-australian-citizens-or-permanent-residents-or-new-zealand-citizens-usually-resident-australia.

Additionally, before travelling, parents must also have a valid passport, a valid visa for travel to Australia and be fully vaccinated with a recognised vaccine. These requirements will be checked by the airline before boarding. Further information on the requirements prior to travel to Australia is outlined on the Department's website at:
https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/vaccinated-travellers.

I acknowledge that since the travel restrictions were introduced in March 2020, many families with parents overseas have missed significant life events and therefore would like to extend my thanks to these families for their patience and their sacrifice over this period.
As Australia progresses through the key vaccination thresholds, the Government will continue to expand the range of circumstances available for international travel to Australia.
The most up to date Government announcements about travel restrictions and travel exemptions is available on the Department's website at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3332 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Child Support Scheme
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021, referring Petition EN3349 for written response.

The Australian Government acknowledges that family breakdowns are incredibly difficult and the Child Support Scheme is in place to ensure that, as far as possible, children affected by a family breakdown remain financially secure until they reach 18 years of age, regardless of the custody arrangements in place. The Child Support Scheme achieves this by facilitating the assessment and collection of child support between parents.
The petitioner may be interested in the following information.

The Child Support Scheme does not make any distinction based on the gender or background of either parent. The child support formula (through the Costs of the Children Table) determines the total costs of raising children in each case (based on parental income and the number and age of children), and distributes these costs between each parent based on their proportion of the assessed income and the amount of care they have for their children.

Child support assessments are generally calculated on the actual care of the children, as this helps to ensure they have access to an adequate amount of ongoing financial support, regardless of whom they reside with. Services Australia may take into account the amount of time during both day and night that each parent cares for the child, as well as who is responsible for making arrangements for, and decisions about, the child's welfare.

For court-ordered arrangements, if there is a dispute, the percentage of care used in the court order can be used to determine the child support assessment for an interim period of up to 52 weeks, if the disputed care change occurs within the first year of the order. For older court orders, the interim period is up to 26 weeks if the person with increased care does not take reasonable action to participate in family dispute resolution. For care arrangements under a non-enforceable agreement or parenting plan, the interim period can be up to 14 weeks.

Where the care of the children is not agreed by the parents, these issues are best dealt with through mediation or dispute resolution, or pursued through the family law system. Services Australia does not have a role in mediating care arrangements.

A parent's adjusted taxable income, rather than net or gross income, is used in the child support formula to calculate both parents' child support income. Adjusted taxable income for the last relevant financial year is usually the most up-to-date and accurate annual income information available to Services Australia. This income comprises taxable income (that is, income before tax but after any allowable deductions) and certain supplementary amounts such as foreign income. reportable fringe benefits, tax-free pensions and benefits, total net investment losses and reportable superannuation contributions. A parent's child support income is their adjusted taxable income less the self-support amount, and the relevant dependent child amount (if applicable).

One of the principles which underpins the Child Support Scheme is that all children of a parent should be treated as equally as possible, regardless of the order of their birth. This is the principle behind how a relevant dependent child amount is calculated. The relevant dependent child amount and calculations are the same regardless of whether the parent is a paying parent, or a receiving parent.

If either parent believes their child support assessment is unfair because of the special circumstances of their case, they can seek a review under the change of assessment process. There are a broad range of circumstances Services Australia can consider, including the earning capacity of either parent, travel costs to visit children and financial hardship.

A child support debt or overpayment may occur if a liability is not paid in full by the due date, or where there are changes to an assessment that are retrospective. such as a care change or corrections to a parent's income when there is a reconciled estimate, or a backdating of income when a tax return is lodged.

Where a child support debt or overpayment has been raised, Services Australia will encourage the parent to enter into a voluntary payment arrangement to repay their debt in the shortest possible time. Services Australia will work with parents who may experience hardship as a result of a debt or overpayment to negotiate a repayment arrangement based on their individual circumstances.

While the majority of parents do the right thing, Services Australia has extensive enforcement powers to ensure parents meet their child support obligation. Enforcement powers include the ability to directly garnishee wages, recover funds from bank accounts, tax returns or certain income support payments, the power to prevent child support defaulters from travelling overseas. and litigation action through a court.

The Government funds a range of support services such as Lifeline. Lifeline provides confidential online, phone and face to face crisis support and suicide prevention services for persons experiencing a personal crisis, 24 hours a day. 7 days a week. The service is available throughout Australia and can be contacted on 13 1114, or online at www.lifeline.org.au. Another program which specifically supports men is MensLine Australia, a 24-hour counselling. information and referral service for men. MensLine Australia can be contacted on 1300 789 978, or through their website at www.mensline.org.au.

Furthermore, the Joint Select Committee on Australia's Family Law System (the Committee) has conducted a wide-ranging Inquiry into the Scheme and made a number of recommendations. The Government is considering the Committee's recommendations, relating to child support and family safety, and will respond to the Committee's report.
For more information, visit:
www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary Business/Committees/Joint/Family Law System.
Thank you again for raising this petition with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition EN3350, requesting legislation against mandatory COVID-19 vaccination passports.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

The Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Everyone maintains the option to choose. However, as the COVID-19 pandemic is a public-health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. In line with this, some states and territories have now issued public-health orders which require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Further information about public-health orders may be found on state or territory government websites.

Some employers have also started to mandate vaccinations for their employees. For individual businesses not covered by a public-health order, whether to require COVID-19 vaccinations for employees or needs careful consideration, taking into account the relevant employment, discrimination, work health and safety, and privacy laws, and the circumstances of the particular workplace. The Government encourages employers and employees to work together on workplace vaccination for COVID-19.

In addition, the Government understands that some businesses are considering whether to require vaccination as a condition of service or entry. Businesses do have the right to make any service they provide subject to conditions and can impose restrictions on who can enter their premises. However, anti-discrimination issues may arise where people are unable to be vaccinated, and privacy laws restrict the collection of sensitive information. In each case, businesses need to consider their legal obligations, and determine what is right for their business.
Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there are exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical reasons.

Before a prescription medicine (including a COVID-19 vaccine) can be legally supplied in Australia, it must be approved for use by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) and it will be subject to well-established and rigorous assessment and approval process of the TGA to determine if the benefits outweigh the risks.

The TGA is responsible for the ongoing monitoring of all vaccines approved for use in Australia and has robust procedures in place to investigate any potential new safety issues. The TGA's vaccine safety monitoring system can rapidly detect, investigate and respond to any emerging safety issues identified for COVID-19 vaccines.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

span.span: I refer to your correspondence of 18 Oc
tober 2021 concerning petition EN3352 requesting a ban on COVID
The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that

hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death. The Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Everyone maintains the option to choose.

pandemic is a public-health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. In line with this, some states and territories have now i

ssued public-health orders that require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Further information about public-health orders may be found on state or territory government websites.

p.span: Some employers have also started to mandate vaccinations for their employees. For individual businesses not covered by a public-health order, whether to require COVID-19 vaccinations for employees needs careful consideration, considering the relevant employment, discrimination, work health and safety, and privacy laws, and the circumstances of the workplace. The Government encourages employers and employees to work together on workplace vaccination for COVID-19.

In addition, the Government understands that some businesses are considering whether to require vaccination as a condition of service or entry. Businesses do have the right to make any service they provide subject to conditions and can impose restrictions on who can enter their premises. However, anti-discrimination issues may arise where people are unable to be vaccinated, and privacy laws restrict the collection of sensitive information. In each case, businesses need to consider their legal obligations, and determine what is right for their business.

Commonwealth agencies have made a wide range of guidance material available to clarify the legal framework around workplace vaccination and help businesses and workers make informed decisions about how to approach COVID-19 vaccination in the workplace.
This guidance is available at the following websites:
Fair Work Ombudsman—www.coronavirus.fairwork.gov.au
Safe Work Australia—www.safeworkaustralia.gov.au
Office of the Australian Information Commissioner—www.oaic.gov.au
Australian Human Rights Commission—www.humanrights.gov.au.

In line with the guidance provided by Safe Work Australia, the introduction of COVID-19 vaccines does not automatically mean businesses need to require workers to be vaccinated to meet their Work Health and Safety (WHS) duties. Vaccines are an important tool for managing the risk of COVID-19 but are just one part of keeping workplaces safe and healthy. To meet their duties under WHS laws, businesses must continue to apply all reasonably practicable control measures including:
ensuring workers do not come to work when unwell, even if they are vaccinated,
practising physical distancing and good hygiene, and
undertaking increased cleaning.
Further information about employers' WHS duties may be found on the Safe Work Australia website at:
www.safeworkaustralia.gov.au/covid-19-information-workplaces.

The Government encourages employers and workers to work together on workplace vaccination for COVID-19. Cooperation is critical and all businesses are encouraged, no matter what vaccination policy they are considering, to consult closely with their workers about how to manage the risk of COVID-19 in the workplace.

Where COVID-19 vaccination has been made mandatory, there are exemptions in place for people who are unable to be vaccinated for medical reasons. State and territories may also accept other categories of exemptions.

Australians can provide voluntary, proof-of-vaccination by accessing their immunisation history statement or the safe and secure COVID-19 Digital Certificate, through Medicare Online, via the Express Plus Medicare mobile app or via their My Health Record. People can also seek a hard copy of their immunisation history statement by contacting the Australian Immunisation enquiries line, or through their doctor or immunisation provider.

Before a prescription medicine (including a COVID-19 vaccine) can be legally supplied in Australia, it must be approved for use by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) and it will be subject to well-established and rigorous assessment and approval process of the TGA to determine if the benefits outweigh the risks.

The TGA is responsible for the ongoing monitoring of all vaccines approved for use in Australia and has robust procedures in place to investigate any potential new safety issues. The TGA's vaccine safety monitoring system can rapidly detect, investigate and respond to any emerging safety issues identified for COVID-19 vaccines.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID-19 Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at:
www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Law Enforcement
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 enclosing Petition EN3356 with 1712 signatures, concerning the Surveillance Legislation Amendment (Identify and Disrupt) Act 2021 (the Act).

The Act forms part of the Australian Government's response to the challenges posed by the increasing use of the dark web and anonymising technologies, which allows criminals, including terrorists and other malicious actors to hide from law enforcement. This has made committing serious crimes at volume and across borders easier than ever before.

The Act provides the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and the Australian Criminal Intelligence Commission (ACIC) with new powers to identify and disrupt serious criminal activities online. Data disruption warrants enable the AFP and the ACIC to frustrate the commission of serious offences online by modifying, adding or deleting data. Network activity warrants enable the AFP and ACIC to collect intelligence on serious criminal activity carried out by criminal networks online. Account takeover warrants allow the AFP and ACIC to take control of a person's online account to gather evidence about criminal activity.

Each of these warrants are issued by an independent issuing authority and must relate to an offence carrying a maximum penalty of imprisonment of three years or more. Before a warrant can be issued, the issuing authority must be satisfied that there are reasonable grounds founding the application for the warrant and have regard to certain matters, including the nature and gravity of the conduct constituting the offence, privacy and the impact on innocent third parties. The Government has no control over issuing authority decisions.

The powers are accompanied by strong safeguards which protect the privacy of Australians and ensures that the powers are used only where necessary, proportionate and reasonable. The Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security and the Commonwealth Ombudsman oversee the AFP and ACIC's use of these powers.

The operation, effectiveness and implications of these powers will be subject to review by the Independent National Security Legislation Monitor and the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security.

These new powers are highly targeted, only able to be obtained in relation to the investigation of serious criminal offences and only once an independent issuing authority is satisfied all relevant criteria are met. The strong safeguards that form part of these powers ensure they will be used appropriately.

The Government has designed these new laws very carefully to ensure the Act strikes the appropriate balance between respecting individual privacy and the rule of law on which our democracy is based, while still giving our Australian law enforcement agencies the vital powers they need to keep the community safe.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3356 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021, enclosing Petition EN3357 with 665 signatures, concerning easing of travel restrictions for fully vaccinated Australians to depart Australia.

Australia's current travel restriction policy has played a key foundational role underpinning management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia and were implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

You may be aware that on 26 October 2021, the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Greg Hunt MP, amended the Biosecurity Determination 2020 so that fully vaccinated Australian citizens and permanent residents would be exempt from Australia's travel restrictions for departing Australia.

As of 1 November 2021, the outwards travel exemption requirement has been lifted for fully vaccinated Australian citizens and permanent residents aged 12 and over. This means Australians can leave and enter Australia without restriction, subject to any local State or Territory health and quarantine requirements upon return.

International travel without needing to apply for an exemption is a 'vaccination advantage' for those Australian citizens and permanent residents who are fully vaccinated. The Department of Home Affairs' website provides guidance for travellers on the requirements prior to undertaking their travel. This information is available at:
https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-vaccinated-australians.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3357 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Parent Visas
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 enclosing Petition EN3366, with 13,271 signatures, concerning Family and Parent visas. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Family migration is an important element of Australia's migration system, allowing Australian citizens and permanent residents to reunite with their family members and contributing to stronger social cohesion outcomes.

It has been the long-standing practice of successive governments to manage the orderly delivery of Migration Program outcomes against planning levels. The Australian Government sets the size and composition of the Migration Program each year through the Government's Budget process following consultations with state and territory governments, business and community groups and the wider public.
On 15 November 2021, the Department of Home Affairs published a request for public submissions as part of the 2022-23 Migration Program planning process on its website at:
https://www.homeaffairs.gov.au/help-and-support/how-to-engage-us/consultations/australias-22-23-migration-program.
The period for submissions has now closed.

Following the public consultations, the permanent Migration Program is set with Australia's immediate and longer-term economic and social needs in mind. Immigration policy has enduring effects on many dimensions of Australian life. Getting the policy settings right is critical to maximising community wellbeing.

The relative merits of any policy needs to be assessed against a broader context that takes into account all the relevant dimensions of societal wellbeing, including issues around Parent visas which are complex because:

the economic outcomes of immigrant parents are typically poor. They tend to have low integration into the labour market largely due to their older ages and, in some cases, poorer than average English-language proficiency. This means lower income (and income tax) than other immigrants;
immigrant parents are at stages of their lives when they make considerable claims on the aged care, health and social security systems, which must be met through taxpayer funds; and

immigrant parents can make valuable social contributions to their families, but these mainly benefit the family members themselves rather than the broader social contributions made by other immigrants.

For example, the Contributory Parent visa charge of just under $50 000 meets only a fraction of the fiscal costs for the annual intake of contributory parent visa holders. As stated by the Productivity Commissioner in the Migrant Intake into Australia—Productivity Commission Inquiry Report Overview & Recommendations- No. 77, 13 April 2016, overall, the cumulated lifetime fiscal costs (in net present value terms) of a parent visa holder in 2015-16 is estimated to be between $335 000 and $410 000 per adult, which ultimately must be met by the Australian community.

The Productivity Commissioner found that reflecting their average older age and lower labour market engagement, the parent visa stream makes considerable demands on Australia's health, aged care and social security system, while not making many fiscal contributions through taxes paid. The contributory parent visa charge recognises the high expected net fiscal costs of parents. However, at its current level, it is only a small portion of these expected costs. Accordingly, most of the costs must be borne by the community as a whole, whereas many of the benefits accrue to the sponsors and the parents themselves.
Historically, Australia's permanent Migration Program has had a distribution of two-thirds Skill and one-third Family visas since 2005-06.

In 2020-21, in response to the impacts of COVID-19 pandemic, the proportion of the Family stream was expanded. The restriction on the number of places allocated Parent visas was designed to ensure that priority in the family stream category was given to partners and dependent child applicants. This aligned with the current Australian Government's policy intentions during the pandemic, the need to give priority to certain applications, and to manage the size and composition of the Migration Program.

On 11 May 2021, the Government announced as part of the Budget, that the overall Migration Program settings would continue into 2021-22. This maintains an expanded Family stream, with priority in the Family stream category given to immediate family members who are partner and dependent child applicants. Further, the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on visa applicants is being continually monitored, and visa settings reviewed to respond to the global challenges posed by COVID-19.

In the 2021-22 Migration Program year, there are 4,500 Parent visa places available, being 900 places for Parent & Aged Parent visas and 3,600 places for Contributory Parent visas. Once this number is reached, no more visas will be granted in the migration program year.

Outside the Migration Program, there are 15,000 places each financial year for parents of Australian citizens, Australian permanent residents and eligible New Zealand citizens to apply for the Sponsored Parent (Temporary) visa, which allows parents to reunite with their children temporarily for up to 3 or 5 years in Australia.

In the interest of equity for visa applicants who apply for a Parent visa in the Migration Program, all visa applications are assessed in lodgement date order. If the visa application meets the initial visa criteria, the visa application is placed in a queue. Visa applications are released from the queue for finalisation in queue date order. There are no provisions to consider compelling and compassionate reasons to expedite one Parent visa application over another as it may disadvantage other applicants who may be in similar or more compelling circumstances.

Processing times for Parent visas are impacted by a range of factors, including the number of places the Government allocates to a program each year, and the level of demand for each visa category. High volumes of Parent visa application lodgements, which for a number of years exceeded annual migration planning levels set by successive Governments, have impacted on processing times.

Additionally, the COVID-19 pandemic has significantly affected the availability of key assessment services (such as medical checks). This has impacted applicants' ability to meet visa criteria, and disrupted the Department's visa processing services. This has had the flow on effect of increasing processing times.

The time taken to process visa applications can also vary according to the individual circumstances of each case. The quality and completeness of applications, applicants' responsiveness to requests for information, and the complexity often involved in assessing 'genuineness of relationship', character, health and security requirements, can influence processing times.

The Australian Government appreciates that the limited number of places for these visas each year may be disappointing for some members of the community. Ultimately, the Migration program must strike the right balance between sustainable family reunion and maximising Australia's longer term economic growth and prosperity.

Your representation and the concerns raised will be taken into account as future policy settings on this issue are considered as previously outlined above. However, increasing the number of places for Parent visa may have significant cost implications and would need to be considered by the Government in the context of budget decisions and the current economic climate.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3366 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning the petition to require the Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency (Ahpra) to direct that all Australian health professionals be able to provide uncensored advice about other possible ways of treating COVID-19.

Ahpra is not an Australian Government agency. Ahpra is an independent body established under state and territory legislation. Ahpra works in partnership with 15 National Boards to regulate 16 health professions in Australia and is responsible for implementing the National Registration and Accreditation Scheme (Scheme). The Scheme's primary objective is to ensure the safety of the public. Neither I nor my Department have the authority to direct Ahpra and/or National Board in their roles.

The COVID-19 vaccinations are safe and effective and are a crucial part of the public health response to the pandemic. The Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI) published 'Clinical guidance on the use of the COVID-19 vaccines in Australia' (Guidance). The Guidance states the goal of the COVID-19 vaccination program is to protect all Australians from the harm caused by COVID-19.

All health practitioners in Australia must adhere to a code of conduct for their profession. The codes require all health practitioners to provide sound, evidence-based advice to patients about all treatments, including the COVID-19 vaccination. This means discussing both the risks and benefits.

The codes also require practitioners to ensure their personal views do not adversely affect the care of their patient or the referrals they make. Under the codes, practitioners who conscientiously object to providing a treatment are obligated to inform their patients and, if relevant, colleagues of their objection. Additionally, practitioners must not let their objections prevent the patient from seeking treatment from another practitioner.

Publicly sharing anti-vaccination statements or health advice that contradicts the best available evidence is not supported by the National Boards and may be a breach of the codes. It is important to note all notifications regarding health practitioner conduct, including reports of anti-vaccination statements, are thoroughly and fairly investigated by Ahpra and action only taken if there is a risk to public safety.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN3375)
COVID-19
Dear Chair

The Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation published 'Clinical guidance on the use of the COVID-19 vaccines in Australia' (Guidance). The Guidance states the goal of the COVID-19 vaccination program is to protect all Australians from the harm caused by COVID-19.

All health practitioners in Australia must adhere to a Code of conduct (Code) for their profession. The Code requires all health practitioners to provide sound, evidence-based advice to patients about all treatments, including the COVID-19 vaccination. This means discussing both the risks and benefits.

The Code also requires practitioners to ensure their personal views do not adversely affect the care of their patient or the referrals they make. Under the Code, practitioners who conscientiously object to providing a treatment are obligated to inform their patients and, if relevant, colleagues of their objection. Additionally, practitioners must not let their objections prevent the patient from seeking treatment from another practitioner.

Publicly sharing anti-vaccination statements or health advice that contradicts the best available scientific evidence is not supported by the National Boards and may be a breach of the Code.
