Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Higher Education
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 to the Treasurer, the Hon Josh Frydenberg MP, regarding Petition EN3384 on the removal of HECS debts. As the acting Minister for Education and Youth, your correspondence has been provided to me for response.

The Australian Government supports access and participation in higher education through a number of programs including the Higher Education Loan Program (HELP) and through the provision of Commonwealth supported places. The HELP scheme is an income contingent loan scheme that removes upfront barriers to education and is one of the most generous schemes in the world. It is reasonable for the Government to require students, who benefit from deferring their higher education tuition costs through HELP, to repay those costs. Outstanding HELP debt as at 30 June 2021 was reported at $68.7 million, repayment of which is necessary to ensure the sustainability of the scheme.

As HELP debt is income contingent, debtors are only required to make repayments if and when they can afford to do so. Repayment rates for income thresholds increase in scale, so that repayment is less for lower incomes. HELP debtors experiencing financial hardship can apply to the Australian Taxation Office for a deferral or amendment of compulsory repayments.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Education and Youth, Mr Robert
Australian Broadcasting Corporation
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 11 November 2021 concerning petition number EN3396, regarding the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC)'s coverage of the Biloela family case.

I have certainly been left in no doubt that the petitioners regard the ABC's coverage of the Biloela family case as lacking in journalistic impartiality and balance. It is very important that the broadcaster's news and current affairs coverage meets the standards which Parliament, on behalf of all Australians, requires of it.
Even though the Morrison Government provides an overall level of funding to the ABC, the broadcaster has content and editorial independence.
Parliament has guaranteed this independence so the broadcaster's decisions are free from political interference.
Under this arrangement, the manner in which the ABC presents its programming is a matter for the ABC Board and executive.

Although editorially independent, the ABC Board is required to develop a Code of Practice relating to programming matters and to lodge this code with the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA).
In addition, the broadcaster is accountable to the Parliament through annual reports, corporate plans, financial and performance audits, and appearances before Parliamentary Committees.
I continue to maintain regular contact with the ABC Board to encourage them to maintain the broadcaster's adherence to its Charter, so it can provide useful and informative services.

I encourage concerned members of the public to actively engage with the ABC. Direct contact is the best way to guarantee that the ABC is made aware of the public's concerns and is given the opportunity to respond.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 enclosing petition EN3418 with 6 signatures, concerning the re-opening of Australia's international border, international safe travel zones, and quarantine requirements.

In accordance with the National Plan to Transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response (National Transition Plan), Australia is reopening its international border in a phased and careful way. Fully vaccinated Australians, permanent residents and their families have been able to return home since 1 November 2021, and on 21 November 2021, Australia welcomed back fully vaccinated Singaporean travelers.

From 15 December 2021, fully vaccinated eligible visa holders, including international students, skilled migrants, and refugee, humanitarian, temporary and provisional family visa cohorts have been able to travel to Australia without a travel exemption.

Australia also reopened its borders to travel by fully vaccinated citizens of Japan and the Republic of Korea from 15 December 2021. This step-by-step and safe reopening is a result of the success Australia, and Australians, have achieved through the vaccination rollout and in implementing the National Transition Plan.

Quarantine arrangements including the type and duration, are a matter for the states and territories in accordance with the National Transition Plan. Quarantine-free arrangements for fully vaccinated travelers, including Australian citizens and permanent residents returning to Australia from overseas, have been introduced in some states and territories. All states and territories now either have reduced or modified quarantine arrangements in place for fully vaccinated travellers, or plans to introduce them once vaccination targets are met.

Travellers who are not eligible for vaccination (such as those under 12 years of age), or who are unable to be vaccinated on medical grounds, can also access modified quarantine arrangements with appropriate evidence. Arrangements are also in place to support the travel of unvaccinated and partially vaccinated 12-17 year olds.

All international travellers are required to follow and comply with quarantine and COVID-19 testing arrangements of the state they enter. People who are wishing to travel onwards to another state or territory may also be subject to a quarantine period or may not be allowed to enter. Information on all of these arrangements is available on the respective state or territory health website.
Thank you for bringing petition EN3418 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Video Game Industry
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter of 22 November 2021, on behalf of 12 signatories, concerning Petition EN3421—Legislate Regulations to Restrict Use of Exploitative Practices. I acknowledge the concerns raised about the impact of loot boxes in games and the interest shown in the Morrison Government taking steps to prevent harm to children and vulnerable people.

Appropriate classification of computer games helps Australians to make informed choices about what games they or their children watch and play. The National Classification Scheme requires that computer games are classified before they are sold or published in Australia. The Scheme is a cooperative arrangement between the Australian Government (the Commonwealth) and state and territory governments.

Computer games are classified by the Classification Board (the Board) or the International Age Rating Coalition (IARC) tool (for online and mobile games in participating storefronts including the Google Play, Microsoft and Nintendo stores). Content in computer games is classified according to standards in the National Classification Code and the Guidelines for the Classification of Computer Games (the Guidelines).

The Classification Board applies consumer advice of 'in-game purchases' where the Board considers that a computer or video game contains the ability to use real-world money to purchase downloadable content including randomised items found in loot boxes.
More information, including the Board's decisions, can be found on the Australian classification website:
www.classification.gov.au.

In December 2019, the Government appointed Mr Neville Stevens AO as the independent expert to lead a review of Australian classification regulation. The review included consideration of the classification of games with loot boxes.
Mr Stevens provided his report to the Government at the end of May 2020 and the Government is considering the report and its response. Public submissions to the review can be viewed at
www.communications.gov.au/have-your-say/review-australian-classification-regulation.

Under the National Classification Scheme, any changes to the National Classification Code or the classification guidelines as to how video games which feature loot boxes or simulated gambling should be classified will require agreement by the Australian Government as well as the states and territories.
The Online Safety Bill 2021 comes into effect on 23 January 2022. This new legislation includes measures to:
implement practical measures to protect Australians against exposure to illegal and harmful online content;
articulate clear Basic Online Safety Expectations of online service providers as to their responsibilities to keep Australians safe online; and
provide a safety net for users where online service providers fail to meet their obligations under the Act.
The Bill requires online safety providers to make updated industry codes so that customers are provided with technological solutions to help limit their access to harmful online content.

The Interactive Gambling Act 2001 (the IGA) makes it illegal for gambling providers to offer some online services to people in Australia. Prohibited services include online casino-style gaming services of chance or mixed skill and chance, such as online poker and slot machines, which are played for money or anything else of value.

The IGA does not capture computer games as they are considered a game of skill, though there may be some chance element in the game. In general, loot boxes and similar items are not considered to be interactive gambling services under the IGA. The IGA, however, does capture third party websites that allow players to gamble on virtual items on casino-style games where the virtual items can be exchanged for money or anything else of value.

The Government has continued to monitor industry developments around loot boxes. Many online app and game storefronts (e.g. Apple App store, Google Play store) advise at the point of sale if a game includes in-game purchases. Both the Google Play store and the Apple App store also require games apps to disclose the odds of receiving items in loot boxes since December 2017.

The major game console makers, Sony, Microsoft and Nintendo, have committed to policies that will require paid loot boxes in games developed for their platforms to disclose information on the relative probability of obtaining randomised virtual items.

Parental controls are available on most devices including computers, tablets, smartphones and gaming consoles. These tools help parents and carers monitor and limit what children do online including allowing parents to control financial purchases made by their children and setting limits on the length of time spent on particular sites, including games and social media. Tool settings can be changed to reflect a child's age and skills.

The Office of the eSafety Commissioner offers information and advice regarding online gaming and gambling risks for children. Further information, including information on parental controls, can be found at www.esafety.gov.au.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission website also includes specific guidance on preventing unauthorised in-app purchases on mobile apps, which includes children using their parent's device to make an in-app purchase.
Thank you for bringing these concerns to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Human Rights
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 22 November 2021 regarding Petition Ministerial Referral (EN3428).

All Bills and disallowable legislative instruments must be accompanied by a Statement of Compatibility with Human Rights. A Statement of Compatibility is an assessment of whether the Bill or legislative instrument is compatible with the rights and freedoms recognised in the seven core international human rights treaties to which Australia is a party. The main function of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights is to examine all Bills and legislative instruments for compatibility with human rights, and to report to both Houses of Parliament on its findings.
Complaints regarding potential breaches of human rights by the Commonwealth can be made to the Australian Human Rights Commission.

The Government considers that existing mechanisms to protect and promote human rights are appropriate. On this basis, the Government does not propose to introduce a charter or bill of rights at the federal level. Nor does the Government propose to subject the Biosecurity Act 2015 to additional human rights assessment, allow appeals to the Privy Council or require additional human rights training for Members of Parliament and Ministers.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition EN3436, to expedite the introduction of VALNEVA vaccine as a safe alternative.
The Australian Government is committed to providing all Australians, who wish to be vaccinated, with access to safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines.

The Government has invested in a diverse portfolio of COVID-19 vaccines that use a variety of technical platforms, entering into five separate Advance Purchase Agreements (APA) for the supply of COVID-19 vaccines. These include agreements with Pfizer, AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria), Novavax, Moderna and the international COVAX Facility.

Combined, these agreements will ensure Australia has access to more than 280 million vaccine doses. Given Australia's participation in COVAX and APAs already in place, the Government is in the process of evaluating its capacity and need for any further APAs.

The Government continues to meet regularly with a range of COVID-19 vaccine and treatment developers and manufacturers, including Valneva, and continues to monitor ongoing clinical trials and review real world effectiveness of vaccine rollouts, globally. The nature of these discussions is commercial-in-confidence but considers the likely timing of supply, cost and recommendations from Government medical experts.

All vaccines must pass the Therapeutic Goods Administration's (TGA) rigorous assessment and approval processes including clinical trials. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and/or disease. The TGA requires robust scientific data before supporting a vaccine candidate and will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is found to be safe and effective.

Valneva's COVID-19 vaccine candidate commenced Phase 3 clinical trials on 21 April 2021. At this time, Valneva has not yet submitted an application for a provisional determination, therefore Valneva is not currently under evaluation by the TGA. More information on the COVID-19 vaccine application and approval process can be found on the TGA website at:
www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccine-approval-process.

It is important for Australians to have access to credible and timely information about COVID-19 vaccines. It is a large and complex project, and the information you are seeking may change over time. I strongly encourage you to stay up-to-date on all news and announcements, by regularly checking my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Mental Health
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 enclosing Petition EN3447 concerning Medicare access for mental health services provided by counsellors, psychiatrists and other therapists.

I appreciate you presenting a petition on this important issue. The Australian Government is committed to mental health reform and is working to ensure all Australians have access to a world-class mental health system supported by a highly trained and qualified workforce.

Importantly, the Government's $2.3 billion investment in the National Mental Health and Suicide Prevention Plan in the 2021-22 Budget includes $58.8 million to grow and upskill the mental health workforce: The Government is also progressing a National Mental Health Workforce Strategy that will consider the quality, supply, distribution and structure of the mental health workforce; and will identify practical approaches governments could implement to attract, train and retain the workforce required to meet patient demand.

On 30 November 2020, the Government announced $2 million to undertake a comprehensive evaluation of the Better Access to Psychiatrists, Psychologists and General Practitioners through the Medicare Benefits Schedule initiative (Better Access) in line with the Productivity Commission's recommendation. The evaluation, due for completion in 2022, provides an opportunity to consider the workforce needed to deliver Better Access services and how the Government can reduce barriers to access while maintaining quality of care for patients.

The evaluation is supported by a Clinical Advisory Group comprising clinical and other experts and a Stakeholder Engagement Group (SEG) including representation from relevant professional bodies, carers and people with lived experience of mental illness. The SEG includes representatives from a broad range of professional groups including counselling, psychiatry and other therapists. The evaluation findings will help guide future arrangements under the initiative. Further information is available at: www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/better-access-evaluation.

People experiencing financial barriers to accessing mental health support can speak to their referring practitioner about accessing psychological therapy programs offered by Primary Health Networks (PHN). The Government funds PHNs to commission services based on regional need, including low and no cost options where appropriate. Contact details for PHNs are available at: www.health.gov.au/phn for people that might benefit from this option.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN3458 Administer inactivated COVID-19 vaccine options already recognised in Australia.

The Australian Government wants everyone in Australia to have access to a safe, free, COVID-19 vaccine, if they choose to be vaccinated. Moreover, the safety of the population has always been the highest priority of the Government. For these reasons, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation.

The Government receives advice on matters relating to COVID-19 vaccines from medical experts, including the COVID-19 Vaccines and Treatments for Australia—Science and Industry Technical Advisory Group (SITAG), the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation and the Advisory Committee on Vaccines.

These expert groups continue to provide clear advice to Government based on the latest scientific evidence and data. Future investments will be subject to the advice of SITAG, and assessment of clinical evidence, including portfolio diversification and risk. SITAG will continue to provide advice to inform the rollout of COVID-19 vaccines in Australia based on the most current data and epidemiology.

All vaccines must pass the Therapeutic Goods Administration's (TGA) rigorous assessment and approval processes including clinical trials. Technical experts analyse the three phases of clinical trials to test for safety at every phase, as well as how effective the vaccine is at protecting against infection and disease. The TGA requires robust scientific data before supporting a vaccine candidate and will only register and approve a COVID-19 vaccine if it is found to be safe and effective.

There are no inactivated or live attenuated vaccines for COVID-19 approved by the TGA. All vaccines approved for use in Australia meet the strict standards of the TGA to ensure safety and effectiveness. This means every COVID-19 vaccine available in Australia has been proven to protect against COVID-19. The TGA has provisionally approved four vaccines, so far:
Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine, called Comirnaty, for people aged five years and older
Oxford University AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria) vaccine, for people aged 18 years and older
Janssen vaccine of Janssen-Cilag Pty Ltd, known as Johnson & Johnson, for people aged 18 years or older
Moderna Australia vaccine, called Spikevax (elasomeran) for people aged 12 years and older.
While approved by the TGA, the Janssen vaccine is not included in Australia's COVID-19 vaccination program.

The TGA has determined that these vaccines meet the safety, efficacy and quality standards required for use in Australia. The TGA also approved the manufacture of the AstraZeneca vaccine in Australia. The Vaxzevria vaccine doses used in the initial stages of the rollout were manufactured overseas.

The TGA has also 'recognised' Coronavac (Sinovac) and Covishield (Vaxzevria/Serum Institute of India) for the purposes of international travel. These vaccines haven't been approved for use in Australia, but people travelling from overseas who have had these vaccines will have their vaccination status recognised in Australia.
The Government has entered into two other agreements to secure vaccines with:

The biotechnology company Novavax, this vaccine has been given provisional determination by the TGA, and if granted provisional approval, it is anticipated that 51 million doses will be available in Australia.

The COVAX facility, this is a global initiative that will provide access to COVID-19 vaccines when they become available. If approved, it is anticipated that 25 million doses will be available to the Australian population.

The TGA is part of a network of international regulators that meet regularly to discuss the development of COVID-19 vaccines. This information, together with the potential to use already established work-sharing arrangements and collaboration with other international regulators, is assisting the TGA to expedite the evaluation of any new vaccines without compromising on strict standards of safety, quality, and effectiveness.

The Government also continues to meet regularly with a range of COVID-19 vaccine and treatment developers and manufacturers and continues to monitor ongoing clinical trials and review real-world effectiveness of vaccine rollouts globally. There are more than 400 trials for 140 vaccine candidates worldwide, including a number that are trialling the use of needle-free technology. These include nasal sprays, oral tablets, skin patches and jet injectors.

The rollout and distribution of COVID-19 vaccines will occur in line with the Operation COVID Shield National COVID Vaccine Campaign Plan. For specific information on the COVID-19 vaccine rollout, please visit my Department's website at:
www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/operation-covid-shield.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Russia
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter of 22 November 2021 regarding Petition EN3459 that criticises the conduct of Russian parliamentary (Duma) elections held in September 2021. I welcome hearing the views of the Russian-Australian community.

I am concerned by independent and reliable reports of serious incidents of election fraud during these elections. The Government is also concerned by the Russian Government's measures to exclude potential opponents from the political process, undermine civil society and independent media scrutiny, and place limits on election monitoring. On 17 September, Australia's Ambassador to Russia publicly stressed the importance of independent observers in guaranteeing the transparency of elections.

Australia condemns the mounting repression of opposition politicians and civil society groups in Russia. I issued statements early in 2021 criticising the arrest of opposition figure Alexei Navalny and advocating for an investigation into his poisoning in August 2020. We are also pursuing answers on Navalny's poisoning via the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons. On 15 November, Australia's Ambassador to Russia expressed our concerns over efforts to close the long-standing Russian human rights organisation Memorial. DFAT has also raised Australia's concerns on human rights matters directly with Russian officials.
I trust that this information is useful to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Immigration Detention
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 enclosing Petition number EN3460, concerning facilities at the Melbourne Immigration Transit Accommodation.

The Department of Home Affairs and the Australian Border Force (ABF) works closely with service providers to ensure all detainees are safe and treated in accordance with human rights standards. The Australian Government has contracted appropriately trained and experienced service providers to ensure detainees' needs are adequately met, including provision of health and welfare services.

The Department and the ABF invests a significant amount of resources to provide high quality facilities, amenities, a broad range of services (including telephone and computer systems), and activities to ensure safety and security within the centres.

The Department provides computer and internet access to detainees. This access allows detainees to perform functions such as word processing, spreadsheets, internet browsing and access to detainee personal email accounts.

Internet is also provided for the purpose of detainees accessing their legal representatives, and to access humanitarian observatory bodies. Access is provided free of charge to detainees. Additionally, while in immigration detention, detainees have the ability to use personal devices in which they can access the internet.

The Department is aware of the issues detainees are experiencing, and have identified a solution to rectify the situation. Service providers are implementing the solution to alleviate the performance issues noted, and will continue to engage with detainees to ensure the performance of computers delivers a suitable end user experience.

All detainees are able to lodge a complaint or provide feedback on any aspect of their immigration detention without hindrance or fear of reprisal. The Facilities and Detainee Service Provider has a complaints management system in place to manage complaints from detainees. Any detainee who is not competent in the English language is entitled to interpreter services for all formal correspondence, which includes complaints.
Detainees are encouraged to contact the Global Feedback Unit within the Department at the following website:
https://www.homeaffairs.gov.au/feedback.

Providing feedback this way ensures that feedback and/or concerns are actioned appropriately, including formal registration, acknowledgment and allocation to the responsible business area for actioning if required.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3460 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Dental Health
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition number EN3461 to the House of Representatives, requesting the bulk billing of dental services under Medicare.

The Australian Government understands the importance of good oral health and its role in supporting general health and wellbeing. States and territories have primary responsibility for public dental services—including, funding, management of waiting lists and determining the scope and availability of services.

Dental treatment was not included under Medicare at its commencement and this policy has largely been continued by successive governments since inception. The Government's policy is to continue to support targeted dental services, rather than include dental care under Medicare.

The Government supports states and territories to provide adult public dental services. Between 1 January 2017 and 30 June 2021, the National Partnership Agreement (NPA) on Public Dental Services for Adults provided $458.1 million in funding and supported services to around 763,000 public dental patients.

In the 2021-22 Budget, the Australian Government announced $107.8 million to extend support for adult public services through a Federation Funding Agreement (FFA) until 30 June 2022. The FFA will provide services to an additional 180,000 public dental patients while the Government and state and territory governments negotiate on options for longer term funding arrangements.

The Government also supports the provision of dental services for children through the Child Dental Benefits Schedule (CDBS). Since its commencement on 1 January 2014, the CDBS has provided over $2.4 billion in benefits and delivered over 39 million services to more than three million children.

Through the National Health Reform Agreement, the Government contributes funds to the states and territories for dental services delivered through public hospitals. This includes services provided through emergency departments, hospitals, and community health settings. Between 2017-18 and 2019-20 the Government provided approximately $541 million in funding for these services.

The Government also supports access to private sector dental services through the Private Health Insurance (PHI) rebate. In the 2021-22 Budget, $6.7 billion ($27.8 billion between 2021-22 and 2024-25) was committed for the PHI rebate to make private health insurance more affordable. In 2018-19, $718 million was provided to support dental services through the PHI Rebate.
More detail on Government funding for dental services is provided in the table below.

Budget 2021-22, Budget Paper No. 2, Specific measures, pg110

p.span: Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 enclosing petition EN3463 with 16,808 signatures, concerning temporary visa holders currently living in Australia being able to return to Australia without the need to seek an exemption, when the international border opens during Phase C of the National Plan to Transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response (the National Plan).

In accordance with the National Plan, Australia is reopening its international border in a staged and careful way. Fully vaccinated Australians, permanent residents and their families have been able to leave Australia and return home exemption-free since 1 November 2021, and on 21 November 2021, Australia welcomed back fully vaccinated Singaporean citizens.

From 15 December 2021, fully vaccinated eligible visa holders have been able to come to Australia outside of arrivals caps, without needing to apply for a travel exemption. Eligible visa holders include skilled and student cohorts, working holiday makers, as well as refugee, humanitarian and temporary and provisional family visa holders. In addition, eligible temporary visa holders currently in Australia are able to leave Australia and return without applying for a travel exemption.

Australia also reopened its borders to exemption-free travel by fully vaccinated citizens of Japan and the Republic of Korea from 15 December 2021. More information will be provided on how Australia will reopen to visitors and tourists at the appropriate time.

People currently in Australia intending to travel overseas and return, and other travellers to Australia are strongly encouraged to check the specific health and quarantine requirements relating to the state or territory to which they are planning to return.
Thank you for bringing petition EN3463 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition number EN3468 asking the House to consider implementing restrictions on financial benefits for unvaccinated individuals.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death.

At the same time, the Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia. Although we encourage and aim to have as many Australians vaccinated as possible.

Medicare is Australia's universal health insurance scheme. It guarantees all Australians (and some overseas visitors) access to a wide range of health and hospital services at low or no cost. This access is regardless of their vaccine status and the Government is not considering changes to this arrangement.

While the Government is responsible for setting Medicare Benefits Schedule fees and rebates, general practices are private businesses and GPs are free to determine the services that they provide to patients and to set the value of the fees that they charge for those services. GPs are also free to set their own policies concerning patient bookings and are not legally obliged to accept every patient who seeks a booking.

The Government has made it mandatory for those working in residential aged care to receive a COVID-19 vaccination, which was advised by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee and accepted by National Cabinet. This is enforced through state and territory public health orders, effective 17 September 2021.
The Government is not considering making the COVID-19 vaccine mandatory in other sectors at this time, including for healthcare workers.
Thank you for writing on this matter
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Housing Affordability
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 29 November 2021 (EN3502), concerning increasing Commonwealth Rent Assistance (CRA) for National Rental Affordability Scheme (NRAS) tenants.
The Australian Government understands housing is fundamental to the welfare of all Australians. Access to secure and affordable housing has significant economic and social benefits.

While state and territory governments (states) are responsible for the provision of day-to-day housing and homelessness services, in 2021-22 the Australian Government expects to spend around $9.3 billion to help improve housing and homelessness outcomes. This includes $1.6 billion through the National Housing and Homelessness Agreement (NHHA) to states.

Under the NHHA, states are responsible for determining priorities and the type and locations of services funded. States also make decisions about social housing, including the building. allocation, refurbishment of dwellings, complaints and all other tenancy matters. They are also responsible for private rental market regulation.

CRA is a non-taxable income supplement payable with income support payments, Family Tax Benefit Part A. and veterans service pensions or income support supplements, to eligible Australian individuals and families renting in the private rental market and community housing.
In 2021-22, the Australian Government expects to spend $5.3 billion on CRA, to assist around 1.5 million eligible individuals and families with the cost of their rent.

CRA is adjusted each year in March and September, in line with Consumer Price Index (CPI) increases. It is important to note CPI increases reflect an average rise in the cost of living and may not reflect an individual's circumstances. CRA is not intended to reimburse recipients for the full cost of their private rent.
In 2021-22, the Australian Government will provide around $250 million for NRAS.

At the conclusion of the 10-year incentive period for these dwellings, ongoing tenancy arrangements are a matter to be discussed between tenants, tenancy managers, approved participants and the investors who own the properties. The dwellings will remain subject to all relevant state government tenancy and landlord laws, with respect to lease agreements and rental increases. CRA will still be available for eligible tenants.
The department recommends tenants contact their state or territory housing authority for information on potential housing options and other relevant services available.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
Waste Management and Recycling
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition EN3503 to stop the banning of plastic products.

The Australian Government is strongly committed to reducing waste, increasing recycling rates and building capacity in Australia's recycling industry. Marine plastic debris, which is largely comprised of land-sourced plastics, poses a significant transboundary risk to marine ecosystems, wildlife and our communities. That is why the government is taking unprecedented action to manage plastic pollution.

The government is working with states and territories to implement the National Waste Policy Action Plan 2019 (the Plan), which sets out the policy direction for priority actions on waste management and recycling in Australia to 2030. Under the Plan, the Commonwealth, along with state and territory environment ministers, have committed to phasing out eight types of problematic plastic products through sustainable design, innovation or the introduction of sustainable alternatives by 2025, or sooner in some cases. These include lightweight plastic bags, plastic products misleadingly termed as 'degradable', plastic straws, plastic bowls and plates, and plastic utensils and stirrers. In addition, the government launched the nation's first National Plastics Plan, which outlines that taking responsibility for our waste will, in some instances, mean phasing out problematic and unnecessary single-use plastics.

State and territory governments are responsible for legislating the phase-out of problematic and unnecessary single use plastics. The government strongly supports jurisdictions to grow our recycling capabilities and to reduce litter and other waste to reduce their environmental impact. The parties who have submitted the petition may wish to contact their state or territory government representatives with their concerns.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Waste Reduction and Environmental Management, Mr Evans
Animal Welfare
Dear Mr O'Dowd

1 refer to your correspondence of 29 November 2021 on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions concerning the request to end animal testing for all chemicals in Australia (Petition number: EN3507).

The Industrial Chemicals Act 2019 implements the legislative component of the Australian Government's ban on cosmetic testing on animals. Through this legislation, animal testing for new cosmetic ingredients was banned in Australia on 1 July 2020. This means new ingredients used exclusively in cosmetics that are sold or manufactured in Australia are unable to use data from animal testing to prove safety.

Australia's ban on the use of animal test data for cosmetics aligns with the European Union's approach to ensure the ongoing protection of public health and the environment, worker safety, as well as minimal impacts on business.

To complement the ban, my Department worked with the National Health and Medical Research Council to ban the use of animals in cosmetic testing through an amendment to the Australian Code for the Care and Use of Animals for Scientific Purposes (Code) and is available at:
www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/ban-cosmetic-testing-animals.
The Code is adopted under state and territory legislation, providing a framework for ethical and responsible care and use of animals for scientific purposes in Australia.

My Department also partnered with Accord Australasia, the peak national association representing the cosmetics industry, and animal welfare groups, predominantly RSPCA Australia, to develop a Voluntary Industry Code of Practice (Industry Code) to support the ban. The Industry Code provides guidance to the industry in relation to appropriate promotional claims about animal testing on cosmetic products and provides consumers with greater clarity around the definitions of animal testing claims on cosmetic products. The Industry Code is available on the Accord Australasia website at:
www.accord.asn.au/sustainability/voluntary-industry-code-on-animal-test-ban.

In line with the Government's commitment around cosmetic testing, chemicals that have a 'multiuse' are excluded from the ban. Expanding the scope of the ban could lead to broader risks to human health or environmental safety and would be inconsistent with other bans internationally. Non-cosmetic end uses of industrial chemicals can pose higher risks and by their nature can expose workers to relatively high chemical concentrations. Therefore, more comprehensive risk assessments are needed to protect human health and the environment.
However, you may be interested to note that it is estimated that less than one per cent of 'multiuse' cosmetic ingredients used animal test data to support their introduction into Australia.

I am also pleased to advise that the ban encourages the use of alternatives to animal test data for industrial chemicals (including cosmetics). The Government remains committed to further exploring the opportunities presented by these alternate approaches to demonstrate the safety of these chemicals for both humans and the environment.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Naloxone
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 29 November 2021 concerning petition number: EN3513 to increase access to naloxone.
The Australian Government is committed to supporting initiatives to reduce and prevent harms caused by drugs and is investing in a pilot program to improve access to naloxone.

Under the Take Home Naloxone Pilot (pilot) which commenced 1 December 2019 and will run through to 30 June 2022, naloxone is available free-of-charge and without a prescription in New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australia to anyone who may either experience or witness an opioid overdose or adverse reaction. People are able to access naloxone from a variety of places, which may include the local pharmacy but also alcohol and drug centres and needle and syringe programs. The program aims to assist both illicit and prescription opioid users in these states (and their carers, friends and family members) by reducing barriers to access this life saving medicine.

The pilot has been evaluated by the University of Queensland with the final evaluation report currently being considered by my Department. Results from the pilot are encouraging and have found that the pilot has saved the lives of people who had overdosed on or had an adverse reaction to opioid drugs.

You will also be pleased to know that access to naloxone has been greatly improved with the Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme (PBS) listing on 1 November 2019 of the Nyxoid® nasal spray. This formulation is simple and easy to use and has been the most commonly supplied product under the pilot.

Naloxone ampoules, pre-filled syringes and the nasal spray continue to be available on the PBS in all states and territories as a General Schedule unrestricted PBS benefit. This means medical and nurse practitioners can prescribe naloxone to users of opioids, their carers, friends and family members. When accessed through the PBS a patient who has a prescription for naloxone will pay a maximum co-payment of $41.30 per script (providing five ampoules, or one pre-filled syringe or two nasal sprays), or $6.60 if they have a concession card.
The PBS co-payment will count towards the patient's PBS safety-net. Individuals can also purchase naloxone privately over the counter at their local pharmacy if they choose.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Health Care
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 29 November 2021 concerning Petition Number EN3515—a perceived political influence over medical professionals in their professional practice, specifically referring to influence and intervention by Australian Health Practitioner Regulation Agency (Ahpra) and the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA).

In Australia, health practitioners are regulated by Ahpra. Ahpra is not an Australian Government agency but rather an independent body established under state and territory legislation. Ahpra works in partnership with 15 National Boards to regulate 16 health professions in Australia and is responsible for implementing the National Registration and Accreditation Scheme (Scheme). Neither I nor my Department have the authority to direct Ahpra and/or National Boards in their roles.

The Scheme's primary objective is to ensure the safety of the public. All health practitioners in Australia must adhere to a Code of conduct (Code) for their profession. The Code requires all health practitioners to provide sound, evidence-based advice to patients about all treatments. This means discussing both the risks and benefits.

The Code also requires practitioners to ensure their personal views do not adversely affect the care of their patient or the referrals they make. Under the Code, practitioners who conscientiously object to providing a treatment are obligated to inform their patients and, if relevant, colleagues of their objection. Additionally, practitioners must not let their objections prevent the patient from seeking treatment from another practitioner.

While the petition does not specifically refer to the COVID-19 vaccination program, references to 'treatment for the masses' and criticism of the 'Government narrative' and 'Government agenda' in the petition appear to carry this inference, and warrant being addressed.

The COVID-19 vaccinations are safe and effective and are a crucial part of the public health response to the pandemic. The TGA is responsible for the assessment and regulation of therapeutic goods. The TGA ensures that all therapeutic goods available in Australia are safe and fit for their intended purpose. They do not provide clinical advice concerning medicines, health products or treatments such as vaccines.
The Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI) published 'Clinical guidance on the use of the COVID-19 vaccines in Australia' (Guidance).
The Guidance states the goal of the COVID-19 vaccination program is to protect all Australians from the harm caused by COVID-19.

Publicly sharing anti-vaccination statements or health advice that contradicts the best available scientific evidence, is not supported by the National Boards and may be a breach of the Code. It is important to note all notifications concerning health practitioner conduct, including reports of anti-vaccination statements, are thoroughly and fairly investigated by Ahpra and action only taken if there is a risk to public safety.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Autism
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 29 November 2021 concerning petition EN3528—request to extend the Helping Children with Autism Scheme eligibility ages up to 25 years of age.

The Australian Government is committed to funding medical services which are proven to be clinically effective, safe and cost effective, and continuously improving items on the Medical Benefits Scheme (MBS) to reflect best clinical practice. This ensures that all Australians are able to access timely and affordable, high quality healthcare.

I am pleased to advise that following advice from the MBS Review Taskforce, the Government has recently announced measures to improve access to psychiatrists, paediatricians, GPs and allied health services for children and young adults living with Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD), Complex Neurodevelopmental Disorders and other disabilities.

From 1 March 2023 the eligibility age limits for MBS services for the assessment, diagnosis and the creation of a treatment plan and subsequent allied health treatment services for patients with ASD or another Complex Neurodevelopmental Disorder or other eligible disability will be increased from under 13 to under 25 years of age.

In addition, the Government has also recognised national guidelines for ASD assessment which specify that allied health professionals should be involved in making an ASD diagnosis and has increased the number of allied health assessment services provided for under the MBS from four to eight per lifetime.

My Department is currently working with stakeholders to progress implementation of these important measures and any requests for additional information can be directed to: MBSClinicalPolicy@health.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Employment
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 29 2021 regarding petition EN3533, which requests the establishment of a Royal Commission into conditions and culture in the Retail and Fast Food sectors. I welcome the opportunity to respond to the petition.

The petition raises concerns in relation to work health and safety (WHS). The Government is a firm believer that all Australians, regardless of their occupation or how they are engaged, have the right to healthy, safe and well-designed work. While WHS is a shared responsibility with the states and territories, the Government takes a leadership role in developing model WHS laws which have been adopted by almost all jurisdictions.

The model WHS Act provides a framework to protect the health and safety of all workers at work and of other people who might be affected by that work. The model WHS Act imposes a primary duty of care on a person conducting a business or undertaking (PCBU) to ensure at all persons in the workplace, including workers and visitors, are not exposed to health and safety risks. This duty requires risks to health and safety to be eliminated or minimised so far as is reasonably practicable. WHS Ministers also recently agreed to amend the model WHS Regulations to deal with psychological health.

Officers of a PCBU must also exercise due diligence to ensure compliance by a PCBU with its health and safety obligations. This duty applies to key strategic, structural, policy and resourcing decisions. Workers also have a duty to take reasonable care for their own health and safety and not adversely affect the safety of others, including through workplace drug abuse.

Companies and individuals who breach their duties of care can be subject to criminal offences and sanctions, regardless of whether an incident occurs. This includes imprisonment of up to five years for individuals, and fines of up to $3million for companies and $600,000 for individuals.

The petition also raises concerns in relation to working conditions. The Australian Government has zero tolerance for the exploitation of workers, including the underpayment of wages and entitlements by any employer.

The Fair Work Ombudsman (FWO) is the national workplace relations regulator, responsible for providing education, assistance and advice about the Commonwealth workplace relations system and impartially enforcing compliance with the Fair Work Act 2009 (FW Act). Since 2016, the Government has committed over $180 million in new funding to the FWO to prevent wage underpayment and improve compliance with workplace laws. The Government has also strengthened the FWO's evidence-gathering powers and increased, by tenfold, the penalties for 'serious contraventions' of the FW Act.

The FWO sets annual compliance and enforcement priorities that reflect the industries with the highest risk of non-compliance. In 2021-22, the FWO's priorities include fast food, restaurants and cafes, and large corporate underpayments.

In the 2020-21 Budget, the Government provided $22.3 million in funding to the FWO to establish a dedicated Corporate Sector Assurance team to identify, investigate and respond to non-compliance by large corporates. As part of the FWO's focus on large corporate non-compliance, the FWO commenced legal proceedings in the Federal Court on 2 December 2021 against Coles Supermarkets Australia Pty Ltd, for the alleged underpayment of salaried employees of $115 million. The FWO also commenced proceedings in the Federal Court on 17 June 2021 against Woolworths Group Limited and Woolworths (South Australia) for the alleged underpayment of salaried workers.

The FW Act also includes strong general protections provisions which make it unlawful for an employer to take adverse action or engage in coercive conduct against an employee because they have a workplace right, exercise a workplace right or propose to exercise a workplace right. This includes making a complaint or raising a question in relation to their employment.
Workers who have concerns about their employment can contact the FWO for free advice and support.

The Government is of the view that the current legal frameworks outlined above provide robust protections for all Australian workers while balancing the rights and responsibilities of employers and employees.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Australian Federal Police
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 29 November 2021 enclosing Petition EN3535 with 332 signatures, which suggests granting the Australian Federal Police (AFP) special powers to investigate alleged corruption and fraud within state and territory police forces. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The AFP's role is to enforce Commonwealth criminal law, contribute to combating complex, transnational, serious and organised crime impacting Australia's national security, and to protect Commonwealth interests from criminal activity in Australia and overseas. These functions are articulated in section 8 of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 (Cth).

State and territory police forces are already subject to oversight from independent bodies, including those focused specifically on law enforcement conduct and corruption. It is appropriate that any oversight of state and territory police is performed by an independent authority.

Should the proponents of the petition have concerns about the efficacy of these existing arrangements, they may wish to contact the individual oversight bodies of each jurisdiction to raise these concerns.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Queensland Road Infrastructure
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your email of 9 November 2020 regarding the petition (EN1910) submitted to the House of Representatives advocating for the Bruce Highway—Tiaro Flood Immunity Upgrade Project (the Project) to deliver a four-lane highway bypass.

I note that on 2 December 2020 you submitted another petition (PN0488) to the House on this matter, with a notable increase in the number of signatures. Both these petitions highlight concerns that a two-lane bypass design may not adequately address safety issues or cater for future demand.

As you may be aware, the Project scope is to deliver a bypass at Tiaro that will improve flood immunity, reduce congestion and remove heavy vehicle traffic away from Tiaro's township to significantly improve safety and liveability for residents.

The Project's business case is currently under development. As part of this process, traffic modelling for future demand has been undertaken. The Queensland Department of Transport and Main Roads has advised that a two-lane option will provide sufficient capacity to cater for current and foreseeable traffic demand, however the business case will consider opportunities to support future duplication.

The business case will also identify the most appropriate safety treatments for the bypass, including consideration of grade separated interchanges and a concrete dividing barrier to reduce the risk of head-on collisions.

I am advised that the business case is expected to be completed by mid-2021 and its outcomes will inform the preferred design. While I understand that this is a matter of importance to the local community, it would be imprudent for the Australian Government to make any formal amendments to the commitment until the outcomes of the business case are known.
Thank you for bringing your concerns to my attention and I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, Mr McCormack
School Nutrition Program
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your representations of 9 August 2021 to the Minister for Education and Youth, the Hon Alan Tudge MP, regarding PN0516; a petition to reinstate the School Nutrition Project in Laramba with full coverage cost by the Australian Government. As the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities, I am replying as Minister for Indigenous Australians. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government has contributed to funding the School Nutrition Projects since 2007. The National Indigenous Australians Agency (NIAA) provides Indigenous Advancement Strategy funding for the operational costs associated with these projects. An integral element of the program requires parental contributions be paid by families utilising the service. While I appreciate this can be a challenge in some communities, it is an important part of the program, ensuring parental responsibility for the cost of food provided to their child, and supports the long-term sustainability of the program.
I understand NIAA representatives are working with a potential new provider in Laramba, with a view for the School Nutrition Project to recommence in the near future.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Indigenous Australians, Mr Wyatt
Australian Constitution
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 22 November 2021 seeking a response to petition PN0521 that expresses support for the First Nations Voice in the Uluru Statement from the Heart and requests that the House of Representatives accept the Final Co-Design Report and establish a Makarrata Commission to supe1vise a process of agreement making between governments and First Nations that enables truth-telling about history.

I would like to thank the signatories to the petition for supporting an Indigenous Voice and acknowledge their view that it needs to be enshrined in the Constitution. I note there are many views and ideas on both constitutional recognition for Indigenous Australians and an Indigenous Voice.

The Morrison Government remains committed to holding a referendum to recognise Indigenous Australians in the Constitution, once there is consensus on the way forward and when it has the best post possible chance of success.

To successfully bring about constitutional change, a majority of Australians and a majority of states must support the proposed amendments. Only eight out of 44 past referenda have been successful and it is important we learn from this and agree to a set of words that are acceptable to the majority of Australians. This is not something that can be rushed, we must consider options that provide the greatest chance of success.

In relation to the Indigenous Voice, the Morrison Government has released the Indigenous Voice Co-design Final Report to the Australian Government. The Report is the result of a robust 18-month co-design process to develop proposals for an Indigenous Voice. Co-design groups made up of 52 members from around the country, primarily Indigenous people, led this process and over 9,400 people have had their say on the proposals.

The Final Report recommends establishing Local & Regional Voices as the first step. Strong local and regional arrangements will ensure legitimacy at the community level as well as helping to establish sustainability and long-term success.

The report made it very clear that for Local & Regional Voices to be successful, they must speak to all levels of government—federal, state and local. This is why the Morrison Government will now commence discussions with states, territories and local governments to encourage their participation in the 35 Local & Regional Voices to be established nationally.

The Morrison Government will also continue to co-design during implementation and will work with the other levels of government to set up a Local & Regional Voice Establishment Group. The Final Report is available online at voice.niaa.gov.au.

On the matter of a Makarrata Commission, in 2018 the Joint Select Committee on Constitutional Recognition relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders considered the Referendum Council's position to oversee agreement-making and noted that there are a range of views regarding the process and meaning of Makarrata. The Morrison Government does not support the establishment of a Makarrata Commission.

On the related matter of truth-telling, this is not a contest of ideas but a sharing of the truth. The Morrison Government supports truth-telling at the national level by working in partnership with Indigenous Australians and communities and local, state and territory governments to support reconciliation and to acknowledge and understand our nation's history.

On 5 January 2022, the Morrison Government announced the establishment of the Ngurra Cultural Precinct, a new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural precinct in the Parliamentary Triangle, incorporating a National Resting Place. The precinct will provide a new perspective on our shared history, as a significant moment for truth-telling, and a new place where the diversity of Indigenous Australia will be celebrated. All who visit Australia's National Cultural Institutions in Canberra will have an opportunity to gain a deeper appreciation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples' cultures, and the richness this offers the country.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Indigenous Australians, Mr Wyatt
Afghanistan
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 29 November 2021 enclosing Petition PN0523 with 566 signatures concerning Australia's humanitarian support for Afghan nationals. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Afghan citizens are a prominent caseload in Australia's offshore Humanitarian Program and have been in the top five countries of origin over the last five years. The Australian Government announced on 18 August 2021 that Afghan citizens will be prioritised for processing within the offshore Humanitarian Program. An initial 3,000 humanitarian places have been allocated to Afghan nationals within Australia's 13,750 annual program, in addition to any visa granted to Afghan nationals up to that date. Particular priority will be given to persecuted minorities, women and children, and those who have close links to Australia.

The Government anticipates this initial allocation will increase further over the course of 2021-22. We are working with Afghan community leaders here in Australia, and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to identify and resettle those Afghan refugees most in need. On 25 August 2021, the Government established an Advisory Panel on Australia's Resettlement of Afghan Nationals to provide advice and support to the Government and the Department of Home Affairs and to ensure that that resettlement planning, service provision, and goodwill across communities is harnessed for the Afghan cohort.

As you would appreciate, the Government is focussed on ensuring that the Australian response, including further consideration of Humanitarian Program settings, is well considered and meets the needs and priorities of the Afghan community. The Government will make further announcements on the composition and priorities in due course.
The Afghan settlement support package is informed by advice from the Government's Advisory Panel on Australia's Resettlement of Afghan Nationals and includes:

$8.0 million over two years to further strengthen the capacity of community and grass roots organisations to continue to play a critical role in supporting the evacuees to begin their lives in Australia;
$6.4 million to support those evacuees on subclass 449 Temporary Humanitarian Stay visas to transition to permanent visas;
$4.8 million to help new arrivals navigate skills recognition and education pathways to quickly secure a suitable entry into the Australian labour market; and
$7.9 million to the Program of Assistance for Survivors of Torture and Trauma (PASTT) to support evacuees and the Afghan community in accessing targeted mental health support.

The Government is working to ensure that visa options continue to be available to Afghan nationals, both within Afghanistan and those who have been displaced from their home country. All visa applications will be processed in accordance with Government announcements and within program priorities, and assessed on an individual basis. All visa applicants must also meet visa criteria and satisfy public interest criteria for character, security and health.

For those remaining in Afghanistan, the situation remains highly volatile, and travel throughout Afghanistan is extremely dangerous. Some borders are closed or may close without notice (as outlined in Smartraveller advice). We urge all people remaining in Afghanistan to prioritise their safety and carefully consider the risks should they attempt to leave by any route.

It is Government policy that refugees who arrive in Australia illegally and are found to be owed protection, will only be granted temporary protection visas (either a Temporary Protection visa (TPV) or a Safe Haven Enterprise visa (SHEV)) and will not be eligible to sponsor family members to migrate to Australia. This policy was part of a suite of measures intended to deter people smuggling and to encourage use of regular migration pathways, such as the visas available through the offshore Humanitarian Program.

A TPV is valid for three years, enables the holder to work, study and reside anywhere in Australia, with access to support services. After three years TPV holders' protection claims must be reassessed to determine their eligibility for grant of a subsequent TPV or SHEV. A SHEV is valid for five years and can be granted to eligible applicants who intend to work or study in a regional area. SHEV holders who have worked without accessing Special Benefits and/or studied full time or a combination of both, in a specified regional area for a period totalling 42 months, meet "pathway requirements". Having met the "pathway requirements", they are then eligible to apply for other visas, including certain permanent visas.

Australia is committed to its international obligations and provides protection to individuals consistent with its obligations set out in the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees, its 1967 Protocol and other international human rights conventions to which it is a party. Australia does not return individuals to situations where they face persecution or a real risk of torture, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, arbitrary deprivation of life or the application of the death penalty. No Afghan currently on a temporary visa in Australia, including on a TPV or SHEV, will be asked to return to Afghanistan while it would be unsafe for them to return. TPV or SHEV holders who want to remain in Australia beyond their visa cease date must apply for a subsequent TPV or SHEV.

The Government recognises the importance of family reunion for refugees and humanitarian entrants. A key aim of Australia's Humanitarian Program is to reunite refugees and people who are in refugee-like situations overseas with their family in Australia through 'split family' provisions and the Special Humanitarian Program (SHP). Immediate family of people who have been resettled under the Humanitarian Program are given highest priority in processing.

The SHP allows people who face human rights abuses in their home country and have a connection to the Australian community to settle permanently in Australia. Permanent humanitarian visa holders (including Permanent Protection visa holders) may propose family members for resettlement in Australia through the SHP. The Community Support Program (CSP) offers an additional pathway for refugees who are ready for employment and have the capacity to be financially self-sufficient within a year of arrival in Australia. Within the Humanitarian Program, the CSP and the SHP both afford priority to applicants willing to live in a regional area or proposed by a relative living in regional Australia (Regional Australia is anywhere outside of Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane).

Afghan Australians are an integral part of Australian society and the Australian community. The Government is endeavouring to do all we can to continue to assist those affected through our ongoing humanitarian, whole-of-government and collaborative efforts.
Thank you for bringing Petition PN0523 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Hawke
BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: Brisbane Airport Curfew and Demand Management Bill 2022

p.span: Brisbane Airport Curfew and Demand Management Bill 2022
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Bandt.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr BANDT (Melbourne—Leader of the Australian Greens) (10:04): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

The story being told right across Australia, from my electorate of Melbourne to the people of Sydney and Brisbane, is one of their lives being disrupted because of unfair and unsustainable aircraft noise.

That's why, following previous bills I have introduced to this place to tackle the problems, I rise now to introduce the Brisbane Airport Curfew and Demand Management Bill 2022. Let me start by saying that this bill is the product of years of community campaigning by thousands of Brisbane residents, standing up to the Brisbane Airport Corporation.

In particular, I would like to commend the work of Max Chandler-Mather, the Greens candidate for Griffith, Stephen Bates, the Greens candidate for Brisbane, and the Brisbane Flight Path Community Alliance, who have led the way in fighting for a reduction in flight noise. The bill itself was produced after direct and detailed consultation with the Brisbane community, and I want to thank everyone who engaged in that process.

I had the chance to meet some of those residents at a community consultation meeting in the Brisbane suburb of Hawthorne, in the electorate of Griffith. This is an incredibly well informed and organised community. Their feedback over the course of this consultation process has improved the bill, and for that I thank them.

Unsustainable flight noise has had a devastating impact on the people of Brisbane. A survey of 2,000 Brisbane residents last year found that 81 per cent of respondents had their sleep disrupted as a result of flight noise, 68 per cent of respondents suffered from mental distress, and 11 per cent of respondents had been forced to seek medical help. Studies around the world have shown the terrible health impacts that come with prolonged exposure to high levels of noise and sleep disruption. With international and domestic flight traffic beginning to return, this situation is only going to get worse.

It's clear that the community was badly misled in the initial consultation for the new parallel runway at Brisbane Airport. This has been confirmed by two independent authorities, including the Aircraft Noise Ombudsman and the Brisbane Airport advisory committee recently established by the federal government. Both identified serious flaws with the consultation, but unfortunately neither have gone far enough in their recommendations.
We need immediate action as well as a sustainable, long-term solution to unsustainable flight noise.

This bill introduces a curfew from 10 pm to 6 am and an hourly movement cap of 45 flights per hour at Brisbane Airport. It also directs the minister to instruct Airservices Australia to produce a long-term operating plan for Brisbane Airport that reduces flight noise, ensures more flights over Moreton Bay and changes flight paths to ensure a fair distribution of air traffic over Brisbane.
A 10 pm to 6 am curfew will ensure every Brisbane resident is able to get a good night's sleep, without being exposed to unhealthy levels of flight noise.
Meanwhile, a flight cap of 45 flights per hour would allow Brisbane Airport to return to pre-pandemic flight traffic, while ensuring they don't grow unsustainably beyond that level.

But, of course, without a substantial change to flight paths and airport operations, a cap and curfew won't address many of the fundamental issues with Brisbane Airport. This is why the Greens will also legislate to force the transport and infrastructure minister to implement a long-term operating plan for Brisbane Airport.
A long-term operating plan will ensure that better consideration will be given to:
more flights taking off and arriving over Moreton Bay;
a fair distribution of flight traffic over Brisbane that ensures no group of residents is forced to bear the overwhelming majority of flights; and
an overall reduction in flight noise for all Brisbane residents by prioritising flight routes that don't pass over residential areas.

These are reasonable and moderate measures that airports around the world have already adopted. Indeed, it's happening around Australia as well. Sydney airport already has a long-term operating plan, a curfew and a cap on flights. The question that both the Liberals and Labor must answer is: if it's good enough for Sydney airport, why isn't it good enough for Brisbane?

Brisbane Airport Corporation has said previously it expected annual passenger traffic through its domestic and international terminals would more than double from 22 million in 2014 to 50 million by 2035. It also forecast the number of annual individual flights would grow from 227,000 in 2019 to 360,000 by 2035 and 500,000 by 2045. That is completely unsustainable, in terms of local air and noise pollution and carbon emissions that contribute to the climate crisis.

Prior to the pandemic in 2018 the four major privately owned airport corporations, including Brisbane, made a combined profit of $757.6 million—up nine per cent. As we emerge from travel restrictions and begin to see more international travellers visiting Australia, we can expect similar profit levels to return. We must not let the private corporations' relentless pursuit of profits get in the way of a better future for all of us.

Let us be clear. This is ultimately about the Brisbane Airport Corporation relentlessly pursuing profit at the expense of the community. Like so many big corporations and billionaires, the rules are written in their favour, with little regard given to the community and the environment.

It is no surprise that Brisbane Airport Corporation has previously donated to the Labor Party, while, as recently as 2018, the Australian Airports Association, the chief lobby group for airport corporations, paid tens of thousands each to Labor and the Liberals for secret cash-for-access meetings. No wonder the major parties are so reluctant to hold the big airport corporations to account.
This, ultimately, is a story of everyday people standing up to the power of a big corporation. And the Greens will always stand with people in that fight.

I said earlier that this is a story that is happening right around the country, and it is. This bill will apply to Brisbane Airport; previously introduced bills were with respect to Melbourne. Now the electorate that I represent is, as some people would know, some distance from the airport. Some might ask, 'How is it that airport noise has become an issue in the inner city of Melbourne?' The answer is the same as the problem that is being sought to be addressed by this bill with respect to Brisbane.

It's a story being told right around the country. As our cities have grown, and as air travel has grown, no-one has paid attention to what that means for people living under areas of flight paths that aren't immediately adjacent to the airport. There is a whole set of rules in place for people who are near airports; but, for people further afield as well as for people who are living next to airports, the law has not kept up with the rise in traffic. As a result, we see two things. We see the point has been changed where all the planes have to gather and turn around before they loop over the city and come in and land on the runway. As a result, in places like East Melbourne you can look up at certain times of day and see plane after plane after plane going over.

We also have the issue in Melbourne of people needing to clock up their training hours, or perhaps going for some joy flights. They're coming in and doing loops around the MCG, which, for the people who live near it, turns into unstainable and unfair aircraft noise with low-level, low-flying planes all the time. No-one has paid attention to it, and it's the same in Brisbane.

Over the years the number of flights has increased and flight paths have been changed. They're going over people's houses, and there's nothing in the law to protect them. And instead of taking on the big corporations and government entities that have the chance to regulate it, Labor and the Liberals are captured by these very same organisations and refuse to stand up on behalf of residents.

This bill is about getting a better balance, and it's about saying that people who live in our cities have the right to live in peace and to have their amenity protected. This is getting to the point where in Melbourne, as well as in Sydney and now in Brisbane, it is affecting people's health. It is not just a question of not being able to go outside in your own home because of intensive aircraft noise; it is affecting people's health. We need to do something about it, and this bill will do that.
The SPEAKER: Is the motion seconded?
Mr Wilkie: I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.
Debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Renewable Energy (Electricity) Amendment (Cheaper Home Batteries) Bill 2022

p.span: Renewable Energy (Electricity) Amendment (Cheaper Home Batteries) Bill 2022
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Dr Haines.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Dr HAINES (Indi) (10:16): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.
In my electorate of Indi, getting a cheap and reliable supply of electricity to every household is a real challenge.
In the bushfires, communities like Corryong got completely cut off from electricity when the power lines to Wodonga burned down.
